PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the Chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ANDREW; BLUNT; BURR; CADMAN; GROOM; HALL; HOWARD; MCVEIGH; WILSON
PETITION.NAMEIDS: HE4; WE4; 3F4; SD4; QK5; 2H4; ZD4; ML7; 0K4
PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Pornographic Publications
To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs (Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law:
The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
The power to require imported video tapes/discs for non-commercial use to be registered by the Film Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled; should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure
That the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Blunt,Mr Burr,Mr Cadman,Mr Groom,Mr Steele Hall,Mr Howard,Mr McVeigh and Mr Wilson.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLUNT; CADMAN; COWAN; FIFE; KERIN; PUNCH; ROBINSON
PETITION.NAMEIDS: WE4; SD4; VF4; CG4; QH4; SI4; YI4
PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development, of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities e.g., boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled should amend the Bill so as the prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Cadman,Mr Cowan,Mr Fife,Mr Kerin,Mr Punch and Mr Ian Robinson.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BOWEN; CHILD; HOWARD; SCOTT; SHIPTON; THEOPHANOUS; WILSON
PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax: Confectionery
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery at the rate of 20% is an unfair and unjust burden on this important manufacturing industry and your petitioners therefore pray that confectionery be treated in a similar fashion to all other foods, including snack foods, which are exempt from sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lionel Bowen,Mrs Child,Mr Howard,Mr Scott,Mr Shipton,Dr Theophanous and Mr Wilson.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ALDRED; GROOM; HAWKER; LUSHER; MCGAURAN; RUDDOCK
PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred,Mr Groom,Mr Hawker,Mr Lusher,Mr McGauran and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows -
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economic health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Drummond,Mr Porter,Mr Rocher and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights overs seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Ms McHugh,Mr Saunderson and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. Omega, by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water, enables hunter-killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a ''first strike'' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
Your petitioners pray that Members and the House assembled will close Omega.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That, having received information from the Attorney-General's Department concerning the New Commonwealth Censorship Procedures for Publication, we are abhorred by the intent of the Government to change the already liberal Censorship Laws into such Laws as will open the doors to nearly complete licence where publications are concerned.
We most strongly feel that in this way the Government would be intentionally instrumental in perverting the thoughts and actions of young and older Australians.
We therefore request the Government to abandon its 1983 decision to alter the A .C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We assert that TAFE, with over 1 million students, requires greatly improved resources if it is to continue to train Australia's skilled workforce effectively.

2. We call upon the Commonwealth Government to provide greatly increased funds to ensure that TAFE is accessible to all Australians, unlike the present time when thousands of people are turned away from TAFE colleges each year.

3. We urge the Commonwealth Government to equip TAFE workshops with the advanced technology used in modern Australian industries, and to expand TAFE's capital works program so that sufficient quality accommodation is available for TAFE teachers and students.
4. We ask that the Commonwealth Government greatly increase TAFE's recurrent expenditure, so that TAFE can respond quickly and flexibly to industry, Government and community demands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth-
that the Australian flag reflects Australia's membership of the Commonwealth of Nations, her position in the southern hemisphere, and her federation of original colonies,
recognises the flag as a symbol of pride for most Australians, such that several organisations, including the ALP, incorporated the flag in their motifs.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will resist moves to change the Australian flag, or if changes is contemplated that the question by put to the Australian people by referendum to seek their views.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Services, North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth-

That ABC radio transmission from 4QA Mackay is antiquated and operates on transmitters installed in 1947-48 to service a region in which the area and population has doubled in the intervening 36 years,

The signal from 4QA is below strength so that station 4QN at Townsville has a far better signal strength into the Mackay hinterland than 4QA, a distance of only 70 km from Mackay and over 300 km from Townsville,
The 4QN news programmes are of no interest in the Mackay region and in emergency situations such as cyclones, the 4QA frequency has limited penetration within the region,

That while FM programmes are available in Rockhampton and Townsville, Mackay, with a regional population of 100,000 people, has been by-passed when towns of smaller size have the advantages of FM radio.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and the Department of Communications will move urgently to rectify both these anomalies.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/ or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ''Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen',
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: School Cadet Corps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows -

We, the undersigned students of Clairvaux College, McKillop College and the Mt Gravatt State High School, hereby express our concern at the decision of the Federal Government to dramatically reduce the effectiveness of the School Cadet Corps programme, and to withdraw funding.
We respectfully request that the Hawke Federal Government reverts to the previous satisfactory system which gave students of all backgrounds the opportunity to participate in the programme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Curfew
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show:

That the potential noise hazard to residents of Sandgate, Shorncliffe, Brighton , and Nudgee Beach (including 4,000 aged people), will become intolerable when the new Brisbane Airport is operative in 1987, if protective action is not taken .
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will, when the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport becomes operative, ensure that-
(i) no jet aircraft use the 32'14' crosswind runway;
(ii) the Department maintain the curfew on the runway from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Woorabinda Aboriginal Reserve, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that:

Woorabinda Aboriginal Reserve (population over 600), west of Rockhampton, Queensland, is severely isolated because of 34 km of unsealed road which can become impassable in wet weather, extremely high telephone installation charges (over $1,100 per phone) being asked by Telecom Australia, and poor radio and television reception.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will:
(a) provide funds to the Duaringa Shire Council to seal the 34 km of the Duaringa-Bauhinia Downs road which is now unsealed, and which services Woorabinda; and
(b) call on Telecom Australia to provide telephone installations at a much more reasonable cost.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we believe that there are unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental, technical and ethical problems associated with the mining of uranium and the development of nuclear power, in particular:
(a) to the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war; and
(b) the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes to ensure that any danger posed by such wastes to human life and the environment is eliminated.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
(1) No new Uranium mines be commenced;
(2) No new contracts for the sale of Uranium be approved;
(3) Uranium mines presently in production cease with the fulfilment of current contracts;
(4) No new Uranium is supplied to countries making or testing nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure background signifying its place in space.
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600.
We, your Petitioners, humbly showeth:

That permitting kangaroos to be commercially exploited when permissible cropping rates are unknown and the means of enforcing controls or protective laws are completely ineffective in this land, is allowing this unique animal to follow the path to rarity or extinction along which all wild animals have gone when subjected to exploitation in similar circumstances.
We Australians have the right to see kangaroos in reasonable numbers on the landscape: We find the commercial slaughter of the kangaroo to be abhorrent and unjustified.
Commercialisation of wildlife should be stopped, particularly as exemplified by the kangaroo industry.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will.
1. Ban the export of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State Governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of the proposed Plant Breeders ' Rights legislation. The reasons are as follows:
(1) We believe it will eventually lead to the restriction of sales of many varieties of seed.
(2) We believe it will cause the disappearance of many useful plant varieties as evidenced by similar legislation in Europe.
(3) We believe that it will cause the Australian seed industry to become foreign controlled.
(4) We believe that a full public debate has not taken place and should take place before any laws are passed on the patenting of a life form.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take positive action as soon as possible to arrest the implementation of such legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Military Establishment, Central Tablelands, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
We protest the proposed relocation of the Artillery and Infantry Schools from North Head, Singleton and Holsworthy to the Central Tablelands of New South Wales, and the Cobar district.

We humbly pray that the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will ensure that the current investigation being carried out in the Central Tablelands is ceased forthwith and that no Military Establishment be located in the Central Tablelands of New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in the Soviet Union
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the Soviet Union continues to violate human rights in Latvia. This is clearly demonstrated by the recent case of Janis Rozkalns, a practising Baptist who, on January 6, 1983, had his house forcibly entered into by K.G.B. agents searching for various religious publications. The K.G.B. confiscated 40 Bibles.
Mr Rozkalns was charged with ''anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda'' and now faces a sentence of seven years deprivation of freedom plus five years internal exile.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled condemns the religious and human rights persecutions within the Soviet Union.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway, North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth-
That the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government,
The Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway,
Queensland has suffered a 15% disadvantage over other states during the past ten years in road funding,
And the state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that
General Revenue Grants to Local Government under Personal Income Tax Sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2% in 1983/84 over 1982/83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2%,
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8%,
Increased demands are being made on Local Government Authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in General Revenue Grants to Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983/84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully show:
Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
Alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
Alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
Alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth our concern over the continuing taxation of Parents' Club bank accounts by way of the Bank Account Debit Tax.
Your petitioners therefore pray that-

Parent clubs being set up by Government Regulation in the State of Victoria ( Regulation XLII) be recognised by the Australian Government as education auxiliaries, in the same way as are School Councils.
The Treasurer move immediately to exempt Parent Clubs from the tax in the same way as are School Councils.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Services to Isolated Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth that:
Residents of Cann River and Mallacoota and surrounding areas in Far East Gippsland receive inadequate or no Television and Radio reception.
The said residents, in spite of contributing to the same State and Federal Government taxes and charges as all other Victorians, do not enjoy the same rights of Television and Radio reception.
The Minister for Communications has stated his expectation that an A.B.C. television translator for Mallacoota will be established towards the middle of 1984, subject to budgetary consideration.

Southern Cross Communications Limited has advised the said Minister for Communications its interest in establishing a translator in the very near future for Cann River, but only if the Minister waives his requirement that the translator be of Ultra High Frequency and not Very High Frequency.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that:

The Government act without any further delay to establish an A.B.C. translator for Mallacoota and permit Southern Cross Communications Limited to establish a Very High Frequency translator for Cann River so that the residents of Far East Gippsland be no longer deprived of their right to the news, entertainment, information and education of television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Goodluck proceeding to give notice of a motion-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is giving far too much information. He will resume his seat. I am sure that all honourable members congratulate the honourable member for Braddon, but we are dealing with notices of motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move, and my colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) will second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes that the Metropolitan Region Planning Authority (MRPA) in Western Australia has given approval to the commencement of high-rise development on the beachfront at Scarborough, Western Australia, and
(2) regrets this decision of the MRPA as it runs counter to the expressed wishes of a substantial number of residents of Scarborough, and
(3) calls upon the Western Australian Government to implement, at the earliest opportunity, a coastal management plan for the metropolitan region of Perth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) congratulates the great Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke Petersen, and the Delhi, C.S.R and Santos Companies and Partners in the Jackson oil field with a capacity of 43 billion barrels of crude oil and the Jackson Moonie pipe line, constructed at a cost of $177 million, which will be officially opened on 31 May 1984 in Brisbane and at Jackson in the fine Electoral Division of Maranoa, and
(2) congratulates all those hard-working, fair-dinkum Australians involved in completing these great engineering projects ahead of schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House-

(1) notes that the Opposition, through its spokesperson on immigration and ethnic affairs, has now changed its claims that immigration policy should be based on the discriminatory policy of ethnic and racial balance, and
(2) welcomes this belated return by the Opposition to an approach based on decency and sanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes with alarm the developing dangerous financial position of health funds providing cover to those who seek health insurance cover above and beyond that provided by Medicare;

(2) deplores the inaction of the Minister for Health for allowing various commercial organisations to set up health insurance cover on the basis of inviting only the very healthy to become contributors, and
(3) notes that-

(a) if this is allowed to continue, the sick and elderly will be members of financially bankrupt organisations and in their hour of need will be left with no choice between Government hospitals and private hospitals, and
(b) this negligence will also destroy the ability of Government hospitals to cope with the resultant increased demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move and my colleague the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) will second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) congratulates the Minister for Health for providing a further $3.8m emergency funding for the program of aids for disabled people;
(2) notes that this money is needed to meet the backlog of demands for aids for the disabled, and
(3) commends the Government for funding the program of aids for disabled people for 1983-84 with $10.9m, an increase of 95 per cent over the $5.6m allocated in 1982-83.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife) will second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government for its disastrous and dangerous handling of immigration policy over the 12 months to June 1984, and now calls upon the Prime Minister to forthwith remove the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs from his present portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Gorman) will second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) urges the Government to give more emphasis in education planning and funding to the concept of lifelong learning;
(2) is of the opinion that adult education, both formal and informal, should be more adequately funded, and
(3) congratulates the Government on its realistic approach to education after 7 years of neglect under the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT AND QANTAS AIRWAYS LTD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The new arrangements that the Government has decided shall apply to the future oversight of Qantas Airways Ltd complement measures already taken by the Government to place the operations of Qantas on a surer commercial footing, and will allow the directors of Qantas a significantly increased degree of responsibility in conducting the commercial affairs of the company. As such, they represent the fulfilment of the Government 's policy pledge to give Qantas greater flexibility and freedom of operation in the management of the airline. They are also further demonstration of the continuing confidence the Government has in the Board of Directors and management of Qantas.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years, Qantas's financial fortunes, along with those of most other international airlines, have not been good. In the four years from 1979-80 to 1982-83, the company reported substantial operating losses. Qantas's operating loss of $47.6m in 1982-83 was the largest on record, and brought the cumulative total of operating losses over the four years to 31 March 1983 to around $123m. In terms of overall financial results however, Qantas's accumulated net loss over the four year period to 31 March 1983 was reduced to about $14m. Losses on airline operations were largely offset by the sale of major properties, the most important being the Wentworth Hotel in Sydney. It should not be overlooked that these large accumulated operating losses by Qantas occurred during the period of greatest economic difficulty encountered by the international airline industry in its history.

The economics of airline operations underwent major and rapid change in the late 1970s and early 1980s as a consequence of increases in world fuel prices. This resulted in strong upward pressure on fares. The international airline industry as a whole was caught between the need to increase fares to recover higher costs, and a declining market brought about by the higher fares and the broader adverse effects of the world economic recession. Few airlines managed to record profits during this period, and several prominent carriers failed. The Qantas losses, although large, represented a much better financial performance than many other major airlines were able to achieve in the difficult circumstances confronting the industry.

After gaining office the Government moved quickly to provide Qantas with additional equity capital. For far too long Qantas had been expected by earlier governments to operate on a commercial basis, but with a capital equity structure quite unsuited to the company's commercial needs. The $60m additional capital provided by this Government enabled Qantas to reduce its outgoings in interest payments. In addition, the Qantas Board of Directors undertook vigorous and sustained efforts to contain costs and increase productivity within the company.

In November 1982 Qantas announced its intention to reduce its work force by 1, 000 employees by March 1983. This program was successful, and by December 1983 the company had its lowest staffing level since 1970. This significant slimming of its work force was achieved without corresponding reduction in services operated by the company, and much of the staff reduction was achieved through voluntary separation arrangements. These arrangements involved separation costs of $25m in 1982-83, but the benefits of reduced labour costs were evident in 1983-84 and will continue in future years.

The Board of Directors improved the company's liquidity position, with consequent reduction in interest payments, through the sale of major properties, in particular, the Wentworth Hotel and Qantas House in Sydney. Other measures taken to reduce costs have included restructuring of services to meet changed patterns of demand on various routes, reduction in services on some routes where travel demand had declined, technical improvements to give increased engine efficiency and lower fuel costs, reduced holdings of spare parts, and general pruning of administrative expenses. As an index of the overall effectiveness of the various measures taken, the company's break-even seat factor, that is, the percentage of seats which must be sold on average per flight in order to recover costs, has declined from over 70 per cent in 1979 to around 56 per cent in 1984.

The overall outcome of all these actions is that the company's financial results for the year ended March 1984 exceeded expectations. Qantas's unaudited group results for the year 1983-84 show a very creditable profit of $58.3m on operations. After making allowance for the taxation provisions and abnormal items the unaudited net result is approximately $58.5m. While the measures to reduce the company's costs are the dominating factor in this result, slightly improved traffic levels and yields have also contributed. The Board of Directors of Qantas has advised me that after deduction of retained losses, the amount available for appropriation is approximately $25m. The Board has decided to pay to the Commonwealth a dividend of 5 per cent on the subscribed share capital. This will be the first occasion since the financial year ended 31 March 1978 that Qantas has paid a dividend. The dividend payment will amount to $6,904,000. The balance of funds available for appropriation is to be transferred to development reserve or carried forward as retained profits. These results are very pleasing and I believe that honourable members would wish to join me in congratulating the Board of Directors, management and staff of Qantas on the company's return to profitability. It should not be thought though that this more favourable trading result can be maintained without a good deal more hard work on the part of Qantas management and staff.

Qantas continues to face a very challenging trading environment. While there has been a recent small increase in travel demand, which is encouraging, it remains to be seen whether traffic growth will be maintained and strengthened. There is intense competition among international airlines that serve Australia for the available traffic. In addition Qantas has embarked on a major and necessary re-equipment program which will make very heavy demands in coming years on the company's financial resources. This program is to be largely financed through anticipated earning and profits. Hence while there are grounds for satisfaction that the company's efforts to date have returned Qantas to a profitable trading situation, there is no room for complacency or slackening of effort if the company is to maintain commercial viability while continuing to perform at the high standards for which Qantas is noted.

It is a further mark of the Government's confidence in Qantas that approval was given in November 1983 to a Qantas fleet modernisation program totalling some $ 860m to be funded from the company's internal sources, but with guarantees by the Government of some of the associated borrowings by Qantas. This re-equipment program will see the retirement of six of the company's older B747-200 aircraft, and their replacement by nine new Boeing aircraft, three new B747-300 stretched upper deck and six B767-200 extended range aircraft. The program, the largest single purchase by an Australian airline will give Qantas the modern, efficient fleet it needs to compete effectively in the market place, as well as the flexibility to provide improved services to smaller gateway points in Australia. The introduction of the new aircraft, beginning in 1984 will ensure that Qantas is in a secure position to take advantage of the upturn now occurring in the international airline industry. It will better position the company in playing its role in promoting tourism to Australia, and in making overseas travel as accessible as possible to the Australian public.

I now come to the decision taken by the Government to establish new guidelines within which the Qantas Board of Directors is to be authorised to conduct the affairs of the company. As a public company, in which the shareholding is fully owned by the Commonwealth, Qantas differs significantly from the generality of the Government's business undertakings. The directors of the company are not only accountable to the government but are obliged by companies legislation to fulfil all the duties and responsibilities of directors of a public company. This latter factor was a very important consideration in determining the relationship that should exist between the Government and the company. The new guidelines were developed by the Government in consultation with the Qantas Board, with this consideration to the fore. The former financial directive to the Qantas Board was implemented in 1949 and has remained largely unaltered from that time. I need hardly to point out that the environment in which Qantas operates has changed markedly since that time, particularly over recent years.

Today's climate in international aviation is very much more competitive than the past. If Qantas is to be commercially successful in this new environment, the directors of Qantas should be given as much scope and flexibility as possible to direct the company's affairs. They also should be enabled to take timely decisions, to adjust plans rapidly to quickly changing commercial situations. Nevertheless, it would not be practicable for the Government to leave the affairs of Qantas solely in the hands of its directors. Because of the company's position as the only Australian airline authorised to operate internationally in its own right, decisions by Qantas to commence and terminate services could have important implications for Australia's foreign relations. Furthermore, it is inescapable that Qantas will be widely perceived outside of Australia as an arm of the Australian Government and an instrument of Australia' s foreign and trading policies.

A further important consideration is that Qantas, although a public company, is not subject to the normal market place discipline of the threat of bankruptcy. For this reason the company would not be viewed by financial institutions as an ordinary commercial risk, it being recognised by such institutions that the Commonwealth stands behind the financial liabilities that Qantas incurs. It is not, therefore, practicable for the Government to leave financial matters entirely in the hands of the directors, because of the government's own accountability to the public in this area through the Parliament.

The revised oversight arrangements which have been decided upon are intended to strike a realistic balance between the Qantas Board's responsibilities and the needs of the Government to ensure proper discharge of its own accountability to the Australian public. As I have already mentioned, the new arrangements relate to the framework within which the Board will be authorised to conduct the company's affairs. They do not relate to the question of ownership of Qantas and it is not intended that there be any change in the present situation whereby Qantas, as the nation's international flag carrier, is wholly owned by the Australian community.

The directors will in future have power to approve all expenditure and leases for the acquisition of land, equipment and buildings essential for airline operations, and other programs involving less than $5m. This will give the Board the freedom to exercise its commercial judgment on a wide range of purchases and leases, while direct Government oversight will be restricted to major items, including the acquisition of new aircraft. This compares with the former requirement for the Minister to approve the purchase of any land in excess of $ 10,000, any equipment from overseas worth more than $20,000 or any lease of land for more than five years. Similar autonomy is granted to the Board to enter into borrowings of less than $5m with a limit of $20m of such borrowings in any one year. Formerly, all borrowings by the company required the Minister's approval. All former controls on the disposal of property and assets by the company are to be removed.

Although the Minister for Aviation will retain the right to approve the creation of any subsidiary companies and any investment over $5m in subsidiaries , Qantas now has the ability to invest temporarily surplus funds in an expanded list of avenues for investment. It is intended in relation to the various limits of autonomy I have mentioned that the monetary amounts in which those limits are now expressed should be revised from time to time to take account of inflation and any other relevant factors. The company is to be given the flexibility to undertake such investments with minimum delay, which can only enhance the company's prospects of earning greater returns on such funds.

The provisions relating to dividends payable by the company to the Government have also been updated. While the directors will continue to recommend the level of dividend to be payable to the Commonwealth, the former requirement for the directors to make every effort to exceed a rate of return on capital of 3 1/3 per cent has been replaced by an obligation on the directors to aim to ensure a reasonable commercial return for the Commonwealth on its total investment in Qantas. The directors of the company will therefore have the responsibility for determining future strategies, with the aim of conducting the company's affairs in as commercial a manner as possible. There will naturally be ongoing, close consultation between the Minister for Aviation and the Board on the company's objectives and performance. It is appropriate that the Minister, as the representative of the shareholders, be kept adequately informed of the overall activities of the company. This will, however, in no way detract from the Government's intention that the Board of Directors plan the company's future operations in the manner it believes most appropriate.

The Minister's role will be to discuss broad future strategies with the Board of Directors to ensure that these take adequate account of public interest considerations and the Government's foreign relations policies. There is no intention that the Minister should become involved in detailed commercial matters, which properly are the responsibility of the appointed directors. A number of provisions in the outmoded directive relating to the treatment of various matters in the company's financial accounts, and procedures for requesting capital funds and additional equity capital are to be done away with. Another outmoded provision discarded is the requirement for Qantas to seek the Minister's approval before entering into agreements on tariffs with other airlines within the International Air Transport Association. It has been the practice for the past several years that Qantas be left free to set its own fares on a competitive basis in response to market conditions and the perceived needs of the travelling public.

The Government recognises that there is a need for Qantas, if it is to maintain high and competitive management standards, to be able to attract and retain high calibre staff. For this reason, the Qantas Board will be free in future to determine the salaries of all Qantas employees, with the exception of the two most senior company executive positions. Salaries of the latter are to be determined in a way agreed by the Minister from time to time. Other guidelines, essentially dealing with the conduct of airline operations by the Board, represent formalisation of arrangements currently in place and to which the Board of Directors is agreeable. Further details of the new arrangements to apply to Qantas are given in two documents which I table for the information of honourable members. One of the documents gives the complete text of the revised guidelines which I will be formally conveying to the Qantas Board of Directors. The other is a summary of those guidelines and contains for ease of reference and comparison the corresponding provisions of the financial directive which is now to be withdrawn.

Australia has in Qantas an airline of which it can be justly proud. I am sure honourable members will join with me in commending the Board of Directors, the company's senior management, and indeed all Qantas staff on their considerable efforts to place Qantas in the forefront of international airlines. The Government's new guidelines for future oversight of Qantas will further enhance the company's ability to perform as a commercially successful international carrier and to meet the needs of not only all Australians who wish to travel abroad but also the Australian tourism industry. I present the following paper:
Future Relationship between the Government and Qantas Airways Ltd-Ministerial Statement, 31 May 1984.
Motion (by Mr Cohen) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is welcome news that Qantas Airways Ltd has made about $50m this year from its airline operations and that it will make a profit of about that sum for the full year from all operations. We all know that Qantas, along with many, but not all, other international carriers, has been suffering from a haemorrhage of losses and in particular, of course, operating losses caused by the very difficult and savagely competitive climate in which Qantas operates. I join the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) in offering congratulations to the senior staff, all staff members and the Board of Qantas for this turnabout in Qantas's fortunes. It was something which was badly needed .

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas's future profitability will, I suppose, depend upon two main factors. The first factor is the level of competitiveness that Qantas can maintain. At present there is an industrial dispute which may have recently been resolved but which involves the question of how many flight attendants should be provided on non-stop journeys from Australia to the west coast of the United States. The claim made would mean that Qantas would operate with substantially higher numbers of flight attendants than its competitors. Of course, that kind of activity, so long as it continues, has a direct and immediate effect upon Qantas 's continuing profitability. It may well be-and I hope it will be the case-that that problem will be resolved.

The second factor that Qantas will have to face, on top of the general problem of maintaining highly competitive operations, will be the success of its re- equipment program. It has entered into commitments for $860m. It has entered into these commitments on very long term forecasts of earnings. I think we all know that those kinds of long term forecasts are simply of a speculative nature once one gets beyond two or three years. If one knows what will happen in the economy or in one's country 12 months from now, one is exceedingly well off. If one were able to look down the track three years from now, one would be paid a fortune if one were able to tell governments and companies what the results would be. So those are the two major factors that Qantas must face for it to remain on the road of profitable operations.

It is sometimes forgotten that Qantas was incorporated in Queensland and still remains a Queensland company. It was incorporated in the name of Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services Ltd. It was back in 1949 that the then Government assumed full ownership of Qantas. When it did so Qantas had had many years of experience as an international carrier. In the original financial directive of May 1949 it was stated on the part of the Government that it was the Government's desire that there should be as little change as possible in the existing organisation and the managerial and operating practices in existence prior to government ownership. That directive has remained substantially unchanged since 1949.

I welcome the changes proposed by the Minister although there are one or two areas in which I think he has not gone far enough and there are problems which need to be addressed and which I do not believe have been addressed in what he has said to the House. But certainly they are a marked improvement on the existing financial directive. I think it should be placed on record that the previous Minister for Aviation was seeking to secure changes of the kind which the Minister has announced to the House-not precisely the same but certainly substantially the same-when he was overtaken by events, as indeed were all of us on this side of the House, namely, the previous Prime Minister's decision to hold an early election. The financial directive which the Minister has tabled in the House provides:

In conducting the Company's affairs, the Board shall have regard to these guidelines, the Companies (Queensland) Code, the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association, and the Air Navigation Act and Regulations.

That follows firstly from the fact that the Government owns Qantas and therefore , as the major shareholder, can call the shots. Secondly, Qantas must look to the Companies (Queensland) Code for the very simple reason that as a Queensland incorporated company it must organise its affairs according to that code and the directors' responsibilities and the responsibilities of officers of the company are organised under that code. Of course, Qantas must also have regard to the Air Navigation Act and Regulations for reasons that do not need stating.

The changes made by the Minister have, as he has indicated, introduced greater flexibility into Qantas's management and financial arrangements. The points which he has made do not need repeating but the following question of general principle needs to be addressed: As the Government is the only shareholder in Qantas, what should be its measure of control? At the end of the day, as the only shareholder, the Government, as I said, calls the shots.

I think that a proposition that should be looked at most closely is that the Board should be responsible for the direction of the company within the terms of its memorandum and articles of association and the provisions of the Queensland Companies Act, paying due regard to its responsibility to the Commonwealth as the company's sole proprietor. In other words, I suggest that the company should organise its affairs on the same basis as those of any other company incorporated under the Companies Act with regard to the views and the ultimate control of the Government as shareholder, that management and Board members should be judged by ordinary commercial standards and that in the event that any one of them fails to measure up-I do not suggest that this has taken place-the usual sanctions should apply, that is, the person is shipped out or the Board is changed.

As I understand what the Minister has said to the House, he has put two arguments in favour of the continuation of existing controls or those controls that he has now outlined. First of all, he referred to what one might call the foreign affairs aspect of Qantas. I do not think anyone really quarrels with the proposition that the Government needs to be able to state and to direct that in certain cases it is not in Australia's interests that Qantas carry passengers to certain countries. The private carriers in the United States of America are always under the direction of the United States Government as to where they can carry passengers. One can really put that argument to one side because there is no problem with it. The control that the Government desirably would need to exercise could be exercised regardless of whether Qantas as a company organises its affairs entirely subject to the ultimate constraints of the owner- shareholder or whether it has to organise its affairs under the kind of financial directive that we have.

The second thing that is said is that there is an absence of market place discipline, and because Qantas is wholly owned by the Government it is not subject to the same sorts of disciplines that apply to companies that do not have government backing. No doubt that is a statement of fact, but it has nothing to do in any relevant sense with why there should be a financial directive. After all, a board is chosen because it is thought that that board will do the kind of job that is wanted from it, and demands are put on it to do so. If the Minister is concerned that the Board might make extravagant and stupid decisions-I do not think that he would be so concerned; I am not concerned myself-there are many ways in which constraints can be imposed in terms of getting information on what the Board is doing or what the Board proposes to do. For example, one could have-I think it would be a very good idea if this were a requirement-half-yearly statements by Qantas as a publicly owned company, because the Australian public owns it, of its profits and losses for the preceding half year.

The Minister, as the shareholder in Qantas or the representative of the shareholder, would be able to get on a monthly basis, if he so desired, a budget reconciliation of actual performance against forecast performance, as Qantas would no doubt have a forward estimate on a monthly basis of what it expected to achieve. It would then be a very simple matter for such a reconciliation of actual performance against the forecast performance to be given to the Minister. Indeed, he would be able to ask at any time for details of the operations of Qantas. As the sole shareholder, he has no constraints on him. If facts came to his attention that required action, he could take action. The two reasons given for imposing constraints really do not support the proposition that such constraints are necessary, not even the more flexible constraints on the management of Qantas that the Minister has outlined today.

Before concluding I should like to point to one or two other matters. There is a major deficiency in the proposal that the salary levels of the two senior officers be set by the Remuneration Tribunal. The Minister knows this only too well, because it would mean that all other salary levels would be set by force according to the level of the two senior officers in Qantas, and that would mean that Qantas would be placed in a most difficult position in competing in the market place for senior and experienced personnel. I believe that the Minister would like to change that situation. It is a grave defect that the Government has not faced up to the need to allow Qantas to recruit personnel on an open market basis.

In stating my second point, I wish to raise a specific question with the Minister. The Minister has eased the requirements dealing with the investment of surplus funds. I should have thought that under clause 6 those requirements were still too restrictive and that surplus funds should be invested in such manner as the Board determines. I have a particular question that the Minister may be able to answer, and that is: Do the proposals contained in clause 6 cover the investment overseas of surplus funds in foreign earnings?

I conclude by saying again that I welcome the results that have been achieved. I hope that the profitable road on which Qantas finds itself continues. I acknowledge that what the Minister has done is most certainly a move in the right direction. I express my gratitude to the Minister that he has accepted the proposition that Qantas should remain a public company, which is somewhat inconsistent with his proposal that Trans Australia Airlines should under no circumstances become a public company. I can only say that the acceptance of the proposition in relation to Qantas seems to negate the other proposition which we will have to debate on another occasion. I am very glad that the Minister has acknowledged that Qantas, as a public company established in Queensland, has been set up with a status that suits the needs of the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984

TALK.START.PARA: —May I have your indulgence, Madam Deputy Speaker, to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Bill 1984, Australian Meat and Live-stock Selection Committee Bill 1984, Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1984, Live-stock Slaughter Levy Collection Amendment Bill 1984 and Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1984 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Order! Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering the six measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The beef industry is riddled with problems, and these cognate Bills are an attempt to grapple with a few of them. At the outset I must say that plans for restructuring the administration of meat and livestock research and development, which are so fundamental to the industry, are conspicuous by their absence. I hope that early in the Budget session the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) will be able to bring this plan before us. Research and development are very much the linchpins which ensure the strength of the industry. We have reached the point where cattle numbers are down from 25.2 million in 1981 to 22.2 million in 1984. Exports, which were 459, 000 tonnes in 1981, rising to 624,000 tonnes in 1982-that increase was due to the drought-are estimated to decline to 450,000 tonnes in 1984 and about 400,000 tonnes in 1986. The gross value is assessed at being $2.4 billion in 1984. Farmers' incomes have shown a negative rate of return for many years, with the exception of 1979-80, with average incomes being minus $1,711 in 1982-83, and this year 1983-84, they are estimated to be $7,968.

SPEECH.PARA: Beef consumption in Australia has declined from 50 kilograms per head in 1982 to 40 kilograms in 1984. With mutton and lamb the prospects are just as discouraging. The average saleyard price of lamb in 1984-85 is expected to be about 115c per kilogram, a rise of 5 per cent on the estimated 1983-84 level. Average mutton prices are expected to increase by 12 per cent to around 70c per kilogram, up from the very depressed levels of last year due to the increased export demand. Farm costs are expected to increase by 6 per cent, so obviously there will be no great improvement in either income or lifestyle.

I have wanted to give the House this information because we need to establish the pattern of the state of the industry to understand the background. Once we understand the background, we come to the inescapable conclusion that in 1984 the industry is facing a watershed.

Quite simply, over the last few years-maybe as far back as a decade-there has been a loss of confidence. The present Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation has not been the reason for this lack of confidence. But there is a widespread feeling in grazing Australia that the Corporation has tried to work in too many directions. The AMLC has been responsible for marketing meat and sheepmeat. It has been responsible for market research and for promotion advice. The consultation mechanisms which were conceived with great hopes have simply not worked as well as was hoped originally. There is no point in criticising those who have been in charge. I believe they did their best in a system which basically was not oriented to the changing circumstances of world and domestic trade.

The Opposition and, indeed, the industry itself overall support the legislation . But we on this side of the House do have some very real concerns and, as far as the livestock industry policy is concerned, we will be moving an amendment in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. We oppose giving this Bill a second reading because we are opposed to the establishment of unnecessary statutory authorities. We will be moving an amendment to clause 7 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill. This is the clause which refers to consultation.

In releasing the Opposition's primary industry policy document last week, I indicated that we believed in consultation and minimum government interference and control. This is the first time that we have had the opportunity of transposing our policies into legislation, and it is because we believe that there are rectifiable flaws in this legislation that we are now translating our words into action.

As far as the AMLC goes, I am concerned that there will be a lack of formal consultation between the various sections of the industry and the newly structured body. We have a real fear that the new statutory authority, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council, could overshadow and replace the activities of bodies such as the Cattle Council and the Sheepmeat Council. What assurance is given that the Minister, when he is approached by bodies such as these which represent livestock producers, will not only listen to them but also take appropriate positive action? Will he instead refer the matter to his industry body with its myriad of representatives, such as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and State meat authorities, where it will be debated by people who in some cases will have no expertise and no direct knowledge of the issue? It needs no vivid imagination to realise the enormous muscle the Minister can exert through an obsequious and sedulous public servant in the name of democracy.

One can understand that legitimate concerns of livestock producers could well become submerged beneath a rousing chorus of 'Yes, Minister'. The Minister says 'yes' to consensus. But how can we get consensus when a number of the groups represented around the policy table will have views that are quite distinct, narrow and, in some cases, utterly prejudiced? One understands that these groups will be doing their utmost to look after their own interests rather than the total industry. I will cite an obvious example: Given the difficulties being experienced with the live sheep export trade, would it not be surprising if the ACTU advocate had any thought at all for the difficulties being experienced by the grazier through low domestic and export mutton prices, and the better position the grazier would be in, and is in, if he could export his old sheep live at a much higher price? Will this person-and I am merely using this as an example-arrive at a consensus or will he or she merely continue to do what has been done for years, that is, deliberately sabotage a great export industry which does little to jeopardise jobs in the processing industry? These sheep are not in demand in carcass form either at home or abroad. There is, however, a multiplier effect with the live sheep export trade-more income for graziers and their families can be spent on more jobs in industry and on the farm.

Let me make it quite clear where the Opposition stands on the live sheep trade. We said this in our policy document released last week. We are totally committed to it so long as proper animal welfare standards are maintained and, if there are any difficulties on any aspect of the live sheep trade, we will ensure that there is adequate producer representation on any inquiry. Stripped to its bare essentials, too few people realise that the producers first and foremost are the industry. Other sections exist to service the producers. But if there are no producers, there will be no industry.

We will, as I said previously, be opposing the second reading of the ALMIPC Bill. There is absolutely no need to have another statutory authority. Already there are far too many of them. My understanding is that this Bill is the Minister's own baby. I give the House fair warning now that this baby will never grow into adulthood.

True to its socialistic objectives, the Hawke Government has absorbed the dictums of the founders of socialism, Lenin and Marx. They said to their comrades: 'Divide and conquer'. Let rural Australia be aware that some of this legislation is socialist dogma in its perfection: Set up a group which will aim to reach consensus, but which will be permanently hamstrung by disagreement because there is really nothing to bind them together; refer everything to a committee serviced by a hand-picked team from the Minister's own Department; then use all of this elaborate statutory framework as an excuse for the Minister to step in and do as he pleases. On our return to power we will repeal this legislation. As I indicated in our rural policy document, we want less and not more government interference in the affairs of industry and agriculture.

There are two other points I make before returning to the AMLC Bill. The Minister proposes meetings about four times a year. This appears to me to be far too few given the complexity and ever-changing circumstances of the industry. Surely it would have been reasonable to plan for a meeting at least every two months. Clause 6 of the Bill requires that an industry conference be held every two years. Its purpose basically is to reach further consensus. But again the Minister asks the industry to take him on trust. Who will attend? What will be the voting rights? Why will the Minister not tell us these things? There has been ample time to come up with voting rights and attendance rules. The Minister has been rabbiting on about this legislation for months. But so concerned is the Hawke Government about rural Australia that it slips in this legislation at the very tail end of the spring session.

I turn now to the annual general meeting of the Meat and Live-stock Corporation . Again the Minister has not told us who will attend the annual general meeting. Will the cattle and sheep producers be elected according to numbers of animals or weight of meat? There are differences in voting entitlements, depending on which criterion is used, and I give the obvious example of beef producers in Victoria and Queensland. How will the processors' and exporters' rights be established? Will it be on a sliding scale? Will there be a maximum and minimum number of votes? Why does the Minister not come clean and tell the Parliament these things? What three card trick has he got up his sleeve in the regulations? This Minister for lame excuses must not be allowed to run for cover and say it will be done by regulation. In his closing remarks in this debate, let him tell us what the voting rules will be. I know he may be a little tired after his belated trip to Japan and Korea, but I hope he can give us these details. We want to know, and I submit that the Parliament and the industry have the right to know. The people in the bush need to know their entitlements, just as others have the right to know.

I am concerned too at the somewhat nebulous power of the industry at the annual general meeting in so far as votes of no confidence in the Chairman or in the Corporation and the fixing of levies are concerned. How does the industry, under the 75 per cent rule of both registrars, contain such increases in levies which are recommended by a corporation, but only one section of that corporation-and a very small percentage-is required to pay the levy? It needs to be made very clear-and it is the producer, the cattle and sheep men of Australia who pay-that it is not unknown for some people to be rather reckless with other people's money. It appears to me that the annual general meeting is nothing more than a facade. It just will not work. The Minister really has endeavoured to cloud the issue. He has set up a framework under the disguise of consensus but his real threat is revealed in his second reading speech, where he states:
. . . provides the Minister with overall supervision of the Corporation's activity.
Let those words mean what they say. That is socialism, and most definitely is not the free enterprise system that the Opposition promotes and upholds.

We agree with the initiatives to make the Corporation have a five-year corporate plan. In our policy document we spoke about a master plan for agriculture. This concept falls within the ambit of our thinking. The right to raise money by issuing securities, subject to the necessary precautions, and the right to act as a sole trader and to trade in meat and livestock that it does not own are all initiatives we support. My understanding is that the industry also supports these proposals. For our part, we will monitor them closely. As a free enterprise farmer in a free enterprise party, I want to compliment the cattle producers for the decision they made to fund promotion by a levy of $1 a head. It will be money well spent. The domestic market is under pressure from other primary products and from arguable nutritional information being circulated in the media. We need to actively counter these measures at home and abroad. Indeed, when I attended the recent annual Cattle Council meeting in Perth, I was told that our displays overseas ran far behind those of our competitors-for example, New Zealand.

The Minister places great faith in the Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee, consisting as it does of three processors and three producers. Without wishing to knock the concept, one can visualise the Committee becoming tied in its deliberations about nominations for the various positions. In effect , the danger is that the Chairman could have an all-powerful vote. If I might express a personal opinion-I stress it is a personal opinion-I would have preferred the Selection Committee to consist of three producers and two from other sections of the industry. We must never forget that the industry, as I stated previously, can never exist without the producers.

The Minister has set up an elaborate framework of selection. One is always cautious of the academic approach. I think it is reflected here. I am not totally convinced by it. It needs to be understood that the success of the proposed amendments to the structure depend very largely on the quality of the leadership. Given competent leadership and goodwill from all parties involved, the new structure would possibly work very well. I hope it does. I want to sound a note of warning to the Minister. Whilst we of the Opposition have given the legislation our qualified support, he must not assume that, in government, we will support a structure which could more appropriately be transferred to other agricultural commodity boards or corporations. I signal my concern in particular at his proposal for the Australian Wheat Board. I do not support the proposals he has announced in this regard.

I want to make some comments on the Bill concerning payments to the Northern Territory for disease eradication. It needs to be realised that the industry faces levies of $10.98 per head for each head slaughtered to meet the various industry expenses. They are as follows: $4.00 for brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication; $5.40 for meat inspection; $1.20 AMLC levy; 35c for meat research- to be increased to 54c in July of this year; and 3c a head industry contribution to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.
