On a more appropriate occasion I will comment on the excessive costs of the inefficient, duplicated meat inspection system we have in Australia and the announcement in our policy document that we will fully fund inspection costs for all primary produce exported where Commonwealth certification is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good policy.

—I am indebted to the honourable member for Murray, who realises the enormous burden placed on meat producers by the action of the Hawke Government in increasing meat inspection charges by 200 per cent. The brucellosis and tuberculosis program is winding down in the southern States and is now centred on the eradication of these diseases in the Northern Territory. There are major difficulties to be overcome in the Northern Territory. The financial impact on the larger stations which are required to destock is enormous because of the loss of income and breeding potential. I am reliably informed by breeders in the Kimberley area that even well-established graziers, like the Emmanuel family, will go out of business through the very high costs required to find replacement breeders.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that a conference will be held in the Northern Territory to design a strategy to ensure that this most difficult phase of our program is finalised with adequate compensation to producers with real reimbursement of operational expenses and with the replacement breeder cost element taken into account. It is possible that 1992, given these circumstances, is not a realistic date for all regions of Australia. To date, over $400m has been spent on the tuberculosis eradication campaign of which 70 per cent, or $280m, has been funded by industry and $120m, or 30 per cent, by government. There have been real problems in the Northern Territory and, unfortunately, there has been some political tension between the Minister in the Northern Territory and the Minister here. I do not wish to comment on these political tensions, but I make a plea to both Ministers to forget about politics and get on with the job of overcoming the problem. These diseases are a threat to the future of the industry, and the industry must be above personalities.

The Northern Territory has been criticised by the Commonwealth Government for not playing its part. This is an unwarranted criticism because the Northern Territory, when it obtained self-government, had to develop a strategy to eliminate diseases through a very large program with very limited resources, money and personnel. One can understand that. On the Commonwealth side, senior management appears to me to have had some difficulty in getting its act together , particularly with regard to solving the problem of developing a strategy for extending the campaign into areas where the Commonwealth has some legal responsibility for land, such as national parks and Aboriginal territory where cattle graze. Of course there has always been, and unfortunately there continues to be, the problem of feral animals. I hope that real work can be done to get on with the job, and I particularly hope there will be generous treatment for those pioneering families in the Kimberleys and the Top End who still possess those wonderful pioneering traits of hard work, self reliance and getting on with the job, looking after themselves and making a contribution to the economic life of this country, for which they should be applauded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure for me to enter the debate this morning on the very important legislation that is before this House, although it is somewhat disappointing once more to have been in the chamber to listen to the Opposition spokesman on primary industry, the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), come out with comments similar to those of his colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I think, though, if one takes the comments of the honourable member for Darling Downs in their true context this morning, one can come to the conclusion, judging by the fact that there is only one substantial amendment the Opposition is proposing to move at this stage to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill, that, by and large, the Opposition supports the measures of the Government. I certainly commend it for that support. I think also the honourable member for Darling Downs is only too well aware that the concept of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation that is envisaged in the amendment Bills before the House this morning is generally supported by the industry itself.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member who preceded me this morning so correctly pointed out, the industry is indeed in a state of great crisis. The industry, to some extent, is lacking in direction. This is clearly evident in two recent reports which have been submitted as a response to the New South Wales Livestock and Grain Producers Association in agreement with the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association. I wish to quote from comments made last Friday, 25 May, by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation reporter, Lyn Wilkes, in National Farm Report, which very clearly give an indication of the way in which the industry is lacking in direction at present. The report states:

The two reports differ widely in their recommendations. One is by former Western Australian Lamb Marketing Board General Manager, Malcolm McSporran, the other by Management Consultant, W. D. Scott and McGowans International. McSporran urges total market intervention with acquisition of all lambs as a first option just in New South Wales and Victoria, but possibly nation-wide. He recommends a statutory marketing authority, funded by levy and pooling of domestic and export returns with exports to be handled by the West Australian Board because of its existing expertise.
It then goes on to say:
On the other hand, the W. D. Scott report takes a much lower profile in market intervention--
which would please, no doubt, the honourable member for Darling Downs in view of his preceding comments-

recommending a series of evolving strategies. The first step is the introduction of carcase classification seen as immediately essential to adjust production towards consumer preference for leaner lamb and so build consumer confidence and demand.

I quoted from those comments simply to illustrate the fact that there is a great deal of uncertainty and a great lack of direction in the industry at present. That is why these Bills that are before the House this morning represent an attempt to alter the makeup and structure of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and represent a long overdue recognition that the Australian industry is in a dire position. The Bills themselves provide the administrative framework for the reform of the meat and livestock industry. Since the AMLC was established through a restructuring of the Meat Board, changes in the structure of the organisation have been a continual feature of the operation of the AMLC. However, one can only query whether or not the AMLC has always come to grips with the changing demands of the market place.

All too often, on the question of marketing of red meats, one must ask whether or not producers or promoters either understand or appreciate the differentiation between advertising and marketing. It is therefore pleasing to me to see that the new package of Bills should ensure that the AMLC's general policy advisory role will change to an emphasis on three important areas: Export market development, red meat promotion and export control. Only yesterday I received the annual report of the Sheepmeat Council of Australia. That clearly pointed out some of the ways in which the consumers are demanding the red meat marketing issue be approached. I quote from page 7 of that report:

The Australian family is also changing. In many cases both parents work outside the home, biting into the time available for food preparation. While some cuts of lamb lend themselves to rapid cooking, the more expensive roasting cuts have suffered.

Again I guess that statement from that very responsible body further emphasises the fact that there is a great change out there in the market place. It is important for us to recognise this. The report also goes on to mention an interesting concept, something that I have been familiar with in my electorate. It mentions the concept of the 'Big Jumbuck' that is currently blocked because of the lack of finance. It caters for this aspect in two parts. The Sheepmeat Council report comments:

The first envisages a chain of Kentucky-style outlets offering both fresh and pre-cooked mutton and lamb which requires minimum preparation at home. Because production would be centralised and outlets manned by a minimal number of semi- skilled staff, overheads would be low, but sales potentially high.
The second part aims at a chain of upmarket Pizza Hut-type family restaurants serving sheepmeat dishes in surroundings featuring the Australian grazing industry and its folklore.

So the report goes on. It has always surprised me to some extent that, while we have McDonalds, Kentucky fried chicken, Chinese takeaways and other fast foods in Australia, there is no Australian equivalent that offers Australian red meat producers, particularly lamb producers, something that could be available in portion-controlled, fresh and pre-cooked forms that recognises the dynamic nature of Australian eating habits today. I believe that, within the scope of the Bills that are before the House today, there is an opportunity for the new Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to address some of these important issues. We must recognise, as so many reports have indicated to us, that there is a changing attitude towards meat consumption in Australia. The 'Jumbuck' concept is an approach to marketing that I believe should be able to sit fairly comfortably with the new AMLC.

Another rather interesting article that I came across during the course of preparing my remarks this morning was an article from an American magazine called The Furrow which, in the early part of this year, published an article entitled 'Restructured Meat Shows Promise'. It makes this point:
Processing low-grade meats to look and taste like higher-priced cuts has been hailed from time to time as a potential boon to the livestock industry.

Unfortunately, we have not always been able to come to grips with that issue as well. Last Tuesday the Government primary industry sub-committee had the opportunity to look at an Australian innovation in the form of restructured meat . Mr Ted Jones of Bathurst, who has been working on this 'Jumbuck' concept, addressed that committee. He was able to demonstrate to members of that committee some of the properties of this restructured meat. One of the significant aspects of this concept is the fact that there is a greater use of the carcass. Unfortunately, with present consumption patterns and present styles of marketing, the basic use of the carcass is restricted to a very small percentage, whereas, under this concept of restructured meat, it is possible to find that most of the meat from the carcass is used.

The downstream effects of this are very significant. If we can move backwards from the market place to the producer the benefits of this are quite obvious. Mr Jones was talking in terms of a basic return to lamb producers of somewhere between $30 and $35 per lamb. That is a very significant improvement on the present price that producers receive for their lambs. I hope that the new AMLC will look very closely at some of these developments in marketing Australian lamb not only in Australia but indeed overseas.

I have mentioned before that we need to look at the change in consumption of meat patterns and look at the reasons for this. As I have said before, we must not confuse marketing with advertising. In 1971 Australian consumption of lamb was 24 kilograms per head and mutton was 20 kilograms per head but in 1982, 11 years later, lamb consumption was 16.6 kilograms per head and mutton only 4 kilograms per head. Clearly there has been a massive change. Peter Cross in an article in the Land on 28 April 1983 stated:
So introduction of mutton into the fast food industry would appear to be the most promising way to lift sheep meat consumption.

It appears that out in the big wide world there is a recognition that we need to do something about our approaches to marketing if we are to save the total collapse of the Australian red meat industry. It is interesting that a firm such as McDonalds in 1980 used 4.7 million kilograms of meat, and nearly 7 million kilograms last year, or nearly 30,000 head of cattle in 1983. That demonstrates that there is a great capacity, if people are able to recognise that there is a change in attitudes towards the consumption of food.

I have also looked at an interesting report by the Cattle Council of Australia which is headed 'Consumer Attitudes, Opinions, Perceptions and Usage of Red Meats'-an exploratory study with particular emphasis on beef. This study was conducted by David McKinna of the Cattle Council of Australia and the report is dated January 1984. Towards the end of the report are some conclusions relating to consumer attitudes and opinions. It states:
The main reasons why consumers are using less red meat are:
There is a lower use of red meat in traditional ways, e.g. Sunday roasts;
Prevailing attitudes that too much red meat is bad for you;
Specific negative attitudes toward red meat and health;
Greater acceptance of food variety offered, and greater recognition of alternatives;
Cost is an inhibiting factor;
A busier lifestyle, with less time and priority given to shopping for and preparing meat.

I urge honourable members who are interested in this very important subject, if they have not had an opportunity to look at some aspects of the report by the Cattle Council, to do so. It is well worth while looking at in the context of my remarks this morning.

I think the other point that needs to be made is that it is important not to differentiate between red meats. We often hear that lamb producers are quite naturally concerned about developments within their industry but it is important to recognise that when there is a downturn in lamb production in Australia there are likely to be spin-off effects in both beef and pork as well. I have before me an article in the Age of 27 January 1983, written by Ken Haley, which provides some very interesting information about the consumption of various types of meat varieties over a period. Without going into all the figures that are mentioned in the article, in 1977 to 1979 the total consumption of meat varieties in kilograms per person was 110.3 but in 1983 that figure had fallen to 95.5, again further emphasising the need for the industry to look at the reasons why it is in trouble and why it needs to take new approaches. I would certainly urge that with the formation of the restructured AMLC from 1 July this year one of its most important tasks is to look at the new directions for the industry.

I take this opportunity of congratulating the new Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation from 1 July, Mr Richard Austen, the Chairman of a very important company in Australia, Austen and Butta Ltd, which is largely concerned with the coal industry. Mr Austen is involved in marketing. I am pleased that he has been appointed to such an important position simply because I believe that a great deal of emphasis needs to be placed on the marketing of red meats in Australia. A pleasing aspect in clause 7 of the Bill gives the Corporation the right to consult any industry groups or individuals on any topic and to compensate those persons or groups for their costs and expenses that are reasonably incurred. I think that is a realistic attitude to take. If there is to be research, and hopefully a lot of development will flow from that research, it only stands to reason that those people involved in it need to be encouraged with compensation for their development costs. In general terms, the amendment removes the direct influence of the producer and the processor exporter groups and replaces this with a greater degree of ministerial control over the operations of the Corporation. The basic day-to-day administrative functions are freed from ministerial control but there will be no reduction in the overall control of the Corporation.

I believe it is important in an organisation such as the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to have people who understand the exporting side and the promotion and marketing sides. The honourable member for Darling Downs commented in his speech that first and foremost the producers are the industry and I would agree entirely with those comments. As I have said before, it is important to look not just at the producer; we must go further down from the producer. We should be taking action that encourages producers to do the things they do best, that is, to produce the product that Australian and world consumers demand. We need to look not only at the producers and encourage them but also at marketing and at what the consumers out in the market-place, both locally and overseas, are demanding from our industry.

I think it is important to have representation on the Board of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation that is not entirely representative of just the producers. Most certainly we have to recognise their contribution but we have to take a greater approach, a stronger approach, to the marketing of our red meats. I believe our approach to marketing has been a post World War II response, a 1950s response, to marketing. Fortunately the times have changed in many instances but unfortunately for the industry it has not caught up with the changing times and it is important that we recognise this fact.

In conclusion, I take this opportunity of congratulating the Minister for Primary Industry on his initiative in bringing these Bills before the House. I know the amount of time and effort the Minister has put into the drafting of these Bills and the widespread industry consultation he has had regarding these Bills. It is no wonder that he is regarded as Australia's most competent Minister for Primary Industry for many years. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate the words of the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) when he began his speech by pointing out that the meat industry does face quite a few problems. I will start by pointing out the size of the industry and particularly its effect on the export trade. In 1982-83 meat exports were worth $1.6 billion and of the exports 73 per cent by volume was made up of beef and veal. Thirty-five per cent of our total meat production is exported. There is no doubt that we have seen a very serious decline in the meat industry and the livestock industry in Australia. I will quote just a couple of figures. In 1976 the cattle population of Australia was 33.4 million and by 1984 it is estimated to be 22.2 million. That is a decline of over 30 per cent. By any imagination that is a very large decline and is something which should be viewed with considerable concern by all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1970 Australia had a sheep population of 180 million. By 1983 that number was down to 133 million. I have to admit, though, that factors other than the meat value of the sheep are involved, causing the decline in sheep numbers. One of the most heartening things to find in the preliminary figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics is that it is anticipated that the sheep population has recovered by over seven million in the last year. I also venture to say that the sheep population would be lower if it were not for live sheep exports. Of course, these figures have been affected, to some extent, by the drought. In time, there will also be recovery in cattle numbers. That recovery will come about only if the meat industry can see long term prospects and definite signs of an increase in profitability. Of course, this has had a serious effect on employment in the processing industry. I will give, the House some figures. Since 1979, of the 180 major abattoirs in Australia, 35 have closed. Of those 35 abattoirs 21 were registered for export. Up until 1983 the number of people employed in the industry fell by 6,000 to some 39,000.

The meat industry has had many problems over the last few years, not least of which-if we run through a short list-is the meat scandal and the royal commission that followed that. There is no doubt that that cost Australian beef producers many millions of dollars. We are probably still suffering from the long term effects of that disaster. If we look at the problems in the sheep meat area, as the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) stated, it was mentioned in the report of the Sheepmeat Council of Australia that we have a problem selling red meat in Australia. Of course, we also have another problem-one that was not mentioned-in some States related to the restriction on selling meat during certain trading hours when other meats such as chicken and fish are for sale. Red meat trading is still restricted after 5.30 p.m. in many States. Another problem faced by the meat industry, which, of course, is not addressed by these Bills but which I hope in due course the Government will look into, concerns processing costs. I quote from the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry of January 1983 on meat processing costs:

These costs compare most unfavourably with meat processing costs in South America, largely because of differences in plant utilisation, labour costs and productivity. The inflexibility with which the 'tally' system is used to set labour earnings, imposes a heavy cost burden on the industry that can be supported only because we do not have to compete with the major low-cost producers. If Australia ever loses its foot and mouth disease-free status, or if the South Americans find a way to control the disease, or if for other reasons the US, Korea and even perhaps Japan, decide to accept imports from these countries, we will find it impossible to compete with our current processing cost structure.

I think that is a very clear warning for the Government and for the meat processing industry. We have to get our act together in this area or we will face further decline in the industry. As the honourable member for Darling Downs has pointed out we have some limitations as regards the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. Of course, one of them is related to the problem of dealing with countries that have single purchasing authorities. I will give one example. In places where countries purchase by tender, such as in some Middle East sheep meat markets, individual exporters can win a contract only if their price is very low. They then must pack poor quality meat to meet the low price. Next time around the tender specifications may be rewritten in such a way as to exclude Australian product because the importing country believes all our product is of poor quality. Worse still, an exporter may be so small in the world market that he can move from buyer to buyer taking profits by overpricing poor quality product. The costs of such actions are borne by the Australian industry as a whole, which means the producer. I think that highlights some of the problems which we have seen in the industry. I certainly hope that the proposed amendment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act will overcome some of these problems.

I will briefly mention something about the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation as it exists at present, prior to the enactment of this new Bill. It was established in December 1977 to regulate and promote the export of meat and livestock, as well as to promote local consumption. The Corporation has the power to be a sole trader but it has been very reluctant to use that power and, as well, that has always been subject to ministerial control. Exporters of meat and livestock are licensed by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. The Corporation also is supposed to assist in overseas market development. As mentioned by the honourable member for Darling Downs, the gross value of the meat and livestock industry is in excess of $3 billion. Meat represents 7 per cent of Australia's total export earnings, which makes it still one of the largest export earners.

The operating cost for the Meat and Livestock Corporation in the last financial year was $13m. I draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that 85 per cent of operating cost funds were raised from livestock slaughter levies and export charges. In other words, the industry is almost totally self-supporting in this respect. We accept that there is a need for change. I think that this has been very well highlighted by Dr Geoff Miller in his address to the National Agricultural Outlook Conference earlier this year. Incidentally, I understand that Dr Miller has more than a passing interest in the structure of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. I think he highlighted the real reason we want to see changes when he said in part:

While Australian farmers are efficient, the same cannot generally be said of the non-farm elements of our industries. Although there are some exceptions, it is my view that the economic performance of our rural industries is very heavily constrained by the poor performance of non-farm activities.

I endorse Dr Miller's remarks. I think the point I made earlier about processing costs is one example of an area where we have some problems. However, Dr Miller went on in his address to give some very clear warnings to governments on this. He said:
Government responsibility is to create, and if necessary to reshape, the economic environment in which our industries conduct their business: to create and reshape, not to take over and control.
I emphasise the word 'not'. I think the next statement is a gem-
There are few industries less efficient in our economy than the government controlled ones.
Dr Miller further went on in respect of government involvement to say:

There should be an end to direct government controls over staffing and financial operations of the new corporations. Ministerial responsibility, parliamentary accountability and public scrutiny should not be confused with bureaucratic control.
I think that those, coming from one of the architects of the new Bill, are very sound warnings. I hope the Government will heed them and ensure that government involvement does not mean a takeover.
In the Minister's second reading speech on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill he stated:

This legislation will also clarify the functions and powers of the AMLC, with particular attention to increasing its accountability to the Parliament and to those in industry whose levy payments provide the source of its finance.

Those are very fine words. I hope that in practice this new Bill will actually achieve that aim. Unfortunately I have reason to question parts of the Bill. I will come to that in a minute. I question the statement particularly in relation to the producer's point of view. As has been mentioned before, without the producer there would be no meat and livestock industry. I think the producers can quite rightly claim to have, and should have, more than a passing interest in how the new Corporation is run. I also endorse some of the changes the Minister envisaged for the Meat and Livestock Corporation when he stated:
The Bill provides for the removal of the restriction that the Corporation can only trade in livestock and meat that it owns.

I think that is a very welcome move, especially in the light of the example that I gave before; that is, in cases of dealing with countries that have a single purchasing authority for all meat imports.

I turn now to a specific part of the Bill to which the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) foreshadowed the Opposition will move an amendment because we are very concerned that the Meat and Livestock Corporation is not bound to consult with the industry. It may consult with other groups if it so wishes, but by and large it will consult only with the proposed Policy Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a spirit of consensus?

—It has been put in those words. The other area of concern is voting rights for the annual general meeting of the Meat and Livestock Corporation. I draw two points to the Minister's attention. One is the question of who actually has voting rights. The Minister said in his second reading speech that they will be determined on the basis of livestock ownership. I point out to the Minister-I notice we have a Queenslander here-that Victoria produces annually 607,000 tonnes of meat in carcass form, while Queensland produces only 578,000 tonnes. In other words, Victoria produces more meat. But in regard to stock numbers, Victoria has 4.1 million head of cattle while Queensland has 9.8 million. I do not know whether that is a reflection on the efficiency of the different States. The position in regard to sheep numbers is reversed. Victoria has 25.2 million sheep and Queensland has 12.3 million. I draw that to the Minister's attention and ask how he will equitably allocate voting right entitlements for livestock owners at the annual general meeting.
—That is a good point. Victoria has been sold short again.

—We do not know yet, but we will make sure that it is not. I also draw the Minister's attention to proposed new section 30, which deals with voting rights at the annual general meeting, the removal of the Chairman and the right of refusal to raise levies. In order for such a motion to be carried, the Minister stated that 75 per cent of votes of persons registered in the producer category and 75 per cent in the processor-exporter category must be cast at the annual general meeting in support of it. I suggest to the Minister that in practice this will be almost unworkable. Obviously, certain safeguards are needed to allow accountability and responsibility; nonetheless, to get 75 per cent agreement from both of those groups would be well nigh impossible. I think the Minister ought to reconsider the 75 per cent figure because it will be very difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Bill 1984. I question why the Minister needs to have a statutory body. The Minister says in his second reading speech on this Bill:
Its establishment with statutory status is necessary to provide a binding charter and to help me ensure its accountability.

I am not quite sure why it is so necessary to have this accountability. The Meat and Livestock Corporation itself is the statutory body. We in the Opposition view with concern the thought of having yet another quango. Australia is already riddled with them. We do not see the need for another. A further concern is whether the Minister is considering using the Council as a means of filtering industry opinion; in other words, forcing industry to go through the Policy Council rather than consulting with the Government. Again, is this a way whereby the Minister is moving himself another step away from the industry? That is something we also view with concern. It has already been foreshadowed that the Opposition will, in fact, oppose the measure for these reasons.

I mention now one area which, of course, is not directly involved but which the Government should continue to monitor very closely; that is, the live sheep export position. I have a particular interest, of course, in the port of Portland in my electorate. I know that the Minister is aware of the problems we have in Portland now. The State Government is giving official status to a picket line that the Australian Council of Trade Unions will not endorse by giving the picketers the right to direct the Victorian police force to stop trucks as they cross the picket line.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is he doing about it?
—That is what I hope the Minister will tell us today.
—It was called off yesterday.

—The Minister has just given me some good news. In conclusion, by and large we welcome the Minister's initiative regarding the Meat and Livestock Corporation. We will be watching very closely to see the progress of the revamped Corporation. For the sake of the industry we certainly hope that the Corporation is extremely successful. The industry has been in a state of decline for some years now. We hope that this will be one step towards reversing that decline. As I have mentioned, the Opposition will move an amendment to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill to insist that the Corporation consult with the industry. As well we also oppose the move by the Government to establish yet another statutory body to be placed, as we see it, probably between the Minister and the industry.
—More red tape.
—That is right, more red tape.
—More toadies for the Minister.
—We have heard all sorts of expressions now. The Opposition will watch with keen interest the progress of this new Corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills deal with a number of matters affecting rural Australia. We hear more bleating from 'animal farm' over there, the National Party of Australia. It often amazes me how the National Party claims to represent rural Australia. (Quorum formed) Before I touched a raw nerve on the part of members of the National Party, I was saying that it amazes me that they claim to represent rural Australia when all of their seats are in the south-eastern corner. I can understand why they changed the name of the Party from the Country Party to the National Party; they had no seats in the country. But it is really a bit misleading to refer to themselves as the National Party when all of their seats are in the south-eastern corner, down in the front paddock. They have no seats in Western Australia, none in South Australia, none in the Northern Territory, none in Tasmania and none in the Australian Capital Territory. It is a city based party. It has seats in the towns. It is a totally misleading situation. The seats held by National Party members, of course, are in the cushy south-eastern corner. They would not know a thing about the outback. They would not know a thing about the bush. They would not know a thing about rural Australia. They know no more about it than an Eskimo would.

SPEECH.PARA: The only party that can honestly claim to represent the whole of Australia, including rural Australia, is, of course, the Australian Labor Party. We hold four of the largest seats in Australia, covering about 60 per cent of the land mass of Australia, including the electorates of the Northern Territory, Kalgoorlie, Grey and Leichhardt. The seats held by National Party members are all in the south-eastern corner. The National Party should either change its name to the South-eastern Australia Party or maybe just be honest and call itself 'animal farm' because that is how it behaves.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member for the Northern Territory to come back to the subject of the Bill and I ask members of the Country Party to remain silent.
—A point of order--
—Point of order--
—The National Party.
—Thank you.

—This legislation deals with some important matters affecting rural Australia. Of course, the Australian Labor Party would be expected to bring forward important legislation like this because we do represent the whole of Australia, including rural Australia, outback Australia and people in the towns and the cities. We have given some priority to this matter. We have an excellent Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) who has brought forward the legislation . The six Bills are in two basic groups. The first group deals with various changes to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and it includes changes to the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act and the Live-stock Export Charge Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The major achievements of the first group of Bills are: Firstly, to clarify the functions and powers of the AMLC and increase its accountability to the industry and to the Parliament; secondly, to establish a meat and livestock industry policy council to advise government; thirdly, to establish an industry committee to select high quality board members for the AMLC and later the proposed meat and livestock research and development corporation; and, fourthly, to provide a new mechanism for consulting the industry about changes in levies charged for meat and livestock slaughter and exports.

It may well be asked: Why are these changes necessary? Earlier speakers have referred to some of the problems in the industry. There is no doubt that the industry has been through a prolonged recession due to the instability of international markets and exacerbated by the effects of the drought. For many years producers in particular have been frustrated by slow progress of the resolution of a broad range of marketing problems. There has been divisive and inconclusive industry debate on such matters as, to name a few, the adoption of carcass classification and the sales of livestock by description, sole trading by the AMLC in single buyer markets, industry stabilisation measures and meat promotion and inspection. Much criticism has been directed by producers at the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation for inadequate progress in dealing with the industry's problems. This criticism is commonly based on misconceptions about the Corporation's ability to take remedial action in these areas. This has led in turn to producers describing the Corporation as unresponsive to their problems.

The three industry consultative groups-the producers, meat exporters and processors and the livestock exporters-which were established by statute as a link between the Corporation and industry have not fulfilled the original expectations. Their existence has tended to perpetuate industry divisions and divert the Corporation's attention from functions where it can exercise its powers. It is interesting to note that those three consultative groups were set up by statute, and the Opposition is now complaining that the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council that is being set up under this legislation is being set up by statute.

In February 1983 the Cattle Council of Australia, after extensive discussions, proposed changes to the meat and livestock industry administration. These changes were intended to enlarge the AMLC's charter to enable greater involvement in domestic marketing issues, increase the accountability of the Corporation to the industry and the Parliament, and increase its co-ordination with State meat authorities. Following the election of the Hawke Labor Government, the Minister for Primary Industry said that high priority would be given to the resolution of the industry's structural problems. Clearly, there was a need to establish a key industry policy formation body which would bring together the industry's diverse talents and resources to provide a more rigorous analysis of and understanding by all sectors of the industry's problems and to produce policies with full industry support and consensus. It was also clear that there was a need to clarify the commercial functions of the AMLC and to strengthen the professional skills and experience of its Board to enable the Corporation to be a more effective operational arm of the industry.

In April 1983 the Minister circulated a paper which developed the industry's discussions of the Cattle Council's proposals into a feasible new system. This paper was the foundation of the present legislation before the Parliament. Following the Minister's consultations with industry leaders a final package was agreed to in August 1983 and its principles were endorsed by the Government in October 1983. The Government agreed that, pending the introduction of enabling legislation, the Minister should establish the proposed Industry Policy Council and the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Selection Committee on an interim basis to avoid delay in implementation. Under this legislation responsibility for developing realistic policy proposals to introduce changes into the industry will now rest with the Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council. It will be composed of leaders of the industry, with the assistance of industry expertise, working co-operatively in specialised working groups to advise the Council. The responsibility for obtaining the highest quality people for the AMLC Board will now rest with the Industry Selection Committee, which will recommend eight appointments to the Minister for Primary Industry.

The new arrangements will increase the accountability of the AMLC to the industry. I am pleased to say that these changes have been well received by the industry. I refer to one recent example of an industry leader who supports the package of legislation that is now before us. In the 17 May edition of the Cattleman, Mr John Purcell, the Queensland Chairman of the Cattlemen's Union, in regard to this package of legislation, stated:
I support the structure and principles contained in the package.
Later he stated:
. . . I believe the new AMLC board will bring a new dimension of professionalism .
I am concerned that even after Mr Kerin's consultation, compromises and commonsense approach, some interstate organisations have the nervous nellies and want to back off.
This to me is crazy and totally negative.
Mr Kerin has my support and the support of the Cattlemen's Union.
That is an indication that the industry supports this legislation. It is now up to the industry to work together constructively to overcome its problems and to advance the interests of the industry.

The sixth Bill, in the second group, which applies specifically to the Northern Territory, applies retrospectively to payments made to the disease fund in the Northern Territory. While some may consider it insignificant, I think it is yet another significant indication that the self-governing Northern Territory is taken seriously by the Australian Government-The Hawke Labor Government. However , I think it is important to make a clear distinction between, on the one hand, the Northern Territory and the people of the Northern Territory and on the other , the Country Liberal Party Government in the Northern Territory. While the Northern Territory and its people certainly deserve self-government, they do not deserve to have a Country Liberal Party government foisted on them. The Country Liberal Party Government's handling of the brucellosis-tuberculosis eradication campaign is becoming a national scandal. Its handling of the scheme is putting at risk the operation of the scheme not only in the Northern Territory but also in Australia generally. That has serious implications for the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!

—The honourable member may not be interested in the brucellosis- tuberculosis eradication campaign but the people in the Northern Territory, including the producers whom he does not represent, are interested. The Northern Territory Government has demonstrated its total incompetence in two areas of its administration of the scheme. The first is its accounting system. It is so bad that the Government has managed to overpay on the brucellosis-tuberculosis eradication campaign compensation budget by over 50 per cent; that is, in about nine months it has paid out $6m against the 12 months budget of $4m. On top of that a number of serious allegations have been made about the scheme being defrauded of substantial sums. The investigation of these serious allegations is a matter for the Northern Territory Minister responsible for police, Mr Everingham. It is now approaching three months since those investigations commenced. Any competent Minister responsible for police would surely have ensured that the investigations of such serious matters affecting the scheme not only in the Northern Territory but also throughout Australia were finished by now. Of course, they are not.

SPEECH.PARA: I think only two conclusions can be reached: The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Minister responsible for police, is either trying to cover up the fraud to protect his Government and perhaps some Country Liberal Party members who may be involved in the fraud or he is hoping that if he strings it out we will all forget about it. I am not going to forget about it. It is about time the Northern Territory Chief Minister came clean on the whole issue. It is about time he discharged his responsibility to the Australian taxpayer and the Territory taxpayer by explaining how his Administration could have allowed a vital scheme such as this to be defrauded and at the same time overpay on the Budget by some $2m.

The brucellosis-tuberculosis eradication campaign conference to be held in Alice Springs next month, which was mentioned earlier by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), provides a perfect opportunity for both Mr Everingham and Mr Tuxworth of the Northern Territory Government to account to the industry in the Northern Territory, and for that matter in Australia, for their inept stewardship of the scheme in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are really desperate; you are running scared.

—The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and the honourable member for Gippsland obviously do not understand that unless the scheme operates throughout Australia and the disease is eradicated throughout Australia the producers in their electorates will be affected just as much as the producers in the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory cannot get away with running the scheme so poorly because it will affect everybody.
—You do not know what your Government is doing with meat inspection.

—It is not the Australian Department of Primary Industry that is responsible for the difficulties with the scheme in the Northern Territory. It is not the cattle producers or the processors in the Northern Territory who are responsible for the mess; it is the Country Liberal Party Government that has got the whole scheme into such a mess that it has overpaid the budget by 50 per cent, thrown away $2m more than it should have, and at the same time has allowed the scheme to be defrauded of substantial sums. I hope that this brucellosis- tuberculosis eradication campaign conference next month does not turn out to be yet another Tuxworth talkfest. I hope that it results in some action being taken by the Northern Territory Government to improve its act.
—What about the Federal Labor Government doing something about it ? The Minister is in charge. Talk to him about it. Talk to the Labor Government.

—The honourable member for Maranoa will be interested to know that in the 1983-84 financial year the Federal Labor Government approved a record increase in funding for the scheme in the Northern Territory and that that increase was received well by the cattle producers and people connected with the industry in the Northern Territory. The problem is that the money is going down the drain in misuse and abuse. All I am saying is that it is about time that the Country Liberal Party Government in the Northern Territory took a look at itself and started to administer the scheme properly so that we can get the scheme running in the Territory. That will help not only the people and the industry in the Northern Territory but also the stars of Animal Farm on the other side of the House and the seats that they represent. I commend each of these six Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I shall address a few comments. First of all I congratulate particularly my departmental staff, personal staff and the speakers in this debate; the first two groups for the time and dedication they have put into getting these Bills together and for all the consultation and discussions they have had over the years with the industry, and honourable members who have contributed to this debate for their approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition fundamentally still chooses to misunderstand the political realities of the meat industry and what the Government is trying to do. This legislation represents a very positive attempt by the Government to resolve a difficult and long running issue. The six Bills together, as I said when I introduced them, clarify the functions and powers of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and increase its accountability to industry and the Parliament. They establish a Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council to advise Government, establishes an industry committee to select high quality Board members for the AMLC and later the proposed Meat and Livestock Research Development Corporation and provide a new mechanism for consulting the industry about changes in levies charged on meat and livestock slaughter and exports.

Why has this been necessary? The industry has been through a prolonged recession, as many speakers have said, due to the instability of the international market on which it is largely dependent and, of course, this has been exacerbated by the effects of the drought. For many years producers in particular have been frustrated by the slow progress with the resolution of a broad range of marketing problems. The former Minister kept on saying that there would be blood on the floor if he did not get some sort of agreement in this industry. He was never able to get it. There has been a divisive and inconclusive industry debate on such matters as the adoption of carcass classification, sales of livestock by description, the question of sole trading by the AMLC in single-buyer markets, industry stabilisation measures and meat promotion inspection, just to name a few of the contentious issues facing this complex and interdependent industry.

I will address the Opposition's amendment when it comes up. The honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) mentioned several other points. Basically, the points raised by the Opposition centred on inadequate representation by producers and the fact that an additional statutory body is to be created. Actually, we wiped out three and even if we include a selection committee as another we still have a net gain of one, but I will not go into the detail of that. It still seems that the Opposition is possessed by this whole idea of a numbers game approach to the solution of industry policy issues. We are trying to depoliticise this issue for the one very basic reason that there is a fundamental clash between producers and processors in this industry.

On the AMLC Board the industry, the producers, always had the numbers and yet more and more they were not meeting the wishes of the producers themselves even when they had the numbers. The source of all their anger was eventually centred on one man, the Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, Geoff Jones. I think he has served the industry very well. Although his position has changed to a part time position I believe that much of the criticism heaped on him has been totally unearned.

There have been problems with the running of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation but the main problem has been the parties involved in it-the producers and processors. We are trying to depoliticise this issue, to let the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation get on with its prime role and functions and have these industry policy questions or the industry's politics settled in a less embattled environment, with a wide range of people focusing on the issues, not on commercial matters in which the interests, because they are vested interests, become even stronger.

I wish quickly to canvass a few of the points raised by honourable members. The question of the selection committee was raised. The two sectors reached voluntary agreement on this question and a balance was struck for objectivity. We did not think it was in the interests of the industries that one group have more power than the other. The Australian Meat and Livestock Research Development Corporation was mentioned. Legislation in respect of that body will be introduced in the Budget session.

Turning to two general matters, I should like to say that there is no inclination on the part of the Government to restrict in any way the role of policy councils. I have seen reference made in other places to the fact that if that is done in respect of the beef industry it will be done in respect of the wool industry. I hark back to the fact that those commodities are basically different. The Wool Council of Australia well serves the wool industry. The beef industry does not have one simple council. That is why we are setting up an industry policy council that takes all points of view into account. No attempt is being made in any way to weaken the role or the negotiating ability of the producers. The fact that the producers will not pay for this organisation does not mean that an attempt is being made to limit the power and role of the producers in this industry. What we are is trying to do is to focus on the issues.

Questions were raised in relation to the annual general meeting. I suppose no issue has taken more time in personal negotiation and negotiation by officers of my Department with the industry than that devoted to this question. As all honourable members know, the producers have fundamental differences. Those differences are based on geographic factors and methods of production. There is a lot of difference between the methods used by a fellow raising a few herefords in Victoria as opposed to those used by someone fattening hundreds, if not thousands, of brahmans in north Queensland. Account has to be taken that in this industry there is great disparity between producers who have a handful of cattle and those who have literally thousands. Some agreement has been reached. That agreement will be enacted by regulation within two or three months. To be quite frank, that agreement has been reached after a lot of number crunching.

I shall cite some figures that I have in my mind. The range from 101 to 1,000 cattle equivalent-we are counting 10 sheep as one cow-represents 56.2 per cent of the whole sheep and cattle industry. That broad group, which is the very backbone of the industry, will be receiving 60 per cent of the votes at the annual general meeting. Those matters will be enacted by way of regulation. Agreement has been reached with the Cattle Council of Australia and the Sheepmeat Council of Australia. I have spoken with organisations at the State level in order to take into account the differences between the States, and in particular the position of Queensland.

The honourable member for Darling Downs seems to think that if he parrots the words 'free enterprise' that is sufficient reason to justify any argument he puts forward, or that if he parrots the word 'socialism' that is sufficient reason to reject any argument advanced. I think we should focus more on the issues because, as the honourable member said, promotion for beef producers by beef producers is free enterprise. Is he saying that promotion for wool producers by wool producers, but also involving government assistance, equals socialism? Abattoirs and the problems they face because of the downturn in the cattle herd could be defined as free enterprise at work. I think there needs to be more focus on issues rather than on slogans.

The whole problem in this industry is that the producers operate on a free enterprise basis all the way to the sale point. The processes operate on a free enterprise basis, again all the way to the sale point. The reason the Government has had to introduce these changes is to facilitate marketing in the interests of all those involved in the industry, including the producers and the processors. There have been technical problems of facilitation which have not been able to be solved under the existing mechanism. The AMLC has been weak on some export questions, due to the fact that there is a fundamental cleavage within its ranks. That again reflects on the situation between the producers and the processors. The Government is trying to depoliticise the industry, to let the AMLC get on with its job of promoting, marketing and facilitating the sale of our export meats; but it is also trying to have the industry policy questions settled in another format. It is trying to get the industry into a position where it can solve its own problems rather than engage in some of the trench warfare that has been responsible for the lack of progress in the past few years .

I thank in particular the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) for his contribution to the debate. I well know his interest in this industry. He spent much time in speaking about the fact that lamb producers in his electorate are trying to do something about their own problems, particularly with the big jumbuck concept. I well know his interest in the Blayney abattoir. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) raised quite a few points. It appears that I will not have time to respond to them in detail. However, I shall make some notes for him. The honourable member raised some constructive points. As he pointed out, the big enemy of red meat is white meat. The reason there has been a downturn in the cattle herd is not only the drought but also the substitution of beef for grain or beef for sheep meat. I have just received some figures that show that the sheep flock has actually increased by some 7.9 per cent. That has occurred since the drought. I suppose the situation has been helped by the birth of a lot of twin lambs. At least that is one section of the livestock industry that is starting to improve.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7, page 3, at the end of proposed sub-section 10(1) add ''and shall consult with various industry bodies including the Cattle Council of Australia and the Sheepmeat Council of Australia under arrangements acceptable to the parties involved''.

I outlined the reason for moving this amendment in my speech at the second reading stage. The Opposition wants to seek to ensure that consultation between the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and industry bodies, including the Cattle Council of Australia and the Sheepmeat Council of Australia, will be on a basis satisfactory to the various parties. The current legislation provides only that the AMLC has the power to fund such consultations as required. I draw the attention of honourable members to the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in this regard. He expects that consultation between industry bodies and the AMLC will be less frequent, probably shorter and more directly concerned with technical issues than has been the case in the past, and that discussion of more significant industry policy issues will be channelled through the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council.

We note that Council retains the opportunity to raise matters directly with the Minister and the AMLC. However, we are very concerned because we believe it is apparent that the architects of the new arrangements expect major issues to be either directed to the Policy Council by the Cattle Council or the Sheepmeat Council or referred by the Minister to the Policy Council after he has received them direct from the industry. We just want to ensure that consultation does take place. A very important plank in the platform the Opposition released last week was that it will consult with the industry. The Opposition wants to ensure that what it said in that policy is spelt out quite clearly in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I addressed some of the comments made by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh ) in my reply to the second reading debate on this package of Bills. I say at the outset that the Government is not attempting in any way to diminish the ability of the two big councils-the Cattle Council of Australia and the Sheepmeat Council of Australia-to be fully involved with this new scheme of arrangements. However, it is trying to depoliticise this whole industry and to get people to focus on the issues that have bedevilled the industry. The Sheepmeat Council and the Cattle Council have policies on a wide range of issues . There is no way that their ability to put those issues forward to the Minister or to the AMLC, personally or in any other forum, will be diminished. However, the problem is what is acceptable to the Cattle Council or to any other organisation on any issue may simply be unacceptable to the AMLC, or it may just be inconvenient. That is fair enough. Those organisations will get their chance to put forward their proposals. To prevent that would militate against the flexibility envisaged in the consultation process. Before anything concrete is done, I want to try to ensure that there is some flexibility in the consultation process.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members know, currently consultations between the AMLC and industry consultative groups are a matter for agreement between the AMLC and the groups. This situation will remain. Some people have been concerned that I have wiped out three statutory authorities-the Livestock Producers Consultative Group , the Meat Exporters and Abattoir Operators Consultative Group and the Live- stock Exporters Consultative Group. If we are honest about it, we will admit that it was only in the last year or so that those consultative groups ever were really effective in going to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. They were constantly frustrated with that formal consultation. That partly reflected attitudes of the Board at various times, but I think inherently the Board had the attitude 'Seen that, done that, come back at some other time', and it never really worked, even when set up formally. That is why this time we are trying for flexibility and openness and are trying to depoliticise the process and have real consultation take place. I am sure that, under Mr Austen and the Board that will be given to the Government by the selection committee, that consultation will take place naturally and will be realistic and constructive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, as you are probably aware, I was listed to have a full 20 minutes on this subject, and as a representative of a country electorate I would have valued that. The Opposition was criticised by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells) last night for having insufficient interest in a Bill relating to education. It is interesting to note, therefore, the Opposition was able to muster speakers at great speed to prove that position absolutely wrong. The Government is unable to do this, contrary to the comments of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves), who took the time to tell us what a wonderful party for country people the Labor Party is.
—Order! Will the honourable member take the time to speak to the amendment?
—I am advised that there is room in this debate, because of the arrangements and because of my removal from the speakers' list, for me to make comments of a more wide-ranging nature.
—Certainly.

—The honourable member for the Northern Territory has unfortunately left the chamber. He introduced into the debate the usefulness of various members of parliament to their electorates. I am reminded of some of the things that he has supported in this place. I find that he was anti-uranium, which seems to be of some value to his electorate.
—Madam Chair, I take a point of order.
—Look, we have made an agreement on this. It is your fault that it has happened. Let me have my say. There is nothing wrong with it when you guys come at it, is there, nothing at all! Now, sit down.
—Order! Will the honourable member for O'Connor please resume his seat.
—On a point of order, I appreciate that the honourable member for O' Connor wants to be fairly wide-ranging, but I do not really appreciate the significance of uranium mining to this Bill.
—There is no point of order. The Chair will keep a watch on the honourable member.

—I am drawing to the attention of Australia, particularly the people of the Northern Territory, the performance of their smart aleck member who does one thing down here and goes back to his electorate and does another. I bet he is anti-uranium when he gets up there! I bet he is anti-railway! I bet he is anti the Aussat arrangements we tried to put through to give remote area people some priority on the domestic satellite. I know how he voted because it is recorded in Hansard. When we tried to change the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund legislation to get the excise fiddle back on to roads, which his people need more than probably any other people in Australia, how did he vote? He voted against it so that the money now goes into Consolidated Revenue. That is the man who chose here to criticise the people who battled for those things on behalf of country people, as I did. We know how to look after country people, and it is a sham when those opposite make statements like that here.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to go on with that because I have a genuine concern about this Bill. This legislation is supported and no doubt is a genuine attempt on the part of the Government to improve the problem in the beef industry. I am not sure that it will achieve that because I think we have too many bodies and because we are failing to recognise that the roles of the producer and the processor in the beef industry have to be looked at. I am not sure that bringing the representatives of those two sectors of the industry into the same room will necessarily improve the industry. In fact it appears to me that, over a period now, it has been the processing sector of the industry that has imposed a burden on the industry. It has been the one sector that has not really and truly been able to be flexible. It has found itself in the position of all other industries which service the primary sector, such as railways and grain handling, which have continued to grant wage increases by indexation. It is now the law of Australia that abattoirs will grant those sorts of increases. They are not able to adjust to the tough times other than by closing their doors, and of course they have been doing that in large numbers.

It appears to me that there may be room within the program that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is laying down with these new bodies to look at whether processors should also be marketers of product. I can see one good reason for that: They would then be responsible for the handling of the product, in other words, the animal they turn into a product which they must stand up for . But they have always been able to shift the cost of their operation back to the producer. This is what worries me. I wonder whether there is not more room for an operation whereby the producer organisations make the sales and consequently call tenders from the abattoir industry, the processors, to conduct the necessary processes.

This legislation gives more power to the AMLC to act as a single seller on certain markets, and I can see some benefits in that. That situation has been caused by individual processors cutting the price from Australia in competition with others in Australia. The only real beneficiary of that has been the purchaser in a foreign country. To my mind, what is needed is a more centralised marketing approach, not necessarily through government but through private enterprise, with the producers and their special organisations then saying to the processing industry: 'We want you to bid and we will give you a profit on the actual processing phase'. Of course, if the processors did not produce the product in the required form, or if they tried to add a bit of kangaroo at the bottom of the carton, they would not last very long in the business and everyone would know who was doing that. I think that is a thought for the Minister and his new meat and livestock group to consider.

I understand that because we are now in Committee I am speaking to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill. Of course, that Bill draws our attention to my other concern. This package of legislation concerns the restructuring of the AMLC, a new Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council, and a new Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee. Of course, then we have to have a couple of changes to levy Acts because levies are always associated with any of these arrangements. That worries me. I think we are getting too many people around the place. Then we have to have annual general meetings; and there are some little problems there of which we have already heard. I think some simpler arrangements would have been better.

Of course, the real concern in the industry is still government involvement in meat inspection charges. Although we now have this massive paper before us, no solutions have been offered by the Government in that area. I am pleased to support the proposal of our shadow Minister that the responsibility for that matter rest in future with the Government so that industry will not be burdened by the ridiculous situation of the Government providing services at double the cost for which they can be provided by other agencies. For that reason, this morning I rang the Northam Shire Council to find out what its meat inspection charges were today. I was told that it is doing a bullock for $3.60, which is considered to be a little high. Unfortunately its previous charge of $2.80 was a little low and, because of the way that the State scale is set out, it had to jump to $3.60. There has been a change to that. The Council would still be happy with $2.80, but the abattoir it services in the main is having a variation in its throughput and the Council has had to ask for a little more. That compares with $10.80 that the Commonwealth charges-$5.40 at the works and $5.40 that it picks up from the taxpayer.

This matter has got to be addressed. It is quite clear that there is something wrong. This is a massive burden compared to some of the other problems that have been established in this Parliament. I wish the Minister well with the legislation in this regard, because I know that the producers would like to see their industry better organised at this level. I just have some doubts. Why the heck we had to have a statutory authority for the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council I will never know. The Minister gave us his reasons. He stated:
Its establishment with statutory status is necessary to provide a binding charter and to help me ensure its accountability.
If the Council is going to be there only to give advice, I do not know why it needs accountability. We can surely provide a binding charter that is simple enough without making it statutory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill and cognate Bills before the House are a major turning point for the meat and livestock industries. I share the disappointment of the previous speaker, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), that the debate has been curtailed, but I want to make some brief observations in this Committee stage of the Bills. Firstly, I strongly support the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh). The Bills propose a structure but set a basis for a bureaucracy. There is no doubt at all that this could, and no doubt will, be far from the objective of business enterprise. For many years we have seen the vexed issue of the marketing, the processing and the ultimate export sale arrangements of meat in this country. That vexed question has resulted in the establishment, first of all, of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and there is a great deal of friction within the industry. I am sure it is the objective of all concerned, all sections of the industry and honourable members on both sides of this chamber that friction be replaced by an effective business enterprise approach to all facets of the meat and livestock industries. Unless that can be achieved, we place ourselves at great disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem that we face today is, without doubt, one of disability to properly organise, properly manage and effectively administer the various strata of the processing and the marketing of meat produced by the producers of this country. What concerns me, and the reason for the amendment, is to try to ensure that there is a satisfactory outcome to the new proposals. The worry is that ministerial prerogative is very evident in what is proposed. We find a structure without knowing exactly what that structure will achieve and we find a real disability in terms of the voting rights of producers. I believe that this does constitute a grave crisis in the short term for the meat industry. Unless the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) moves effectively to ensure that there is no crisis I will be extremely concerned for the industry. I am concerned because we are at the mercy of more effective marketing by our competitors on the world market. That is basically what it is all about. The Australian producer is being saddled with extraordinary costs without any subvention on the part of the taxpayers to produce a commodity to go on to a world market. Entry into the world market by our competitors is on the basis of very high subvention , high subsidy-virtual production by organised government backing to produce huge quantities of high standard meat on the world market. We have to counter that by a sensible approach on the part of Australia.

The six Bills before the House set out to alter the structure of the AMLC to produce what is known as the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council. The question one asks at once is: Will that Policy Council be a yes panel for the Minister and for a bureaucracy? If it is, it is doomed to failure. If it is made to be effective with proper participation from all strata of the industry-from the producers right through to the processors, to those who have the expertise in marketing and particularly in export marketing-it might succeed .

The Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Selection Committee referred to is nothing new. It comes from the history of the unfortunate divisions within the industry. I appeal to the Minister today to ensure that there is a repetition of good common sense within the ranks of the industry in this matter. It is all very well to use that worn and tired word 'consensus', but what is the use of consensus if it means that we are denying real business enterprise the right to do the job that it alone can do effectively? We have seen the mistakes of the past in the business of trying to deal with governments which want to take our product from this country on a bulk basis and the need to bring together the expertise within the production and marketing sector to ensure that those requirements are met and met effectively. This can be done only by a proper, sound business approach. It will be a dead failure if we just see a bureaucracy with ministerial prerogative and people kowtowing to some system within this country that leaves us even further behind in the very highly competitive meat market around the world.

The Minister can well be tongue in cheek on real issues. I hope that what is realised in all of this is that there is no substitute for the hard, tough line in respect of business enterprise. As the honourable member for Darling Downs said, it is not simply a matter for the Government and its supporters, particularly those on the back bench, to say: 'Let us have a little bit of socialisation and that will solve the problem'. That little bit of socialisation could be the real rock on which we perish, as the honourable member for Darling Downs correctly said. Platitudes by the Minister in that matter are totally insufficient to satisfy the whole question of where we go on this important issue.

I regret the time limitation. I do not want to take away the opportunity of some of my colleagues speaking on this important issue. This debate is significant for Australia, our economy and the future employment prospects of many Australians. It is lamentable that it has been curtailed in the way in which it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) in moving his amendment. I put a big circle around the word ' consult' in the amendment. In my opening remarks I would like to point out the lack of consultation by this Hawke socialist Labor Government with the cattle producers of Australia. I mention the Government's intention for the Australian Army to take over huge tracts of pastoral land in New South Wales. I believe that cattle produced in Australia are an endangered species. Not only do they have to put up with what the Army is doing, but also the conservationists are continually going around wanting more national parks and taking up good grazing land. The heritage Act could be invoked on cattle stations without the owner knowing what is happening. The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare has been set up. It is full of animal liberationists who want to make the production of cattle twice as expensive as it is now. God knows what we will end up with. But honourable members can be dead sure it will not be of any benefit to the animal producers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill will be introduced in this chamber tonight. It is a most iniquitous piece of legislation. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is nothing short of a Hitler. He has set up this Bill and, again, there will be no consultation with the cattle producers in Australia. Large tracts of grazing land will be taken up by Aborigines on which are heaps of stones, so-called sacred sites. The owners and producers of livestock throughout Australia will not be consulted. They have not been consulted. The Cattlemen's Union of Australia has come out strongly to opposed the Bill. The National Farmers Federation spent the first half of this week meeting with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is totally opposed to the heritage Bill. Not only is the heritage Bill being introduced, but also the Aboriginal land rights legislation will be extended. The Aborigines want a national land rights Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to mention two matters-one involving local government personal income tax sharing and the other concerning problems of the coal industry in Australia. The first concerns the announcement of the terms of reference and membership of the Committee of Inquiry into Local Government Financing by the Minister for Territories and Local Government, the Hon. Tom Uren, made not in this Parliament, which has initiated the inquiry, but at a public seminar held earlier this month in Canberra. This has left this Parliament no opportunity to debate or to question the process adopted in the Committee appointment by the Minister.
