However, it should be noted that one State has not agreed to the inquiry but will be included within the terms of the Inquiry itself, so there is very little consensus here.

SPEECH.PARA: The appointments to the Committee, except for two, are unknown to me but also relatively unknown to local government. The claim is justly made that the appointees are expected to make up in academic qualification what they lack as a majority in the practical application of local government in Australia. In fact, there is not one elected local government representative on the Committee, no one from the Australian Council of Local Government Associations, no one from the Advisory Council for Intergovernment Relations, and no one from the multitude of country shire councils that could be vitally affected by the results of an inquiry. The opportunity of providing such specialist representation was offered by the Opposition in notice of motion No. 215, which appears in today's Notice Paper. I presented this to the Parliament as far back as 9 November 1983, but this has been completely ignored by the Minister. It has not been called on for discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—One wonders why, and this is the only opportunity we have to question why that has not been presented. I understand also that the most senior member of the Labor Government supported the approach for an inquiry by the ACIR but was rolled. Again, so much for consensus. Item No. 5 of that notice of motion called on the Government to extend the terms of reference of the review to determine local government's proper share of the total Commonwealth tax pool appropriate to the additional programs and responsibilities it has assumed from the Commonwealth since Federation. Again, this opportunity for a meaningful inquiry has been rejected by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: While the terms of the inquiry seek to define the respective roles, functions and responsibilities of each level of government, there is no requirement to ascertain the extent to which those responsibilities have devolved on local government from the Federal Government and then to what extent the total Commonwealth revenue receipts should be directed in favour of local government as a result of this devolution of responsibility for community services. Whilst I agree with the other objects of this inquiry, without the specialist services of the ACIR and the ACLGA and without the fuller inquiry that I have just mentioned, I fear that the result of the inquiry will be some major reduction in the amount of the personal income tax share which is the only untied grant currently available to local government.

There is another matter regarding the personal income tax grant. In the PIT sharing arrangements for the year 1983-84 and specifically the grant made to local government in the State of Victoria, it has been brought to my notice that there was an undue delay-perhaps one could say that it was a deliberate delay by the Treasurer of Victoria-in making that grant available to local government bodies. The Municipal Association of Victoria had sought to reduce any delay in the transfer of these funds from the State Treasury to local goverment by requesting what I consider to be its legal right to have the funds, properly authorised, paid direct to the Municipal Association of Victoria's investment service.

It had been estimated that there would be an opportunity interest advantage to local councils of between $80,000 and $120,000 per day in obviating the delay for the normal processing of cheques from Treasury to individual councils. The Victorian Treasurer, the Hon. R. A. Jolly, replied to the request and I wish to quote from part of his letter of reply to that suggestion. He said:

This proposal has been examined, and there are a number of reasons why, at least in the short term, it cannot be implemented. Firstly, the State has a legal responsibility to pay the grants to particular municipalities. The terms of the Commonwealth legislation are such as to cast doubt on the legality of making payments to municipalities via 'MAVIS'. However, this objection could, perhaps, be overcome by having municipalities collect their own cheques and then deposit them with 'MAVIS'. This procedure would require amendment of the Audit Act and relevant Treasury regulations. Further, as you are aware, the State Government finances the operations of the Victoria Grants Commission (currently running at around $200,000). It is arguable therefore that the Government is entitled to the benefit of some recoupment towards these expenses from any interest which may be earned during the short period involved while the distribution of the grants from the Commonwealth is being organised. This is, of course, done without any undue delay.

To suggest a State entitlement is to suggest a deliberate delay, not an 'undue delay' which is provided for under clause 7 of the legislation. The Victorian State Government in particular, among others has already profited by the Commonwealth's distribution of PIT by drawing back from its own responsibility and it has reduced its own level of funding to local government. It has in this way been paid its $200,000 for the Grants Commission many times over and it is morally and legally wrong for it to further profit in the use of funds, which were never intended to be for the States' to use under the Commonwealth legislation.

If the Minister wants an investigation, if he is fair dinkum in this, let him look closely at this practice, at the States' retreat from their traditional funding responsibilities, and at the additional cost to local government for State and Commonwealth charges and taxes, such as the bank accounts debits tax, fuel excise and other government charges.
The inquiry requires a much wider application than the present terms provide. It requires a genuine intention by the Minister to assist local government, not to hinder it.

On my second subject, coal, I believe that this Government has no real appreciation of the difficulties the industry faces or the detrimental effects of its 'Utah tax' of export levies on industries viability, or of the concern that is being felt about the threat of the application of the resources rental tax. Certainly I applaud the dropping of the coal levy to other companies, but the same consideration should also be given to Utah, and it might be well argued now that the Government is acting unconstitutionally in imposing this charge on an one-company basis.

The posturing of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) about the price recently taken by BHP-Utah shows a lack of appreciation of world market prices. To be realistic, it is South Africa that is artificially setting the low world prices, not Australia. We hear the Government threatening Utah with reprisals. That shows how remote the Government is from market realities-

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—Absolutely shameful. Today there is a surplus of 20 million tonnes of coal on the world market. To an intelligent person, this would indicate a buyer's market. In such a market, all that enables Australia to sell is its reputation as a reliable supplier, the quality of its product and the competition for some of its high-grade coal. Those who support a single marketing authority show an ignorance of all those factors in selling into a market, and of the fact that coal is not just a one-grade product but is of many qualities and blends. How could one authority be sensitive to the demands for the various qualities and what prices they should command, and make decisions that require reporting back? It is a nonsense and cannot be supported from the point of view of rational argument. It receives support from the Labor Party and the unions as a commitment to a philosophy of the socialist Left, who would seek control of the whole industry, and this would allow domination by the New South Wales unions, with a smaller coal production, over a larger producer, Queensland , that suffers this domination through having a smaller work force in a more efficient industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Two weeks ago I led a delegation of the Opposition coalition's Trade and Resources Committee to Queensland-one of the members is present, the honourable member for Wide Bay, the Honourable Clarrie Millar-for a discussion with the coal industry and to inspect developments on the Bowen coal basin. Apart from the problems of marketing and the Commonwealth, there is a growing concern over the pending Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill and the further restrictions that it could impose. The Government has been requested by the Australian Mining Industry Council and primary industry bodies to withdraw the legislation. I, too, urge it to do so.

State charges in all States, where they contain elements of royalties, are too high in relationship to current world prices. In fact, prices of coal are still at the same dollar terms as they were four years ago; real values have considerably decreased.

There needs to be a more realistic approach to the whole coal situation, where inter-State and inter-union rivalries have no place. The competitors are not other Australian mining companies; they are the overseas industries of South Africa, Canada and the United States. The Australian mining industry must stay in the world market. To relinquish its share, as some suggest, would be to give advantage to overseas marketeers and would mean a permanent loss of that share to Australian miners.

If the Australian industry is to survive the present conditions, it requires co -operation from the miners and unions. It requires reduced State opportunity charges that are now being imposed and a complete reassessment by the Commonwealth of its taxing and marketing policies. The industry must receive the encouragement of unions and governments to reduce the unit costs and to provide productivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Education is in crisis in this country-and before the conservatives start their cacophony, let us look at some indisputable facts of history. The Whitlam Government systematically set about building a universal education system which would open up the benefits of education for all . It was the Whitlam Government that initiated a comprehensive rational approach to Commonwealth funding in education. It initiated needs based funding, free tertiary education, the introduction of the tertiary education assistance scheme , a magnificent capital works progam, the Commonwealth Education Commissions, the Curriculum Development Centre, and retrospective cost supplementation of education funding. Those are just a few examples.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Fraser years of Liberal-National Party Government, we saw education slide rapidly backwards. Let us look at the post-secondary sector first. According to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission-and all figures I quote here are in 1982 dollars-in 1975, the last Whitlam education year, $455m was spent on capital works and equipment in post-secondary education. By 1983, under Fraser's draconian economic and social policies, only $165m was spent. In eight years, capital and equipment expenditure was slashed by virtually 64 per cent. It was cut by 64 per cent in a time of the greatest technological advancement that this world has ever seen, and we are paying for that now. We shall keep on paying for that for decades to come. Where are the Australians today who can develop our new technology? Where are the educated Australians to develop our new industries that we need so badly? The failure of the previous Government to respond to education is one of the reasons why hundreds of thousands of Australians are today out of work, and it is also one of the reasons why we are a technological disaster area, and why we are being swamped by an educated, technologically advanced Asia.

According to the latest report of the Commonwealth TEC, aggregate expenditure on education as a proportion of the Commonwealth Budget has decreased from 9 per cent in 1976-77 to 7.4 per cent today. Higher education spending as a proportion dropped from 4.6 per cent to 3.4 per cent. It is no wonder that there are queues hundreds of thousands long to get into our universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education colleges. Our young people and our old people have been denied an education-an education dollar that will pay itself back a hundred-fold in a lifetime. Every dollar that we spend on education builds our future. It builds the quality of our life and it breaks the bonds of poverty.

We often hear in this House the hollow facade of concern expressed by those opposite when it comes to education and equality-and of late, those opposite who cry about the waiting lists for education in their electorates, those who condemn this Government for not raising the rate of the TEAS allowance, et cetera. Every student in Australia knows who kept TEAS and student allowances down so low without increase for year after year. It was not the Hawke Government. We increased student allowances by 9 per cent in our first Budget, and we are committed to bring in a proper income support system for young people -students, unemployed or whoever.

Over the past year, the first year of the Hawke Government, direct outlays on education are expected to increase by 10.7 per cent, but what is more significant is where that money is and where it will be spent in the future. It is a primary obligation of every government in Australia to support the public education sector. There are just no two ways about it. This Government clearly accepts the diversity of education systems in this country and it has a commitment to education funding on the needs basis. The wealthy and the privileged, who are represented in our political system by the Liberal and National parties, believe now that education should be funded by the noise principle, not by the needs principle. That is, if one makes enough phoney noise about rights, freedom and democracy-hollow phrases in their terminology-then one 's privilege will be protected by this noise.

I reiterate that this Government is committed to the needs principle. Those sectors of education that needs resources to build them up to an adequate and respectable level will get it, as they did through the Whitlam years and now today. Those who do not need it, except to subsidise the decline in their real fee levels and to build their extra swimming pools and sporting complexes, will have to wait for once, wait for their turn in history.

It is about time that the lowest resources schools in the non-government sector woke up to themselves. It is about time that they realised that their viability and their future lie squarely with the policies of this Government, not with the rabid fear-mongering conservative parties and their wealthy privileged supporters. It is about time that some people in this sector took off the ideological blinkers that they have worn for decades, accepted what is being done for them and what is necessary for the common good of this country and accepted publicly the fact that they know to be the truth-that a Labor government has protected and will protect the poorest sections of our community, and that a Labor government is committed to an equitable distribution of wealth according to the needs of all Australians.

Education is the key to our economic growth, the key to social development and equity and to our future prosperity. These indicators of a true nation, which is now nearly 200 years old, a nation that is based on the finest democratic ideals , must also be evidenced by the realisation that it is the primary obligation of government to provide a universal education system open to all. Private education systems, despite the window-dressings of scholarships and bursaries, are discriminatory. The very existence of fees is discriminatory. A free, strong and vital public education system must be supported by all Australians as a primary need and a primary obligation of governments.

Without such a strong public system this country will sink deeper into being a serf state of the better education nations all around us. Only public education gives this country a common thread, a thread that holds our very society together as the Commonwealth of Australia. Public education accepts all people as equals regardless of their race, their religion, their social status, their wealth or their health. It is responsive and responsible to the Commonwealth and the common good. No longer must it be chained by a lack of funding and respect.

In the years of Fraser and the Liberal-National Party governments there was a regressive redistribution of education spending by the Commonwealth. This redistribution was designed to do nothing less than condemn public education to mediocrity, and it was only because of the dedication of some concerned State governments, because of the dedication of teachers in government school systems against the morale-sapping budgetary cuts and political abuse, and because of the dedication of so many parents in the public school system, that that system has survived as it has today.

The wealthiest schools under the Liberal-National Party Government received increases in recurrent funding between 1976 and 1982 of $189 to $509 per pupil per annum in real terms-an increase of more than 250 per cent. In the same time, the conservatives, who had the primary responsibility to the public education system, chopped funding to Government schools by 12 per cent. Let me repeat: In real terms, there was an increase of 250 per cent to the wealthiest section and a cut in the government sector by 12 per cent. That government sector represents more than 75 per cent of the Australian population. That is what the previous Government thought of them.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission has recently released two documents. The ' Commonwealth Standards for Australian Schools' attempts to define a community standard of resources for Australian schools. It is the view of many members of this Government Caucus that the community standard definition is quite inadequate. This view is held widely, obviously in the community as well. Let there be no doubt about it. That concern will rise, and I welcome open discussion of that issue.

Let us face it: We are in a crisis in this country in education. We are years and billions of dollars behind countries that many would consider to be educationally inferior to us. The previous Government set out to destroy public education in this country, to the detriment of the majority of Australians that they were meant to represent. We will be continuing to pay the price of that for decades yet to come. Now this Government, in accepting its primary obligation to all Australians, must invest hundreds of millions of dollars extra this year in public education. We need new capital works after years of negative growth. We need more recurrent funding and resources for the public sector. We need to spend on public education now-not next year, but now-if we are to hope to survive in this new world that discounts our mineral resources and puts so much value on our human resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express a grievance which I expressed possibly too forcibly here the other day and it resulted in my expulsion from the Parliament; but I am taking this opportunity to bring it to the attention of the Parliament once more. It is the failure of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to respond to a significant question that I put to him originally without notice in this Parliament and then, of course, at a later date, with notice. On both occasions I have failed to get an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like, first, to state some of the history of the situation. The circumstances with which I am concerned and about which I seek information relate to a question that I first put to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 3 April 1984, in which I asked him, in the interests of national security, whether he had been careless with certain documents and, in fact, as careless as he had been with money that he had reportedly lost in the Boulevard Hotel-some $5,000; I mentioned $4,000 at the time. The Prime Minister got extremely angry, which was rather surprising when one considers that the question was one of national security, but answered, of course, confirming both parts of my question when he said:
The answer is that I was careless on neither occasion.

Having, of course, been impressed by the Prime Minister's anger and realising that it was not to do with a section of national security, I wished to look then further into the matter. On the next day, 4 April 1984, I asked the Prime Minister another question in regard to this matter and pointed out to him that the amounts concerned were $3,600 in Commonwealth bank notes, $1,000 in United States currency and a quantity of travellers cheques-bank and number unknown, and that, of course, is in itself a surprising statement to appear in a police report. Then I asked the Prime Minister whether he was aware that section 5 (1) of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations state:
A person shall not, either on his own behalf or on behalf of another person, buy, borrow-

I was stopped at that time by the Speaker, who thought I was putting too much detail into the question; but I was asking the Prime Minister whether he was aware that in having that $1,000 in American currency in his possession he could have been in breach of banking regulations.
Of course, the Prime Minister quite glibly answered on this occasion:
Mr Speaker, I would think it apparent that if I made a report on this matter to the police, I have nothing to hide.

Of course, that may be the case, and I am not here today to suggest anything or reflect at all on the Prime Minister; but of course, I can say from those two statements that the events that I refer to did occur and apparently $1,000 of American currency was involved.

The Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations forbid the transacting of this sort of currency-not the having of it; the transacting of it-and it is clear to me that the Prime Minister now, with his knowledge, earned after eight years on the Board of the Reserve Bank, would clearly understand that. He has a right, of course, to tell someone. So consequently, I asked in this House of the Treasurer whether Robert J. L. Hawke was a member of the Board, and whether the Reserve Bank, of which he was a member, was the body referred to in the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations, and whether, in fact, Robert Hawke was an agent authorised by the Bank to transact this type of currency. Of course, this is it. When asked about a matter concerning the Government's economic activities or policy, the Treasurer gives us a history lesson about the Fraser Government, which is no help to the Australian people or this Parliament. He gave to me on this occasion some words, and then he said:
The Prime Minister dealt adequately with that issue in his previous answers.
I did not think that to be so, and nor did my colleagues in granting me time to ask the further question.

So I put the full matter on the Notice Paper, giving the Treasurer all the information. Let me remind the House that not one of the questions asked would require great research on the part of his Department. They are all factual. They do not in any way ask him to express an opinion or do anything that he could not do promptly. Although I have a Notice Paper here which shows that it was then on the Notice Paper on 7 May 1984, the Treasurer has not deigned to answer. I should warn him that by not doing so he is creating a set of circumstances which allow the arousal of great speculation in this matter.
While that was going on, Senator Lewis asked certain questions in the Senate of the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. The Attorney-General stated in a letter to Senator Lewis:

If the Member for Wills was in possession of $1,000 of United States currency in Sydney on or about 21 February 1982, that would not have been a contravention of the Banking (Foreign Exchange) Regulations.

No, to have it is not a breach; but the section of the Act to which I have just alluded refers to every possible means by which one can acquire that amount of money, and forbids it-unless a person is an authorised agent or has obtained it from an authorised agent. Whether the Prime Minister obtained it from an authorised agent or was at that time an authorised agent are questions that the Treasurer can answer for us quite simply. Why does he not come in and tell us about this? Why does he leave it in abeyance. It relates to a law of Australia and the person concerned is the Prime Minister of Australia, and I am referring to a period in February 1982 when he was also a member of a parliament and a shadow Minister of the then Opposition.

It is not good enough that this particular matter is left in the way it is. It is not good enough that the Treasurer avoids answering. It is not good enough that the Prime Minister does not want to know about it, particularly when he showed so much sensitivity to the matter. Let us look at a few of the facts there to support my argument. The reported amount of money that was lost that night is $5,600. That is about 16 per cent of a backbencher's salary at that time. It is a large amount of money to have in a briefcase and to leave in a room. More importantly, it is rumoured that the hotel, quite contrary to its obligations under the law of New South Wales or any other State-which, of course , indemnifies hoteliers against claims in relation to any property lost by guests in their rooms-has apparently refunded this money. But more importantly, when we inquire of the New South Wales Police to seek some information on the matter, to see that Federal laws are not being breached in regard to this currency, we find that not even the officers of that department are entitled to talk to each other about the matter. How in the heck they will ever solve that crime if they are not entitled to talk about it within the department I would like to know. Clearly, there is a lot more in this issue than meets the eye-not only the currency, but maybe where it all came from, and maybe where it was all going. But if the police cannot find the criminal, is it because the Prime Minister, for instance, does not want that person to be found. But more importantly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the honourable gentleman's attention to standing order 76, under which he should not impugn improper motives to any member of this House.

—All right, Madam Deputy Speaker, I will not do that. I am just interested in getting answers to my questions. But when I read the report of the theft, I find that a duplicate key or possibly a master key was used to gain entry to the particular room. That may have been done, but we find also that no other room in the whole of the Boulevard Hotel was robbed that night. If I were a thief with a master key, I would try more rooms than only one. The question must be asked as to whether the person who entered the room knew a lot more about the circumstances and the situation. As I say, the hotel has now lost the money, and that could create a circumstance in which if any information is being withheld from the police, it means that the hotel has no chance of recovering this money or at least seeing that the offender is punished.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about this matter. Because he is the Prime Minister-lesser persons can possibly avoid having to answer on such issues-the Prime Minister should be answering me on this matter. So should the Treasurer, because the questions before the Treasurer at the moment do not call on him to impugn anybody but to answer matters of fact. It might be that the Treasurer might then have to consider his responsibilities in this issue, because he has had drawn to his attention what appears to be, prima facie, a situation relating to improper dealing in foreign exchange and foreign currency within Australia. As I say, that is forbidden by the section of the Act I have mentioned. Incidentally, the penalties for offences under it can be as high as a $100,000 fine or five years in prison, although I doubt whether such penalties would result from a charge involving $1,000.

Some answers are needed and I am anxious that those answers be provided. I am, therefore, severely aggrieved that the Treasurer has ignored my questions. I can only presume sinister motives, because it is not a difficult question that I have asked of him. When that is answered maybe the Prime Minister will answer some of the other questions that arise from this situation. It is quite clear to me that there is a lot more to this matter than meets the eye, and that was supported by the Prime Minister's original reaction. We know of other events occurring around about that time, and we just have to wonder whether the Prime Minister has some answers that he would not like to give to this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my very strong opposition to the proposed relocation of the Bendigo Army Survey Regiment unit to Bonegilla, which is proposed to take effect from 1992. For the past 15 years successive Federal governments, both Liberal and Labor, have advocated such a relocation to Bonegilla. Following the establishment of the Royal Australian Survey Review Committee in 1967, that Committee recommended one year later the formation of an Army mapping and charting centre which involved relocation of the Bendigo unit to Bonegilla. That recommendation was endorsed at that time by the then Liberal Government, and it met considerable opposition, of course, from the Bendigo community. Indeed, early in 1970, the then Minister for Defence, now the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, in reply to questions in the Parliament from the Federal member for Bendigo at that time, Mr Kennedy, and representations from the Bendigo City Council, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I am satisfied with the decision, and must confirm that the present plans to re-locate are entirely justified on administrative, technical and operational grounds . . . In the light of all the evidence, I am unable to put aside the recommendations of the Review Committee that Bonegilla is preferable as the site for the Survey Regiment.

Later in 1970, the Army Works Committee and the Chief of the General Staff approved facilities for the co-location of the Army Survey Regiment, the map depot and the School of Military Survey, all at Bonegilla. Following further strong local and political pressure in the early 1970s, which was aimed at retaining the centre in Bendigo, the Defence Facilities Location Committee reconsidered the question of relocation in 1973. But it also recommended that that transfer go ahead. Finally, in June 1982, a facilities brief prepared by the Army confirmed the relocation decision and listed detailed justification in support of the relocation to Bonegilla. Late last year, the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) confirmed that it was still the intention of the Department of Defence to proceed with that relocation of the unit from 1992.

On the basis of that advice the community of Bendigo, earlier this year, prepared a comprehensive submission to the Minister for Defence seeking the retention of the Survey Regiment unit in Bendigo. I must take this opportunity to make it quite clear that the Bendigo community is totally and unequivocally opposed to the relocation proposal. Not only would the transfer of the unit have a devastating effect on the Bendigo local economy; there are also very sound arguments to suggest that the redevelopment and upgrading of the existing Bendigo facility would be far less costly to the Government than the relocation option and would at the same time offer strategic locational advantages in terms of Australia's overall defence capability.

I turn now to examine each of these arguments in closer detail. Firstly, in an economic sense, the presence of the Army Survey Regiment in Bendigo represents a major component of the local economy. The annual wages and salaries paid to 239 members of the unit and the 32 civilians at 'Fortuna' total approximately $11m. This amount is estimated to represent about one per cent of the total annual wages and salaries bill generated by the Bendigo economy. Expenditure of this order within the local economy has a considerable multiplying effect upon the direct and indirect demand for goods and services, which is estimated to be in total about $23m. As would be expected, the loss of the annual wages and salaries bill of the unit would have a significant contracting effect on the local economy.

A comparison with Melbourne assists to indicate the potential impact of the loss of 271 full-time positions on Bendigo's economy. For Bendigo to suffer the loss of this number of persons from its work force is equivalent to Melbourne losing a business employing approximately 12,500 persons. The resulting impact on Melbourne's economy would be regarded as an economic catastrophe. I strongly contend that no government would countenance such a deliberate loss of jobs in the Melbourne economy, yet such a devastation is proposed for the Bendigo economy.

The second point I wish to raise concerns the redevelopment potential of the existing 'Fortuna' site in Bendigo. The facilities brief which was prepared in June 1982 dismissed the redevelopment of 'Fortuna' as a viable option. It contended that 'Fortuna' was unsuitable without complete and expensive modification, which required National Trust permission. It must be emphasised that this statement is inaccurate in that the National Trust has no legal powers whereby its permission in relation to this building must be obtained. The National Trust has classified the building, but the Army could propose to modify or alter the building to suit its needs.

However, it must be said that in view of the availability of additional land adjacent to the Regiment and the historic importance of the building, the use of adjoining land for expansion of the facilities is considered the most suitable option. An area of Crown land of 1.6 hectares which adjoins the south-east corner of the 'Fortuna' property is already available for the expansion of the Army Survey Unit. The land has road frontage to Barnard Street which provides the existing access to the Regiment. The State Department of Crown Lands and Survey has advised that in the event that the land is required for Army purposes the Commonwealth could exercise its powers of acquisition to obtain the site. I should add that an additional area of land of almost 3 hectares can also be made available to the Government for further expansion of Army facilities if required . It is quite clear in my view that, contrary to the views of senior Defence personnel, considerable and significant scope exists to upgrade the existing ' Fortuna' site in Bendigo.

The third point I bring to the attention of the Parliament concerns the economic viability of the proposed relocation. It is clear that in any context the maintenance of the value of assets held by a government obviously involves their continued use by a suitable organisation. In the case of the 'Fortuna' Regiment, the cost of redeveloping would be less expensive than the development proposed for Bonegilla. The attractiveness of the proposition to redevelop ' Fortuna' is further strengthened when one considers the benefit of using the Government's funds wisely. To ignore the monetary loss associated with quitting a facility is quite unrealistic, even though the facility may be costly to maintain. If the value of the buildings in use is compared to their realisable value and the resultant loss is equated to annual maintenance costs, it can be seen that there would be a cost benefit to the Government in continuing to maintain this facility. Extending this view by having regard to the common concept of opportunity cost of the relocation proposal further favours the redevelopment on the existing site.

The final point I wish to raise concerns the effect of the proposed relocation to Bonegilla on defence manpower and personnel requirements. In considering any proposal to relocate a Commonwealth establishment, the likely loss of experienced and key personnel must be taken into account. In the case of the Army Survey Unit there is absolutely no doubt that a number of staff would choose to resign their position in preference to leaving Bendigo. In this respect, it should be noted that 183 members of the unit are married and living in Bendigo. Many have established homes, with children well settled into schools , and they have associations with clubs and organisations. It is well recognised that in the past the shift of Commonwealth operations has had the effect of causing the loss of key and experienced personnel. A recent example was the relocation of the Australian Antarctic Division in early 1981 from Melbourne to Hobart. On that occasion about 90 persons were proposed to be shifted. However, 50 per cent chose not to make the move and subsequently resigned. In the case of the Army Survey Regiment unit, it is quite clear that personnel loss would be significant and that consequent delays to the Government's mapping program would be considerable.

In conclusion, there is an abundance of sound evidence which suggests that the Defence proposal to relocate the Army Survey Regiment unit to Bonegilla is unsound. Apart from the devastating effects that such a relocation would have on the Bendigo regional economy, it is demonstrably clear that the cost to the Australian taxpayer of the proposed relocation exceeds the cost of redeveloping and upgrading the 'Fortuna' site. It is equally clear that defence, strategic and personnel considerations are far better served by retention of the unit in Bendigo rather than relocation to Bonegilla. Whilst the proposed relocation is some years away, it is time-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today, I am sure, is shared by the greater majority of this nation's people. It is a very real concern over the Hawke Government's persistent, continued and unrelenting determination to undermine Australia's defences. As usual, whenever a Labor government moves against the defence forces, it is the reserves that bear much of the brunt, especially the Army Reserve. This Government started to emasculate the Army Reserve in the last Budget and has continued its destruction since then. Before the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) discounts this claim as an exaggeration of mine, let me tell this House that this feeling is shared not only by members of the Reserve but also by the Citizen Military Forces Association and senior regular Army officers. Concern is so great among members of the Victorian branch of the CMF Association that its President, Brigadier Ian Lowen, on 21 May this year, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) expressing the Association's concern. In that letter he told the Prime Minister that members of the CMF Association were ' increasingly concerned about current trends in the Army Reserve'.

SPEECH.PARA: Men of the standing of Brigadier Lowen do not easily write to Prime Ministers with complaints about their policies. In fact, the Brigadier wrote on behalf of his organisation to the Government twice in September, then in February and again in May twice. What grievances do these men and women of the Reserve have? These men, many of whom have devoted many years service, are distressed to see the Army Reserve disintegrating because of this Government's actions. Let us look at some salient figures. In the first four months of this year Army Reserve officer resignations and transfers to the inactive list were up 70 per cent on those for the same periods in 1981, 1982 and 1983. What is even more disturbing is that the majority of the reservists leaving are in the middle ranks, that is, senior non-commissioned officers and officers with skills in medicine, other professions and in technical trades. It is the high achievers who are being driven out of the reserves. It has taken many years to train these key men and their leaving will have a cumulative effect on the regular services also.

There are several reasons for this exodus, all of which have been caused by this Government's changes in policy towards the Reserve. The erratic policy of taxing reservists' pay, later to be changed by the besieged Defence Minister to partial taxing, has been a major blow to reservists. As the official journal of the CMF Association, 'The Citizen Soldier', writes:

The Government expects the CMF to continue to work unchanged out of a spirit of patriotism-Mr Hawke said so. Mr Hawke and his Cabinet haven't taken a half cut in salary-do they lack patriotism for this country of ours?

Taking the kindest view the Government took its steps without realisation of their effect. It certainly took steps without even seeking, let alone obtaining military advice. Indeed here is a Labor Government which professes its intent to communicate disregarding any form of consultation, even with the Government's own committee for that purpose-the Army Reserve Advisory Committee.

That is what the CMF Association's journal thinks of the Government. It is now a matter of record that the Government announced the taxation measures without any mechanism in mind. The consequences of this decision have been horrific for many reservists. For instance, the ordinary working man serving in the Reserve has been caught up in the payment of provisional tax for the first time. The members of university regiments were also hard hit by this decision. Let me quote the words of Mrs J. Millett, from Belmont, which adjoins the electorate of the Minister for Defence. In a letter to the Melbourne Herald of 24 October last year Mrs Millett told us that because her son, a member of the Deakin University Unit, now had to pay tax he will no longer be eligible for the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance for students. Mrs Millett also did some quick calculations regarding her husband's situation, who is and has been a member of the Reserve for the last 35 years. Her calculations show that for the privilege of being a member of the Army Reserve Mrs Millett will be paying out $ 1.46 per week. Mrs Millett concludes:
The Government should have had the fortitude to disband the Army Reserve in the first place if this is the ultimate intention, instead of resorting to this type of subterfuge.

Mrs Millett's concern is widely shared. Some 3,000 submissions have been made to the Coldham Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay, which is currently reviewing Reserve pay. The overwhelming majority of these have vigorously opposed the removal of tax exempt status for Reserve pay. This Government may be able to fool the public for some time but it will be caught out. On this occasion the Minister and the Hawke Government have been caught out in their determination to destroy the Army Reserve.

It was this Government that announced last year cuts in the number of annual training days for reservists from 38.25 days to 36 days. In reality senior officers report that training days have actually been cut to as few as 30 days and, for some units, even fewer. If the Defence Minister takes off his tin hat and listens to his Army Reserve advisers, he will learn that for a soldier to have the bare minimum of efficiency he needs at least 26 days of training. In fact, senior Reserve officers regard the desirable levels of training for field forces as 43.3 days, for logistics command 45 days and for training command 52 days. But what is happening? All around Australia recruit courses have been cancelled with two recruit courses cancelled in Victoria so far this year. The reason? Lack of man days and insufficient recruits. The military skills competition for the Third Military District, scheduled for November last year, was cancelled, again through lack of man days. The 2nd Battalion, Royal Victoria Regiment has not had a full parade since late 1983. The reason? Lack of man days .

But this Government continues its subterfuge even further. In August, the Minister for Defence said that the Reserve would be maintained at 30,000. A positive statement? No, a statement of deceit. The Army Reserve posted strength at that time was 33,523. The Minister was actually announcing a cut in Army reserves. The reserves have been ordered to reduce their numbers by 30 June this year. This is already under way with many units now being forced to discharge efficient soldiers. At a time when tension in the world is high and obviously set to heighten this Government cuts back on Australia's defences. In reality the reserves will be cut back to an effective force of around 24,000 to 25,000 or even less, as the 30,000 target announced by the Minister must also include reservists with less than the 26 days efficiency requirement. The field forces will be hardest hit. In my State of Victoria the Army Reserve field force will be reduced by 1,200. This is a ludicrous situation. At the very least, administrative procedures should be simplified so that Reserve units can expeditiously discharge inefficient soldiers and replace them on posted strength with efficient soldiers as soon as possible.

Is it any wonder that morale is rock bottom and resignations are ever increasing? I know that the men and women of the Army Reserve are dedicated but there is just so much kicking from this Government that they can take, and kicks they have got. Yet another kick came in February 1984, a few months ago when the Reserve Branch in the Army office was abolished. This step was taken in spite of contrary recommendations from the Millar Committee of Inquiry into the Citizen Military Forces to establish the Reserve Branch. Let us not forget that the Millar inquiry was set up by a Labor government. The time has come for this Government to come clean. It must cease hiding behind deceit, subterfuge and false statements of support for the Army Reserve. This Government should announce in the coming Budget that it intends to abolish the Reserve. It should admit its true aims and then take the consequences from the Australian public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is about betrayal. Betrayal of public responsibility, civic duties, public interests and betrayal in a few more areas. Some would question my right or capacity to speak on the local government situation in Newcastle in the last 15 months and the Newcastle Herald. Firstly, my qualifications to speak come from my nine years as a member of the Newcastle City Council. Secondly, in the current financial year the Newcastle City Council will spend between $4m to $7m of Federal taxpayers' money and that is, of course, of very serious concern to me. Thirdly, the Federal Government will be providing $3m to Newcastle for its foreshore development. Fourthly, I am one of the longest serving people of those who I feel have been affected.

SPEECH.PARA: The betrayal relates to events in Newcastle since May of last year but to understand them one has to go back to 1974 when the Newcastle City Council, of which I was then a member, elected the first ever woman Lord Mayor in Australia. In my lifetime I have worked with many different people of varying skills and qualities but I have yet to meet a person of the capacity and the talent of that Lord Mayor, Alderman Joy Cummings. Alderman Cummings has been Lord Mayor for eight of the last nine years. She had majority support within the council for only three of those eight years, yet for the remaining five years she was capable of making the council productive, effective and responsive. The working relationship that was established between herself and other aldermen from various political interests was excellent and one based on trust and mutual respect. It was very productive. Newcastle in the last 10 years has gone through a renaissance, one that is very visible.

The events of last year started with the leaking to the Deputy Lord Mayor of information regarding the Lord Mayor's secretary's promotion. Information on the personal files of council staff regarding regrading procedures is strictly confidential. The lady in question had more than 40 years of service. Her personal matters, affairs and applications were trotted out for the world to see in a light that she did not deserve. The betrayal was clearly by a fellow council officer or fellow council staff member because the information was not available outside the council officer level. That is the first level of betrayal . It was obviously aimed at the political events of September last year and the local government election.

In May of last year the Town Clerk of Newcastle, it was subsequently discovered , supplied to the alternative Lord Mayor to Alderman Cummings, Alderman Don Geddes, computer tapes of the council electoral system. I had a conference with the Town Clerk and Lord Mayor in July of last year and suggested that Alderman Geddes had access to the council's computer systems, a suggestion the Town Clerk strenuously denied. We discussed the matter for at least half an hour. Early this year the Town Clerk indicated publicly that he had supplied computer tape. The second part of the betrayal is a personal betrayal of me, because I believed what I was told at that conference in July.

The third part of the betrayal relates to the stroke suffered by the Lord Mayor on 13 April this year. She and her family have suffered a tragic loss and tragic pain. Newcastle has also suffered enormously because the respect in which she was held was very far reaching and profound. Following her unfortunate attack, no attempt was made by the Town Clerk or the Acting Lord Mayor in any way to reconcile or advise either her or her husband as to her allowances, whether she was covered by workers compensation or other such matters. Mail marked private and confidential, which had been opened by persons unknown was forwarded to her from the council. That betrayal is one, I think, of a very profound nature. The fact that the Town Clerk and the Acting Lord Mayor of the day failed, in any way , to initiate or formalise the position that the Lord Mayor was in at the time, left the Lord Mayor's husband no choice but to approach the council formally to clarify the position. That formal approach was also required in view of the hospital situation. If she was in fact covered by workers compensation, Alderman Cummings failure to notify would be seen as a breach of responsibility.

During the last fifteen months in Newcastle there has been a series-I indicated that it started with the Lord Mayor's secretary-of information being made available to people who had no official right to it. Information was supplied on computer tapes to people who had no right to it. Furthermore, the people supplying it, clearly had no statutory authority to supply it. That to my mind is very clear. It means they had no legal right to provide information, therefore the information was illegally obtained and illegally used. That, to my mind, is nothing less than a criminal conspiracy.

There have also been some other interesting leaks or betrayals of confidence in that time. Shortland County Council reports have suddenly appeared in very large detail in the pages of the Newcastle Herald. A report of a local government inspector was, in fact, available to reporters from the Newcastle Herald prior to being circulated to the aldermen of the council in general. It has become clear that the Town Clerk in recent days has discussed with reporters from the Newcastle Herald a letter that was received. He is quoted in the Press as saying that it explained why the Lord Mayor's allowance had not been paid at the normal time. In fact, the correspondence he received was from the Lord Mayor's solicitor; it was personal correspondence to establish her rights and relationship with council. It seems to me that for a very long time people in senior positions in the Newcastle City Council have been having discussions with people who had no right to access to the information being provided.

That betrayal is one of public responsibility. All through this whole grubby exercise has been an enormous willingness by a self-styled senior reporter from the Newcastle Herald to attempt to make these issues important. Newcastle has serious problems of unemployment, in the steel industry and in the whole economy . The matters that the Newcastle Herald seems to devote itself to consistently, and in a major way, are essentially personal and trivial. They will not affect the problems that those in Newcastle are suffering. In fact, it is interesting to conjecture the source of the information. To my mind, the reporting indicates that source. It is very hard to believe that journalists with such excellent access to confidential information do not pay the price that that information fetches. I have no doubt that if they reported accurately and fairly, the sources would disappear; the information would no longer be available.

The Newcastle Herald was once a great paper of Australia but in recent years its decline in circulation, standards and public support has become most noticeable. Whether it sees this new campaign of salaciousness, poor taste, degrading and grubby journalism as being a way to recover its circulation, I do not know. But I can assure that newspaper that, after 10 years in public office I know the people of Newcastle and I know they do not support what is going on. I suggest that the people of Newcastle themselves have been betrayed by their own newspaper. Newcastle is a great city with great people. Not only do they deserve better but also I think they will indicate in the best way they can that they demand better. My grievance is not about a single betrayal but a series that have been going on for some time. The 10 minutes I have in which to speak is very brief, and I will bring some of these matters back for the House's attention in the weeks ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance concerns the editorial in the publication News Weekly on 2 May 1984. The headline in that editorial states: ' Why Liberalism is going down the drain', and the charge at the conclusion of the editorial states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the penetration of Liberal policy on so-called 'women's issues' by Mr Macphee and Mrs Sibree are generally and rightly understood to be selling the family down the river.

Now that charge is untrue and preposterous and anyone who knows much about me knows how much my family means to me. Indeed, I cannot imagine more family oriented persons than my wife and myself. But it is not the personal hurt that that charge occasions which causes me to speak today; it is the damage to my reputation. I will therefore speak without prejudice to my right to sue the publication for defamation. As I understand it, that publication is of the National Civic Council so, presumably, the views expressed are those of the National Civic Council. The editorial states the obvious in very plain print that it represents the official policy of News Weekly. I understand its founder and leader, the National Civic Council leader, is Mr Santamaria and presumably it represents his policy as well.

This is not the first time that the publication has carried material expressing hostility to me. Sometimes it has been as hostile to my wife. On each occasion the vitriol has been either totally unsubstantiated or has been based on distortions, fabrications or combinations of both. In the past I have ignored them on the basis that the publication was insignificant and the allegations were so absurd that no one would give them credence. In the past year, however, I have received evidence of a persistent and pernicious campaign of character assassination upon my wife and me by members of the National Civic Council. Being a Democrat I have tolerated the campaign and have been reluctant to sue the persons concerned for defamation. I put them on notice today, however, that I will not tolerate that vicious campaign of lies any longer. The National Civic Council apparently works on the basis that if it tells a lie often enough people will believe it. Such tactics are tactics of totalitarians and cowards, not Democrats or Liberals.

The News Weekly editorial of 2 May provides no substance at all for the charge that either I or Mrs Sibree, whom it mentions too, are 'Selling the family down the river'. If it is true, as News Weekly claims, that this is generally understood to be so then, of course, I will presumably be defeated at the next election and all of its worries will be over. But if it is even believed by anyone it is because people believe what they read in News Weekly or in the Toorak Times which sometimes publishes equally unsubstantiated attacks on me by National Civic Council members and identities. There is no other basis for believing what the article asserts is believed. The fact that my personal vote continues to rise even when the Liberal Party has swings against it ought to cause them to consider whether it is widely believed.

There is nothing in my words or in my conduct which could possibly justify such a conclusion. Moreover, News Weekly says that not only is this generally understood but also it is rightly understood. Yet nowhere does it provide evidence for this astounding proposition. The real criticism is 'the penetration of Liberal policy on so called women's issues by Mr Macphee and Mrs Sibree'. So it is really a criticism of Liberal policy. I do not doubt that the National Civic Council might find aspects of Liberal policy incompatible with National Civic Council policy. Where it does it is the NCC's democratic right to say so, but the NCC is not the Liberal Party and has no basis for asserting that liberalism is going down the drain. Because Mrs Sibree and myself have the official responsibilities of propounding some areas of Liberal Party policy with which the NCC disagrees, it has decided to set out systematically to destroy our reputations. Let me briefly remind the House of official statements of both liberalism and Liberal policy which precede my involvement in major policy formation and presentation. I quote first from a book called Liberal Thinking by Mr Chris Puplick and Sir Robert Southey, published by the Macmillan Co. of Australia Pty Ltd in 1980 and promoted by the Liberal Party of Australia. On page 52 the authors state:

The family has always been a critical factor in the philosophy of liberalism for a number of reasons. It is the private sphere within which the individual may live most of his life. It is the principal sphere within which the individual's needs for close and supporting relationships are met. It is the primary institution through which the individual learns values and gains an understanding about the world. It is primarily within the family that the individual develops his conception of himself, of his worth, his capabilities and his values.

I subscribe completely to that philosophy. Nothing that I have ever said or done could be regarded as being inconsistent with it. Let me also remind the House of the policy commitment of the Liberal Party and what was then known as the Country Party in the election campaign in 1974, at which election I was elected. I had nothing to do with the writing of the policies. The document called 'The Way Ahead' at page 51 quotes at length the approach of those two parties to the question of lifting the status of women to one of equality with men and removing all the areas of discrimination suffered by women. I read that at length in the debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill which I do not doubt is one of the areas in which the National Civic Council regards me as having offended. It is recorded at page 340 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 1 March and I will not quote it again. It represents a very succinct statement of principles of liberalism to which I fully subscribe and every statement and action of mine is completely consistent with that statement, now a decade old. It represents a positive and practical approach to all families and the Liberal Party would be failing those families if it did not address their needs.

I challenge the editor of News Weekly to produce evidence to justify his assertions that firstly, I am generally understood to be selling the family down the river; and, secondly, I am rightly understood to be doing so. If the evidence is not produced in the next issue of News Weekly in answer to each of those questions or unless an appropriate apology is made, an apology acceptable to me and given the same prominence as the editorial, I will place the matter in the hands of my solicitors. I also warn, as I did a moment ago, that infamous publication, the Toorak Times, to which I have had to reply in this House before , that if I am defamed again by it I will adopt the same strategy as that adopted by Mr Costigan, the Royal Commissioner, and sue the distributors of the Toorak Times. The House is aware that the need to go to that elaborate and expensive procedure is because the publisher, and most of the regular journalists of that infamous publication, are bankrupt. Therefore, they are not in a position to pay any damages that one might recover. But the distributors of that publication are in such a position. I want them to be in no doubt whatever that whether they be milk bars, butcher shops, newsagencies, supermarkets or whatever, I will do, on the next defamation of me, exactly what Mr Costigan has done. I hope that the editor of News Weekly will either apologise appropriately or produce the evidence, or that publication will also be called to account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is for the people of the Island of Sri Lanka. I grieve especially for the Tamil community but, indeed, I grieve for all the people of the beautiful island for violence inflicts its wounds on those who are the targets of violence as well as those who perpetrate it. There has been a long history of communal violence in Sri Lanka. The number of lives lost or the scale of destruction of property have not held the attention of the media in this country for very long. Part of the reason for this lack of interest is the way in which the outbreaks are covered. They have been reported, whenever this was possible, using local news sources, tourist accounts and the censored writings of a handful of foreign correspondents. These reports have not been distinguished by detailed investigation of causes, confirmation of the facts by independent inquiry or any of the other qualities that Western journalism has aspired to in recent decades.

SPEECH.PARA: Sri Lanka has experienced many episodes of blood baths. There was a blood bath in 1958, 1965, 1971, 1977 and 1981. In July 1983 the Tamils in Sri Lanka were victims of the worst violence ever seen in the history of that country. In just over one week hundreds of Tamils were killed and tens of thousands made homeless . Homes and business establishments belonging to Tamils were burnt to the ground . Tamil political prisoners in maximum security gaols were massacred, innocent Tamil civilians-men, women and children alike-were indiscriminately killed by racist hooligans including Sinhala police and Army personnel. Today the same Government which stood by when Sinhalese mobs took knives and torches to their Tamil neighbours is once again not only allowing passions to rise but also allowing Tamils to be murdered.

As a student of international law I recognise the domestic jurisdiction principle. Article 2, paragraph 7 of the United Nations charter I support, but no country, I suggest, can stand by and say nothing while genocide is carried out against a minority in a country. The question of the so-called terrorist is often raised. I refer here to the so-called Tamil tigers. I condemn violence wherever it occurs but let us get this matter into perspective. The tigers are a group of only a couple of hundred young people. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that if you had seen members of your own family raped and murdered and your homes burned you too would probably become a freedom fighter. Of course, the Sri Lankan Government regards every young Tamil as a terrorist. It arrests them just on suspicion and many have died mysteriously in detention. If the Tamils engage in some form of civil disobedience the Army goes beserk, entering Tamil areas, shooting into houses, burning houses and, in general, acting as an undisciplined mob.

There have been many outrages against human rights in Sri Lanka and, unfortunately, time does not permit me to go into the many documented details I have in my possession but I draw this House's attention to one episode that happened last year when 53 political detainees were massacred in prison. It hardly rated a mention in our local media. On 26 July, the day after the killings, the Government stated that several hundred prisoners in the gaol, including reconvicted criminals, defying orders from prison officers broke into the wards of detainees under the terrorism law, including those convicted, and attacked them. In the clash that ensued, 35 detainees and prisoners died. It said that an inquiry would be held into the deaths. An inquiry was held on 26 July returning verdicts of homicide in all cases and directing the officer-in- charge to conduct further investigation. That outcome is unknown. But despite this official investigation, the very next day on 27 July, Tamil detainees were subject to a second attack and a further 18 were killed. Mr Speaker, I ask you, how could prisoners in a maximum security gaol, break into another part of the gaol, armed with knives and other such things and cause the death of 53 innocent people? It really takes some believing that this could happen.

Time does not permit me to go into all the details but I am particularly concerned at what is happening in the Jaffna area in the north of Sri Lanka where more communal violence is going on. At this stage, I commend the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) for his sympathetic response on behalf of the Hawke Labor Government to the plight of the detainees and the refugees caused by this communal violence last year. I personally saw the Minister, as I know other members did. We received a very sympathetic hearing and, of course, Australia took many of the refugees from this communal violence.

I believe, as I said before, that despite Article 2, paragraph 7 of the United Nations charter, Australia has a role in regard to what is going on in Sri Lanka . We cannot stand idly by and see genocide being committed in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with Standing Order 106 as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to the Prime Minister's statement that the principle of the assets test legislation remains and ask: Why does the Government persist with piecemeal approaches to retirement incomes such as would be involved in the introduction of the assets test when a large number of community groups, including even the Australian Council of Trade Unions, are calling for a coherent, non- discriminatory approach to the treatment of retirement incomes?

—First of all let me say that the Government has a comprehensive program in relation to retirement incomes; we are not thinking simply of the assets test. Legislation is already before this House relating to superannuation payments, which is another part of--
—That is another slug, an absolute slug.

—The question that was asked was whether the Government had a comprehensive policy. I am simply trying to answer that question for the Leader of the Opposition. We have considerations in relation to annuities as well as the assets test. So there is a range of proposals here. The answer to the honourable member's question is that there is a comprehensive policy. As I pointed out to the House quite clearly yesterday, in any comprehensive strategy to redirect resources to those in need an assets test is a key element of that strategy.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of a Press statement released by the honourable member for Barker on 27 May alleging that the Federal Government had drastically reduced funding for the national trachoma eye health program? Has the Government reduced funding for this vital and important program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Brisbane for that question. Happily , I have a copy of the Press release referred to. It is basically a tirade about government spending on the national trachoma eye health program. I do not think we need to worry about the tirade from the honourable member for Barker but the tirade is based on three statements. Each of those statements which he has made is wrong. Let me just take the three of them. First of all, he makes this astounding statement:

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Government has been condemned for reducing funding for the National Trachoma Eye Health Program for the second successive year . . .

I know that Opposition members may think that this Government has been in office for a long time but, as yet, there has been only one financial year for this Government. So the notion that somehow we are reducing funding in a second successive year when we have had only one Budget is the first error. Secondly, the honourable member for Barker says, to praise the previous Government, that the coalition provided $1.8m in the 1982-83 financial year for this program. First of all, he has the figure wrong. It was $1.08m, a difference of $720,000 or nearly 70 per cent. The second thing he has got wrong, which he never owns up to, is that that was purely an estimate. It was not what the Liberal Government spent in its last 12 months. What the Liberal Government managed to spend was $ 531,200. That is the second statement that is wrong. The third and only other statement in this document is that we have allocated only $353,000 for this program.

The honourable member for Barker was told, as an act of courtesy by my office on 30 April this year, that the estimate was $700,000. We had already spent $539 ,000 by 30 April. This Government has already spent more in one year than the Liberals have spent. We will get very close to spending the whole $700,000. Let me suggest to members of the media that, whenever they get a Press statement from the honourable member for Barker, they should divide by half any claim he makes about the former Liberal Government and double any minimisation he makes of the Labor Government's programs.

Having dealt with this complete and total fabrication let me say that I would not want to pretend that all is well with the national trachoma eye health program. First of all, as I think the honourable member for Mackellar would realise, we inherited a bureaucratic nightmare in this scheme. It was in fact an institutionalised form of conflict that the previous Government had designed. Even at the time we came to office the scheme had already broken down in Western Australia. Since that date the Royal College of Opthalmologists has withdrawn from the scheme. I am not pretending that it is working satisfactorily. But what the Government has done is appoint a task force. I have had that task force report for about four or five weeks. In the next financial year we will follow the major proposals of that task force to ensure a scheme which is both cost efficient and responsive to Aboriginal aspirations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his statement in his 1983-84 Budget Speech which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: There is evidence of extensive and increasing avoidance of the pension income test by people who do not need the pension.
One reason for this was the removal of the assets test in 1976.

I also refer in contrast to the statement made on page 35 of the Gruen Assets Test Review Panel report that, in the course of its deliberations, the Panel had not uncovered hard evidence of the extent or magnitude of avoidance although some particular cases have been drawn to its attention, as has the increased availability of investment advice. I ask the Treasurer: Did he or his Department provide the Gruen inquiry with the evidence that would justify the statement in his Budget Speech? If so, will he now concede that the Gruen inquiry statement implies that the Treasurer misled the House in his Budget Speech? If the information referred to was not provided by the Treasurer to the Gruen inquiry, why not? Will the Treasurer now make it available to the House so that its validity can be checked?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is drawing a very long bow to suggest that there is a difference of opinion on the question of whether I have misled the Parliament or attempted to mislead the Parliament on a matter like this. I am not certain, without inquiring, what information was tendered to the Gruen inquiry by the Department of the Treasury. I can find out. If the honourable gentleman wants to know I will let him know.
—You can see the contrast in the statements made by you and the inquiry.
—You have been into the dye pot again, Andrew.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Minister should be asked to withdraw. That is a disgraceful and unnecessary statement. He has got the Prime Minister getting under the drier--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—It was only with the advantage of this proximity that it became apparent to me. I suppose that the honourable gentleman's hair, like his intellect, will recede into darkness.

—Can the Minister for Aviation assure the House that reported deficiencies in equipment and staffing within the Bureau of Meteorology will not lead to any reduction in the high level of aviation safety in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I assure him that the people of Australia can continue to have confidence in the safety of the Australian aviation system which has one of the finest records in the world. I listened with very considerable interest to the remarks in the House yesterday of my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology on the relationship between aviation safety and meteorological forecasting and I think it would be helpful if I were to provide some supplementary information on these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: The International Civil Aviation Organisation has established standards to be met by meteorological forecasts for civil aviation. By agreement between the Department of Aviation and the Bureau of Meteorology, the latter is responsible for providing forecasts in accordance with these internationally agreed standards. The Department of Aviation is responsible for determining the conditions for the safe conduct of flights in Australia, taking account of meteorological forecasting standards among other things.

Where, for any reason, the Bureau considers it is unable to provide forecasts to the agreed standards, the Department of Aviation imposes compensating additional controls over flight operations. These include, for example, requiring aircraft to carry additional fuel to allow them to divert to alternative airports if necessary; directing aircraft to divert from planned routes or land at the nearest suitable airport; or directing that aircraft not operate at all.

The imposition of these compensating additional controls may mean that aircraft would then be unable to operate to the timetable or route originally scheduled and there may be economic penalties to the operator of the flight. However, these penalties are more than offset by the maintenance of the normal high safety standards under which the Australian aviation industry operates and which the public has a right to expect.

My colleague the Minister for Science and Technology, told the House yesterday of his concern that the Bureau of Meteorology may be unable to continue to provide an adequate level of service. Should that occur the House should be assured that aviation safety would not be jeopardised, for the reasons that I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. In view of the pessimistic outlook for maintaining our share of the Japanese beef quota market after the recent trade negotiations conducted by his colleague the Minister for Primary Industry, does the Minister now agree that he should have become actively involved in the round of negotiations when the Anthony-Okawara beef agreement expired on 31 March last year? Is he concerned that as Minister for Trade he has failed, for reasons that he should perhaps explain to the House, to maintain our quota share of the Japanese beef market of around 70 per cent as the Prime Minister claimed he had achieved during his Asian tour? What plans does the Minister for Trade have to become actively involved to maintain our promised share of the Japanese beef market under quota?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable gentleman would know negotiations for beef entry into Japan are conducted through officials of the Department of Trade. I think he would have the utmost confidence in them because they are the same officials who were conducting those negotiations when he was a member of the former Government. I am not aware that Mr Anthony went to Japan every time beef negotiations were conducted; in fact I very much doubt that he did. If he did the share of our beef market continually declined in the last decade.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us be very clear about what the honourable member is talking about. It is very obvious that every year we get more of our beef into Japan; that is the position. However what confuses the honourable member-I want to put him at rest- is that he does not understand what market share means, whether it is the quantity or the percentage share. Admittedly we are getting less of the percentage share of the Japanese beef market and we have got less every year for the last six or seven years because the Americans have access to the beef market on what is called a grain fed, high quality beef basis.

The significant thing about the former Government was that when the Americans entered into a bilateral arrangement with Japan under the multilateral trade negotiations, which provided for that discrimination against Australia, the former Minister for Primary Industry congratulated the Americans on entering into that arrangement. Obviously he did not understand that the MTN arrangement on a bilateral basis clearly gave the United States a preference in beef entry which we could not match because the MTN had allocated a quota on a grain fed basis and we did not have that sort of beef. I acknowledge that fact.
