The Government is objecting to its being discriminated against by Japan but Japan is taking refuge in the fact that it has that arrangement under the MTN, an arrangement which the former Government congratulated the Americans on having agreed to.

Let us look at the history of the former Government. Having realised that the MTN was obviously opening a large door of entry for United States grain fed beef , surely the Government must have realised that it would not get the same sort of access.

The point at issue now is that the Government is in a position that, whilst it exports more beef each year to Japan, it gets only a percentage of the total extra that has been given to the Americans on a grain fed basis. The Japanese say to us 'Of course, that is a matter of consumer preference in Japan' because their consumers--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not.

—I am telling the honourable member what the Japanese say. The point is this: The Japanese tell us that they allow that entry into Japan and that they did agree to that bilateral arrangement because their consumers wanted that grain fed, high quality beef.
—I have no grain fed beef.
—I accept the interjection. I think we can give the Japanese grain fed beef too. That is the position but the Government has never promoted it in the course of negotiations.
—In 1976 we did.

—If the former Minister did it, he did it out of a vested interest, I suppose. Somebody says: 'Get out of the gutter'. It is not a question of being in the gutter; it is a question of having the knowledge of what the Japanese want and the ability to indicate that there is grain fed beef.
—He doesn't have any grain fed beef.

—If the right honourable member does not have any grain fed beef he will not be able to get into the market. There are grain fed beef producers in Australia who have been making recent representations on the basis of why cannot they be considered. However, the Government does face up to the arrangement which had already been entered into some time ago and it is now saying to the Japanese: 'You are discriminating against us because we want to try to get access to the grain fed beef market'. That is the Government's present case but it is not a very strong case because Australia does not produce a great quantity of grain fed beef as against chilled beef.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, as the honourable gentleman would understand has made representations to the Government. The Corporation would like to have a greater entry of chilled beef rather than what is called a lower priced manufactured beef into the Japanese market and that is where the present negotiations are being directed.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to Japan?

—At this stage I do not think there is any need for me to go. My distinguished colleague the Minister for Primary Industry has already been there once and he is going back again. I cannot think of any better advocate than my colleague.

ANSWER.PARA: I think this is a matter for the Government to discuss with the beef industry. If the industry feels there is discrimination and the Government says there is- the former Government never did, but it approved of the MTN as a satisfactory arrangement-the Government must suggest that the Japanese are discriminating against us, pursuant to an agreement that has already been entered into. That will make it somewhat difficult for us. However, if the beef industry thinks so, we are entitled to take the case to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade on the basis that the Japanese are discriminating against us.

We must weigh that against the fact that it will take some time to have the matter determined. We must weigh it in relation to the industry itself. If the honourable member thinks this is the way to go, perhaps he will be prepared to say that he does and whether it would affect future entry into Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you ought to go to Japan as Minister for Trade.

—That is the honourable member's only refuge-to point a finger and say that I ought to do something. The point I am making is that the Opposition did nothing but lose the market. On the same basis the Opposition approved of a bilateral arrangement that guaranteed that our producers would be discriminated against.

—Is the Minister for Housing and Construction aware of proposals by the Opposition, as part of its program of privatisation, to sell off the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation? What is the Government's reaction to this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of this threat. It is to be regretted by all thinking people in this country. The threat is nothing new; the Fraser Government held this threat over the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation for about four years. The Fraser Government first of all made an announcement in July 1979. However, it had not got round to doing anything by March 1983, for very good reasons. Of course, this threat will be one that matters only if there are some unthinking people who believe that the Opposition will take over government within the next 10 years. Such people are hard to find, but there are some such people among the staff of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. That affects the morale of that organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is a business enterprise which pays normal commercial charges and taxes as well as returning a regular dividend to government. A number of results would flow from the sale of the Corporation. The first one is a reduction of high ratio loans being insured, and thus the work of the building societies in particular would cease. It would result in a lessening of competition in the mortgage insurance market. It would lead to an increased premium rate in that market and thus a reduction of services. It would result in a setback in the development of a secondary mortgage market, which is very much an objective of this Government. In short, such a move would result in an adverse impact on home ownership in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—If the honourable member wants me to go through the list of the results of selling the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation again, I am very keen to do so. The fact is that I have come to the conclusion that the honourable member's colleagues could not be as dull as he is. The honourable member does not have to take my word for it that this would have an adverse effect on the home ownership market.
—I don't.

—All right, so the honourable member does not. Therefore, let me read the list of people who support me. I instance the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies which, when I announced that the Government would not be selling the HLIC, stated that it was:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . a positive initiative for the encouragement of home ownership.
Is that good enough for the honourable member? If not, I can instance a few more . For example, the Trustee Companies of Australia stated:
We applaud you on the Government's decision not to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

Also the Real Estate Institute of Australia, the Master Builders Federation of Australia and the Housing Industry Association have all supported the retention of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation in the government sector. Is that enough for the honourable member, or would he like me to go on? I see that it has sunk into even the honourable member by this stage. It is generally recognised by anybody interested in the housing sector that if the national Government got out of the ownership--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I suggest to the Minister that, if he is so keen to debate the issue with me, he make a statement and he and I can debate it.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I do not think the honourable member's colleagues would choose him to debate the issue. It is generally recognised that, if the Commonwealth got out of the ownership of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, government involvement in this area is so important that the States would have to take up the challenge instead. That merely drives home the stupidity-as represented by what I have quoted from the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies and others-of this aspect, as with so many other aspects, of the Opposition policy. In short, as I sum it up, this is a crazy move announced by ignorant people and against the interests of the community. Otherwise it is all right!

—I address my question to the Prime Minister, in the wake of the Minister for Housing and Construction saying that this Government takes notice of industry associations. I refer the Prime Minister to a speech entitled 'The Labor Alternative', which he gave to the Australian Institute of Political Science in January 1983, when he was Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, and in which he said that one of the principal reasons a Labor government would repeal section 45D of the Trade Practices Act was that many employers had branded that legislation an industrial nuisance. In view of the fact that in the last two months the Business Council of Australia, the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and the Confederation of Australian Industry, as well as numerous individual business organisations, have called for the retention of section 45D, will the Prime Minister take this opportunity of discharging his commitment to evenhanded government by reversing the Government' s decision to abandon one of the few effective sanctions against predatory union behaviour?

—I welcome that question from the top parliamentary Liberal. I recommend to him that he read the whole of that speech that I made and also what I have had to say on other occasions about this matter. He will find, particularly if he consults with the organisations to which he referred, that I have listened intently to the concerns which they have understandably expressed to me about the possible difficulties they see if section 45D were removed from the trade practices legislation. Not only I, but also the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, have made it clear that-following the discussions that are going on concerning what should happen to this legislation-it will not be simply a matter of taking the section out of the legislation but consideration will be given to dealing with the sorts of issues which are involved in secondary boycotts in the area of legislation where it should always have been dealt with, that is, the Commonwealth conciliation and arbitration legislation. The attitude of the Labor Party has been consistent in believing that we should not clutter up the trade practices legislation with provisions more properly at home in other more relevant legislation.

—Can the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment please advise the House of the situation with regard to recent Press reports to the effect that the Australian Bicentennial Authority has abandoned a First Fleet re-enactment as a major part of our celebration program, because of pressure from the Aboriginal community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the House that there will be a First Fleet re-enactment, as there has been for years. We recognise that Aboriginal people do not see the arrival of the First Fleet as a cause for turning handsprings. Nevertheless, it represents the beginning of European civilisation in Australia. That is the starting point and that is the thing that we are celebrating in 1988. However, the Authority does not wish the bicentennial to be obsessively concerned with the First Fleet and its descendants but wants to ensure that all Australians who live here now should feel involved, whether they or their descendants arrived on 26 January 1788 or in 1984 and whether they came from Britain or Burma, Ireland or Indo-China.

ANSWER.PARA: Right from the word go, since 1980, I have been involved as a director of the Bicentennial Authority. The question of a First Fleet re-enactment was raised. The question was on what scale should it be. In 1980, a study was done by Dr Pascoe which estimated the cost of building the Fleet at $16m. Later we rejected the proposal on the grounds that it was too much money to spend on one day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, what about a weekend?

—Nobody has a better idea of how to spend money in a short period than the honourable member. However, in view of the persistence of Jonathan King and company the Authority commissioned another inquiry under Sir Donald Trescowthick and the economic research unit which did a study which came up with the findings that to build a First Fleet would cost $18m and to lease it would cost $31m and that the sale of the ships afterwards would yield only $6m. So honourable members can see that the cost would be astronomical for a very small part of the celebrations. Mr Michael Edgley and company have talked about getting the money from the private sector. I believe that he has estimated a scaled down re- enactment as costing about $7m or $8m. The point is that the Bicentennial Authority realises that a certain amount of money for the Bicentennial will come from the private sector. If it endorses this project, that means that this is $ 7m or $8m it will not be able to get for a whole range of other activities which it is anxious to pursue for the Bicentennial. However, let me assure the House and Australia that there will be a First Fleet re-enactment--
—Well, support it.

—We are supporting the re-enactment; we are not supporting the building of ships and a First Fleet coming from all over the world. We are saying that there will be a re-enactment, but not of the scale that some people would like it to be.

—Has the Special Minister of State obtained a report about the information in today's Age newspaper concerning the discovery of a huge drug racket in Queensland? Is it a fact that the drug distribution centre referred to in the Age is located at Noosa in Queensland? Is the Minister aware that there are inadequate numbers of police and Customs officers at Noosa to deal with this situation? Is it a fact that effective investigation into this drug racket has been made possible only because of assistance from officers of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? Will the termination of the Costigan Commission affect the continuing investigation of this drug ring?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Boothby directed a number of questions to me. Firstly, let me say, no, I have not received a report on the matter referred to in the newspapers this morning. Secondly, in relation to the cut-off of the Costigan Commission, a lot of publicity has been given to the announcements that we have made that the National Crime Authority was to be established once the legislation was passed by both Houses. The timetable for that is, hopefully, by 1 July. By arrangement with Commissioner Costigan, he will be working for a month during the period of transition from the Costigan Commission, because it was seen as a total transfer of the Costigan and Stewart commissions to the National Crime Authority. For eight weeks following that month of transition, he , of course, will write his final report which will be presented to the Government and ultimately to the Parliament. There is in no way any inference by anyone or any authority that there would be interference with the Costigan Commission. I will get a report on the matter and make it available.

—Has the attention of the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to recent reports of the building of a $500m airport at Lefkoniko in the Turkish-occupied zone of Cyprus? Is the Minister aware that this proposed airport is only 20 kilometres from the occupied city of Famagusta? Does the Minister agree that the building of that airport will lead to increased tensions in Cyprus and a fear that the Turkish Government will not surrender any occupied territory in Cyprus? Will the Minister draw to the attention of both the Turkish Government and the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers that Australia is concerned about this matter and that it may cause added tensions in Cyprus and fail to bring about success in the reunification talks that are currently proceeding regarding that troubled land?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of the continued interest the honourable member has in this matter because of the large number of Cypriots now resident in Australia. The tragic situation in Cyprus is a matter of concern to all Australian governments. I have not had the report drawn to my attention but I take note of what the honourable member said. I agree that if an airport is to be constructed on what is called the Turkish side it will do nothing to alleviate the problems of all the people of Cyprus. On 2 May, the United Nations Security Council convened to consider the Cyprus question. Australia voted in favour of a resolution which condemned the exchange of ambassadors between Turkey and the so-called Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.

ANSWER.PARA: I was in Cyprus in December, which confirmed for me what the honourable gentleman has said. There is a great deal of tension there because of the failure to resolve the current problem and the additional problems created by Mr Denktash declaring unilaterally that there was to be a Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. The real issue that the United Nations obviously has to deal with is to get support from all parties to guarantee that the Turkish Army leaves Cyprus so that the problems of Cyprus can be settled by all the Cypriots who are there. The Government continues to support the Secretary-General of the United Nations, who has the responsibility of continuing in what is called a good offices role in an endeavour to solve that problem. He indicated that he required the unambiguous support of all countries. If, as the question indicated , there is to be further development on one side which could lead to suspicions on the other side, one could well think that we are getting no closer to but in fact getting further away from a settlement.

I assure the honourable gentleman that Australia will continue to do all in its power to bring about a just and lasting solution to the situation in Cyprus. The forerunner of that, of course, is the immediate withdrawal of all Turkish forces .

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Primary Industry to the critical problems being experienced by Australian dried fruit producers. Will the Minister respond urgently to submissions seeking underwriting, appropriate changes to the rural adjustment scheme, registration of plantings and the maintenance of adequate levels of import duties for the retention of the domestic market? Does the Minister recognise that the failure of the social security system to assist growers in financial stress is being reflected in family breakdown, health deterioration and low self-esteem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman reflects on a very serious social situation, particularly in his electorate, which produces the majority of dried vine fruit in Australia. As he is aware, some of the new entrants into the industry find themselves in a particularly difficult situation because they bought in on a basis of high prices and are financed in by packers and banks. Because of the price of dried vine fruits and because of some imports they are now in a critical situation. I am sympathetic to the producers and to the concern that imports of fruit can injure the domestic industry. That matter is being looked at. A request for countervailing duty has been accepted and is being processed through the normal channels under the jurisdiction of the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable gentleman is aware, when delegations came to see me, the Minister for Social Security and I, in conjunction with the Victorian Government , saw what we could do to assist individuals. I think it is fair to say that the provision of household finance under the rural adjustment scheme is not adequate . However, every time I raise that with the States they prefer to use the rural adjustment scheme for the more usual goals of debt reconstruction and farm build -up rather than to get on to household finance. The Department of Social Security faces a particular problem with its criteria, inasmuch as people with assets who are carrying on a business are not eligible for unemployment benefits . They can be eligible for special benefits under certain circumstances. But it cannot be opened up much more, otherwise every small businessman in the same position would also be entitled to social security benefits. There is a conceptual problem.

In terms of overall assistance to the industry, after a three-month inquiry including a public hearing at Mildura, for this season the Industries Assistance Commission recommended against the provision of assistance to the industry for 1984. However, the Government said that we would keep the industry situation under review, as we would have a clearer view of the financial situation after the 1984 harvest has ended. My Department is now gathering data on this aspect. Carry-on loans under the rural adjustment scheme might be possible. However, that will depend on evidence now available and agreement by producing States to join in funding loans. The part B option in the rural adjustment scheme will have to be taken up with the State Ministers involved, and I will raise it at the next Australian Agricultural Council meeting. But only potentially viable producers could qualify for such loans. Producers who are doubtful about their future should check their eligibility for adjustment assistance under the RAS through the State organisation. The IAC is continuing its inquiry into assistance in 1985 and subsequent seasons and it is to report to the Government in mid-September. By and large, what we are doing at present relates to trying to get evidence of the producers' financial situation for this season. I will take up the matter with the Government and the States as soon as possible.

What is the Government's response to this belated return to fairness by the Opposition?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask you to rule the question out of order. I did not use those words. An examination of Hansard will prove it . It is a false question and it should be ruled out of order.
—Order! It is not for the Chair to judge the honourable member's statement. If the honourable member for Denison is offended, he will have the opportunity to correct the misrepresentation.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a further point of order. My second point of order is that that Minister is not, thank God, responsible for what I say.
—Order! That is not a point of order. I call the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the House that, on 8 May, the Leader of the Opposition said that what I, as Minister, must do was to retain the present number of Asians already here and increase the number of Europeans and British to restore balance to the program. It should be pointed out to the House that if we were to retain the present numbers of Asian people coming to Australia this year- approximately 23,000-and then return to a so-called balance of approximately 23 per cent, which was the average figure for the last two years of the previous Government's term in office, we would be taking in excess of 100,000 people.

ANSWER.PARA: I want the House to reflect upon the remarkable change that appeared to occur after I made my statement yesterday on the new intake for 1984-85. It now appears that the Leader of the Opposition and the Opposition spokesman are saying that they were not calling for balance on racial grounds, but were calling for a balance of the components-such as family reunion, business migration, skilled migration and so on-within the program. If that is their current attitude, the Government welcomes it, because we do not want them to be calling for racial balance in the program. But, of course, that is not what the Leader of the Opposition said on 8 May. He made a clear assertion that this Government was anti-British and that we should take more Europeans and British to redress the balance. Now that we have produced figures in this Parliament both several weeks ago and yesterday during the statement that I put down which outlined the intake for this year, the Opposition seeks to retreat and to resile from the position that it put several weeks ago.

Further, there is no use in the Opposition pointing to the very moderate increase in skilled labour and business migration programs to which we have agreed-that is, only 3,000 people in the skilled labour program and 2,500 in the business migration program. It is no use members of the Opposition pointing to that as evidence of acceptance of their earlier advice, because that is not the position. The Government and I foreshadowed one year ago a very moderate increase in the skilled labour and business migration categories. I reiterated that position last March. I say simply that this moderate increase does not represent a response to the Opposition's ill-considered call for racial balance in the program; but it reflects our determination to introduce a new scheme for selecting skilled migrants-the occupational share system-and it reflects the economic upturn that has occurred under this Government. I conclude by saying that, despite what the Opposition may say or may call for, there will be no discrimination on racial or regional grounds in our migration programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the report by the Australian Science and Technology Council-ASTEC-on Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle. I seek leave to make a statement in respect of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Government's examination of policy in relation to the export of Australian uranium last year, I wrote to the Chairman of Australian Science and Technology Council, Professor Ralph Slatyer, on 9 November 1983, requesting that ASTEC undertake an inquiry, under his personal direction, into Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle. The inquiry was asked to examine in particular Australia's nuclear safeguards arrangements, giving particular attention to the effectiveness of the bilateral and multilateral agreements, and to the scope for strengthening these agreements; the opportunities for Australia through the conditions of its involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle to further advance the cause of nuclear non-proliferation, having regard to the policies and practices of recipient countries; and the adequacy of existing technology for the handling and disposal of waste products by consuming countries, and the ways in which Australia can further contribute to the development of safe disposal methods.

SPEECH.PARA: The Council was subsequently requested to include some consideration of the issues raised by the possible extraction of thorium for nuclear use from Australian mineral sands containing the mineral monazite. The Slatyer inquiry was an integral part of the Government's uranium policy decisions announced last November. At that time the Government decided that, firstly, the Roxby Downs Joint Venturers be advised that if a commercial decision to proceed with the development of Roxby Downs were to be made by them, the Government would permit the export of uranium produced from that mine, and the export of the uranium would be subject to whatever safeguards arrangements applied generally to uranium exports at the time of export; secondly, with the exception of Roxby Downs if commercially feasible, the Government not permit the development of any new uranium mines; and, thirdly, all future exports of Australia's uranium-under both existing and any future contracts-be made subject to the most stringent supply conditions, such conditions to be determined by the Government following an inquiry into Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle.

In setting up the inquiry, the Government considered it to be important that there should be an independent and objective audit of policies and practices in regard to Australia's uranium exports to ensure that they contributed to and strengthened Australia's pursuit of its disarmament and non-proliferation objectives. The Government also sought a scientific assessment of the adequacy of ways in which countries managed and disposed of radioactive waste. ASTEC, as the pre-eminent council providing independent advice to the Government on science and technology questions, was judged best qualified to perform this role under the personal direction of Professor Slatyer. The terms of reference for the inquiry focused primarily on the issues of non-proliferation, safeguards and waste management, both because of their intrinsic importance, and because they are of particular concern in the community in relation to Australia's involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle.

The final report reflects a broad interpretation of the terms of reference, and provides a comprehensive identification of the elements of the fuel cycle and the issues which they raise for the export of Australian uranium. The report indicates that, while the percentage of world electricity requirements which will be generated by nuclear means cannot be forecast precisely, no new energy source is likely to have a significant impact for the next quarter century. Accordingly the report notes that the world can be expected to rely largely on coal and nuclear energy, supplemented by oil, to provide the major part of its electricity requirements for this period. This would be the case even if Australia were not to export its uranium.

The report notes that there is no shortage of uranium in the world to supply fuel to the nuclear power industry, and points out that the future development of the nuclear power industry will not be dependent on Australian uranium, and will proceed irrespective of whether or not Australia is a supplier. The report suggests that, if international tensions are to be reduced and the prospects of a peaceful global environment enhanced, the importance of national and international energy security cannot be overemphasised. It notes that disruptions in the supply of resources of any sort have been a cause of international tension and, through human history, have led to war.

The report points out that countries which do not have indigenous energy resources are most concerned to ensure reliability of supplies and, to this end, place great emphasis on diversity of supplies and the political stability of supplier countries. For this reason many countries have turned to nuclear energy for electricity generation out of concern about reliability of oil supplies both in the short and long term.

The inquiry has concluded that Australia, through being a reliable, long term supplier of uranium, is in a position to contribute significantly to international energy security. Further, the report brings out that assurance of reliable long term supplies of uranium at reasonable prices will also reduce the motivation for individual countries to seek greater energy security by carrying out more steps of the fuel cycle, particularly reprocessing, within national boundaries.

Against this background the report concludes that Australia will best be able to make a significant contribution to non-proliferation and world peace if it is actively involved in the nuclear fuel cycle. By involvement of this kind, the report argues, Australia will be able to make a direct contribution to the development of the civil nuclear fuel cycle in ways that will increase global energy security, strengthen the elements of the non-proliferation regime and reduce the risks of misuse of civil facilities and the diversion of nuclear materials from civil to military uses. Without such involvement, global energy security would be less assured, and Australia's ability to strengthen the non- proliferation regime and to influence future developments in the fuel cycle would be reduced.

The report expresses the concern that we must all share that the prevention of nuclear war is of the greatest importance to all humanity. A major component of global efforts to prevent such a war is prevention of further proliferation of nuclear weapons, either by an increase in the size of the arsenals of those countries which already have such weapons, referred to as vertical proliferation , or by an increase in the number of countries with such weapons or which have exploded nuclear devices, referred to as horizontal proliferation. The report recognises that, since nuclear fission not only provides power for electricity generation but also constitutes the explosive source of weapons, it is understandable that there should be widespread public concern about the degree to which civil nuclear activities could contribute to the development of nuclear weapons.

In this regard the inquiry makes a number of points. The great majority of the countries of the world have found compelling reasons for not building nuclear weapons and have given a commitment not to do so by becoming members of the Non- Proliferation Treaty. They have also accepted safeguards on all their nuclear facilities so that their commitment to non-proliferation can be verified. The report points out that if a decision is taken by a country to develop nuclear weapons this can be achieved, provided that the country has sufficient determination and a reasonable scientific and technological infrastructure. The absence of a civil nuclear industry would not prevent such a development, although the procedure would be more difficult and slower. But the report suggests that, should a country decide to embark on a weapons program, it is unlikely to use a civil power reactor to do so, as this would be inefficient both in terms of producing weapons usable material and in terms of electricity generation.

The report concludes that the task for all countries is to create an international political climate in which actions leading to the growth of the arsenals of nuclear weapons states, and the extension of a nuclear capability to so-called 'threshold' countries, are not taken. In this regard the report focuses on the Non-Proliferation Treaty, as the most important multilateral non- proliferation and arms control agreement in existence-a view which this Government strongly supports and will continue to in multilateral form, and in our discussions with other nations on non-proliferation and arms control matters .

The report makes a number of recommendations aimed at strengthening adherence to the Treaty. In particular it notes that continued support by many countries will depend upon the fulfilment of the three-way bargain contained in the Treaty . This involves a pledge by non-nuclear weapon states neither to manufacture nor to acquire nuclear weapons and to accept verification of this, a commitment by all parties to pursue nuclear disarmament, and an undertaking to provide access by members to nuclear items for peaceful purposes. In this latter regard, the report refers to the importance of Article IV of the Treaty, which affirms the right of all countries to use nuclear energy for peaceful purposes. It also requires those countries in a position to do so to contribute to the further development of nuclear energy in member countries.

At a more fundamental level the report highlights the necessity not just of maintaining the non-proliferation regime but of demonstrating that the obligations contained in the Treaty are being met. In this regard, the significance of the forthcoming 1985 NPT Review Conference is emphasised as is the need to register some positive achievements in the field of disarmament before the future of the Treaty is decided in 1995. The Government has stressed on a number of occasions and reaffirms the fundamental importance it attaches to the role of the Review Conference to the future of the NPT. Among the Government 's more important initiatives in support of an effective non-proliferation regime has been our backing for a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific. The reports sees this as contributing to the international non-proliferation regime in a substantial region, as well as responding to the fears of small island states in the region about the future conservation and use of their major resource, the ocean.

There can be no doubt that the issues of disarmament and non-proliferation are among the most important of our time. It is the international community's ability to deal with them effectively which will determine our future. It is particularly important that we be clear-sighted in our thinking on the issues involved. The report notes that two key arguments have been put forward opposing Australia's involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle. It has, for example, been suggested that the solution to the problems of nuclear proliferation is for the world to forgo the use of nuclear energy, and for countries such as Australia to take a lead by withholding supply of uranium. The report rejects this suggestion , observing that the use of nuclear energy is an established fact of life, and that Australia's withdrawal would not affect the decisions that countries have made and will make to use nuclear energy. A second line of argument is that, by supplying uranium to nuclear weapon states, Australia might be freeing up uranium for use in weapons. The report also rejects this argument, drawing attention to the fact that those states already have adequate supplies of uranium and are not assisted in any way by the supply of Australian uranium. Put more bluntly, the report concludes that denial of supply to nuclear weapon states would not affect in any way their weapons programs.

On the basis of these and other related considerations, the report concludes that there are more practical measures that Australia can take to assist the cause of non-proliferation than by withholding the supply the uranium. Principally these go to the strengthening of the existing non-proliferation regime. Proposals made by the report in this regard will be addressed by the Government in the near future. The report also thoroughly considers the issues involved in waste management and disposal. It judges it to be absolutely necessary for countries to adopt high standards and to ensure that the best practicable waste disposal technology is employed. The report advocates an approach which involves containing and isolating the source of radioactivity as far as possible.

The most effective way to put such an approach into practice is seen to be the confinement of the radioactive wastes in a stable waste form, and to isolate the waste form from the environment by additional barriers. Proven methods are identified for handling waste with low and intermediate levels of radioactivity. The report, however, expresses reservations about the dumping of radioactive waste in the oceans, noting that, while this may be a safe procedure, much further work remains to be done before any final judgment can be made. In the meantime, the report urges Australian support for a continuation of the present moratorium on ocean dumping. For high level waste, the report notes that investigations in progress, the level of technical knowledge attained and the progress of programs of site investigation provide confidence that safe disposal of high level waste can be undertaken. The results of theoretical assessments of geological repositories provide additional confidence that safe disposal of appropriately packaged waste is possible using existing technology, provided that the best practicable technology is used at each stage and that an optimum geological repository is used. Under these circumstances, the report considers that any return of radioactivity to the biosphere can be held to safe and acceptable levels over long periods-up to one million years-so that maximum doses to the most exposed individuals would be a small fraction of natural background levels. It considers, moreover, that the technology required to achieve these objectives is available. The report notes the contribution which Australia can make to research and development in the area of waste disposal and recommends continued involvement in this important work. Attention is drawn particularly to the potential significance of the Australian-developed waste form Synroc and it is recommended that work on Synroc be continued. If the promise which Synroc appears to hold is demonstrated by further research, the report concludes that its adoption by other countries should be pursued.

At this stage I should like to thank Professor Slatyer-may I say that Professor Slatyer is with us in the House today-the members of the inquiry and ASTEC staff for the production of a comprehensive, thoroughly professional report. It should become the standard technical reference for those seeking an understanding of the issues involved in this complex and critically important subject, on which a range of views are held within the Australian community and indeed within the Australian Labor Party. My judgment and indeed my hope would be that it will further enhance the more rational and reasoned discussion of nuclear issues which has emerged in recent months. The Government will give careful consideration to the ASTEC recommendations, and as decisions are made Ministers will advise the Parliament. I commend the report to the House. I present the following paper:
Nuclear Fuel Cycle-Ministerial Statement, 31 May 1984.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition speaking for a period not exceeding 20 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the report of the Australian Science and Technology Council on Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle. It is a comprehensive and clear-headed statement on this important issue. Of course, it makes an absolute mockery of the Australian Labor Party's selective uranium policy. It underlines the need for change in the policy at the forthcoming Federal Conference of the Australian Labor Party. Let me say here and now that the Opposition gives the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) full support in his endeavours to adopt our policy towards the mining and export of uranium, for that is what is involved-the adoption of the policy of the previous Government and the current Opposition on the mining and export of uranium. We want the Government to join us in a bipartisan approach on this important issue. I am sure that, with the degree of work that is being done buying off the Left, that can be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems involved in nuclear energy and nuclear weapons should be seen as practical problems requiring practical solutions. It is, therefore, pleasing that the Council has followed the example of its distinguished predecessors in presenting a realistic report which reflects the current international environment. This report is a valuable work which complements the monumental report which flowed from the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry undertaken by Mr Justice Fox.

When we were in government, the coalition recognised that the process of strengthening and improving international safeguards and arrangements was a continuing one. Nuclear policy and safeguard arrangements should always be kept closely under review to take account of the evolution of international thinking on safeguards. No decision in Australia's political history was preceded by more careful and thorough deliberation than the decision by those of us now on this side of the Parliament to develop and export Australia's uranium resources when we were in government. I urge those who hold contrary views within the Government to adopt the policy pursued by us both in government and in opposition. The fact that so much consideration was given to our adoption of the mining and export of uranium and the clear and rational policies that flowed from that determination is clearly recognised in the Slatyer report. Firstly, we based our decision on authoritative predictions of a serious long term world energy problem in which it will be necessary to rely largely on coal and nuclear energy supplemented by oil.

Secondly, we based our decision on our international obligations with regard to nuclear non-proliferation. To this end the coalition Government initiated the most comprehensive and stringent safeguards policy adopted by any country in the world. I say it with a degree of pride because I was Foreign Minister at the time when we were implementing those most stringent safeguards. It was designed to promote universal adherence to the Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Our policy offered a tangible reward: Access to Australian uranium for those countries which renounced nuclear weapons by becoming parties to the Treaty. Equally, our policy offered a tangible incentive to non-parties to adhere to the Treaty. Thirdly, it was our conviction that, given these circumstances, a failure to mine and export uranium would deprive Australia of a major competitive industry to no rational end. As I have said, the report agrees with that.

In accepting the valid, commercial considerations we did not accept that these should be balanced against the safeguards policy. We viewed adequate safeguards as a fundamental prerequisite of any uranium exports. The essential ingredients of the policy the coalition implemented were the careful selection of customer countries; the application of international safeguards to verify that material supplied for peaceful purposes was not misused; the establishment of additional safeguards through bilateral arrangements; and an active involvement by Australia in international efforts to upgrade safeguards. On page 158 the Slatyer report sets out in detail the relevant elements of our nuclear safeguards policy that we announced on 24 May 1977.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very comprehensive.
—It was extremely comprehensive. As I have said, there could not have been any more thorough consideration of a policy decision by any government than what we did in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us now look at what the Slatyer report has to say on this whole subject. It sensibly notes the substantial role nuclear energy plays as an energy source. It points out that this would be the case even if Australia were not to export its uranium. It points out that disruptions in resource supplies of any sort have been a cause of international tension and, indeed, often war. It concludes that Australia, through being a reliable, long term supplier of uranium, is in a position to contribute significantly to international energy security. It makes great play of the need for us to be a reliable, long term supplier of uranium and the benefits this will have on world peace. I will return to this point in a little while.

The report expresses the concern, with which honourable members on this side of the House would agree unequivocally, that the prevention of nuclear war is of the greatest importance to all humanity. Nuclear disarmament and the avoidance of nuclear war is rightly the preoccupation of this generation of young people today. Here again the report makes an important contribution. It reaffirms the importance of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the need for us to honour our international responsibilities under that Treaty. That Treaty represents an implicit covenant between those nations with nuclear weapons and those without, an undertaking by the nuclear powers that they will pursue in good faith negotiations on arms control and on limiting the spread of their weapons technology, and an undertaking by other states that they will forgo the military use of nuclear energy in return for the benefits of its peaceful use in fields such as energy, medicine or agriculture.
The report refers to the importance of Article IV of the Treaty. This affirms the right of all countries to use nuclear energy for peaceful purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is critical.

—It is absolutely essential; I stress the importance of that. As I have said, it affirms that right as long as nuclear energy is used for peaceful purposes, written into that critical Article-Article IV. It also requires those countries, if they are in a position to do so, to contribute to the further development of nuclear energy in member countries. That is a requirement. I commend this advice to the Australian Labor Party. I recommend that the report be compulsory reading for all its members, as indeed was implied in the closing statements of the Prime Minister. Regardless of preconceived notions and prejudices, this report plausibly argues for the strengthening of Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted with particular interest the attention the report pays to the 1985 Non- Proliferation Treaty Review Conference and the recommendations aimed at strengthening adherence to the Treaty. We believe that action needs to be taken to strengthen the Treaty. Although it has been signed by some 119 nations a number of key states remain aloof, including several with the capacity now, or the potential, to develop their own nuclear arms. Our policy should be to encourage the five nuclear weapons states to strengthen their side of the non- proliferation commitment so that countries such as Australia, with a distinguished record in disarmament matters, can more effectively bring common sense to bear on those which have not yet signed.

Doubtless we will need to increase the incentives for Third World states to forgo nuclear weapons. As such, there will have to be a direct linkage between disarmament and development; I do not run away from that necessity. Our influence in this process can be significant if we can balance our established diplomatic credentials in the disarmament field with the reputation of a stable and reliable supplier of uranium under the strictest of safeguards. The coalition has consistently maintained this stance, as I have indicated, both in government and in opposition. I also note the report's realistic comments that the development of nuclear weapons can be achieved in the absence of a civil nuclear industry and that, should a country decide to embark upon a weapons program, it is unlikely to use a civil power reactor to do so. The thrust of this whole report is crystal clear. It firmly recommends:

That exports of Australian uranium should not be limited as a matter of principle but should be permitted subject to stringent conditions of supply designed to strengthen the non-proliferation regime.

We agree entirely. In welcoming the report we, on this side of the House, must nevertheless point to what we perceive in the report as problems in its recommendations for a nuclear-free zone in the South Pacific. There have been three levels of concern in the South Pacific: Firstly, the decision of France to continue nuclear testing in the Pacific; secondly, the proposals to dump radioactive waste in the Pacific; and, thirdly, the expressions of concern about nuclear powered or nuclear armed naval movements in the South Pacific. These concerns are important to governments that consider themselves custodians of one of the great oceans of the world. It is a job of governments to be sensitive to them and to work carefully toward the resolution and dissipation of these fears. The key question, though, is the strategic effects flowing from the application of a nuclear weapons free zone policy.

The crucial ingredients affecting strategic responses are political. What will be the consequential effects of the political movement in the Pacific seeking a ban on the movement of nuclear powered and nuclear armed ships? This question is not asked by the scientists because, with great respect to them, it is not within their competence, as a body, to pose the question or, more particularly, to answer it. This is appropriately the responsibility of the Government's defence and foreign affairs advisers. What is the nature of their advice to the Government on this question? It is clear that the Government will seek to use the authority of this report to seek endorsement for its preconceived views that a nuclear free zone be established in the Pacific.

The report places great emphasis on the Tlatelolco treaty. It fails to observe, however, that the main stimulus for that treaty was the attempt by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to install weapons in Cuba. That treaty was a response to that move and this gave the treaty considerable local meaning and content. We know that when the Government's nuclear free zone proposal was put to the South Pacific Forum significant island leaders considered the proposal meaningless. They were asked to undertake not to acquire or to allow nuclear weapons to be installed in their territories. They obviously considered it inconceivable that they would have such intentions. Therefore it is reasonable to assume that this dissatisfaction could issue into a greater reception being given to the political drive in the region to ban the movement of nuclear powered and nuclear armed ships, and that is not in the interests of Australia.

I believe the Slatyer report has in this instance moved, with great respect, into areas beyond its competence. I commend to the Government its own endorsed strategic basis paper which puts a contrary view, with respect, to the report on this issue. The strategic basis report-I remind the House that the report, leaked or not, was endorsed by the Government-stated:
We can assist the island states to develop a more considered approach to nuclear questions.

It argued that we should draw their attention to the practical difficulties of verification and enforcement and the need to exempt vehicles in transit. Frankly , the nuclear free zone proposal in the South Pacific will not work and if it is to impede nuclear powered vessels it calls into question the ANZUS Treaty.

Let me return to the report's theme and the principal recommendation about the importance of being a reliable supplier of uranium. It is a great tragedy that emotive issues have been allowed by the current Government to stand in the way of proper industry development. That, I hope, is changing now with the form of endorsement that can be read between the lines in the Prime Minister's statement today because the emotive issues that have been allowed to stand in the way of proper industry development have placed in some jeopardy Australia's reputation as a reliable supplier of uranium.

The report before the House spells out a clear message to this Government that it must approve the mining and export of uranium as a matter of urgency. It must do so without the previous signs of bias it has shown towards what it regards as politically favourable centres to receive mining approval. It would be the Opposition's hope that this report puts some rational thinking into the heads of those members of the Labor Party who are responsible for its current illogical, emotional uranium policy. It is a policy which says that there are two kinds of uranium in this country. There is good uranium at Roxby Downs while the higher grade uranium at Ranger and Nabarlek is not too bad; but at all the other places in Australia it is bad.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an idiotic policy.

—It is absolutely idiotic and the inability of the Labor Party to date to accept a reasoned, coherent uranium policy has already cost this nation heavily in terms of export income, economic growth, jobs and international reputation. The longer the Labor Party vacillates, the worse Australia's position will become. The failure to allow Australia to compete fully on the world market and the failure to support that export industry have meant that today our rich uranium resources supply only one-tenth of the world market. The current oversupply position has also meant that Australia will not be able to compete for and fill new major contracts until the early 1990s and this compromise of our national interest is, bluntly, a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: The uranium industry, with proper safeguards, will make a major contribution to the improvement in lifestyles of many millions of people in our country and in other countries. The future is clear, as the Slatyer report shows. There will be an expansion in demand for nuclear energy. As at 1 March this year there were, as I recall, 243 nuclear plants in commercial operation in the Western world and another 160 were under construction. It is estimated that in the United States nuclear power will provide around 20 per cent of all electricity requirements by 1990. That makes opposition to the development of Australia's uranium industry even more of a sham than it is.

I have pointed out that our nation has safety standards on uranium which lead the world. Quite simply, other nations with far less rigid restrictions are supplying the market gap which Australia would otherwise fill. Uranium is here to stay and it is nothing short of the most major indictment of this Government that it has been unable to formulate a strong uranium export policy. This is to the very real detriment, as a consequence, of Australia and Australians.

As I have said, according to the Labor Party there are two kinds of uranium- good and bad uranium. The good uranium is at Roxby Downs. It is good because it is mixed up in the ground with other minerals such as gold and copper. The higher grade uranium at Ranger and Nabarlek is not too bad but the really bad uranium is at all other places in Australia where this very valuable and important energy resource occurs. In those places the uranium is not mixed up with other minerals but exists on its own. The Labor Party, in applying that double standard for which it has become notorious, has decided that the uranium at Roxby Downs can be mined and exported but that the other uranium in places other than Ranger and Nabarlek must stay in the ground. It would be hard to find a more hypocritical, opportunistic, expedient and blatantly political policy of convenience than this. (Extension of time granted) How can people who so loudly and persistently speak of the so-called dangers of uranium and of what they see as the evil nature of this mineral agree to its being mined and exported from Roxby Downs simply because it occurs there with other minerals which ought to be mined?

Australia at present is a minor supplier of uranium to a world generously endowed with that mineral. Indeed at present it is oversupplied with it. But if we withdraw from the uranium market we will reduce ourselves to a position of total impotence and irrelevance so far as having any influence on the use of uranium is concerned. Is that what some of the ideologues of the Labor Party want? I trust that the more balanced members opposite will be able to talk such people out of that. This report logically, plausibly, argues their case in so moving the Leftists who would restrain us in the development of this area.

It has been estimated by the South Australian Chamber of Mines that up to 4,650 potential jobs were lost because the South Australian and Federal governments prevented the development of the Honeymoon and Beverley mines and of an enrichment industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace.

—It is absolutely disgraceful. One must add to it the facts relating to the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory Government estimates that around 2,000 potential permanent jobs will be lost if the Koongarra and Jabiluka mines do not go ahead. At least $1,000m in investment will be lost. Western Australia and Queensland will also see jobs lost if the misguided attitudes of the Labor Party persist. The Aboriginal people, for whom Labor professes to have such concern, are being completely ignored by the Government and their wishes in the matter of uranium development have been treated with contempt.

SPEECH.PARA: The expected export earnings at Jabiluka and Koongarra would have totalled about $4 billion and tax payable was around a billion dollars. This Government at present believes that tax revenue can be forgone and ordinary taxpayers can make up the difference. This Government at this stage, by adhering to a thoroughly discredited and unrealistic policy, is doing enormous economic damage to our country and to the lives of many thousands of Australians. The Government 's policy-or should I say non-policy-is illogical and unacceptable to the international community. It has disadvantaged the industrial development of the Northern Territory and parts of the States that I have mentioned. It is sidestepping its way down a path which will utterly destroy Australia's influence on the world's nuclear industry and which will undermine our influence in disarmament matters.

I hope and trust that the Slatyer report on Australia's Role in the Nuclear Fuel Cycle will at least encourage some reason and logic in regard to the uranium debate within the Australian Labor Party. For it is our hope that the Government will at long last adopt an intelligent and responsible policy on the mining and export of uranium following the forthcoming Federal Labor Party conference. We wish the Prime Minister well in seeking to persuade those recalcitrant members of his Party to adopt a positive stance on the mining and export of uranium. If he succeeds he will be adopting a policy that we adopted some years ago. He will be adopting our policy. As a consequence he will be adopting a policy on the mining and export of uranium which is to the benefit of Australia.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bilney) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW BUSINESS AFTER 11 P.M.:ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of anticipation and optimism that I ask leave of the House to move a motion to suspend Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That standing order 48A, as amended by the sessional order on 29 February 1984, relating to the adjournment of the House, and standing order 103, the 11 o'clock rule, be suspended for the remainder of this period of sittings.

It has not been my intention as Leader of the House to restrict speakers in the debates taking place. As honourable members opposite and members of the Government realise, we have set ourselves the target of the House rising on Thursday of next week. This is much preferable to the manner in which former governments have dealt with business by guillotining it and by chopping off all debate on matters. In fact, some years ago the Senate with a Liberal-National Party majority guillotined 14 Bills in half an hour. It is not the intention of this Government to do that. It may be necessary-I hope it is not-for us to sit one or two extra hours over the next five days. Opposition members all look a very healthy lot, so I do not think this will have a detrimental effect on their health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people were so tired they could not move their lips.

—The honourable member for Moreton can sit in the House, bring his superannuation in and count it to make sure it is all there. I can assure the honourable member that, as Leader of the House, I will continue to be just as generous with honourable members' right to speak over the next five days as I have been over the past three months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the motion. There is no doubt that we all remember the way in which the former member for Grayndler used to come into this place and move guillotines and keep us here inordinately. There are few opportunities for back benchers of the Parliament to participate in debates.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members have short memories, I am afraid, because it was the former member for Grayndler who set low standards in the running of this Parliament. We all hoped for better things from the Special Minister of State ( Mr Young); sadly that was not to be so. Indeed, when he was talking about one of my colleagues a little while ago in relation to superannuation one could not help but think of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and wonder just how those bank coffers are turning over. That was an extraordinary period. I have no doubt that it might be even better if the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs were to see the Parliament sitting longer.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure honourable gentlemen that in opposing the motion we believe the proper course is not to have people sitting here till a ridiculous hour, as we had last night and the night before. On Wednesday nights we were to have a great innovation, we were going to rise early. Last night, what time did we adjourn? It was 1.15 a.m. It is just not good enough. We know the difficulties the Special Minister of State has. His Ministers have not got their acts together. The legislative program is way behind.

Certainly, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been trying to keep out of public note all those matters of controversy. He is trying hard to ensure that that image of purity which he would espouse is one he can take to the polls. Sadly the mess-up with the assets test, the absolute disaster that he has now fallen into with the breaches in the accord, the problems in migration policy and the difficulties we have with superannuation are all cumulative. What is happening is that instead of legislation being introduced into this place as it should have within a proper compass, with time for honourable members to consider it rationally with a forward program and with adequate opportunity to debate, we have now been told that we are going to have to sit late every night-not just tonight but every night.

I know how the Special Minister of State in response to similar motions used to enjoy coming into this House and making the sort of speech which I am making now . However, I thought he was a fast learner. I know he does not like keeping secrets. I thought that after all that period sitting learning about how to run the House he might have decided he would have an extra week or two of sittings. I suggest that we do that instead of sitting late and calling on the staff, who so wonderfully serve us-even now they are taking down the interjections-being called on to work hard and stay in this place. For example, last night we had the Clerks at the table trying hard to keep their eyes open. It was in those circumstances that we had the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) telling us that we were not interested in the debate. If the Government likes to incite us by suggesting that we are not interested, then of course we will participate in the debate. We are prepared to co-operate. We believe the legislative program is paramount in the deliberations of this Parliament. We are not prepared to see the private members run over by a motion of this sort. We believe it is absolutely essential that there be whatever additional time is necessary for us to sit in order that there be proper deliberation on matters of this ilk. Therefore, the Opposition does not accept that the 11 o'clock rule should be suspended for the balance of this session. Indeed, the Opposition intends to oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We see here the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) moving a motion for us to sit night after night into the early hours of the morning. Only yesterday a letter was sent to all Australian Labor Party members. I will read the letter. It states 'Urgent' in great big letters and is addressed to all Government members of the House of Representatives. It says ' Extended Sitting, 30 May 1984'. This letter does not even mention the hours. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I indicated in the House that the House would sit tonight with a dinner break from 6.30 to 8 p.m. I would stress the need for all Government members, including Ministers, to be in the building prior to 8 p.m. to avoid a repetition of last night's lack of quorum.

I ask honourable members whether they know who signed the letter? The letter is signed Mick Young, Leader of the House. Here is the Minister wanting us to sit all night, day after day, yet he has to issue urgent letters to members of his own Party to come back into Parliament at 8 o'clock at night. Government members will not even come back at 8 o'clock. Yet, the Minister expects the Parliament to keep sitting. I watched honourable members on the Government benches last night. They were so tired that they could not even move their lips. This morning they were back in their offices sound asleep. There are only 11 Government members here now because they are all exhausted. I think most of the new Labor Party members of parliament must wonder what they have offered themselves for. They come in here and listen to the Minister at the table. When in opposition they used to criticise us for sitting one late night in three. They used to sit there agreeing with the honourable member who is now a Minister. He promised that Labor in government would never do that. The difference is that now the Government is doing it night after night. The Government will sit late all through next week. It has four or five doctors on its benches who are deeply concerned about the health of members on their side and members on this side. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is being sent home to bed at 8 o'clock at night because he cannot control himself in the House at Question Time. I am suggesting , Mr Speaker, that, if the Government has to issue urgent letters from the Leader of the House to Government members saying that they have to be back at 8 o'clock at night, it is absolutely ridiculous that we are expected to sit here through to 1 a.m. or 2 a.m. We sat until l o'clock the night before last and until 1.15 this morning, and it will be 2 o'clock, 3 o'clock or 4 o'clock next week. The Government is running this Parliament the same way as Joh Bjelke- Petersen runs the Parliament in Queensland and I have read the Labor Party's speeches about that. Therefore there is great inconsistency.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.
The bells having been rung-

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Is it a fact that Government Business could not proceed at 1.15 a.m., as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce was not in the Parliament?
—That is no point of order.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage to investment and employment as a result of the Government's apparent approval of a campaign of industrial action by the ACTU to gain superannuation for all employees within 18 months in addition to full wage indexation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government should be in no doubt whatever that in the business community there is a very great fear emanating from, firstly, the industrial action in the building industry to get under the guise of superannuation what was disallowed as a wage claim by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and, secondly, the announcement by the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions that there would be support by the ACTU for a superannuation claim on all employers on behalf of all employees within the next 18 months. This would obviously be in addition to full wage indexation and would be handled as an industrial matter, even though it is outside the jurisdiction of the industrial tribunals.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble began with the fact that the Arbitration Commission, in accordance with the principles agreed to by the ACTU and the Government in the prices and incomes accord, rejected part of the claim in the building industry. It has been made quite clear by building union officials that the so-called superannuation claim in that industry is to compensate them for what they lost in having that agreement ratified by the tribunal. In fact, on 22 November 1983 at page 728 of the Arbitration Commission transcript, Mr Clancy, on behalf of the Building Workers Industrial Union, stated:
. . . in the light of the disallowance of-
what was called the BIRP allowance-

the Building Industry Recoveries Procedure Allowance that there should now proceed a working party . . . to investigate the possibility of introduction of a national superannuation scheme for building workers . . .
At another hearing in the Commission on 27 February 1984, at page 3 of the transcript, Mr Cummins, representing the Builders Labourers Federation and appearing before Commissioner MacMullan said:

We are pursuing the $9 shortfall one way and blind Freddy can now see that the other building unions are doing the same. I can indicate that as late as noon today on the ABC 3LO program Mr Clancy indicated that he will be putting a scheme-a national superannuation scheme with the Government and A.C.T.U. support . And all that goes to underline the simple fact of our submission that why the double standards from the employer's point of view. There is $9 owed all around. We are pursuing it. The other unions are pursuing it in their own right as they see fit.

That leaves one in no doubt that the way in which the trade union movement sees it is that what was disallowed by the Arbitration Commission will be gained over the award and outside that Commission, not as an alleged claim-because that would clearly be in breach of the accord and clearly in breach of their written undertakings to the Arbitration Commission-but as a so-called superannuation scheme.

I have raised this matter in the House with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and also in other debates outside the House. In the last debate the Minister told the House that the claim for superannuation was a genuine one, although people in the industry as well as union leaders have made it quite clear that that is not so. It is money in lieu of rejection of the so-called BIRP allowance. The cost to the building industry alone is estimated at about $200m a year-not to mention, of course, the effects on the construction industry. Mr Tom McDonald of the BWIU has also admitted publicly that it would flow on to all other industries. I have mentioned in previous debates the effects of long service leave claims in the building industry. They have flowed on to other areas. Of course, the Minister has on his plate at the moment another problem concerning glass workers which has every prospect of flowing on. Clearly, the building industry union will be a stalking horse for the ACTU's recently announced campaign for superannuation for all within 18 months. That is the fear of industry and there is a belief that the Government is acquiescing in that campaign. Before I refer to what the Minister has said I quote from page 7 of the prices and incomes accord:
There must be continuous consultation and co-operation between the parties involved.
Government policy at all levels should be accommodating and supportive.

One would have thought that the Government would lead and the trade union movement would be accommodating and supportive of it. Certainly, from the newspaper reports there does not appear to have been the degree of consultation that one might have expected on this matter. But we have now a simple factual situation where the accord gives consumer price index adjustments automatically without the ACTU even mounting a substantial case. There is therefore plenty of time for the trade union movement to mount claims which are in fact wage claims, but which are mounted under another name. As it is outside the jurisdiction of the tribunal, I suppose technically it may not be in breach of the guidelines or the undertakings given to that tribunal. Of course, practically, it is a fundamental breach of the spirit of the accord.

The Government's decision to tax superannuation and its view of the assets test no doubt has stampeded activity by some trade unions, and the ACTU has decided to be in the vanguard of that action, without paying any heed to the effects on the economy. Now, presumably, the Government must be accommodating and supportive. Again, one must ask the old question: Who is leading? Is it the Government or is it the ACTU? The Minister has a chance today to indicate that point. Surely, the Government should be leading. But what is the Government doing to stop the flow on of the building industry claim? What action is the Government taking to lead on the issue and to assure the small and large employers-the investors of capital, whose investment and profits are needed to create more employment in Australia and increase our competitiveness-that they will not meet a crippling cost or go out of business next year?

On 22 May the Secretary of the ACTU made a statement and it just happens that on the same day, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 May, the ACTU advocate in the building industry case, Mr Garry Weaven, made it quite clear when he told the Arbitration Commission that the ACTU would bring back industrial action by building unions in support of achieving a building industry superannuation fund. So on 22 May the ACTU supported industrial action in respect of superannuation in the building industry and, of course, as I have stated before, the $9 spoken of became $11 and the ACTU has been co-ordinating the handling of that claim, even though Mr Gallagher said: 'Let no one be in any doubt that it is a wage claim'. The ACTU-Australian Labor Party prices and incomes accord, at page 25, says this about superannuation:

An immediate priority will be consideration of the possible role for a national superannuation scheme; more fundamental change may need to involve the creation of a specific fund into which workers could contribute for their own personal and family security.

There is no suggestion from the building unions that their members will make any such contribution. There has been a half-hearted suggestion, so it seems, from the ACTU that there might be a contribution. But that contribution, as one reads about it or hears of it, seems to be out of productivity wage claims to which the trade unions say they have been entitled since 1981, but which they are prepared to forgo.
