Let us remember that they have not been awarded them officially; anyone who understands the economy could legitimately say that whatever productivity improvement had been occurring in those years has already gone in satisfying wage demands; in any event, even if arithmetically they were to say that the so-called productivity improvement of about 4 per cent was appropriate, where does that leave a viable superannuation fund with an employee contribution? The employers' contribution would be so burdensome, for it to be a meaningful scheme, that it would finally put many employers out of business or oblige them to use the depreciation allowances and install more technology to replace people.

We will have a crisis situation if the business community, which is being begged by the Government to invest, is faced with a further on-cost. In fairness to the Minister-this is the point to which I want him to respond in particular- there was one report and one report only on 23 May, the day after the ACTU announcement. That was in the Australian. Under the heading 'National super plan not possible by end of 1985, says Willis', it states:

The Minister . . . said it was 'not at all possible or desirable to have a national superannuation scheme introduced in 1985 without adversely impacting on both the prices and incomes accord and the economy.
Mr Willis said it was the responsibility of the Government and the Arbitration Commission to ensure national superannuation did not destroy the wages system or the economy.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in rejecting the BIRP allowance made it abundantly clear that the accord could not work with full indexation and with these extra claims being granted. The Minister has often made those remarks too but the industry now fears that the Minister has approved the building industry claim and that he and the Government are tacitly supporting the demands by the ACTU for superannuation for all in the next 18 months. That same report states:
Mr Kelty also foreshadowed discussions with the Government on the possibility of trading the ACTU's productivity claim next year for superannuation coverage.

The employers not only know that productivity has been low but also believe that it has already gone in wage increases via the indexation system. As the report also indicates, Mr Kelty's superannuation announcement is apparently at odds with the statement by the ACTU President, Mr Dolan, who said that the ACTU would seek in its productivity claim to reduce working hours. The last part of this report-the Minister will certainly need to address himself to it-states:
Mr Willis said there was no reason why superannuation should be denied to half of the work force but added the anomaly could only be rectified in a gradual and orderly manner.
This would have 'some impact but not a large impact' on wage increases and the economy.

The situation is that we cannot afford it. The Minister is correct in what he is quoted as having said. It is a desirable end but not all things are affordable at once. On 22 May, the date of the ACTU announcement, I released a two-page Press release with a whole series of questions to the ACTU and to the Minister. No response at all has been made to that. I believe that that Press release, which raised very thoughtful and very fair questions, must be answered in detail by the Minister. If it is not, the business community, the investing community, will have no confidence in the Government's willingness or capacity to control the claims of the ACTU. On 23 May the Australian Financial Review in a splendid editorial titled 'Superannuation and the Accord' set out all of the economic reasons why we could not at this moment afford to have an increase of that magnitude. I quote some portions of that editorial:

After the tax cuts negotiations between the ACTU and the Federal Government, it looks as though the next major social wage issue to be pressed by the trade union movement will be extension of employer-funded superannuation schemes to the rest of the workforce.

In this context, the push in the building industry for a superannuation scheme funded by a contribution of $11 per week per employee by employers, is effectively the spearhead for a wider ACTU strategy of securing superannuation gains in 1985.
If this is to be an ACTU priority, then the first point which needs to be made is that any superannuation deal cannot be seen as a way of sidestepping the restraints of the prices and incomes accord.

The editorial goes on to set out what the costs would be. Indeed, it states that if a claim of $11 a week per person were granted across the board to industry the additional direct cost on business cash flow could be of the order of $1.7 billion to $2 billion a year. That is an incredible burden for Australian industry in the state in which it is now placed. I commend to the Minister all of that editorial, which makes great economic and social sense.

It must be clear to any thoughtful person that we cannot afford the following combination of outcomes: Low productivity, wage indexation, tax cuts, increased government services, increased employment and generous employer-funded superannuation for all. The ACTU leaders and the Federal Government must explain that to militant union leaders and to employees generally. The priorities of job security, retirement security or the maintenance of real wages must be determined. It is not possible to have all three in the foreseeable future. If superannuation is to become more widespread it will need to be funded by employees out of existing wages and the employer contribution will have to be regarded as a cost of a wage related character until both can be afforded when productivity improves.

It is the responsibility of the ACTU and the Government to run an education campaign so that employees may understand the nature and objectives of superannuation. This should not be the subject of an industrial claim. The education campaign should be fortified by the employers at the place of work. Unless these steps are taken the prospects of superannuation must be resisted by employers and rightfully so.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: — The wording of the matter of public importance which we are discussing is quite incorrect and misleading. Indeed, the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) is quite wrong in suggesting that the Government has endorsed a campaign of industrial action by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to gain superannuation for all within 18 months. He is also quite wrong in saying that the ACTU has said that it will conduct a campaign of that nature. Let me get down to what the ACTU has said is the situation as far as it is concerned in relation to superannuation. The ACTU, after its congress last year and the executive meeting earlier this year, published a document which referred in part to this matter. It pointed to various matters which concern the trade union movement regarding occupational superannuation. It pointed first to the need for adequate incomes in retirement. It noted the inequitable distribution of occupational superannuation in terms of both the numbers covered by it, referring to the fact that less than half of the work force is covered by occupational superannuation, the quality of coverage, some people having very good superannuation and others having very poor superannuation coverage in one form or another. It has also called for a national retirement package to try to redress the situation and has indicated that that package could take various forms. I wish to quote briefly from the document which I referred to called 'The Way Ahead', which was an ACTU special report from the executive meeting held from 19 to 23 March 1984. Under the heading 'National Retirement Package' it said:

SPEECH.PARA: In negotiating the national retirement package, the ACTU will advance the following propositions:
It further stated:
The means of providing retirement incomes to be based on either
(i) A three tiered system based on
(a) The improvement of existing occupational superannuation schemes, including a review of the taxation treatment of lump sum superannuation.
that is a matter on which there has since been much discussion with the ACTU-
(b) A national superannuation system which is either

A supplement to existing occupational superannuation and pension schemes; or A minimum to which all employees not in superannuation schemes or in schemes with benefits less than the minimum would be entitled
and
(c) a Government pension which would necessarily be subject to an effective means test
or
(ii) A two-tiered system based on
(a) The improvement in occupational superannuation . . . .
and
(b) A pension, which is not subject to any means test, to be funded on a supplementary basis by a levy. This in effect would be national superannuation.
There were two alternatives which the ACTU postulated as forming a possible basis for a national retirement package. It went on:

In line with our view that national productivity increases can be shared through other than increased real incomes, consideration be given to sharing such increases through the provision of genuine superannuation entitlements.

In other words, it is saying that as an alternative, in whole or in part, to national productivity increases being put into a wage increase, as is contemplated under the wage fixation principles established by the Commission last September-that there would be a productivity case in 1985 in which it would consider the level of real wages-there could be increases and improvements in superannuation benefits for workers rather than in real wages. That aspect seems largely to have been missed by the honourable member for Balaclava.

Subsequent to that executive meeting, on 21 May the Secretary of the ACTU made a speech which was referred to by the honourable member for Balaclava in moving this matter of public importance. That speech was reported in some parts of the Press as being a call for superannuation for all next year. Indeed, some newspapers in reporting that speech used that heading on their articles. In reporting the speech the Age newspaper used a heading of that type. That article reads:
The ACTU next year will begin a superannuation campaign on behalf of more than three million workers not covered by existing schemes.
The secretary of the ACTU, Mr Bill Kelty, yesterday foreshadowed the campaign, which would be based on an expected rise in national productivity of 4 per cent.
Mr Kelty said the campaign-which would cover about half the workforce-would be pursued in an orderly way and would not conflict the prices and incomes accord of the centralised wage-fixing system.
He said the ACTU would discuss the mechanics of presenting a productivity claim dealing with superannuation in meetings with the Federal Government.

Although the Secretary of the ACTU refers to a campaign, what he is talking about is discussing, in negotiations with the Government, the possibility of having a trade-off for a wage increase based on productivity instead of through an improvement in superannuation coverage and benefits. I believe that is an extremely important aspect to get thoroughly fixed in one's mind on this issue, and that is that the ACTU is not talking about some wild industrial campaign in which it intends next year to hammer every employer into the ground to get superannuation for all, but rather it is talking about negotiating with the Government as a means of obtaining next year a wide coverage in relation to superannuation by means of a productivity trade-off.

Let me say straight away that that proposal has various problems which I shall come to later. Nevertheless, that is the position it is putting forward. Of course, that does not mean that there could not also be some spread of occupational superannuation other than through that course of negotiation with the Government. That also is clear from the alternative paths to which I referred in the ACTU's document entitled 'The Way Ahead'. Clearly the ACTU is talking about an expansion of occupational superannuation, recognising that if that happens there has to be a trade-off for a real wage rise which would otherwise have been a possibility. I believe that that is tremendously important . It does not indicate an irresponsible attitude on the part of the ACTU. On the contrary, it indicated a realisation of the facts that it has to pursue this claim for wider coverage of superannuation so that all workers are entitled to have a decent retirement income. If it is to pursue that objective, it has to do it in a responsible way. In fact, that is what it is suggesting that it will do. There is no suggestion of a wild, irrational rush of claims, regardless of the effect on the economy, economic recovery, the prices and incomes accord, the national wage fixing principles or whatever.

Nowhere has it been said that the objective was necessarily superannuation for all in 1985. The ACTU said that it would commence a campaign of superannuation for all in 1985. It has not necesssarily said that it will achieve superannuation for all in 1985. Certainly without some national negotiations that would involve a trade-off of a real wage increase for productivity, there would be no chance of achieving the objective in one year. However, that is realised by the ACTU. It is wrong to say, as the honourable member for Balaclava said or as he implied, if he did not say it explicitly, in the terms of his matter of public importance, that all workers would be covered by superannuation in 1985. That has not been said by the Secretary of the ACTU, nor has it been said in any ACTU document that I have ever seen.

I come to the Government's view of occupational superannuation. The Government recognises that a large proportion-more than half-of the work force has no superannuation coverage. As I said, according to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, about 40 per cent of the work force are covered by some occupational superannuation and 60 per cent are not. The Government believes it is not reasonable, possible or fair to say to that 60 per cent of the work force that they have no entitlement, now or ever, to seek occupational superannuation coverage. The Government does not say at all that because those workers have not managed occupational superannuation coverage until now, under the wage-fixing principles that we are following occupational superannuation coverage, that they will have no entitlement to pursue it ever. It would be totally unreasonable if the Government were to say that. One has to bear in mind that in the 1970s in particular Australia went through a period when there was a spread of occupational superannuation schemes. It must be expected that as the economy becomes buoyant that process will recommence. It certainly went into hibernation during the recession but, with a return to economic recovery, we must expect that there will be a recommencement of the spread of occupational superannuation schemes. Some 40 per cent of the work force are already covered by such schemes; the other 60 per cent obviously will eye off such schemes and increasingly demand to be part of them.

The Government does not regard the pursuit of occupational superannuation as being outside the prices and incomes accord. Indeed, it is specifically mentioned in the accord. The honourable member for Balaclava was wrong in saying that the part of the accord that he quoted was the only part that mentions superannuation. It says also:
The objectives of social security policy are to . . . redress anomalies in the availability of occupational welfare such as superannuation benefits.

So it is specifically mentioned in the accord as being an element of that accord . The Government does not say that it is against the principles of the accord to pursue occupational superannuation; nor does it say that such pursuit is against the national wage fixing principles. I note in that regard-the honourable member for Balaclava omitted to do so-that it is not an industrial matter or a matter in relation to which the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission could make an award. Nevertheless, it does involve an increase in labour costs. The Government admits that. Obviously that is the case. If an employer on behalf of an employee makes contributions to a fund for superannuation, that adds to his labour costs. That has to be taken into account somewhere. The Government certainly agrees that that is the case. It cannot be expected that the funding of occupational superannuation will have no consequences whatever. Account must be taken of that . It seems to the Government that the obvious way in which to take that into account within the current principles is for the Commission to have regard to it in the context of a national productivity case.

Regardless of the negotiations mentioned by the ACTU, if there is a spread of occupational superannuation, when a national productivity case is heard-the first one will be heard in 1985 under the existing principles-the Commission, in considering what real wage increase it could give, would certainly in the Government's view be right in having regard to the spread of occupational superannuation in the period that was relevant to its considerations. The Government admits that. It certainly will assert that to the Commission. It has made that assertion to the Commission recently in the case involving the flow-on of the 4.1 per cent to the building workers. The Government said that that is the way in which the extension of occupational superannuation could be taken into account. Of course, the greater the spread of superannuation the smaller will be the wage rise granted in the productivity case next year. That is a fact . The ACTU recognises it. Indeed, it goes one step beyond that and says that it is prepared to negotiate for a spread of occupational superannuation, knowing that it would reduce any real wage increase that might otherwise have been possible.

I ask the House to note also that the occupational superannuation spread was substantial when the Opposition was in government. It is not something that has commenced only under this Government. In 1974, 32 per cent of the work force was covered, compared with 40 per cent in 1983. That increase in coverage occurred under centralised and decentralised wage systems. The Fraser Government never argued that the spread of such occupational superannuation was a cause of economic disaster and should be prevented. I never heard that Government put forward that argument in this House or before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Rather, it said that it supported the development of occupational superannuation.

This Government also supports the spread of occupational superannuation. As the honourable member for Balaclava mentioned, we supported it in the building industry, an area into which it is difficult to introduce superannuation on an individual employer basis. If it is to be introduced, it has to be done on an industry basis. Doing it in that way provides the prospect of finalising an agreement on industrial relations practices which is desperately needed in the industry. I have never seen an industry in as much of an industrial relations mess as is the building industry. The Government inherited the industry in that mess. I think there has been a distinct improvement in that industry since the Government has been in office, but I would be the first to admit that there are still some fairly wild elements in that industry which continue to cause disruption. That is a continuing problem.

One of the things that the Government must do to get the economy going properly , even better than it is at present, is to improve industrial relations in the building industry. One way in which we can do that is by tying up the superannuation scheme, including an industrial relations agreement which is the key basis on which the Government has supported the extension of superannuation in the building industry. It also has to be genuine superannuation and there must be an orderly extension of superannuation schemes after that. The ACTU has given us that assurance. In a telex to me it said:
. . . the ACTU reaffirms its commitment given to you verbally that
1. the proposed building industry superannuation scheme will not form the basis for flow-on of such schemes to other areas, and
2. the further development of occupational superannuation will proceed in a gradual and orderly manner.

That is a telex to me from Mr Bill Kelty, Secretary of the ACTU. The superannuation-productivity trade-off for 1985 has some difficulties. We will discuss those with the ACTU. I will not go through the problems involved but we will certainly discuss them. I applaud the ACTU-I do not denigrate it-for the responsible way in which it is going about the pursuit of the expansion of occupational superannuation in this country. It is doing so very much with an eye to the wage principles and economic recovery of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May, during a debate on the prices and incomes accord, I was prepared to give the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) the benefit of any doubt about his personal involvement in efforts to circumvent his Government's wage guidelines. Despite having an indisputable right on that occasion to respond to views expressed in the debate, the Minister chose not to answer. In particular, he failed to deny the widely- held belief that he has done more than any other to undermine his own Government 's wage guidelines. Today he has not chosen to deny his leading role in subverting that part of the Hawke Government's guidelines which include the words 'only in circumstances which could not have been foreseen at this date'- that is, the date the accord was agreed-'should increases in existing award allowances or service increments be created'.

SPEECH.PARA: Since soon after the Hawke Government's election in March last year, just 15 long months ago, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has been up to his armpits helping to devise and disguise schemes to get around the just quoted guidelines on allowances. The Minister played a personal and a leading part in defeating his own Government's guidelines and wage fixing principles in at least one major industry. He made mention of that in the remarks he has just concluded. He did that by masterminding an infamous device which became known as the building industry recovery procedures allowance. It is not to the Minister's credit that that artificial ploy was seen for what it was and rejected by an Anomalies Bench and a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; nor is it any credit to the Minister that on receiving that rebuff from the Commission to his behind-the-scenes plotting he promptly and publicly advocated the pursuance of an industry-funded superannuation scheme for building industry employees that was in effect to replace the failed building industry recovery procedures allowance claim.

What followed this advocacy of the Minister was all very predictable. Industrial disruption on building sites around Australia became the order of the day and is still the order of the day in support of the $11 superannuation claim , and the blame for that rests squarely with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Now we find that, whilst the building industry superannuation scheme was the brainchild of the Minister and until recently was confined to one industry, the building industry, the concept has been escalated to encompass all industry. That sad and sorry development is a direct consequence of the Minister's behind-the-scenes plotting and scheming, dating back to his connivance in developing the so-called package demanded by the Builders Labourers Federation and other building unions early last year. It was, and is, the act of a man who remains essentially a union advocate, not the work of a Minister in a government which lays claim to be able effectively to manage the nation's economy. It was the act of a union advocate and not the work of a Cabinet Minister who accepts the need to eliminate uncertainty that comes with the cost pressures that an industry-wide superannuation scheme will generate.

The economic insanity we talk of in this context is quite simply the work of an industrial advocate for the union movement, a man incidentally directed by another industrial advocate in the form of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Both the Prime Minister and the Minister have made the trade union movement agents of their Government. The Australian Council of Trade Unions is fast becoming no more and no less an arm of government under this Administration. Part of the price to be paid for this second and largely unwanted arm of government is ACTU domination of economic policy, and economic planning. One does not have to look too far for evidence of ACTU dictatorship in economic matters which were hitherto the sole prerogative of universally elected Australian governments. We need refer only to demands by the ACTU and seemingly accepted by the Government on the size and targeting of income tax cuts which will form part of the next Budget. In fact, the precedent-setting decision to divulge Budget information to the ACTU, and the ACTU alone, must rank as one of the all-time great sell-outs by any democratically elected government anywhere.

Not only is even-handed and firm leadership in industrial relations matters heavily discounted under this Minister and the Prime Minister, but also are confidential Budget information and figures being divulged to their union masters. What other Australian government could be so mindlessly coerced into meeting the outrageous demands of the unrepresentative few who comprise the ACTU executive? We all knew that the Government would have to pay the price of ACTU support sooner or later. The debt is obviously thought to be due and the first instalments are being demanded. The trouble is that those instalments will go on and on and no one, least of all the Government, seems to know the total price or even when the final payment will fall due.

Currently we have the ludicrous situation where the Hawke Government, through the Minister has asked the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to pay a claim to building workers who are in breach of the Government's own guidelines and the wage fixing principles that it has agreed with the Commission. In its submissions to the Commission on that matter, the Government has again shown its preparedness to yield on its own wage fixing principles. Despite being told by the Commission that building workers had breached wage fixing principles, this Government persists in supporting the payment of the 4.1 per cent national pay rise properly being withheld by the Commission. Given all that has happened in the process of breaking down the cornerstone of the Government's wages and incomes powers and policies and the Minister's unqualified support it seems for superannuation schemes, firstly, for the building industry and, latterly, for the whole of industry, all Australians will understand the concern we express in raising this matter of public importance. Of course we are concerned about the damage to investment and employment growth as a result of the Government's apparent approval of a campaign of industrial action by the ACTU to gain superannuation for all employees within 18 months in addition to full wage indexation.

The Minister referred to previous Liberal governments and their attitude to superannuation. It should be noted that, since the times of the early Menzies governments, encouragement has been given to employers in the private sector to adopt private superannuation schemes. They have grown and developed on actuarial advice employer by employer. What we do not subscribe to is the imposition of a scheme across the board by government edict. That is an entirely different matter. The adverse implications for employment and private sector investment are enormous. The expected industrial campaign by the ACTU in its almost inevitable attempt to force acceptance of a universal superannuation scheme will be economically debilitating in the extreme. Uncertainty will be magnified and economic recovery will be retarded as those in existing superannuation schemes ponder their position. For example, the 25 per cent of workers in the private sector who already take part in superannuation schemes want to know whether they will have to forgo a share of future productivity increases so that others may be superannuated at what promises to be considerable cost to them.

The Minister talks about trade-offs. What about the effect on the 25 per cent of people who already belong to a superannuation fund and who would, almost certainly, be excluded as a result of the negotiations he spoke of? Worst of all will be the consequences for private sector employment if the cost of a universal or near universal superannuation scheme becomes another superimposed on-cost along with payroll taxes, workers compensation insurance, public holiday loadings, annual leave and leave loadings which add anything from 40 per cent to 60 per cent to the gross wages payable by employers. That will be another crippling burden for industry and private employers to carry. It might very well prove to be too much of a burden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond in relation to the matter of public importance which has been put forward by the Opposition today. I am somewhat amazed that members of the Opposition have the hide even to come forward with such a matter of public importance, worded as it is. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has already pointed out that the statements made in it are incorrect and highlight the thick hides of members of the Opposition. The matter of public importance, in part, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The damage to investment and employment . . .

Anybody who has been watching what has been happening over the last seven years in Australia will realise that if anybody has damaged investment and employment it is the people sitting on the Opposition benches. Under their regime we saw unemployment skyrocket and investment fall through the floor. It was in a constant decline for most of the period they were in office. The confidence of private investment totally disappeared.

Since attaining office we have been able to turn around unemployment to such an extent that we have reached a stage now where some 225,000 jobs have been created, unemployment has dropped by 33,000, there is greater participation by people in the work force and, in the area of investment, a number of signs indicate that there is renewed confidence by private enterprise in the way Australia is going.

With this matter of public importance, members of the Opposition have, once again-as in so many other areas such as immigration and pensions-attempted to distort the quite reasonable stands being taken by organisations such as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government in an attempt to hype up some issue for which they can try to gain some credibility. In order to do so they have totally distorted the position of the ACTU: They have suggested that what the ACTU was about was an industrial campaign, industrial action. Any reasonable reading of the statements that have been made by the representatives of the ACTU make it quite clear that that is not the decision that was made. Let us take the statement that was made by Simon Crean on radio station 3LO. He was talking about putting superannuation on the agenda in the terms of the productivity cases which are to take place next year. Mr Kelty has made it quite clear that any movement in the superannuation area would be done in an orderly manner and, what is more, it would not threaten the prices and incomes accord or wage indexation.

As has been pointed out, it is very important to realise that there has been a constant trend of increasing involvement in superannuation by the whole of the work force. It is not as if there were not changes under the previous Administration. In fact, there has been somewhere near an 8 per cent increase in participation in superannuation across the board. Seventy per cent of works in particular industries are involved in a superannuation scheme. It is a fact of life that the most disadvantaged in relation to participation in superannuation schemes are those on low incomes, those in unskilled areas and women.

As has been pointed out by the ACTU and by the Minister, it is simply not good enough for members of the Opposition to be able to come into this chamber and say what we, as a government, should be doing and what the ACTU should be saying to those people who are disadvantaged, in particular the low income earners and the women. They are saying to 60 per cent of those in the work force: 'You have no entitlement and no right to believe that you should be able to participate in superannuation schemes'. The ACTU has said that what it is about in terms of its decision to highlight superannuation is that with any productivity case there is no reason to believe that the gains that workers are rightfully entitled to-this was recognised in the prices and incomes accord-should all be paid in the form of wage increases. There are other ways that the benefits of increased productivity can be received by workers. As the ACTU said, superannuation is one of those ways. It has said that it is raising superannuation in that context, there should be greater participation and that productivity gains should be shared and will flow on to those who are being disadvantaged.

The Minister has pointed out, both in interviews and in reports, that the Government is saying that as long as it is done in a reasonable, orderly manner, in a progressive way and still within the accord, the Government will not be opposing it. As he has quite rightly pointed out with the communiques that he received from the ACTU, the ACTU has given the assurance that that is in fact what it will do.

The reports that have been made in the media on the Minister's statements in relation to the decision by the ACTU make the Government's position quite clear and show that the stand being taken is a very reasonable one. What do members of the Opposition do? Once again, they distort the facts. As I said, it is typical of their current method of operation to take every issue, totally distort it, try to gain some credit and then not come forward with any alternative proposition. Members of the Opposition have spent some months developing their industrial relations policy. When they announced it they admitted that, if introduced, it would lead to industrial unrest. They are talking about the ACTU' s policy, which is not one of industrial unrest. They are talking about the performance of this Government. There have been drastic reductions in industrial disputation since we attained government and introduced our policies. They are saying that they have a better alternative because what they will introduce will cause industrial unrest! We have their previous record which has shown that they were incapable of managing the economy and that they had a disastrous impact on the work force. They are saying to the community and to industry that if they were re-elected they would ensure that there would be more industrial disputation because their policy is aimed to achieve that. I think that the public is quite capable of seeing through their absurd policy and also the absurdity of the matter of public importance.

There is no doubt, if we have a look at the economic indicators, that there is confidence in private industry. As I have stated investment and employment are increasing and unemployment is decreasing. The gross domestic product is likely to increase by about 6 per cent between 1982-83. We are seeing the participation by the trade union movement, under the auspices of the ACTU, in ensuring that it observes the accord. The policy that it has come out with in relation to superannuation is one which is quite reasonable and falls within the expectation of the accord. Given that we have all that, the public will be able to see that the Opposition's matter of public importance is absolutely absurd when compared with its record.

As I have said, those who are most disadvantaged by the superannuation scheme are the low income earners and women. Those are the people in the greatest need for superannuation coverage. Those are the people who have the least capacity, during their working lives, to be able to set aside enough assets to ensure that they have a reasonable retirement wage. The ACTU should be applauded for setting out to try to redress the disadvantages that those people are suffering rather than the Opposition coming into this chamber and attempting to denigrate the ACTU for taking a very positive stand in relation to improving the working conditions of the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has now expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
The Bill.
Question put:
That the amendment (Mr McVeigh's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reiterate one point that I made earlier today . The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said that he did not have time to refer to it. Proposed new section 30 states that there will be two annual general meetings of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation; one for livestock producers and one for exporters and processors. As proposed in the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill, if the annual general meetings wish to pass a vote of no confidence in the Chairman of the Corporation it will require a 75 per cent majority of both annual general meetings. I pointed out to the Minister earlier that I think in practice such a situation could almost never occur even though there may be very valid grounds for wishing to pass a vote of no confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions also apply in reverse should the Corporation wish to raise levies. In other words, both meetings would have to vote by a 75 per cent majority to refuse to increase those levies. In practice I do not think it would ever be possible to get that system working. I draw this to the attention of the Minister and I hope that he will comment. In practice I think such a system is unworkable and would weaken the Meat and Livestock Corporation because it would virtually take away the opportunity for the annual general meeting to carry out that function should it in the unlikely situation ever have to do it.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY POLICY COUNCIL BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'the House declines to give the bill a second reading as it is of opinion that the establishment of a statutory authority for this purpose is unnecessary and that the proposed functions of the Council should be carried out by agreement between the interested parties, provision for which should be included in existing legislation'.

Notice of this amendment was given by the honourable member for Darling Downs ( Mr McVeigh), the shadow Minister for Primary Industry. He has had to attend a long-standing engagement and therefore I have moved the amendment. The reasons for moving this amendment were canvassed during the general second reading debate.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has said, we have partially covered this matter in the more general debate but I think it is necessary to give the reasons why the Government rejects this amendment. First of all, as I have already said, this is not another quango, an additional statutory marketing authority. The Government is eliminating three statutory authorities and even counting the new Statutory Selection Committee it is still a reduction of one. Of course honourable members opposite have made their usual disparaging remarks about public servants. The public servants from my Department who will be associated with the Livestock Industry Policy Council are people known to me, particularly one. They are excellent public servants. They have a detailed knowledge of the meat industry and there are no fears on my part on that account.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be some confusion in the minds of honourable members opposite about whether or not there is a need for the Policy Council to be in a statutory form. The Policy Council will be more than just an advisory committee; it will formally assume a function now vested in the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. I have given the reasons for making the AMLC a more constructive, active marketing organisation and the Government is trying to move the politics of the industry-the agro-politics, the general politics-into this Policy Council . So we are putting the power which is now vested in the AMLC into the Policy Council and that power is to prepare reports and formulate plans on matters affecting the meat and livestock industry for consideration by the Minister. Thus an existing function is being transferred from one statutory body to another. Without statutory obligations and accountability there could be no confidence that a body which was set up would carry out the work expected of it, especially given a similar interest to those represented on the Council and the need for reaching agreement.

There were other comments in the more general debate about the Policy Council and I would like briefly to canvass them. As I said in my concluding remarks in the cognate debate, one of the criticisms or views was centred on the number of meetings held each year. It is expected that the Council would wish to meet more than four times in the first calendar year of its operation. Six meetings are planned in its first year of operation. In any case the chairman has the power to convene such meetings as he thinks necessary. If honourable members read the legislation carefully they will see that any six members of the Council can request further meetings of the Council in writing.

In respect of the biennial conference the Policy Council is required to hold a conference at least once every two years. This is realistic as industry-wide conferences of a worthwhile nature take time to organise and to prepare background papers for it. I point to the very constructive outcome of the grains conference some years ago. It took a while to get that conference organised but it was a very effective conference in terms of the wheat industry indeed. It is envisaged that there will be a very wide opportunity for members of the industry to attend the biennial conference. Voting rights at the conference is a matter for the Policy Council itself to decide as the conference organiser. Voting on most matters may not be required because the conference is primarily an exchange of views from industry sectors so that they can focus on the issues. It is envisaged that conference views should not be binding on policy councils. In that way we will get a more effective discussion. The Government totally rejects the view of the Opposition that the Council is just another quango. The Council is inherent and intrinsic to the legislation and to the approach we are taking with this most important package of Bills of reform of the Australian meat and livestock industry.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Lloyd's amendment) stand part of the question.
