TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill 1984 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering both measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I understand that the principal Opposition speaker on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1984 and the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill 1984 is to be the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), so I will leave him to address the more substantial part of the legislation. As he will inform the House, the coalition does not oppose either of these Bills although, as he will explain in detail, it holds very serious reservations about them. The honourable member for Gwydir will talk in some detail about the problems they will create.

SPEECH.PARA: The area I would like to talk about in particular is how this legislation affects the people of Tasmania. I should explain to the House that liquefied petroleum gas is a very important energy form in Tasmania. In fact, its importance to that State cannot be overemphasised. The reason it is so important is that, unlike all the mainland States of Australia, there is no natural gas in Tasmania. Because of the special nature of the Tasmanian market-a very small market-and the fact that there are no gas or oil fields which are likely to be tapped for that market, it is very unlikely in the foreseeable future that, even if gas fields were found adjacent to the Tasmanian coast, they could never be developed for the use of the Tasmanian community. So Tasmania has no natural gas . We have no coal to speak of. Although there are some deposits which are being earmarked around the State, they will almost certainly have to be used for any power scheme involving the thermal generation of electricity, if that is the course the Tasmanian Government finally chooses to take. Finally, and most unfortunately, because of decisions taken by the Hawke Government to deny to Tasmanians the ability to use Tasmania's dams and the hydro-electric potential which could have been developed by the Gordon below Franklin dam scheme the potential for hydro-electricity development has been considerably shortened. What it boils down to is the fact that Tasmanian consumers who wish to use energy have the choice of electricity or LP gas, either in the form of household cylinders or, in the case of Launceston, LP gas which is reticulated to a number of houses and other users.

The users are very widespread. For example, they include a number of hotels, snack bars and restaurants. So the use of LP gas is terribly important for our tourism industry, which is one of the key industries in the State. It is also used by industry, both large and small, for the raising of steam and so forth and thus its use is a very important component of industry and its costs. It is used also by householders, amongst whom are a great number of pensioners who are very hard pressed to be able to pay for it. I will come to that in a few moments .

The problem is that users of LP gas, have been very hard hit because of the price that they have to pay. There are several reasons for this high cost. I will pinpoint three: Firstly, the Federal Government's unfair manipulation of the parity pricing policy; secondly, the very large excise tax which the Federal Government levies on LP gas; and, thirdly, the very high cost of freight in bringing that LP gas across Bass Strait.

First I will deal with the manipulation of the parity pricing policy. The Government stuck very rigidly to the existing price mechanisms that were put in place by the previous Government. This means, if we go back to 1 July 1983, that it has stuck to this policy even though it took the price of LPG out of line with other fuel and like commodities. This had the direct result of increasing by 87 per cent the net price paid by those people who used LPG. It went from $ 120.15 to $224.44 a tonne. Of course, 1 January 1984 was another point when a determination had to be made by the Government in pursuing its parity pricing policy. In this case the Government did not follow the existing price setting mechanisms. If it had, the wholesale price of gas which was then $304.44 a tonne -or an effective $224.44 a tonne after subsidy was taken off-would have been brought down to slightly below the CPI indexed level; that is, it would have been brought down to $254 a tonne including the subsidy. Instead, the Government left the price at $304.44 wholesale or $224.44 after subsidy. This meant that the producers of naturally occurring gas and those who were producing it in the refineries benefited by selling into our local markets at a price which was $50 a tonne higher than they could have obtained on the export market. That, of course, provided a windfall profit for them at the expense of all other Australian LPG consumers, and that is despite the fact that this country is bubbling over with gas in the West and in the Bass Strait oil and gas fields. We have a superabundance of it. As the honourable member for Gwydir will point out, we produce several million tonnes of gas but only consume 500,000 tonnes here.

The Government levies a large excise tax. The honourable member for Gwydir will point this out, so I will do no more than emphasise that point. The Government, in a full year, using the new excise-as we all know it is now indexed-will get $ 1.2m in a full year and for this year it will get $600,000. So the Government takes a hefty whack from the people who use LP gas and pops it into its coffers. The particular problem of Tasmania is the freight component. All consumers in Tasmania must pay the cost of getting the LPG across Bass Strait. That is a costly factor in the price because of the very low volume which the State uses. The item of LP gas is not included in freight equalisation-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are going to get rid of that scheme anyway.

—So there is no allowance through that scheme to equalise the cost of the freight-a cost which applies in moving it around any other mainland State. As the honourable member for Braddon said, most Tasmanian members are looking very anxiously at the work that the Inter-State Commission is doing on freight equalisation. We all hope very strongly that that Inter-State Commission will present its report to the Government in time for everybody to see what the Government may propose to do before it calls an early election.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the cost of freight of LPG. It is costly, first of all, to transport it across the Strait because of the low volume that we use, and secondly, it is not included in freight equalisation so it does not accrue any special subsidies through that scheme. But an even more wretched position is raised, one which not only I but all of my colleagues find obnoxious-that is, when our ship lines up in the Bass Strait fields to take on LP gas, it takes its chance behind all the other international tankers that are waiting to get their loads to take to places like Japan and other places where we sell the LP gas. Those ships, in taking their place in the queue behind international shipping, accrue demurrage, sometimes at quite high cost. Those costs of demurrage are then added to the cost paid by Australian consumers in Tasmania because it is added to the freight costs of getting it across Bass Strait. If that is not adding insult to injury, I do not know what is. Tasmanians are forced to pay more for their gas because in loading gas foreign ships have priority over our ships. That is one situation which must be urgently rectified.

What is the effect of all these factors? As I said, despite the fact that Australia is endowed with vast quantities of natural gas, Tasmanians are being denied reasonably priced access to these resources. They are resources which should be shared equally and fairly among all Australians. But Tasmanians are missing out. I will cite some figures. A Tasmanian householder in Launceston using liquefied petroleum gas pays $35.40 for an average household cylinder. In Melbourne, the same cylinder can be purchased for as little as $23.77; in Echuca , the price is $28; if it is bought from Henderson's gas it will cost $26; in Wodonga it costs $26.50; in Bairnsdale, $29; in Mildura, $30.50. If it is bought from the Gas and Fuel Corporation in Melbourne it will cost $27. The average price of Victorian LPG is $27.50. I compare that with the figure paid by the poor Tasmanian consumer. As I mentioned before, it affects a wide cross-section of the community, including pensioners. They have to pay $35.40 for that same cylinder of Australian gas which, as I say, and which all Tasmanians say, should be shared equally and fairly among all of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no need at all.
—I refer to another example, a comparison between electricity and LPG prices to domestic consumers.
—I suggest to the honourable member for Braddon that the honourable member for Bass does not need any help.

—I do not mind receiving help from him, Madam Deputy Speaker. I refer to a table issued by the Australian Gas Association in a document entitled 'A Proposal for Wholesale Prices for LPG in Australia'. It gives figures for September. In Tasmania we pay, effectively, $2.90 to $3.28 for a megajoule of fuel for cooking. For space heating, the figures are $2.07 to $2.34 a megajoule. That compares with the figures for South Australia of $2.40 to $2.94 for cooking fuel and $1.71 to $2.10 for hot water. I repeat: The figure for space heating in South Australia is $1.71 to $2.10 a megajoule compared with $2.07 to $2.34 in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: That is another example of how Tasmanians are being slugged compared with their counterparts on the mainland. A Tasmanian family on a reticulated gas supply pays at least twice to three times the amount paid by a Melbourne family using natural gas. Tasmanian commercial and industrial users who pay high prices for their gas are penalised in trying to compete with mainland enterprises because their costs are considerably higher than those paid by industry users on the mainland. The crowning insult is that a Japanese housewife boiling a billy in Tokyo pays less for her gas than do those housewives who might be trying to do the same thing in Launceston.

The facts are these: Tasmania and Tasmanians are a part of Australia and we deserve a fairer deal. Given the huge amount of revenue collected by the Government through taxes on gas and given that Tasmania uses only a fraction of one per cent of the gas used in Australia-that is calculated to be 20,000 tonnes out of 500,000 tonnes-the Federal Government has to act to alleviate this unfair problem. The Federal gas subsidy of $20.31 per tonne should be increased for Tasmania to compensate for Bass Strait freight charges. The subsidy should be raised for Tasmanian users so that they pay no more than the average paid by Australian users, which is presently about $28 per average cylinder. This would result in a fair reduction of $5 to $7 per cylinder for Tasmanian householders. The cost to Canberra of providing this help would be absolutely trifling.

It is very interesting to go back to see what the then Opposition spokesman on energy, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), had to say about it. On 21 September, as recorded in Hansard, he has this to say about the question of subsidies:
This decision-
that is, to have the $80 subsidy-
has the full support of the Opposition, as liquefied petroleum gas has become an important energy source in many parts of rural and provincial Australia. Any attempt to remove the subsidy-
boy, is this hollow when one thinks about it-
. . . without notification and without adequate phasing-out provisions would not receive the support of the Australian Labor Party.
We do not believe the consumers who receive the subsidy should be significantly disadvantaged in terms of energy costs relative to consumers in the cities.
I quote that again-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The honourable member for Blaxland, now the Treasurer. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe the consumers who receive the subsidy should be significantly disadvantaged in terms of energy costs relative to consumers in cities.

I remind the House that Tasmanian householders are one example but that all other commercial and industrial users are likewise disadvantaged. A householder in Tasmania pays $35 to $36 for a household cylinder. In Victoria the average price is $28 per cylinder and it can be obtained for as little as $23 in Melbourne. That is what the honourable member for Blaxland had to say. There is a clear case here of the whole of Tasmania being disadvantaged compared to mainland cities or, in fact, mainland country areas. Then he went on:

It was the disadvantaged position that these consumers were in that led to the introduction of the subsidy . . . It is only fair that the people in these areas receive some assistance to narrow the gap between their costs and the costs which their city counterparts bear when it comes to the price of energy in this form.

All we ask now is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) put his mouth and his hands where they were back in September 1982 and that he recognise that there is indeed now a grave disadvantage in Tasmania. In fact, Tasmania is once again being left in the cold when it comes to the fair and equitable sharing of Australia's gas resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —All those promises!

—The honourable member should look at some of the things he promised. I hope his electorate is remembering what he said and has failed to deliver. We have been denied the benefits of being able to use our own cheap hydro- electricity and now we are being slammed for using the only alternative left to us, gas. Subsidies are not always palatable but in this case both sides have accepted that subsidies are required. I think that all parties should now go further and recognise that Tasmania has a special position. It is a special position, and that it should be recognised. It is a special position that can be easily recognised out of the vast amount of money which the Government collects in revenue by way of excise. The easy way of remedying the situation is to provide a subsidy for the freight cost of getting LPG across Bass Strait. A subsidy could be applied so that any user in Tasmania, using the criterion of the householder, pays no more than the average user in Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman). It was interesting to hear some of the selective socialist principles which he espoused, seeing he is a member of the Liberal Party, in this chamber tonight. As I said, it is a pleasure to follow him. I am delighted that he has changed his views over the years on the use of liquefied petroleum gas. I remind the House that when the honourable member for Bass was the Minister for National Development and Energy he tried to convince the New South Wales local government gas industry that LPG was indeed a premium fuel which was available only for automotive use and was not to be burned or wasted away on kitchen stoves. I was pleased to hear some of his remarks tonight in the course of the debate on the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also interesting to look back at some of the other comments that have been made over the years by members of the Liberal and National parties. Interestingly, the former Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, stated in Parliament on 28 February 1980 that he thought it was 'in the best long term interests of Australia if people can move to other types of energy'. He went on further to state that people ought to recognise that if they could move on to electricity instead of LPG, in the long term that was in their interests both economically and nationally. It was a pleasure, then, to hear the views of the Liberal Party. It could be interesting to hear the National Party's views, to see whether they have moderated to some extent.

My interest in this matter arises out of my involvement for five years as a member of the Bathurst City Council and my interest in energy matters in the Bathurst area. For four of the five years that I was on the Council I represented New South Wales local government on the Gas Advisory Committee of New South Wales and for two years I had the privilege to serve as the Deputy Chairman of that body. One of the pleasing aspects of the last 12 months in government has been the fact that we have had a Minister who I believe has been very approachable. Some of my New South Wales and Victorian colleagues, particularly the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), who will be speaking later in the debate, have found that Senator Walsh as Minister for Resources and Energy has indeed been a very approachable person as honourable members from rural and provincial areas have tried to put over a very substantial case for a realistic position on the pricing of liquefied petroleum gas.

As I have indicated, my interest arises principally because of my concern for the New South Wales local government gas industry. In the context of this very important Bill it is important to reflect upon what I believe are the special characteristics of local government LPG distribution in New South Wales, as we have heard some of the special characteristics of LPG distribution in Tasmania. In New South Wales since the 1960s a large number of town gas utilities have converted their gas works from the manufacture of gas from coal to the utilisation of either petroleum feedstocks, usually LPG, or the direct reticulation of natural gas. The changeover by Municipal Gas Works took place over a very short period. Indeed, it was encouraged to do so by the liquid fuels industry.

In the case where LPG is processed to produce a gas which can be utilised by a town gas reticulation system, two major types of production plants are used: First of all, a reforming plant where LPG is used as a feedstock and is processed in association with steam and, secondly, a plant where LPG propane is mixed with air in controlled proportions to produce tempered LPG. The development of oil refining in Australia led to a local supply source of LPG, a very substantial supply source, as the honourable member for Bass has indicated, and a large scale distribution, both in bulk and in bottles, began throughout Australia in 1958. From that date until the price escalation in the 1970s that followed from the oil crises of that decade, LPG was considered to be the sawdust of the refining process-somewhat of a nuisance, as far as the oil companies were concerned, but great if one could get a few extra dollars for it. Otherwise, the easiest method of disposal for surplus LPG, as most people who are interested in the subject would be only too well aware, was to burn it off at the refinery.

The local government industry has gone through tremendous traumas over the years because of the difficulties associated with the pricing of LPG. I believe that since these new measures were announced there has been a general acceptance -indeed, a willingness-to embrace the new measures by the local government gas distribution system in New South Wales, something with which I am familiar. It is important to reflect upon those measures this evening in the debate. From 28 March this year the basic wholesale price of LPG was set at the export parity price for Bass Strait propane operating on 1 March this year. The new export parity price of $244.75 represents a reduction of $60 a tonne on the wholesale price of LPG operating prior to 28 March.

In addition to the new parity price arrangement, changes have been made to the pricing formula, with the intention of improving the stability of LPG prices. This situation is to be achieved by limiting increases in the wholesale price of LPG to a level not exceeding the increase in the fuel and light component of the consumer price index over a six month period and averaging the export parity price on a monthly cumulative basis beginning on 1 April this year. A major objective of these changes is the avoidance of wholesale LPG price rises similar to the 43 per cent increase that occurred during the 12 months ending 1 January 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disastrous.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Bendigo says, it was a disastrous situation. The new pricing arrangements represent an attempt by the Federal Government to improve a number of difficulties associated with the sale and distribution of LPG which have primarily resulted from the instability and level of LPG prices. As a result of the new arrangements two important situations arise. firstly, unsubsidised consumers, such as feed stock and automotive consumers, receive a significant reduction in the price of LPG as a direct result of the reduction in the export parity price of $60 a tonne to the current level of $244.75 a tonne. This reduction in price represents an important reduction in costs to a sector which represents approximately 40 per cent of total LPG consumers throughout Australia. For example, this reduction in the wholesale price of LPG represents a reduction of approximately 3c a litre in the cost of automotive LPG.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, a reduction in the degree of price instability also represents a positive influence on both consumers and certain LPG distributors, particularly local government distributors in New South Wales. In the case of consumers, it is important that the capital investment involved with conversion from other fossil fuels be accompanied by a situation where operating costs are readily able to be calculated. If the situation which occurred in the past where fluctuation in the wholesale price of up to 43 per cent in a 12 month period were allowed to continue, the viability of both conversion and continued use of LPG could in some cases by threatened. Problems of a serious nature also arose for local government LPG distributors as a result of unstable prices. Local government distributors currently purchase LPG at the unsubsidised price of $244 .75 a tonne. Upon sale to the consumer the subsidy of $20.31 is paid by State governments to local government distributors, which in turn receive a grant from the Federal Government. The grant paid by the Federal government reimburses the States for the subsidy payments made to local government LPG distributors.

The major problem suffered by local government distributors has revolved around the budgetary problems associated with volatile LPG prices. Unstable LPG prices represent a situation which adversely affects the level of local goverment budgeting and administrative efficiency. However, the new pricing and subsidy arrangements will assist in reducing volatility in the price of LPG supplied to local government distributors. This will assist local governments to set the LPG retail price with increased accuracy when calculating the Budget estimates which in New South Wales usually commence in September each year. The accuracy with which local governments set the retail LPG rate is important because of the administrative and public relations value of reducing the frequency with which LPG retail prices change.

Another factor which also enhances the efficiency of the budgetary process is the alteration by the Federal Government of the six monthly LPG adjustment dates to the beginning of October and April. The October date was selected following Federal Government consultations with local government representatives so that, as I mentioned previously, the new price level could be considered in formulating the Budget estimates beginning in September.

It was my pleasure early in March of this year to lead to the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) a deputation from the New South Wales Local Government Gas Advisory Committee, a committee that is ably led by my colleague and friend, Alderman Gordon Ravell from the Shoalhaven City Council. I take this opportunity to pay a great tribute to the work of the New South Wales Local Government Gas Advisory Committee and for its very positive support of the initiatives taken by the Federal Government. I take this opportunity also of thanking that Committee for affording me the privilege of delivering the key note address at its annual conference in Bega a few weeks ago.

Without taking too much of the time of the House this evening, I wish to summarise the important points that I think need to be stressed about the new policy that is implicit in the Bill before the House. Firstly, domestic LPG prices will be made more stable and more predictable. Big price rises and rapid price fluctuations of the past will be eliminated. Such price fluctuations have caused consumer distress and have not been conducive to rational decisions on domestic LPG consumption. Secondly, future LPG price rises cannot exceed changes in the fuel and light component of the consumer price index. In other words, the real price of LPG to subsidised consumers will not rise under the new arrangements and the wholesale price to subsidised consumers will remain unchanged from 1 July 1983 to 30 September 1984. Thirdly, as far as Local Government is concerned-that is my interest in this matter-its efforts to convince the Government of the timing of price adjustments were obviously successful. I pay tribute again to Senator Walsh for heeding those representations. Consequently, such adjustments will now occur in the autumn and spring, rather than in the extremes of summer and winter.

Despite some industry criticism about the starting point operating with the present subsidised price, the new policy has been very well received. It was enthusiastically received by the annual conference of the New South Wales Local Government Gas Advisory Committee. The Australian Gas Association, in a media release following the announcement, said this:
. . . now that the decision has been made, the industry will make the best of the situation and will continue to provide top quality service to its consumers at lowest possible prices.

This Bill presents an opportunity to ensure that a realistic pricing regime for liquefied petroleum gas remains in operation until March 1987, at which time the policy comes up for review. I believe the new proposal is a substantial improvement on the existing policy. As the honourable member for Bass acknowledged, people generally do not like subsidies. I assure honourable members that the New South Wales local government gas industry is keen to move away from the subsidy arrangements. However, quite obviously extreme escalations in prices occurred over a short period. I give all credit to the former Government for taking the initiative in 1981 in relation to the $80 a tonne subsidy. The industry would be happy to move away from the subsidy arrangements. It sees in the present proposal an opportunity to put in place a policy that will be acceptable to it as a distributor and to consumers who, after all, have to pay in the end. I congratulate the Minister for Resources and Energy on his initiatives. I commend the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties do not oppose either of these Bills, although we hold serious reservations about the approach the Government has taken in framing the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill, to which I will refer shortly. We welcome the move to correct an anomaly resulting from the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1983. This legislation requires that the new excise duty rates calculated from changes to the consumer price index be rounded to the nearest decimal point. Increases in excise beyond the true level imposed by the change in the CPI have been imposed when the excise figure has to be rounded upwards. In the case of the brewing industry, for instance, the anomaly cost a total of $20m in February of this year. At a time when cost pressures are closing in on the profit margins of many Australian industries, such anomalies as this need to be identified and removed.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two other aspects of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. A standing provision will be inserted in the principal Act covering the imposition and application provisions which are normally included in Bills amending the Schedule to the Act. It also enacts the Excise Tariff Proposals (No. 1) 1984 which alters the excise duty rate on liquefied petroleum gas from 1 January this year. The LPG excise will rise from $48.57 per kilolitre to $49.23 per kilolitre . It follows the Government's policy announcement on 19 December last year and will result in an increase of $600,000 in Government revenue this year and $1.2m in a full year.

The other Bill before the House seeks to amend the Liquefied Petroleum Gas ( Grants) Act 1980 to extend the subsidy scheme to 31 March 1987, although the subsidy will be in a form different from that set out from the original legislation introduced by the Liberal-National Party Government. The Bill has two aims: First, to set a new pricing formula for LPG which places major emphasis on stability of prices rather than parity with import or export prices and will over time ensure that the domestic price of LPG falls below the export parity price; and, secondly, to alter the existing Government subsidy arrangements for LPG by, first, immediately reducing the subsidy from $80 per tonne to $20.31 per tonne and, secondly, setting in place a mechanism that will reduce and eventually eliminate that subsidy. The legislation shifts the funding of a subsidy on LPG away from the Government and on to producers, using price control as a mechanism for forcing producers to subsidise consumers.

Although honourable members on this side of the House will not be opposing the passage of legislation, we hold considerable reservations about the way in which the subsidy scheme has been fiddled. The handling of the LPG pricing and subsidy arrangement smacks of a political sleight of hand we have come to expect from this Government. A decision on the fate of the $80 a tonne subsidy should have been made public well in advance of the expiry of the former scheme on 31 March this year, but it was not. We well might ask why. The Government's decision to cut the subsidy by 75 per cent did not become public until Saturday afternoon, 24 March, the day voters in New South Wales went to the polls; and the timing of the announcement was no coincidence. The Government simply did not have the courage to reveal its gutting of the subsidy scheme earlier because it knew that there would be a backlash from gas consumers in New South Wales and people like the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), especially those in country areas who depend so heavily on this fuel. So, the Federal Labor Government waited until the news would be too late to affect the outcome of the New South Wales election.

In a statement on 23 March, the eve of the New South Wales poll, I made it clear that the Federal Government was playing a cynical brand of politics in holding back its decision on the subsidy's future. I said that there were 500, 000 users of LPG, most of whom were in rural areas, who had been left in the dark over the subsidy's future, even though the scheme was due to expire in less than a week. I said at the time that it would be despicable if the Hawke Government was timing its decision in such a way as to minimise any political backlash should it tamper with this subsidy. With hindsight this is the only conclusion we can draw. The original LPG pricing mechanism announced on 8 April 1980 set the price of LPG equal to either export parity price or the January 1980 price of $205 per tonne indexed by the percentage change in the price of indigenous crude oil, whichever was the lower. This led to the price of LPG fluctuating roughly in line with movements in world prices of gas and oil. Under this arrangement the Labor Government would have been expected to approve a cut of around $50 a tonne in January this year, in line with the reduction of crude oil prices to take into account the changed value of the Australian dollar. It failed to do so. This Government chose to keep the price of LPG artificially high for three months until the expiry of the original subsidy scheme on 31 March this year.

The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) might well be dubbed the 'Six Million Dollar Man', because that is how much the consuming public would have saved had the Government stuck to the guidelines in the original legislation. What he succeeded in doing on behalf of his Government was to squeeze out of the consumers no less than $6m. The Government announced the slashing of this subsidy, a subsidy which applied to around 60 per cent of all LPG sold in Australia and in particular to the people of rural Australia, with the grand statement that no one would pay more and that some consumers might pay less than the current price. What it simply failed to say is that consumers were eligible for a price cut of that magnitude three months earlier. They saw nothing of the $6m to which they were fully entitled. They have in short been ripped off by a fiddle which the Government had hoped would quietly go unnoticed . The liquefied petroleum gas consumers know it. The people in the country know it.

While the Government has been hiding behind a mask of concern for these people, it has been denying them a price cut which was rightfully theirs. It has made fools of many members of the Government, members of the Australian Labor Party. I know that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) in good faith made a pledge on behalf of the Labor Party prior to the last election, saying that the ALP was committed to at least a three year extension of the $80 a tonne Federal subsidy. I would not blame him; it has been a fiddle undertaken by the Minister and by the Government to squeeze out of consumers $6m at the expense of people mostly living in country areas. The business editor of the Age newspaper, Mr Terry McCrann, made this clear in a review published on 27 March when he said that the Minister announced:
. . . that his new LPG pricing policy would mean that 'many consumers will pay less and that no consumers will pay more than they do under existing arrangements'.

He continued by saying: 'As a matter of objective fact the comment was inerringly accurate. However, the statement failed to mention that if those existing arrangements had been properly followed on 1 January all-repeat, all- consumers would have paid substantially less for their LPG for the last three months'. The Government should have had the courage to introduce a $50 a tonne price cut on 1 January and then accept full responsibility for a 75 per cent cut to the subsidy three months later, with the effect of raising the price by about $60 a tonne. I quote the same article in the Age: 'These consumers will be excused if they digest the generosity of the Government with a considerable helping of salt'.

The Government has claimed that its refusal to pass on the January price cut was 'in the interests of price stability'. But whatever justification it may claim for holding up the price for those consumers subject to the subsidy, the reality is that the hold-up was solely to mask the subsidy's pending demise. There is no credible reason why the unsubsidised sector of the market was not given the $50 a tonne cut in January of this year. And there is no credible reason why the subsidised consumers were denied for three months the benefits of a price cut that was rightfully theirs.

I turn to a further aspect of this legislation before the House which also points up the Government's swindle of LP gas consumers. I refer to the revised pricing mechanism, which the Minister has hailed as a source of price stability in the future. We should closely examine how this stability will be achieved, and at whose expense. The Government has set a March 1984 price of LPG at the export parity price ruling at that time. Every six months the price will be adjusted on the basis of the average of the monthly export parity prices from 1 April 1984 to the month preceding the new price date.

The increases in the wholesale price resulting from increases in parity prices when they occur are not allowed to exceed the increases in the fuel and light component of the CPI for the six months prior to the adjustment date. This will tend to smooth out fluctuations in price as the Government claims-there is no doubt about this-but it is a double-edged sword because in a situation of falling prices, as we have experienced over the last 12 months, the price will be held artificially high. I would agree that many consumers will probably benefit in the long term if the rules are not changed again because, in essence, this mechanism limits the rise in the domestic wholesale price of LPG to the lower of the increase in the world parity price or the increase in the fuel and light component of the CPI in the immediately preceding six months period. As the rises are non-cumulative over time, the rise in domestic LPG wholesale price will fall below the cumulative increase in both the world parity price and the CPI fuel-light component.

It might be said that this is providing an implicit subsidy which will eventually help replace the one which has been all but taken away by the Hawke Labor Government. But who pays for it? In direct terms, the producers will pay as they are forced, by law, to sell the LPG at a price lower than they could get on the world market. In the long term, we will all probably pay due to the misallocation of the resources caused by this fiddle engineered by the Government. The only winner, of course, is the Government iself-by substituting a subsidy that the industry has to fund for one which the Government previously funded. We are seeing yet another case of the Government putting its short term revenue objectives before the long term interests of this nation.

The Bill before the House has two principal objectives: Firstly, to phase out the government subsidy and, secondly, to even out price fluctuations. Despite the attractive language used by the Minister in his statement of 24 March, this legislation is bad news for the consumers and producers, while the Government quietly boosts its coffers. The only beneficiary of this iniquitious policy will be the Government. If the Government can use the domestic industry as a milch cow, what does it have in store for the export industry?

Total LPG production in this country is running at close to two million tonnes annually, the bulk of which is coming from the Esso-BHP Bass Strait fields. The home market consumes around 500,000 tonnes or one quarter of the annual production. On the domestic market, producers will be held to a price below world levels, and it appears likely that this gap will increase over time. The Government will be moving away from its responsibilities while the producers will have to meet the cost of that world price gap.

The Age commented on 28 March this year that these producers have every right to believe they have suffered a form of discrimination. The Government ought to come clean. It has been caught out fiddling this subsidy at the expense of LP gas producers and consumers. The Government has not shown any real concern for the industry and the consuming public, and especially for those consumers in country districts who find the cost of fuels so much higher than their city cousins. Where is the Government's concern for these people? The Government's actions on this matter have seriously disadvantaged people on farms and those living in regional centres who have no alternative fuel source. Now they are paying higher prices than should otherwise be the case for their gas, coming on top of the decision to abolish tax concessions encouraging conversion to LP gas in last year's mini-Budget. The people in the country will suffer from this policy when the subsidy phases out. The people of Australia will judge the Government ultimately for what it has done. I believe it is a discriminatory policy. The Government is prepared to place the interests of its own coffers before the welfare of the people it was elected to serve.

I know that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) will be speaking on this Bill later tonight. I suggest that Government members listen to his address. No one in this House knows more about the petroleum industry than Bruce Goodluck. No one in this Parliament has addressed himself more to the petroleum industry than the honourable member for Franklin. I am sure he will give the Government heaps. I look forward to hearing what he has to say, because I know he speaks from a base of such great and deep knowledge on this and other subjects.
