(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to rise tonight to speak on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill which are before the House. We have heard a number of speakers on this legislation, including an excellent speech from the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and a speech from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). The Deputy Leader of the National Party indicated that this legislation is of enormous significance to some 30,000 rural consumers of liquefied petroleum gas around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am absolutely and totally appalled at the lack of support and interest shown in this important legislation by members of the Liberal-National Party. When a quorum was called just two minutes ago I counted some 30 members of the Government in this House. Not one National Party member was here to listen to this constructive contribution to the debate. That is so typical of the attitude of members of the National Party to a whole range of concerns of people who live in rural Australia. In an excellent speech earlier today, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) succinctly pointed out the incompetence of National Party members when they were in government and their failure to represent the interests of primary producers when in opposition. As I have said, it is significant that, in the legislation before the House, the House is totally devoid of any representation or interest from National Party members.

I want to concentrate my remarks on the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill. The purpose of this legislation is to amend the principal Act which was introduced in 1980 by the previous Government. When that Act was introduced in 1980 it provided grants to the States for the purpose of reimbursing subsidy payments to registered LPG distributors. The legislation was introduced by the previous Government at that time. The reason it introduced it was that there had been a trebling of LPG wholesale prices over the previous 12 months; 1979-80.

The principal features of that policy which was adopted by the previous Government in 1980 were as follows: The wholesale price was set at the lower of the export parity price, or the price then introduced, which was $205 a tonne. That was indexed for movements in the price of domestic crude oil. A subsidy of $80 a tonne was introduced, initially for a period of three years, and that was later extended for a further 12 months to March 1984 for household use.

When the subsidy was introduced its stated aim was to provide consumers of LPG with temporary assistance to give them time to adjust to rising LPG prices and to convert to other energy resources. But I must say that, despite the stated aim of that subsidy and the honourable and genuine intention of the Government at that time to provide some assistance for LPG consumers, the policy of the previous Government in terms of LPG was vitally flawed in a number of areas. It had a number of disadvantages. Foremost amongst those disadvantages in the previous Government's policy was the total lack of price certainty and stability . That was manifested in massive price fluctuations in LPG over the period in question. By way of example, by early 1983 those disadvantages of the previous Government's policy had become a matter of enormous concern to LPG consumers throughout Australia.

Despite that $80 per tonne subsidy which was paid by the Government the price of LPG to subsidised consumers rose by a massive 43 per cent between January 1982 and January 1983. It is clear, of course, that a rise of that magnitude in prices was less than acceptable to organisations such as the Australian Gas Association, the National Farmers Federation, which was representing some thousands of farmers throughout Australia consuming annually 32,000 tonnes of LPG and, of course, the 5,700 estimated LPG consumers throughout my electorate of Bendigo, the large number of consumers throughout my neighbouring electorate of Ballarat, so ably represented, and the-

TALK.START.PARA: —Fourteen thousand.

—And the 14,000 consumers of LPG throughout the New South Wales electorate of Calare. During the early months of 1983 that problem of price fluctations, in terms of the previous Government's policy was exacerbated by a further increase in the price in June of that year. I should point out that that increase was applied by our Government in accordance with the pricing mechanisms which had been established by the previous Government. I was very pleased, and I know that several of my colleagues representing rural electorates were also very pleased at the time, to learn that the Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) announced in June that he would be undertaking a comprehensive review of LPG prices throughout Australia. As I have said, we welcomed that announcement. Many others welcomed the announcement at that time. The President of the Australian Gas Association, Mr Tibbey, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government must correct the present pricing mechanisms which permit . . . LPG prices to swing wildly with short-term aberrations in the international LPG market.
That was the comment that was made at that time by the President of the Australian Gas Association, representing some hundreds of thousands of LPG consumers.

Many submissions were made to the Government in the course of that review. I made very strong representations to the Minister arguing for a more stable and predictable base for LPG pricing. I am well aware that my colleagues, particularly my colleague in Victoria, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), and my colleague in New South Wales, the honourable member for Calare, also made similar representations to the Minister. When we made those representations we emphasised very strongly that the previous Government's policy had caused undoubted consumer distress and was less than conducive to rational decisions concerning the domestic consumption of liquefied petroleum gas.

Following that review our Government announced new pricing and subsidy arrangements which have taken effect from 28 March this year. Under the new policy announced by our Government many consumers gain a price reduction in LPG and no consumers pay more than they did under the previous Government's arrangements. I think that is an important point. Most importantly, all consumers are now protected from the wild price fluctuations that have occurred in LPG pricing over the past four years. The reduction in the wholesale LPG price from 28 March represents a reduction of about 3c a litre on automotive LPG . That will further improve the competitive position of automotive LPG relative to petrol and diesel fuel.

In that context I think it is relevant to note some statistics concerning the use of LPG in motor vehicles. Some years ago, I am informed, there were only 250 automotive LPG outlets throughout Australia. Earlier this month, on 5 May when the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) launched the second edition of a booklet listing automotive LPG outlets throughout Australia, he said in his Press release that there were more than 650 automotive LPG outlets now throughout Australia. He did make the point, as I have made, that there were only 250 outlets operating in June 1980 and clearly there has been a great widening of the availability of LPG across Australia. Of course that is an important factor in promoting LPG as an alternative fuel. There are many benefits in the conversion of motor vehicles to LPG. The major reasons, of course, are that the fuel is cheaper than conventional petrol or diesel and most importantly it is free of lead and other emissions. Those members of the Parliament who are here tonight, including the honourable member for Flinders ( Mr Chynoweth) who is taking a keen interest in this debate, are well aware of the significance of automotive emission, particularly the sulphides and the leads from petrol-based fuels which are causing such serious air pollution problems in Melbourne at the moment. That matter has been given wide publicity in the media; it is a matter of concern to the Victorian State Government and I think it is a matter of concern to all people who live in Melbourne. Clearly one way of diminishing the effect of that automotive emission is for a greater conversion of motor vehicles to LPG gas.

One final point that I would like to make on the issue of automotive LPG relates to pricing mechanisms for automotive LPG. This week I made representations to the Minister concerning the retail price of automotive LPG. While the effect of the Government's policy was to reduce the wholesale LPG price by some 3c a litre in many cases it is clear that retailers have not passed on that reduction in price. I for one am somewhat concerned that in Bendigo at the moment people are paying a price premium of somewhere near 30 per cent to 35 per cent for LPG as against consumers in the Melbourne metropolitan area. Those are just some points about the issue of automotive LPG consumption. I return to the major context of the Bill. There are two key elements to the Government's new LPG policy and those two key elements respectively are the pricing arrangements and the subsidy arrangements. I want to describe briefly the arrangements concerning each of those. In terms of price the Government decided that from 28 March this year the basic wholesale price of LPG will be set at the export parity price for Bass Strait propane as it was on 1 March, and that was $244.75 a tonne. That represents a significant reduction of about 20 per cent of what was the pre-March price of $304.44. Under the Government's new policy the price of LPG will be adjusted on 1 October and 1 April each year and it will be done on the basis of the average of the monthly export parity prices from 1 April 1984 to the month preceding the new price date. This averaging formula will contribute to stability of LPG prices by moderating any fluctuations in world LPG prices. Importantly in terms of price future increases in the wholesale price of LPG will however not exceed increases in the fuel and light component of the consumer price index for the latest six-month period prior to the adjustment date. That arrangement will be continued until March 1987.

Under the previous policy traditional users of LPG did, of course, benefit from a subsidy at a fixed rate of $80 a tonne. Under the new policy a subsidy on LPG consumption will continue to apply until 31 March 1987 under the same eligibility and other conditions that presently exist. I do not want to go into immense detail on that but I will briefly run through the many benefits of the new pricing and subsidy arrangements compared with the arrangements that existed under the previous Government. Earlier in the evening my colleague the honourable member for Calare succinctly pointed to a number of the benefits of the new policy and I think it is worth elaborating on some of those.

Firstly, under our policy no LPG consumers will pay more than they did under the previous arrangements, in fact many consumers will pay less. Secondly, domestic LPG prices will be made much more stable and more predictable. Big price rises and rapid price fluctuations of the past will be eliminated. Thirdly , future LPG prices cannot exceed changes in the fuel and light component of the consumer price index. Fourthly, a subsidy continues to be paid under the existing arrangements and conditions and, importantly, the real price of LPG to subsidised consumers has not risen, and will not rise, under the new arrangements. Fifthly, the wholesale price of the LPG to subsidised consumers will be unchanged for a period of 14 months. In other words it will be unchanged from 1 July 1983 to at least 30 September 1984 and that is a massive improvement on the policy of the previous Government when over one 12-month period, as I have said, we saw increases in the price of LPG of some 43 per cent. All of the repercussions that had for rational consumption and for our subsidised consumers will not occur in th future. Unless by some strange factor, the fuel and light component of the CPI were to increase by that amount, it is simply not possible for increases in price and fluctuations of that magnitude to occur under our policy.

Automotive LPG consumers have already received a price reduction of 3c a litre in the wholesale price. They will benefit in the future from the greater stability of the new arrangements and automotive LPG will, importantly, continue to enjoy a substantial price advantage over petrol. The new arrangements ensure definite benefits for the 5,700 LPG consumers throughout my Federal electorate of Bendigo and they have been very strongly endorsed by the Australian Gas Association. When the Government's new policy was released later in March, the President of the Association at that time, Mr J. M. Shaw stated:

The Government decision on the new Wholesale Pricing Policy for Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) introduces a great improvement on the previous system. The arrangements will provide stability and predictability for producers, distributors and consumer.
He went on:
For too long the industry and consumers have suffered excessive variations in price because of the previous more direct link to export parity.
The media release of the Australian Gas Association went on:

Mr Shaw also welcomed the Policy for indexation of the subsidies price for traditional users of LP, which will adjust the price according to Australian energy price indicators rather than overseas factors.

I have no hesitation at all in strongly supporting the two Bills before the House. As I have said the arrangements that we have introduced in terms of LPG pricing are far superior arrangements to those which operated under the previous Government. Under the arrangements we have introduced there will be much greater stability and predictability in prices for consumers. That is so essential to all consumers trying to make longer term decisions about minimising the cost of energy in terms of things such as cooking and heating their homes. The great disasters of the previous Government's policies such as price movements of 43 per cent in one year simply cannot exist under our policy. The price of LPG will effectively be tied to the price movements of other energy sources incorporated in the light and fuel index of the consumer price index. As I said this is a superior arrangement. It is to the benefit of producers, consumers and distributors throughout Australia. I commend the Bill very strongly to the House .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will talk specifically to the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill. It has two aims. the first aim is to set a new pricing formula for liquefied petroleum gas which places major emphasis on stability of prices rather than parity with import or export prices and which will over time ensure that the domestic price of LPG falls below the export parity price. The second purpose of the Bill is to alter the existing Government subsidy arrangements for LPG by firstly, immediately reducing the subsidy from $ 80 a tonne to $20.31 a tonne and secondly, setting in place a mechanism that will reduce and eventually eliminate that subsidy.

SPEECH.PARA: The original LPG pricing mechanism announced in April 1980 set the price of LPG equal to either the export parity price or the January 1980 price of $205 a tonne, indexed by the percentage change in the price of indigenous crude oil, whichever was the lower. There have always been complications with the pricing of LPG as there have been with petrol. I think it is a duty of all governments, of whatever persuasion, to give the consumers in Australia a fair chance and a fair opportunity to a fair price. In essence we in the Opposition support the Bill and we hope that this will eventuate.

LPG production in this country is running at close to 200 million tonnes annually, the bulk of which is coming from the Esso-BHP Bass Strait fields. The home market consumes about 500,000 tonnes, or one-quarter of the annual production of LPG. Of course, each State is different. I come from Tasmania. We have specific problems there. I support the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) in what he had to say. I compliment the honourable member for Bass who has done a lot to bring to the notice of the consumers in Tasmania the problems they have and the problems that domestic and industrial users of LPG have. I am sorry to have to duplicate to a degree what the honourable member for Bass said, but I think it is important to repeat that there is no natural gas in Tasmania and that there is no coal to speak of.

TALK.START.PARA: —None discovered.
—No, none has been discovered. Of course, there is no hydro- electricity.
—I beg your pardon.

—There is some hydro-electricity but it has been reduced by the Federal Government which sits here today. As a consequence we in Tasmania have to look to alternatives. I think the Minister should stay with koala bears.
—They are not bears; they are marsupials.

—I am sorry, they are marsupials. The only way that people in Tasmania can use LPG gas is firstly, as reticulated gas, and secondly, by gas cylinders. As we know there is large excise on LPG and, of course, a high cost of freight across Bass Strait. We must admit that with a population of 420,000 people there is a low volume. Of course there is a difficulty. We appreciate the difficulty and the high cost of bringing the LPG across Bass Strait. When Tasmanians make a comparison of what people in Japan are able to buy their LPG for, a lot of them ask a lot of questions. They say to me: 'Bruce, why is it that a person in Japan has the ability to boil the billy cheaper than the billy that can be boiled in Tasmania?' That is a very good comparison. We start to ask what really occurs with LPG. Why is so much LPG exported to Japan? Why is LPG used in other countries when in fact we could use LPG in Australia as an alternative to petrol?

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) said tonight that LPG can be used as an alternative to petrol. Of course it can. At about a 10 per cent reduction in power it is clean. There is, of course, less wear on spark plugs and oil does not need changing as much. It can be used, and should be used, more in automotive areas in Australia. If we go overseas to a place such as Seoul, with a population of 10 million people, we can see that every car has LPG. Of course, one starts to wonder and ask what is happening in Australia. Why do we not make more use of the LPG that we are able to produce? Why do we not start using the capacity that we can produce? Why do we not store it for emergencies? Why do we not talk to the manufacturers of motor vehicles? The Datsun company tried it but marketed it incorrectly. That company produced an LPG car when it should have produced a dual purpose car that could run on petrol or on LPG. That company's marketing strategy was all wrong. Of course, people in Australia thought: 'We cannot fill up with LPG so we will not buy the Datsun'. Motor vehicle manufacturers in Australia such as Ford, General Motors-Holden's Ltd give options on gear boxes, differentials, the colour of the car, the seating and all the other things but not an option of LPG or petrol. Why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —They must have shares in gasoline.

—That is right. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), a nice fellow, talks about theoretical things; and talks about the future, but we have to be very practical in this world. We should talk about the 16 new industries that have not come to Tasmania. It is useless talking about these things, we have to act. We have to get these things in place so that they can be beneficial to all Australians in the future. My good friend, the honourable member for Bendigo, mentioned that LPG outlets have increased from 250 to 650. That is not enough. There have been LPG outlets in Holland, England and many other countries for many years where it is possible to fill up with LPG beside the petrol pump. Yet we have people in Australia who say that LPG is not safe. After all countries such as Japan and South Korea use it in their motor vehicles. We have cynics in Australia saying that it is not safe and that it spoils the motor vehicle engines.
—Have you got LPG in your car, Bruce?
—No, I have five children. I cannot afford it.
—Order! The Minister has been persistently interjecting on the honourable member for Franklin. I ask him to desist. I call the honourable member for Franklin.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. You are handling the situation beautifully. I will mention the price of LPG in Tasmania. The very important point that we in Tasmania try to make is that we are disadvantaged. We would like to be self- sufficient. We would like not to have to come to other governments and ask them to help us. Unfortunately, we are an island and we have disadvantages and difficulties in being able to compete with the larger markets. I mentioned the volume of LPG into Tasmania. I ask whether honourable members opposite could tell me the price of LPG for a motor vehicle in Tasmania at the moment. Honourable members probably would not know. I do not mean to be unfair.
—Thirty cents a litre?
—No, it is more than 30c a litre.
—They probably have no interest, Bruce.

—No, I do not want to be rude to them. The honourable members are interested. I think they are genuinely trying to say to me: 'We understand your point'. I will give them the benefit of the doubt. The cost of LPG is roughly 22c a litre in Melbourne and 34c a litre at the moment in Hobart. Of course the taxi proprietors are complaining that they spent the money on the conversion.
—Why do we hate Tasmanians?

—The honourable member took the words out of my mouth. The price of 34c a litre is excessive. The price of a 45 kilogram cylinder of gas at the moment is roughly $34.40. A litre of petrol in Tasmania at the moment is roughly 52c. When we were in government we said that the price of LPG should stay at roughly 50 per cent of the price of petrol. So of course people converted on that basis. They thought that LPG would be a proposition over a period, that the cost could be amortised and that it would be a good idea to convert. But unfortunately it has all gone out of kilter and the people who have converted in Tasmania, such as taxi proprietors, are saying to me 'Bruce, it is not worth it. We have a 10 per cent reduction in power. It has cost us money to convert' et cetera.
—It costs a thousand dollars.
—Yes, and now a litre of LPG costs 35c a litre.
—Who did that?

—I could explain it, but I do not have time because I want to go on to make a few points and try to tell the people of Australia about the fallacy surrounding LPG. They are told that they cannot use it in their motor vehicles, for cooking or for heating. That is a lot of rot. Liquefied petroleum gas can be one of the best means of power, of heating and of cooking, et cetera. And we have not made the best use of it in Australia. We should have. I think that everybody in this House would agree with me.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that honourable members would be interested in a few interesting points about LPG. I am sure that the people of Australia who are listening tonight-and I hope my wife is-would be most interested. The amount of LPG production from Bass Strait in 1975 was 1,260,202 tonnes. Exports exceeded 1,180 ,000 tonnes of which over 1,113,000 tonnes were shipped to Japan at a price-I think I did a price on that at the time-of between 5c and 6c a litre. So, of course, the Japanese in their motor vehicles were laughing. They were laughing all the way to the cookers-laughing everywhere. Yet we in Australia did not put our policy in place. I make another very interesting point. Liquefied petroleum gas was initially imported into Australia from California in bottled form in the mid-1930s. Transport and landing costs, however, raised its price to the Australian consumer to an uneconomical level despite its utilitarian value. I make the point that even in that year we imported it from America and thought it was worthwhile. But now we are producing so much and we are not making the best possible use of it for Australian consumers.

Examples were given of the domestic and commercial uses of LPG. Where fixed domestic off-takes are beyond the reach of reticulated gas or electricity, LPG is used domestically for water and space heating, refrigeration, lighting, air- conditioning and as a fuel for cooking. Domestic cookers, ranging from small single burners to complete cooking stoves, can be fired by LPG. It is also used for camping, caravaning and boating. It is supplied in cylinders varying in size . It can be used for all those domestic purposes. It can also be used by industry. Industry uses LPG in a large number of diverse ways which can be grouped as: Heating in processes which require careful control, such as glass and ceramics, electronics and fine mechanics; heating directly where the quality of the combustion gases is important, such as in milk drying, biscuit manufacture and baking; producing in the metallurgical industry of protective atmospheres for metal cutting and heating.

Then there are the advantages of LPG as an automotive fuel. They include longer engine life, particularly in respect of cylinder bore wear during cold starting. This is because LPG, being gaseous, when it enters the cylinders, does not wash oil off the walls. However, it is necessary to ensure that suitable valves and valve seats are used, generally stellited or similarly hardened. Because people do not understand LPG, do not study it enough, they think that it would not be advantageous to use as an alternative fuel. As a consequence of longer engine life, the effective life of lubricating oil is longer as a result of the absence of fuel dilution. Deposits on surfaces and spark plugs are also reduced, owing to the cleaner combustion characteristics of the fuel. Consequently, the frequency of top overhaul and plug servicing can be reduced. Thus car maintenance is reduced. Of course, any economy we can make in regard to the family car is terribly important today. Liquefied petroleum gas means easier cold starting because of the gaseous nature of the fuel. As LPG enters the engine in gaseous form, the mixture distribution to the cylinders is more often uniform than with motor spirit. Consequently, engines operating on LPG can utilise leaner mixtures, giving improved economy. Exhaust emissions are greatly reduced in LPG engines compared with those running on motor spirit. The simplest type of LPG fuel conversion will reduce significantly the carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon exhaust emission, making the atmosphere cleaner. Today, when our cities are growing, we have to be careful to reduce air pollution. That is why the Japanese and the South Koreans are using LPG. They are advanced in what they are doing with LPG. We in Australia are stupid. We should have been following their lead years ago but we have not. We should start to do so.

The Minister for Science and Technology is a good fellow. This is the sort of thing he should be looking at, rather than talking about valves and the 16 new industries. He has the brains and the capacity to be able to put these sorts of things in place. He would be able to save the consumers of Australia, and the pensioners of Tasmania, real money. That is the important thing. We have to have people with a bit of practical knowledge plus the brainpower of the Minister for Science and Technology who can theorise. But we have to put such things in place . That is what we should be doing with LPG in this country today-building storage capacity, using production and using LPG and forgetting about some of the rot that goes on concerning its use.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always enjoyable to follow the speeches of honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). I thank him for his remarks about the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) regarding the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill 1984. The Minister for Science and Technology does indeed have brains. He has chosen to join this Government and this Party. That is the most intelligent decision one could make. However, in fairness to the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) I should respond to him. He raised the question as to why in January 1984, when the Government had the opportunity to reduce the price of liquefied petroleum gas, it did not act upon it. In fact, the reality is that in the Budget Speech last year we made an announcement that we were reviewing the process of pricing. As a consequence, of course, that process was set in train. It would not have made sense to make a piecemeal decision at that stage. It was more sensible to come up with the legislation we are dealing with tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the legislation on the pricing of LPG, the honourable member for Franklin talked about making things cheaper for people. In fact, this legislation does that. That is why we are pleased that the Opposition supports it. I take the opportunity to get clearly on the record that this legislation establishes a degree of price stability and a reduction in price. That is exactly what the honourable member for Franklin called for. That has been pointed out very clearly by members on this side of the House, particularly by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons).

What we are talking about in this place tonight is the structure of the pricing of one of the basic resources; that is, LPG. That is the basic issue. We can sum up very briefly the announcement that was made by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) when talking about the pricing structure of LPG: The LPG pricing policy will mean that many consumers will pay less and no consumers will pay more than under the previous arrangements. That is the first point. The second point is that consumers will be protected from wild fluctuations in prices. They are the two overarching goals of this legislation. Later I will talk about some of the structural factors in relation to this legislation. The legislation is about establishing some degree of price predictability, and in this case lower prices. The second thing the legislation does is establish some degree of price stability.

Already the honourable member for Bendigo and the honourable member for Calare have spoken about price instability. Clearly, when we look at price instability we see that the Consumers of LPG have had to experience great movements in price over time. I will talk about those in a moment. The National Farmers Federation, industrial users and consumers experienced that fluctuation in prices. We as a government are responsbile for trying to produce some degree of stability and predictability in economic management. One of the things that I believe has come about since we took office in March 1983 is a degree of predictability and stability. In the Budget last year we made announcements with regard to the indexing of excises and this legislation brings that into effect for LPG. I will talk about the particular calculation and the mechanism for setting that in place.

It is important to point out, as the honourable member for Bendigo pointed out previously, that there could be no better example of price instability under the previous Government's arrangements than the fact that the wholesale price to subsidised consumers rose by 43 per cent from 1 January 1982 to 1 January 1983-a 43 per cent increase. That is not the sort of price instability that this economy can tolerate; nor the sort of price instability that we should ask consumers or industrial users to tolerate, because it produces further instability in economic performance. Clearly, we inherited an unsatisfactory situation. We have tried to produce some stability. It is important for the population in Western Australia and my electorate of Stirling. LPG production at the refinery in Western Australia in 1982-83 was 38,000 tonnes. That figure was part of an Australian total of 365,000 tonnes.

LPG sales in Western Australia in 1982-83 totalled about 50,000 tonnes. Automotive use accounted for 10 per cent. The honourable member for Franklin spoke about that point. Visitors to Japan will recognise that there is an overwhelming environmental demand for LPG. One of the costs that the Japanese are not prepared to pay, of course, is the increasing social cost of pollution; nor should we be prepared to pay that cost. I endorse the honourable member's remarks and the remarks of the honourable member for Bendigo. They were quite accurate in saying that there is a great environmental plus in increasing the use of LPG. I believe the communities in Melbourne and Sydney would recognise that point. Hobart and Perth are blessed to some extent by having relatively clean air, but it is not something that we can afford to ignore and it was a good point to be made. As I said, automotive use accounted for 10 per cent. Domestic use accounted for 33 per cent. That is a very important area. One of our goals is to produce some degree of stability and predictability for consumers. Industrial use accounted for 40 per cent and petrochemical use for 16 per cent. The subsidy applies particularly to domestic and industrial users. But I will say more about that shortly.

I have talked about the end users of LPG. Some examples of price instability in LPG show that we really had to intervene to try to reduce the degree of fluctuation. I will cite some figures that will, I believe, illuminate the debate. For example, taking movements from July to December of 1980, the designated wholesale price was $227.63 a tonne. That was an increase from $205 a tonne in April-June of 1980-an 11 per cent change in the wholesale price. The table further shows that in January to June of 1981-that is the next six-month period-it increased again to $250.23 a tonne. That is a 9.9 per cent change. But in the next six-month period-this is what made it very difficult for business and consumers-from July to December 1981 the price fell to $228.88 a tonne, an 8 .5 per cent reduction. The problem was that external factors impacted enormously on domestic prices. Some external factors will arise from the disastrous conflict between Iran and Iraq in the Gulf. What we are doing with this manoeuvre is trying to reduce the domestic impact of such international events.

There were further fluctuations, in the next six-month period, from January to June 1982. The price fell to $200.15 a tonne, a 12.6 per cent reduction. From July to December 1982 it moved up to $220.09 a tonne-a 10 per cent increase. From January to June 1983-the first six months of last year-the figure was $251. 85 a tonne, a 14.4 per cent increase. Finally, from July 1983 to March 1984 the price increased to $304.44 a tonne, a 20.9 per cent increase. This occurred under the previous arrangements. As a result of this legislation and the enabling regulations, we operated in March 1984 at a price of $244.75 a tonne.

Obviously, we are trying to reduce those wild fluctuations. The figures I have cited indicate to people who are listening and to honourable members what fluctuations occurred. It is very difficult in those circumstances to manage industry, and it is certainly difficult for end users and consumers. One of the points that has already been made in the debate is that the reluctance of people to switch over to LPG is because of those wild fluctuations in prices. One can understand that point.

We are trying, in effect, to establish a degree of price stabilty. I have talked about price instability and I have cited some figures which show the fluctuations in prices. Clause 5 of the Bill inserts a new section 6A (4). From 28 March 1984 the basic wholesale price will be set at the export parity price for Bass Strait propane which was in force on 1 March 1984. That price was $244. 75 a tonne. When that decision was made by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) there was in effect a reduction of 20 per cent or $60 a tonne on the current price.

We have inherited wildly fluctuating prices. We are trying to set in place a mechanism which will reduce those fluctuations. How will we fare in terms of future movements in price? I have indicated what the price was in March 1984. How will we go about adjusting prices in the future? What is the adjustment mechanism? This is the point at which I need to talk about the indexing to which I referred earlier in my speech. The price of LPG will be adjusted on 1 October and 1 April each year on the basis of the average of the monthly export parity prices to the month preceding the new price date. Future price movements will not exceed increases in the fuel and light component in the regimen of the consumer price index. In other words, we recognise that we need to ameliorate influences on the prices of LPG by referring back to a basic price structure. We are referring back to the structure of the consumer price index. That makes sense. If a person is in business and he is trying to predict movements in terms of his budgetary strategy each year, it is very important to be able to get an estimate of these costs. It is much easier under this Government because the prices and incomes accord has introduced a degree of economic stability. If a manager can say: 'This is the kind of movement we will get in the CPI automatically, in terms of that costing component of using LPG in an industrial application, he can predict the sort of costs he will be up for.

As a consequence, industry users will be encouraged to use LPG because it has a much more stable price movement. Obviously, as other honourable members have said, if there is a reluctance to use a commodity it is not only because it might be scarce in supply but also, particularly, because of wild fluctuations in price, and that has been the experience. I have referred to the large movements in price because of external factors under the previous Government's policy. Under this indexing arrangement we will be able to begin to tie some costs in business terms to some predictable movements, and that makes sense. It is sensible government policy and sensible business policy. It is something that we are prepared to put in place.

From a consumer's point of view it is also valuable because it is helpful to people doing household budgeting, if in advance, they can predict the costs of LPG. Therefore, there is an incentive to use it. The honourable member for Bendigo spoke about the involvement of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Chynoweth) with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. We as a government are concerned about environmental factors. Obviously we want to see more people using LPG because of the social gains and the social disbenefits of using other petroleum products, particularly those with a high lead content. If there are social gains to be reaped, we would want consumers and industrial users to feel more confident about using such a commodity as LPG.

I suggest to the House that this price arrangement and capacity to predict movements in advance will mean that both consumers and industrial users will be encouraged to use LPG. In my view and, I believe, in the view of the Australian community, that is good government and sensible management. It is good business management and it is good household management. That is the nub of this legislation.

To sum up, this legislation is about offering cheaper and more predictable LPG to consumers and to industrial users. It enables us to do it because the pricing mechanism has a predictive capacity as we are using an indexed arrangement in relation to the consumer price index. I believe this legislation is sensible and sound in terms of economic management and business consumer management. It is with pleasure that I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the salary that is paid to the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) is good enough. I believe that he was in the accountancy profession previously. He should be in the sales profession because on his presentation a moment ago he would be able to sell the proverbial iceblock to an Eskimo. But I am afraid that if I were the housewife listening to his story, particularly a remote area housewife who had absolutely no choice but to use liquefied petroleum gas for her cooking and had been doing so for many years, I would have a little doubt about his sales pitch if I sat down and analysed it. What he has told her is good for her is not to have wild fluctuations in price but to have higher prices. That is what he has offered her . I think the average housewife would take a bit of a bump in her budget occasionally if at the end of a 12-month period she could see that her gas purchases were $60 a tonne cheaper than they will be under this arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the reality of the situation. The reality is that the Government has taken back a subsidy of $60 a tonne from its arena and has taken the windfall of the drop in international pricing, which assists it in the setting of world parity prices, to arrange the currently low pricing structure. Yes, the consumer is no worse off but the consumer in this arena, the remote area consumer, has lost another area of government support. That is the reality of it. The Government can put that into any clothes it likes. It is clearly doing this as best it can. Because the price has not gone up the people believe that in this day and age it is not a bad thing to start with.

A previous speaker said that the farming communities and others are not all that keen on subsidies anyway. I agree that it is not the Government's role to subsidise every product, but we have to look at what the Government sneaks out the back door from that same remote area housewife. We find that for some unknown reason it has imposed a levy of some $48 now indexed to $49.23 per kilolitre. Although I have never really worked it out, I guess a kilolitre is 1, 000 litres. Would a thousand litres of LPG weigh half a tonne? If it did, by strange coincidence the excise that the Government collected would be $80 a tonne. If it just happened to be $60 a tonne, the Government would be getting back an extra $60.

So the housewife gets a pretty raw deal but we will send out the honourable member for Stirling. I am sure that in his quiet, persuasive way he would convince many of them, particularly in the electorate of Stirling, that they had a good deal. Alternatively, of course, the Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown), who is handling this Bill in this place, could get Mr Hogan to put a few advertisements on the television screen. I am sure that by that means also the Government would be able to convince some ladies. Hoges would probably do an even better job than the honourable member for Stirling.

The fact is that the ladies who have to turn on their gas are losing money in comparison with their situation under the previous arrangement. The Government has taken money from them. It has done so in two areas: it has reduced its subsidy-that is a fact-and it has increased its excise under this new method of taxation by stealth. I will deal with that a little further in my remarks on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill.

This is a serious business. We know also that the consumer price index is to come into this matter. As the Government has done with its fuel freight subsidy, it has implemented a reserve form of indexation under which, little by little, the CPI will further erode the assistance that the Government gives to remote area dwellings. If one went into the average remote area house and said to the housewife, 'I am going to take something away', I am sure one of the last things she would want taken away would be her gas stove. I have recollections of the remote areas of the north-east of Western Australia prior to LPG. I know what those people put up with. In some of those areas even wood was difficult to find .

The Government is hitting people in an area of great importance to them. If one happens to have a business or industry in those areas-I still have an involvement in such an arena in hotels and caravan parks-where large quantities of gas are used, one finds that it is a major cost and a major concern. I say to another person representing, as he claimed earlier tonight, people who are stuck with LPG-the people from Tasmania-that it does not matter what the Government has done and how good it looks; it has cost them money. The Government has taken $60 a tonne off the people and has increased the excise. That is the reality of the situation and that is what we are confronted with in the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill. Nevertheless, it could have been worse, I guess. Country people have certainly been hit the worst by many of the Government's other decisions.

I wish to take a little time, particularly as few other speakers have done so, to look at the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill, the other Bill with which we are dealing. This concerns the issue of resolving the great problems that the Government created with its proposal to index excise. It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Stirling tell us how all these things are good business. There are little increases all the time but nobody gets the opportunity to argue about them when it happens. The history of excises as they apply to fuels, liquor and everything else has always been one of the Government making a decision, probably at Budget time.

Of course, the representatives of the people gathered in this place-I am talking about the properly elected ones, not the friends of the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) whom he invited on one occasion-have an opportunity to expose that situation to the general public. Consequently, governments are somewhat constrained in their budgeting knowing full well that they can be criticised. But when they can sneak excises up in relatively small amounts every six months, knowing the politics of that, they know that is easier to get away with. In the process of the Government doing that we had a double whammy. The Government was not even prepared, considering this regular indexation and the size of these things, to extend the decimal point past two places. In the process of that we had a rounding. With this Government, being the good government that the honourable member for Stirling told us it is, there was no rounding downwards; it was always a rounding upwards.

The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) has already told us that the liquor industry alone in the very short period for which this indexation proposal has been in place has had to find an additional $20m. We continue to refer to the liquor industry because that is the industry which is excised and pays a cheque for it. But of course, that is not the end user of the product. The end users are the hard workers of Australia that the Labor Government says it has such a close affinity with. Of course, it is principally the beer drinkers of Australia who have to pay this money. I just wonder whether the Minister would admit that the Government during the period of his custodianship, outside of the costs that the Government has imposed upon the community by its indexation process, knocked off an extra $20m out of people's pay packets. More importantly, the Government is not going to give it back.

I would have been supporting this Bill and congratulating the Government if it had not only resolved the problem but also made provision to give the money back , the money that one might say was stolen from the drinkers of Australia. Of course, the motorist, the Sunday driver and all those other people, many of them having great need for a vehicle because of infirmity or whatever-even those people who have to climb on a bus-have had to pay this extra money because of the device the Government has used. It is taxation by stealth. In fact, that is what this Bill is all about. Honourable members have heard me say time and again that there are four words that describe a good tax, and they are: Simplicity, certainty, equality and visibility. When governments learn that the only place to impose a tax is where the people can see it, we will get good government in Australia. I do not say that by way of message only to the present Government. I sincerely hope that some of my colleagues also hear it. I think that to do that is really truly honest government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you learn that at Thredbo?

—No, I have known that for a long time. I have been lecturing on that point for a long time. If the honourable member criticises it, he is not an honest politician. They are the words that describe a good tax, and 'visibility' is the No. 1 word. An honest government is prepared to show the people where it taxes them so they can judge the Government on that taxation. I am sorry to say that the present Government is even worse than the previous Government in that regard, because almost all of this Government's options for increasing taxation have been imposed in a stealthy fashion. The Government snuck into the communications area and put on $150m. The people are only just starting to realise what has happened to licence fees on two-way radios and items of that sort. That is a disgraceful way for a government to get some money. That is not the way in which a government should impose taxes, any more than is this indexation process that it has introduced in respect of fuel and liquor. Let us look at what this indexation process has meant to certain sections of the community. Of course, the Bill also provides for the cessation of the practice of rounding off the amount of tax payable. As I say, it fails to give the money back.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue of great concern also in relation to this indexation process is the fact that the Government has not increased the rebate on excise that was available to farmers in relation to fuel used in tractors and other implements used for seeding. Since the present Government has been in office, the excise on distillate, because of indexation, is now 9.397c a litre. The rebate that was granted by the previous Government has been kept at 7.155c a litre. Suddenly a farmer who never before had been called upon to pay excise on distillate is paying 2.242c a litre. In fact, the National Farmers Federation estimates that this excise has cost farmers $24.9m-that is almost $25m-that they have never had to pay before. Compare that figure with the figure for the fertiliser subsidy- the big handout that everybody says the farmers get-which is $51m. In other words, the Government has taken back half the fertiliser subsidy which the farmers were not getting anyway because it was going to the Australian National Line. Honourable members might like to compare that situation with that applying to drought relief. Farmers received only $45.4m in drought relief in 1983-84. Just how quickly can the Government take the money back? It is doing pretty well out of tonight's little effort-$60 a tonne on liquefied petroleum gas. I have pointed out the effect that the Government's indexation proposal will have. It will affect all those people in country areas who are the consumers of LPG and distillate.

Then, of course, there is the humble beer. I might say that country people do not have available to them the entertainment opportunities that are available to people in the cities. Even the humble beer is more important to country people than city people. Country people cannot go to the type of entertainments which do not attract tax and which are so frequently available to city people. They have to go to the pub because that is their only form of entertainment, and that is one of the most highly taxed areas. In that regard it is interesting to note that on 9 April 1981 I drew the attention of the Parliament to just what happens to a $2 bottle of whisky, even after the Government has had some fun with it. I will not bore the House with all the details, but the fact is that the price of a $2 bottle of bonded whisky increased to $12.50 by the time it got to the retailer. Of that $12.50, $8.81 was made up of various government taxes and charges; in other words, the Government takes 420 per cent of the bonded cost of that bottle of whisky. That amount of tax is now to be indexed because, according to the Treasurer, the Government was not catching up quickly enough; the Government was not getting its bit.

I can tell honourable members that the liquor industry and its customers are thoroughly fed up with this taxation by stealth. They have had enough of it. Of course, in one respect the proposal before the House tonight will save the public a little money. As I said, I would feel much better about that had it given back the money that it got by a device without even really trying. I think it is time that this Government or any government was prepared to make admissions of this nature. There are plenty of ways in which this money could be refunded to the people who paid it.

The subject of this legislation is indexation. The Government even chose to index some excise duties raised for a specific purpose, namely the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund. It still refuses point blank to reverse that decision. The Opposition has given it the opportunity to do so by moving an amendment to the latest piece of legislation that dealt with the Fund. That amendment provided the Government with an opportunity to reverse its decision and to ensure that at least the money raised from the indexation of those excise duties was used to improve our roads and assist people in remote areas. The Government will not do that either. At the same time, the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) is writing to councils in my electorate to the effect that the reason he cannot put the money into that Fund is that the legislation will now allow it. It is about time he stopped writing letters in those terms. We are talking about honest government and visible taxation.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I thank you for allowing me the time to complete these few remarks. It has been said that 500,000 people are consumers of LPG. I think they will be reasonably satisfied because the Government has not tried to get more money out of them. However, they should not believe that the Government has been kind to them, because in fact the Government has reduced its level of support by $60 a tonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I offer a few closing remarks to the debate. I commence by offering my congratulations to the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) for their reasoned response to the debate on behalf of the Government. The honourable member for Stirling even elicited some praise from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I do not know whether that is the kiss of death or a highly valued form of flattery. Nevertheless, the honourable member for Stirling managed to achieve that. I think that the contributions from Opposition members in supporting the Bills have been reasonable, with the possible exception of the stridency of a couple of Tasmanian members who, in usual form, exhibited the great siege mentality of Tasmanians. I suppose that is fairly understandable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Amendment Bill introduces pricing and subsidy arrangements that became effective from 28 March. I think that the speakers from the Government side have pointed out very clearly that the intention of the Bill is to provide a more stable price regime, which of course is of obvious benefit to all consumers. The major reduction in price to unsubsidised consumers is incipient in the Bill, while subsidised consumers are assured now of greater price stability in the future. The most important factor is that all consumers, no matter where they are located, will be protected from wild fluctuations that featured during the previous Government. In fact, in the period from 1 January 1982 to 1 January 1983 the price of liquefied petroleum gas increased by 43 per cent. The outlook for stable and predictable prices under the arrangements of the present Government will enable industry to invest in LPG facilities, which is the point that was made by Government members. Business will now at least have the protection of knowing what the forward policy is, and that will encourage people to invest in LPG facilities, without the uncertainties and the distortions that were created by the previous arrangements. In fact, these arrangements will ensure that LPG can realise its potential in the Australian energy scene.

There were a few points made by some members of the Opposition to which I should refer. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) complained that the new pricing or subsidy arrangements were unfair to Tasmania. Firstly, I point out that the Bill was about the subsidy being provided by the present Government and nothing to do with pricing arrangements. The Government in fact sets a uniform wholesale price for liquefied petroleum gas at the points of supply. The retail prices paid by consumers will include obviously the cost of transport and handling from the point of supply to the point at which the product reaches the consumer. By its very nature LPG is very difficult to transport and, of course, is costly because of that. Retail prices could be expected to reflect that, and of course they do. The point made by the Tasmanians was that it was unfair that the cost of LPG gas to Tasmanian users was higher than the cost in other parts of Australia. That is not correct, because the price of LPG in other remote parts of Australia, particularly in western New South Wales, as the honourable member for Calare would attest, and in Western Australia, as I am sure the honourable member for Stirling would agree, is in fact higher than it is in some parts of Tasmania.

The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), in his normal rambling and hysterical fashion, screamed about Tasmania being disadvantaged, not even realising that LPG is carted to Tasmania across Bass Strait by the ship called the Island Gas and that the current pricing arrangements for the transfer of LPG across Bass Strait were instituted by his own Government in its desperate period of government. We heard nothing from the honourable member for Franklin in those years but, as is his wont, every time that any Bill appears in this House on which he gets the opportunity to speak he screams about this Government's unfairness to Tasmania. In fact under the subsidy scheme we have introduced Tasmanians are far better off, but it would be very difficult to get that into his thick little head. I hope that he is listening and that he can understand that.

The honourable member for Bass suggested that Tasmanian consumers of LPG should get more subsidy than consumers in the rest of Australia. As a former Minister for Administrative Services he should have known that constitutionally that is impossible and that there would be extraordinary difficulties in having selective excises or selective subsidies for various parts of Australia. I would have thought that a former Minister of the Crown-not a very distinguished one- should at least have known that.

The honourable member for O'Connor berated us about the indexation of excise and claimed that rates were always rounded upwards. To put the record straight for him I point out that since indexation was introduced following the Budget last year the rates for tobacco and spirits have been rounded downwards. I should point out to him, because he was railing about what we were doing to the poor beer drinkers of Australia, that under indexed excise beer drinkers at least know that the cost of beer will increase only according to the consumer price index, and in fact in the next quarter will not increase at all, which will be rather a novelty. It will be the first time in a long while in Australia that the cost of beer has not increased. The indexation arrangements in fact prohibit the sort of wild fluctuation we used to get. I recall one budget in which the previous Government, in one wild sweep, put up the price of a bottle of beer by 29c. That does not happen any more, and the harmless increase in the price of a middy or a schooner which occurred because of the last indexation increase would hardly affect the thirst of even the most ardent drinker. I thank the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), the other speaker from the Opposition, for as usual presenting a reasoned, logical and sensible contribution when leading for the Opposition and supporting the proposition that the Bills contain.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 10 May 1984.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments-
No. 1-Page 1, clause 2, sub-clause (2), lines 11 and 12, leave out the sub- clause.
