SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

My remarks are common to both messages from the Senate in respect of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill. The amendments proposed in the Bills originally sent to the Senate were aimed at providing more flexibility in tendering. They provided for exemptions to be sought from the compulsory calling of tenders in respect of national road construction works and works on urban and rural arterial roads under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act, firstly, where there were conditions requiring emergency works; secondly, where the works were of a minor nature so that additional cost would be imposed upon the cost of the works by the calling of tenders; thirdly, where it was not practicable to proceed with tender specifications being prepared; and, fourthly, where the projects were located in remote areas and the receipt of competitive tenders was unlikely. The four amendments to provide those exemptions from the calling of tenders have been agreed by the Senate in respect of each of the two Bills. Clearly they represent good administrative practice and make good common sense.

The two additional exemptions rejected by the Senate were contained in proposed new paragraphs (e) and (f) in clause 5. Paragraph (e) provided that exempt works involve adjustments to utility services which would normally be undertaken by a government authority or public corporation. This provision was aimed at enabling utility service operators to perform work on their own installations in relation to road construction. Examples of these would include gas distribution authorities where there was a need to shift gas mains in relation to construction of a road; electricity distribution; Telecom Australia installations; and water distribution and supply services. It would also include work on level crossings and bridges where the work has to be performed by railway employees under operating conditions. It made good sense and it made for greater efficiency if, in those cases I have outlined, the actual roadworks were to be carried out by the authority or corporation involved rather than putting the project out to a private tenderer and then trying to co-ordinate the provision of supplies at the same time as the work proceeded. This exemption was limited to construction of utility services only and did not cover ancillary works, such as bridge approaches. As I have mentioned, it was a sensible, practical measure. In fact, the Opposition spokesman in this chamber at the time said as much during the debate. Regrettably, the Liberal Party, National Party and Australian Democrat senators rejected that sub-clause and it has been deleted by way of their amendment that is now before the chamber for consideration.

Let me say, in reference to the debate, that no logical explanation was put forward by any of those senators as grounds for the rejection of that sub-clause . Paragraph (f) states that the performance of the works under contract would cause unavoidable retrenchment of or significant and unavoidable inefficiency in the deployment of a substantial number of State or local government road construction employees. The purpose of providing that exemption from the calling of tenders in circumstances outlined in respect of sub-clause 5 (f) was perfectly clear: It was to provide the opportunity for continuity of work for road gang employees in country areas. The attitude of he Opposition, particularly Opposition senators, towards that amendment is beyond comprehension . In respect of proposed new paragraph (e), members of the Opposition were divided between this House and the Senate. As I said, the Opposition spokesman said in this chamber that proposed new paragraph (e) was reasonable and would be acceptable. In the Senate the same paragraph was rejected by Liberal, National Party and Democrat senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not sound like me at all.

—I suggest the honourable member read Hansard. As to paragraph ( f), again the Opposition's attitude is quite bewildering. The doctrinaire dries in the Opposition prefer to ignore the practical realities of the need for an established work force for road maintenance and construction in country areas. By rejecting proposed new paragraph (f) Opposition senators have effectively retained the threat that has existed to the jobs of local government and State road authority employees in country areas where there are limited alternative employment prospects. Their action so concerned the New South Wales Department of Main Roads workers in the south coast region that they were prepared to suffer a loss of income and to go on strike to express the depth of their reaction to the course followed by the Liberal, National party and the Australian Democrat senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The people in the country, country towns, country road authorities and councils are well aware of the important role of road authority regional work forces. They are well aware that the road construction and road maintenance employees in country towns provide one of the few stable work forces. They are well aware of the role played by those people in the event of a civil emergency and the use of their plant and the facilities that are available. Therefore, the action and attitude of the Opposition hit at the very social fabric of many small country towns.

The Government's proposals were not aimed, as was suggested by some Opposition members, at simply making work for road authority employees in country areas. It is an established fact that main roads authorities must retain day labour forces to undertake urgent works or for situations where private contractors do not tender or submit excessively high bids. It makes good economic sense that these work forces be effectively and efficiently deployed at all times-that is, if the taxpayer is to receive value for money in the road construction sector. I have no doubt that country people will be astonished at the action taken by their so- called representatives in this place and in the Senate. The question arises: Who does the National Party represent? It certainly does not represent the interests of country council employees, it certainly does not represent the interests of country road authorities and it certainly does not represent the interests of country townspeople who are dependent upon the regular and stable employment provided by country road authorities and country councils to maintain the level of services and the quality of life that are provided in those country towns.

I made it abundantly clear in the debate in this chamber when the Bills were dealt with here that it was not the Government's intention or my intention that the proposed amendments; undermine the tendering arrangments, they were designed to meet a clear and established need for flexibility in the administration of both Acts. They were amendments that were sound and that made good common sense. They were amendments that had the unanimous support of all State road Ministers through the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

I want to emphasise that the National Party Government in Queensland, the Liberal Government of Tasmania and the Country-Liberal Party administration of the Northern Territory were some of the strongest supporters of the amendments. They, like people in the country, now recognise that they have been betrayed by the actions of their Federal colleagues in this place and by the actions of the Liberal, National Party and Democrat senators in the other place. I emphasise also that the Tasmanian Minister for Roads, the Hon. Ian Braid, telexed me the day these Bills were dealt with by the Senate and advised me of the appeal he had made to all Tasmanian senators to support the amendments. If they had supported the amendments they would have been carried in their entirety- including proposed new paragraphs (e) and (f). Unfortunately his appeal was ignored by his Federal colleagues in the Liberal Party when the matter was put to the vote in the Senate. Again, that indicates the shambles in which the Opposition now finds itself, and particularly the Liberal Party. The State Liberal Government in Tasmania is pursuing one course and the Federal Liberal senators in the other place are objecting.

The attitude of the Opposition should be a concern for all Australians for a number of reasons: Firstly, they refuse to recognise the reality and persist with their theoretical dogma in ignorance of the real needs of people in country towns and remote areas. The question arises: Just what are they trying to achieve? It seems that they prefer the pursuit of dogma, a theory, to dealing with the real needs and aspirations of people who live in the country towns and who work for councils and for country road authorities. It is obvious that they are not going to stop at anything, not even the requirements of their own colleagues in their State governments, even if they have to ignore their colleagues in their State governments, to achieve what they see is a desirable dogma, a desirable theoretical objective.

I repeat that all of the State Ministers for Transport requested these amendments. All of them supported them and this Government, in the spirit of co- operation in which it has sought to work with the States, responded to their requests. This legislation is a joint effort-a joint effort that has been marred by the action of the Federal Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats.

As I have said, in these circumstances, in moving that we accept the amendments , I want to emphasise that we have no choice. There is no practical alternative but to accept them. The four sub-clauses that have been agreed to by the Senate provide some minor flexibility. Where a State Minister was prepared to put a case to me for exemption to be granted from the calling of tenders the real flexibility and protection for country councils is no longer available and the jobs of people working in country councils and country road authorities are now in jeopardy because of the actions of the National Party, the Democrats and the Liberal Party. In those circumstances, we have no alternative but to accept the amendments as passed by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is naturally very pleased that the Government has come to accept the good sense of the amendments that were moved and passed in the Senate. On behalf of the Opposition I congratulate the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) for having had the good sense to acknowledge that the action that was taken in the other place was appropriate.
—Nonsense.
—The honourable member for Banks says: 'Nonsense'. If he just listens to me for a minute or two he will understand exactly what I am talking about.
—I will not learn much.

—The honourable member will learn a lot; he is someone who can learn a lot. He is one person who I know has an open mind. The amendments come in two parts. The first amendment, which the Senate has passed and which the Government has indicated it will accept, deletes sub-clause (2) of clause 2 in the original Bill which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments made by Section 5--
Those amendments detail the exemptions from the tendering arrangements-
shall be deemed to have taken effect on 12 February 1984.

I really do not understand why. The Minister might like to explain to us why he included 12 February 1984 as the operational date in the first place. It is interesting that some claims have been floating around outside this Parliament that the reason the Minister backdated the legislation to 12 February 1984 was that in anticipation of its going through the Parliament he had approved some variations to tendering procedures under the exemption, in the Bill. I do not know whether that is the case, but it seems to carry some credibility by reason of the fact that the Minister wanted to backdate the amendments in clause 5 for a significant number of months. If he approved variations to the normal tendering process that would have been okay if the Bill had gone through at the time that he approved them. They are not now covered because the Senate has rejected paragraphs (e) and (f) and the House is about to accept the Senate's amendments and also reject paragraphs (e) and (f). The Minister ought to come clean and explain to the House whether that was the case. If it was I think he is probably guilty of having acted improperly in this matter and he ought to be accountable to the Parliament for having done so.

The second of the amendments removes paragraphs (e) and (f) from clause 5. As the Minister has said, those are two of what would have been six provisions that he could use to justify waiving the tendering procedures. I made it very clear in my speech during the second reading debate and the Committee debate in the House the last time this Bill was in the chamber, before it went to the Senate where it was amended, that we would not have a bar of it and that we would oppose all those changes to the tendering arrangements.

The Opposition has a very strong commitment to the tendering procedures. It has been made clear in this House on a number of occasions that the achievements of a former Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who is now the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, in getting those tendering provisions into this Act were excellent achievements. The question of getting value for road dollars had to be taken into account. It was acknowledged that there were inefficiencies within some of the State Government road making authorities and some competition had to be provided to ensure that the State road making authorities were kept on their toes. There was absolutely no discrimination in this arrangement. If the State road making authorities were efficient there was no reason why they could not get the work. They were quite entitled to tender and in many cases, as I understand it, they have tendered for work and have won those tenders.

I indicated that there was no big problem in principle, as far as we were concerned, with paragraphs (a), (b), (c) and (d) because they were minor matters . They allow the Minister to waive the tender procedures in cases of emergency, when very minor work is involved, or when the amount of work involved means it is not practical to prepare tender specifications. The fourth paragraph involves those sorts of jobs for which tenders are unlikely to be received. We did not object too much to those provisions. If the Minister was going to insist on those sorts of changes they were probably the sorts of changes that arose out of experience and ought to have been accepted. We thought that paragraph (e) relating to work of a kind that is usually carried out by the department of main roads-type body left the whole system wide open.
The last paragraph, paragraph (f), states:
. . . in order to avoid the occurrence of a loss of employment by, or the inefficient deployment of, a substantial number of those employees . . .

This relates to a DMR-type organisation. One of the reasons we want tendering and one of the reasons, obviously, why the Senate has moved the amendments that it has moved, is to ensure that those State road making authorities have some competitive element attaching to them so that they cannot go out and do road jobs as of right regardless of the cost.

The Minister has said that he is looking to the interests of the State road authority employees and the interests of country towns and remote areas. I respect that. I hope that, in any of the statements I have made, I have not detracted from the interests of the State road authority employees or the interests of country towns or remote areas. In a situation like this obviously a balance of interests has to be considered. Thousands of millions of dollars are being outlayed on roads in this country and we have to ensure that this is being done in a proper manner. We cannot afford to featherbed any particular sector. We cannot afford to put the interests of one sector above any other. In that way we provide that competitive environment. As I have said, if the road authorities are good enough they will get the work.

The Minister also said that the amendments have the support of all the State roads Ministers. He quoted at length the experience of Tasmania. It does not surprise me that the State road ministers are supporting the amendments because they are responsible for those day labour forces. It is their responsibility to ensure that those people are getting work. It is obviously easier for them if they do not have to compete for it. Therefore, I do not necessarily put too much weight on that example. I can understand that a State road minister would prefer to have things a little easier than a little harder. It is in his interests to do that.

The Minister has had to lean heavily on the assertion that our amendments are ideologically based, based on dogma and things of that nature. I reject that because it is quite clear from the stance that the Opposition has taken right through this debate that we are concerned about efficiency and value for money. The Minister finished up with a plaintiff cry that he has absolutely no choice but to accept the Senate's amendments and that there is no practical alternative to doing that. Poor Minister! Other Ministers in this place have taken the view that they will not be pushed around by the other place and they have sent legislation back. I take the example of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) with his amendment to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill which has been in and out of the two Houses on I think four or five occasions now. The Treasurer is not prepared to lie down in the face of Senate pressure. Yet this Minister, on the first occasion that the Senate has attempted to move an amendment to his legislation, has come into this chamber and given 150 good reasons why what the Senate has done is outrageous and should not be accepted. He then turned round weakly and limply at the end of it and said: 'We have no choice and there is no practical alternative but to accept the Senate's amendments'. I think the Minister ought to be seen for what he is. But I would like to hear a few words from him as to why he wanted in the first place the amendments in clause 5 backdated to 12 February and whether any action was taken in relation to tendering under clause 5 before the legislation was passed by the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Some $500m is being lost. I think it is a tragedy that the Minister did not see the same sense in these amendments. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) complains about the lack of funds for roads and national highways and yet he is denying the road systems of Australia $500m. He has been given the opportunity to vote for the amendments but he is on record as having voted against them. He has denied not only the people of Australia and road users $500m but also his own electorate. Yet he complains bitterly about the lack of funds.
—Which electorate is he from?
—He is a oncer from Leichhardt.
—Where is Leichhardt?
—It is way up north where the roads require--
—I am sure that the honourable member for Dawson needs no assistance from the honourable member for Hume.
—Why does he hate North Queensland?

—One could think of why he hates Queensland. However, the honourable member is only a oncer. It offends me to think that the Minister is given the opportunity of making the amendments. I can assure him that there is a rage in the electorate, not only from local government but also from all road users, that roads construction will be denied $500m. It does not matter what the Minister says or does or who he writes to, it is a fact that he has denied that extra amount of money to road construction, and he is the Minister for Transport . A few weeks ago I think the honourable member for North sydney (Mr Spender) said in this chamber that having this Minister in charge of roads is like having a vegetarian in charge of an abattoir. It is precisely the same situation. I ask the Minister to take this final opportunity of giving justice in this regard. He has talked about tendering and what is required of the main roads forces and local government. However, if he is listening to his electorate, if he is listening to the people outside, if he is listening to local government he will know that they are telling him that there is some requirement to make those indexed funds go to road construction or the transport needs of Australia instead of being lost in Consolidated Revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister thinks that transport users, the people who pay this indexed road levy, are in a rage at the moment, given six or 12 months that rage will be a bushfire. I certainly hope that the Minister will take this final opportunity of making this further amendment. I agree with the honourable member for Hume that the amendments are absolutely necessary, that they are logical and make common-sense. The Minister has not been pressured into this. As the honourable member for Hume has said, once around the ring is not really going to the wall. In other words he has been rolled by the Senate. Common-sense has prevailed, which is unusual for the Minister. I just ask him to place a little more justice within the Roads Grants Amendment Bill by agreeing to this amendment. I also ask the Minister whether he has already acted on his discretion to allow some of these provisions to be passed before the Bill goes through and whether that is the reason for its retrospectivity.

One is not surprised by retrospectivity from the Government. It seems to rule by retrospectivity and discretion. This discretion is still evident in the Roads Grants Act, and I do not believe that is a good thing in itself. Can the Minister answer my question about whether any action was taken outside the law pending the passing of this legislation, and will he amend it further to provide for the indexed funds to go to roads?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I take a point of order. The Minister says that the honourable member for Gwydir was ranting and raving yet I heard the Minister deliberately praise the honourable member.
—There is no point of order.

—As I said, the honourable member was ranting and raving about the possible non-use of some $500m of excise revenue in the years to 1988. He said what a terrible thing that was. The former Minister and the former Treasurer, who has now left the chamber, are well aware that the utilisation of excise revenues is not a matter for the Minister for Transport. He has an input in regard to how he would like to see it spent.
—You were not even consulted. You didn't even know it had happened.

—The honourable member should be patient. It is not a matter for determination during the year. It is a matter for normal budgetary consideration . As I said some time ago, it will be considered during the forthcoming Budget deliberations. Every former Minister who now sits in this chamber knows that to be true, but if they want to delude themselves let them proceed. They are talking about what might be in the future. Let me talk about what they did. It is on record. Let us talk about that, because that is a fact and not speculation which they are trying to raise. The fact is that during the Opposition's term of government, the Liberal Party and the National Party, which masquerade as representatives of people in the country, quadrupled Federal fuel-rated revenue.
—You have not improved it.
—In fact, you trebled the price of petrol--
—You promised to reduce it. That is another promise you have broken.
—Order! I ask the Committee to come to order.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, we listened to the Opposition speakers in silence. Please may we have the same courtesy. Those who sit on the other side quadrupled Federal fuel-rated revenue during their term of seven years. They did not double it, they quadrupled it. They trebled the price of petrol and what did they do about Federal road expenditure? They slashed it by $570m. They repeatedly voted in this chamber in support of budgetary measures that reduced Federal road expenditures by some $517m. Yet they have the effrontery to run around the country saying: 'This might happen in 1986, 1987 or 1988'. Let me say to the members of the National Party and the Opposition that the deplorable state of so many roads in this nation and in so many of their electorates is because they robbed road users of half a billion dollars during their term of government. So let them not speculate about the future. Let them try to do something about what they did in the past. The last matter I mention is why the amendments are being accepted. I thought the reason would have been evident without explanation to honourable members, even those of the National Party. That is because there has been no expression of a change in view of the National Party, the Liberal Party or the Australian Democrats in respect of this legislation, which means that if the amendments are rejected by the House of Representatives and sent back to the Senate for further consideration and are again rejected by the Senate, honourable members opposite will be back here in several weeks time to deal with them. I do not expect that they will want to do that. I thought I judged them correctly in forming that conclusion-unless they want to volunteer tonight to come back in three weeks time to deal specifically with that matter only. If the amendments made by the Senate are not accepted this evening, even the minor flexibility that has been provided by the Senate's agreeing to the first four conditions for exemption for the calling of tenders could not be utilised until the matter could be dealt with again during the Budget session at the earliest. So for that reason the Government has no practical alternative other than to accept the amendments.
