DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE (INTERIM PROTECTION) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have circulated the amendments that I will move to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill 1984. I felt that, having regard to the number of honourable members who want to participate in this debate, it would be beneficial to have the amendments in the hands of honourable members so that they can endorse or reject the principles involved in them during the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are, in part, a response to the continuing consultation in which I, and officers of my Department, have been engaged over recent weeks. We have been in personal contact with Ministers of State governments and State officials. We have exchanged correspondence and telephone calls with them. We have spoken to interest groups, in particular representations of the mining and pastoral industries.

Many changes to the legislation have been proposed. Some people would have the Bill withdrawn and new legislation prepared. Others have suggested changes which are unnecessary, either because the legislation already covers the matters of concern to them, or it is more appropriate that those matters be dealt with in the administration of the legislation rather than in the Bill itself. Honourable members will recall that in my second reading speech on this Bill I stated in some detail what the Bill was intended to do and what it was not intended to do. The scope of the legislation, the way in which this Government intends it will be administered, and the purpose of it have been clearly spelt out.

In recent days attention has been focused on criticisms of the Bill, particularly those criticisms made by the Australian Mining Industry Council. It is now a well known fact that on Monday this week senior representatives of the Council met with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) and me. The meeting lasted almost two hours, and a number of matters of concern to the Council were discussed. Various means of meeting those concerns were explored on a confidential basis. Details of the discussion were not and will not be disclosed. The Council rejected a scheme put forward by the Prime Minister, Senator Walsh and me. There has been speculation in the Press and elsewhere about the details of that scheme. As I have said, those details were and will remain confidential. However, I am bound to say, with the approval of AMIC, that it was no part of our discussion, or any scheme involving those discussions, that involved the proposition that the Bill before the House would be amended. Some positive suggestions have been made which will make the Bill more clear and the administration of it more flexible. Those suggestions are incorporated in the amendments which I propose.
Prosecutions

Some have criticised what they say is provision in the Bill for the prosecution and conviction of people who innocently, without knowledge of a declaration, breach some provisions of the declaration. It is neither the intention nor the effect of the Bill that such prosecutions take place. However, in consultation with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), I have agreed to reword parts of clauses 22 and 24 to set out in a more acceptable form the way in which the Act will operate.

The amended scheme makes more clear the intention of the Bill. In summary, it provides that a person contravening a provision of a declaration will be guilty of an offence. The defendant may adduce his own evidence that he neither knew, nor had reasonable grounds for knowing, of the existence of the declaration. Such evidence may also be drawn out in cross-examination of prosecution witnesses. Where there is that evidence, the prosecution will bear the onus of proving beyond reasonable doubt that, at the relevant time, the defendant knew, or ought reasonably to have known, of the existence of the declaration. Unless the prosecution can discharge that onus, the person cannot be committed for trial or convicted for an offence.

Let me assure all honourable members that innocent picnickers, bushwalkers and campers will not be prosecuted. Where appropriate, fences and signs will be erected to mark areas which are the subject of a declaration. This will be in addition to gazette and newspaper notices, and notices to persons likely to be substantially affected by the declaration. There will be nothing secret about a declaration. However, where a person genuinely does not know, and could not reasonably have known, of such a declaration that person will not be in any danger of being convicted.
The Effect of a Declaration on Proprietary Interests

Miners and some State officials have drawn attention to what they see as a possible limitation on the matters which the Minister is obliged to consider when deciding whether to make a long term declaration in respect of a significant Aboriginal area. The limitation, they suggest, is found primarily in the provision setting out the matters with which an independent person must deal in making a report to the Minister. Among the eight categories of matters to be dealt with in a report are the effects the making of a declaration may have on the proprietary interests of persons other than the Aboriginal applicant, or those Aboriginals on whose behalf the application was made. It has been suggested that the expression 'proprietary interests' can be read narrowly, to exclude from the report and from the Minister's attention the legitimate and substantial interests of others who might be affected by a declaration. For example, a person having an exploration licence over the land may not have a legal interest in the land, and so may not have his interests considered.

A number of responses may be made to this point. Firstly, the provision refers to the 'proprietary interests of persons' not to the 'proprietary interests of persons in land the subject of an application'. Thus the proprietary interests of people, other than those having a property right in respect of that land, could be considered. Secondly, a Minister ignoring the relevant interests of such other people would take the risk that the failure to have regard to them could be the basis of an application for a court order to review his decision. Thirdly, I would expect that those administering the Act would interpret the expression 'proprietary interests' to cover a wide range of interests. However, to avoid any ambiguity on the point, and to ensure that all those who may be subject to some financial consequences arising from a declaration will have their interests considered, I have agreed that the Bill be amended to include reference to pecuniary interests. The relevant provisions will now refer to the 'proprietary or pecuniary interests of persons'. It will be clear that, for example, a person who has no legal or equitable interest in the land, but who has a business interest which will be affected by the closure of the area, could make a representation to the person making the report to the Minister. That representation would be attached to the report and considered by the Minister.
Delegation
Recent discussions with some State government officials have shown the advantage of including in the heritage Bill a power for the Minister to delegate certain functions. Such a power would serve to:
(A) avoid duplication of functions already performed by a State or Territory under its own legislation;

(B) avoid the risk that a State or Territory government would discontinue performing a function, preferring to transfer the performance of it to the Commonwealth on the basis that the Act effectively covers the point; and
(C) allow some administrative matters to be handled by Commonwealth officials rather than the Minister.

The Bill already provides in clause 7 for the concurrent operation of State and Territory laws. The power to appoint authorised officers who are empowered to make emergency declarations-clauses 17 to 19-could be used to appoint certain State officials. To complete that scheme it would be useful to be able to delegate responsibility for some administrative matters-for example, the fencing and sign posting of declared areas-where those administrative functions are already being performed effectively at a State body willing to accept extra responsibility.

A particular example of potential duplication arises from the requirement in clause 20 to report the discovery of human remains. Where a State law has a similar requirement and even if that law is being administered effectively, the Act will still require reporting to the Commonwealth Minister. As well, the Minister will be required to make certain inquiries which may overlap with similar inquiries of a State administration. Rather than duplicate the work, and consequent cost, it would be useful to be able to delegate that investigation function.

Already some States have indicated a willingness to co-operate in the implementation of this legislation. Where appropriate arrangements can be made, this delegation power will enable formal endorsement of those arrangements. There are other matters, such as the notification of people who might be affected by a declaration, which could usefully be delegated to Commonwealth officials.

Mr Speaker, there is no suggestion that the decisions which must be taken by a Minister, and for which he will be held responsible, will be delegated. The amendment specifically excludes from delegation the Minister's power to make declarations, the Minister's obligation to consult with his State or Territory counterpart and the Minister's power to seek injunctions from the Federal Court of Australia. These amendments reflect the desire of the Government to meet any suggestion of ambiguity in the Government's intention in respect of this legislation.

I again remind the House that this legislation is interim legislation. There has been more consultation in the preparation of this Bill than previous coalition governments engaged in when amendments to other Aboriginal land rights legislation were made. There has been more consultation than either the Queensland or Tasmanian Governments have engaged in when preparing Aboriginal legislation with implications for the Commonwealth. In anticipation of preparing more comprehensive land rights legislation, invitations to consult have already been issued to the mining industry and the farmers-the groups which have been most vocal in their criticism of the Bill before the House. I therefore commend these amendment for the consideration and support of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The turbulent history of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island (Interim Protection) Bill 1984, both in Cabinet and in the subsequent public discussions prior to this debate, has added to the growing public concern with this Government's handling of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. I have said on many occasions that this is an extremely sensitive area that requires a rational and balanced approach. The good will built up in the past by positive government initiatives aimed at meeting the real needs of the Aboriginal people is being eroded by this Government. Public understanding of and support for special programs to assist the Aboriginal people is gradually being replaced by antagonism, ill feeling and distrust towards this Government, and it is the Aboriginal people who will inevitably suffer the consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: Soon after his appointment the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) made some extravagant and ill-conceived promises which have given life to extremists on both sides in what is a sensitive and volatile area. Instead of criticising and peremptorily dismissing those who have raised doubts and concerns, he ought to be looking at the causes. If he were to adopt a more conciliatory and balanced approach to these matters the extremists would have no case to peddle and the cohesion of the peoples of this country would not be placed in jeopardy. The Minister calls for bipartisanship and yet has done everything in his power to destroy it. Instead of seeking consultation and co- operation with the Opposition and other organisations which have a role to play in relation to his responsibilities he has sought through confrontation to implement an inflexible and unrealistic predetermined set of principles without consultation or reconciliation.

The Bill and its predecessor have travelled a very tortuous path. The original legislation introduced into Cabinet by this Minister was rejected as being totally inappropriate. The Minister was sent away to have another go. Unfortunately, he did not do much better. This legislation was sneaked into Cabinet as an unlisted item. Other departments had no prior opportunity to consider the contents of the Bill. Since then the Minister has been in an inordinate hurry to introduce the legislation and have it passed by this House before any worthwhile consultation can be held. In his usual confrontationist approach to these matters, the Minister failed to seek the support of the States , industry, the Opposition and others who have a vital interest in such legislation.

We are left guessing as to the reasons for the sudden urgency for the Government to pass this legislation. Certainly, I appreciate that the Minister would want to get at least one run on the board before the next election. He rushed around the country making all sorts of promises soon after he was appointed and this is the first legislative move he has made in an attempt to fulfil just one of them. I am not suggesting that a Minister's performance ought to be based on the amount of legislation introduced. In fact, in some areas I believe performance ought to be judged on the amount of legislation repealed in this grossly over-regulated society. However, the undertakings made by the Minister can be met only by legislation. Therefore, if he is to have any credibility he needs some legislation. Honourable members will be acutely aware of the fact that on the last occasion the Minister had a rush of blood to the head he introduced his Aboriginal affairs motion into this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—The honourable member might well ask what is wrong with it. Perhaps he will tell us why the motion has not been brought on for debate. It is now nearly six months since it was moved, and it has run into so much trouble that it has not come on for debate and is not likely to be debated until the Budget session. If we accept that the Minister needs to get this legislation through so that he has at least one run on the board, we are still left wondering why the Bill has to be dealt with this session. The only answer to that can be that the Government is acutely embarrassed by the Minister's handling of this portfolio and does not want to delay this debate until the Budget session, in the lead up to the early election. So this is the last desperate effort to recover some credibility with an increasingly disconcerted Aboriginal community. Unfortunately, the Bill will have the opposite effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The House is well aware of the concern which is being expressed by State governments of all political persuasions in relation to both the lack of consultation and the ramifications of this legislation. The Minister's idea of consultation was to send the legislation to the States and a number of interested groups at the eleventh hour. In the couple of days provided for responses to be given, the Minister was overwhelmed with criticisms regarding the operation and implications of the legislation. His reaction to these criticisms has been to ignore them and press on regardless. The result has been a public and almost unanimous call for the withdrawal of the Bill.

Opposition to the legislation has come from the Australian Mining Industry Council, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, the Australian Archaeological Association, Aboriginal communities and many others. The State Governments of Western Australia, Tasmania, Queensland and New South Wales and the Government in the Northern Territory have all expressed grave concerns about the legislation. I am not aware of the response of the governments of South Australia and Victoria. However, I would not be surprised if they shared the concerns of the other States. Let me quote just one State's view. I pick a Labor State to show the depth of concern. Mr Wilson, the Minister for Housing, Youth and Community Services with special responsibility for Aboriginal Affairs in Western Australia said on 8 May in the Western Australian Parliament:

The State Government was not convinced, and it remains unconvinced of the need for the legislation. It continues to have doubts and concerns about the lack of consultation between the State Government and the Commonwealth with respect to this matter.

The Western Australian State Minister is not alone. I understand that since he made that statement the Western Australian Labor Caucus has voted for the withdrawal of the legislation. No wonder the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made sure the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) was sent to London while this debate was on. The handling of this legislation has been atrocious and it clearly indicates the inability of this Minister effectively to administer his portfolio. The Minister should have made a genuine attempt to ascertain the views of those concerned and to develop a Bill which, whilst meeting the needs of the Aboriginal people, reflected a proper balance and protected the rights of others who will be affected by the legislation. The Minister could still achieve this by withdrawing the Bill and undertaking a fundamental redraft of the legislation. However, I doubt that he will adopt this course, because, as I have said, the Government is operating on a political timetable and is unwilling to let this debate flow over to the next session. No doubt the Minister would also like to avoid going to the July Australian Labor Party Conference empty handed. Australia's future unity is being jeopardised for the sake of political expediency.

The coalition parties in government and in opposition have made clear their concern for the need to protect significant sacred sites, and the need to preserve the integrity of Aboriginal culture and history. Indeed, the Northern Territory's land rights legislation includes specific reference to such sites. The Bill before the House does not refer to sacred sites and the areas around them which may need to be protected.

The Bill and the second reading speech by the Minister make it clear that he intends this legislation to have much wider application. There are so many fundamental flaws in the legislation that the Opposition has no alternative but to oppose the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they?

—Just wait and listen. The Bill is to apply not only in the Territories under Commonwealth control but also in the States. The legislation is based on the Minister's view that the Commonwealth is the seat of all wisdom in these matters. The States have legislation covering these issues and some States are in the process of reviewing their legislation. But this is a centralist government, and the Minister believes that where he is of the view that the State legislation is insufficient to provide the protection which he thinks the situation requires or, indeed, if he thinks the States have not acted in accordance with his wishes, even though they may be adopting a course of action to protect the area in question under their own legislation then he will override the State and intervene by making a declaration under the legislation before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has made no secret that it is the Government's intention to use the race relations power under the Constitution to impose on the States federal views in relation to Aboriginal affairs. It will be remembered that the Commonwealth Constitution, up until the 1967 referendum, denied the Commonwealth the power to legislate in relation to Aborigines. The 1967 referendum changed that by deleting that restriction from the Constitution.

The Yes case supporting the change in the Constitution clearly stated that the Commonwealth power would be used in co-operation with the States. This legislation is not in accordance with the Yes case, which was supported at the referendum. In the face of almost unanimous opposition from the States on this issue, any reasonable and rational Minister would reconsider this legislation, but not this Minister.

Let me give an example of the ramifications of this Commonwealth legislation and its effect when it is involved in the States. In August of last year an article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald indicating that the Minister was going to introduce legislation of this type because of the confrontation which had arisen at Cane Grass Swamp in the north of South Australia. Honourable members will recall that in that instance some members of the Aboriginal community did not want a road servicing the Roxby Downs mine to go over the Cane Grass Swamp area because it was claimed to be sacred. The Minister is quoted as saying at that time that the Roxby Downs confrontation had shown up the present inadequacies of laws on Aboriginal sites and given the problem more immediacy. Later in the article it was reported that Mr Holding had expressed his support of the Aboriginal claim but he said he was hampered from active Federal intervention because there was no relevant Commonwealth law protecting Aboriginal sites. Since that time he has made clear that the Roxby Downs dispute at Cane Grass Swamp was a case in point where by believed he needed Federal powers to intervene.

In relation to the dispute at Cane Grass Swamp, it will be recalled that as a result of negotiations undertaken under State legislation with the active participation of the State Government, the Roxby Downs management and the Aboriginal community, the issue was resolved. The original claim that the access road would have to go round Cane Grass Swamp was not maintained by the Aboriginals and agreement was reached that certain specific areas would be avoided with smaller deviations. Without going into all the details of those negotiations, it is clear that the parties did sit down and discuss the matter, and agreement was reached. However, the Minister says that that dispute is an example of why he wants this legislation passed. But I repeat, the dispute was resolved under the existing State law.

Given the repeated claims by the Minister that he needs this legislation because he would have liked to intervene, therefore let us look at what would have been the result if he had intervened. Under clause 9 of this Bill an application could have been made to the Minister by the Aboriginals concerned claiming that it was a significant Aboriginal area which was under serious and immediate threat of injury. There is no doubt that given the Ministers public statements on the issue, he would have then made a declaration prohibiting entry into the area which initially could be for up to 60 days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who says that?

—The legislation, Minister; read your own legislation. Under this legislation, the Minister then could have sought a report from a person nominated by him which, under the legislation, could have been one of the people seeking the declaration. Once he received the report-it may have been made by someone independent or it could have been made by one of the applicants making the report-he could have then prohibited entry into the area for a period up to two years, the period of this legislation.
—What provision is that?
—Clause 9. Has not the honourable member read the Bill either? That is the problem.
—Here it is in my hand.

—The Bill has not been to half of the honourable member's committees. He has not read the Bill and he does not understand it. Those are the powers which are given to the Minister under this legislation. Even Blind Freddy could see that the making of an emergency declaration or a more permanent declaration will not be conducive to the establishment of consultations to resolve the differences between the Aboriginal community, seeking to protect sacred sites which are significant to them, and the interests of the company, in that case seeking access to water. Rather than assisting in bringing together and initiating a process of consultation whereby the interests of both parties can best be served, this legislation is more likely to lead to a stand off and a delay in the resolution of the problems.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Roxby Downs example I use is a very relevant one, because the Minister in his second reading speech refers to a number of situations which have arisen during the life of this Parliament, and he said that these highlight 'the need for legislation to enable direct immediate action by the Commonwealth.' There is no doubt in my view that had this legislation been enforced at the time of the Roxby Downs dispute the Minister would have used his powers under this legislation and the dispute would still not be resolved.

The basis of a declaration being made under this legislation is that the area is a significant Aboriginal area, in accordance with Aboriginal tradition. So we are not talking about the protection of significant sacred sites. This legislation relates to the protection of significant Aboriginal areas. The legislation does not define whether the significance of the Aboriginal area relates to the fact that it is sacred or that it has a mythological or historic or recreational significance. It is an extraordinarily wide definition, and the power and discretion of the Minister under this Bill are almost unlimited.

TALK.START.PARA: —What clause is that?

—Try the definition clause, clause 3, you dodo. The unlimited power of the Minister is made dramatically clear when one considers that the Bill provides no guidelines as to how the Minister is to assess, in regard to an application made by an Aboriginal or an Aboriginal group or someone applying on their behalf, whether an area is a significant Aboriginal area and whether it is under threat. The Bill does not provide for the Minister to seek independent or expert advice, and there are no verification procedures set out in the Bill. The realities of the world are that in every community there are honest and dishonest people, and this proposed Act seems to be based on the fact the Minister believes only legitimate claims will be made. Given that all land in Australia-that is, Crown land, private land, urban land and rural land-is subject to claim under this legislation-
—What about leases?

—They are included as well. I believe the Australian public has a right to know how the Minister will satisfy himself that a claim is in fact legitimate and warrants protection before he imposes limitations on the use of the private or Crown land involved. There is no such procedure, especially in relation to emergency declarations. Under this legislation the Minister can not only make a declaration prohibiting people from entering their own land but also he can demand that the owner of a piece of land fence the area in question to stop others going on to that area without compensation being payable unless the courts consider that the Minister's declaration amounted to an acquisition. Of course it is not an acquisition in the true sense of the word. The land is not being purchased by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is merely limiting its use . Many believe that compensation would not be payable in such a case.

SPEECH.PARA: The next question is what area of land can the Minister declare under this legislation. In fact he could use this Bill as if it were land rights legislation and make a declaration in relation to unlimited areas of land within Australia. The Minister responded to this claim in his second reading speech by saying this:
I will not be making declaration with respect to vast areas of land in defacto recognition of a claim which Aboriginals may wish to make later under another law.

It is extremely important that we note the limitation placed on the area of land that the Minister is willing to declare. He says he is not willing to declare vast areas of land. Vast, of course, implies a very large area of land, and its interesting to note that the Minister did not use the words 'substantial' or ' large'. In the Minister's second reading speech he said that the Bill 'is not meant to close off huge areas'. I put it to the House that in fact this guarded qualification is no qualification at all. The Minister's choice of words makes it clear that he will not hesitate to consider using this legislation as if it were land rights legislation. There is no limitation to the area of land that he could declare. I suppose there is only one other word he could have used to give the qualification less meaning, and that is if he said he was not going to use the legislation in respect of gigantic areas. The fact that the Minister did not use the words 'large' or 'very large' or even 'substantial' indicates that he is reserving to himself the greatest possible powers under this legislation. Not only is all land claimable under this legislation but also there is virtually no limit on the amount of land that can be claimed.

There are additional areas of concern to the Opposition. In many instances of development in outback Australia, especially on Aboriginal land, mining companies and others enter into agreements with the owners regarding the use of the land. Those agreements cover sites to be avoided, and other arrangements are made if development is to proceed. This legislation throws those arrangements into doubt because whilst an agreement could be reached between a company and the traditional owners or land council this proposed Act provides an opportunity for a dissident Aboriginal to seek a declaration in relation to an area not covered by the existing arrangement which could put at risk the whole of the arrangement. In addition, under this legislation there is no requirement for the Aboriginal applicant to have a traditional affiliation with the land the subject of the application. I believe this introduces an intolerable element of uncertainty and confusion for those dealing with Aboriginal communities. Traditional owners and land councils could, in effect, lose control of their areas and Aboriginals could be barred from their own sacred sites, depending on the nature of the Minister's declaration. The Opposition has a number of very serious objections to the declaration provisions of this legislation and I shall deal with them in more detail at the Committee stage.
I turn now to the question of the means of reviewing the Minister's decision. In the Minister's second reading speech he states:
Review by the Houses of Parliament will, in effect, be the only review of the merits of the Minister's decision to make a declaration.

The review by Parliament is by means of disallowance of the declaration within 15 sitting days after it has been made. In the Opposition's view this review is totally inadequate. If this legislation were to be passed by the Senate next week and the Minister made his first declaration next Friday, that decision would not be reviewable by this House until it resumed its sittings on 21 August . So a declaration could be in force for up to three months before it is subject to review by the Parliament. The fact that this is the only form of review of the merits of the Minister's decision is of fundamental concern to the Opposition. The discretionary powers of the Minister are too wide and the opportunity to review is meaningless. Where there has been a breach of a declaration made under this legislation the penalties to be imposed on an individual are extremely high. For example, if someone were to enter an area which the Minister had declared was an Aboriginal area into which entry was prohibited-it should be borne in mind that under this legislation there is no restriction on the size of the area that can be so declared-the penalty is a fine up to $10,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding five years. I shall deal with this in more detail at the Committee stage. However, I make the point in passing that the provisions for notification in clauses 10 and 18 are, in our view, in breach of natural justice. We believe that it is vital for people who have an interest which is likely to be affected by the making of a declaration to have an opportunity to put their case. The notice provisions do not guarantee that. In fact, under clause 18 no notice is to be served. Clause 18 deals with declarations made by authorised officers and these officers are not required to advise those who will be affected by a declaration. Not only are the penalties under this legislation very substantial but the provisions of this legislation requiring notification of declaration are deficient.

The Government has tonight introduced further amendments to the legislation and whilst they overcome some of the objections the Opposition had in relation to the liability for penalty and the evidentiary provisions, the basis of our concern remains. This Bill does not relate to sacred sites but has much broader application. The Minister has almost totally unfettered powers to declare an area, and whilst the merit of his declaration may be reviewed by Parliament, I have already indicated this could still involve a substantial lapse of time between the making of the declaration and the review. Given the nature of the discretionary powers involved, the Opposition believes this is totally unsatisfactory. Compensation will be payable only if the declaration involves an acquisition and in most conceivable cases, even if severe limitations are put on the use of private land, this is unlikely to amount to an acquisition and therefore will not be compensatable.

The legislation allows substantial ministerial discretion to be made especially in relation to the area of land claimed and even the Minister's qualification regarding how he intends to use the legislation is no limitation at all and provides no restriction on the powers this Bill confers. The legislation applies to all land and there is no guarantee that private interests will be protected. The Opposition opposes the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take great pleasure, in fact sheer delight, in participating in the debate tonight on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill 1984. I must begin by commenting on the speech we have just heard from the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). What a pathetic contribution to emanate from the mouth of a shadow Minister in this Parliament. For all we knew we could have been witnessing a debate about the protection of miners' rights. We could have been witnessing a debate on some esoteric subject. We certainly were not witnessing a contribution at all helpful to an understanding of the Bill before the House or, most importantly, the issue that the Bill seeks to address, that is, the protection of Aboriginal sites of significance.

SPEECH.PARA: I have joined the debate on this Bill because, like other members of the Government, I have been outraged by the contributions of those from the Liberal and National parties who oppose the Bill but particularly from individuals in the mining industry such as Mr Hugh Morgan who purportedly speak on behalf of the mining industry. The opposition to the Bill has been based on a campaign of misinformation and outright misrepresentation, but, more than anything else, has at its foundation the deliberate incitement to racial hatred. The Bill is, of course, one of the most historic pieces of legislation ever to come before the Parliament. It is the first important national legislation for the protection of Aboriginal rights ever enacted in the entire history of the Commonwealth Parliament. As the honourable member for Barker pointed out, the Commonwealth gained power to pass this law only in 1967 when the necessary Bill to amend the Constitution was passed, I remind honourable members, unanimously by this House and subsequently was ratified by a record 92.7 Yes vote of the Australian people .

Despite the fact that that Bill was passed unanimously by the Parliament there were clearly very different views as to what might be achieved by the Commonwealth's newly acquired powers. The then Opposition Leader Whitlam stated in the House that as a result of the change 'the members of this Parliament will be able for the first time to do something for Aboriginals-Aboriginals representing the greatest pockets of poverty and disease in this country. The Commonwealth can at last bring the resources of the whole nation to bear in favour of Aboriginals where they live'. On the other hand, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), then Minister for Social Security, said following the passage of the referendum that the Government had 'nothing specific in mind' and that its policies would be worked out during the Budget discussions. What a tragedy that nothing has really changed in the Liberal and National parties and in their attitudes to Aboriginal affairs.

The policies of this Government are directed towards building a society based on tolerance and mutual understanding. We do not seek confrontation but there comes a time to draw the line. In the debate on this legislation sections of the Australian mining industry and elements in the Opposition have transgressed the baseline of public and commercial morality and their record and actions should be publicly exposed and rejected by all concerned Australians. I stress that I do not seek to attack all members of the Opposition, because many honourable members on the Opposition benches have a genuine concern for the well being of Aboriginal Australians. Regrettably, however, in political terms the members of the Opposition parties in that category do not have the numbers and increasingly Opposition policies on questions of race are being dominated by the extreme right wing in those parties, particularly by a rump element in the now discredited National Party. This trend is evident in the soft policy of the Opposition on southern Africa, the desperate attempts to introduce racial prejudice as an element in the immigration debate, and now in the overt overtones evident in the opposition to the Bill. Likewise, I do not seek to condemn all sections of the mining industry because that industry has every right to express its views on the legislation before the House and on Aboriginal land rights. Some mining interests have indeed expressed opposition to the legislation in good faith. Those mining interests, in my opinion, have generally maintained good relationships with Aboriginal communities and have not sought to ride roughshod over the interests of the Aboriginal people. My comments are not directed towards that section of the industry nor to what I would describe as the concerned sections in the Opposition.

I now turn to the real opponents of this legislation in the Opposition and in the ugly face of sections of the Australian mining industry. Following white colonisation, Aboriginal Australians-as a matter of historical record-were driven off their land by force and confined to reservations. This dispossession enabled the establishment of a large scale pastoral industry which continues to be a major part of the country's economy. A further stage in the exploitation of Aboriginal land and people was reached with the development of the mining industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't be here if they had not-

—No doubt that interjection came from the National Party. Members of that party know that they are treading on dangerous ground. They know that people in the rural community no longer look to the National Party for representation but rather to members of the Labor Party like the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler). Increasingly the National Party is seen to represent not just mining interests but multinational foreign mining interests and has deserted its constituency. Those telling facts will come home to roost at the next Federal election.

SPEECH.PARA: The mining companies have frequently discovered minerals on land inhabited by Aborigines. With only limited recent exceptions, the Aborigines have been powerless to resist the pressure of powerful mining companies, particularly because of the ability of the foreign mining interests to enlist the support of Liberal and National Party-controlled State and Federal governments which have actively collaborated in using force and brutality to evict Aboriginal people from their land and to destroy places of particular significance to Aboriginal people in accordance with their traditions.

It should be made crystal clear, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has repeatedly done, that the purpose of this Bill is not to enact Aboriginal land rights but to enact an interim measure to protect areas of significance and to ensure the protection of objects of particular significance to Aboriginals or Islanders in accordance with their traditions. In this regard I cannot help but comment on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation which only last Friday broadcast for almost the entire day a news story which said that this Bill was all about Aboriginal land rights. It has nothing to do with Aboriginal land rights. It is about time that the media lifted their game and paid Aboriginal land rights the attention that it deserves as we lead up to the Australian Bicentenary. The legislation before the House has become particularly urgent because of the unrestrained activities of mining companies which have led to the destruction of sites of sacred religious significance to Aboriginal communities. To add insult to injury, mining development has failed to generate significant employment opportunities and where jobs have been provided the working conditions were sometimes so bad that major occupational health hazards were created, as at the James Hardie Baryugal asbestos mine. It is clear that the activities of some mining companies clearly constitute the cutting edge of efforts to destroy what remains of Aboriginal culture and sites of significance.

Let me demonstrate the appalling record of the mining industry which makes this legislation necessary. In 1969 Nabalco Pty Ltd, a company owned by Alsuisse, and in which Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, CSR Ltd, Peko-Wallsend and the AMP Society had substantial interests, was granted bauxite strip mining rights over 80 square miles of the Arnhem Land reserve. Nabalco was granted a large part of the land of the Yirrkala Aborigines around the mission settlement on a lease that did not expire until the year 2053. Nabalco plundered the land and the people and what was once one of the most culturally intact societies in Australia has suffered disastrously. Despite the efforts of Methodist missionaries to support the people and an historic attempt by those Aboriginal people to use the whit legal system to protect their community, the mining companies were again victorious. Nothing has changed for the majority of Aboriginal people since 1969.

At Noonkanbah in 1980 in Western Australia we saw another case study of the relationship of mining companies to Aboriginal people. The Yungngora tribe has lived in this part of Western Australia since time immemorial and at that time held a pastoral lease over an area of land on which a co-operative cattle station was run. On this property was a site called Pea Hill which was of great significance to the Aboriginal people. The United States oil company, Amax Exploration, with the complicity of the former Western Australian conservative government, obtained licences to drill for oil at Pea Hill. Extensive opposition by tribal elders, churches and trade unions was ignored and eventually the police and mining interest led a military style convoy of 50 trucks to Pea Hill and brutally evicted those making a last stand there.

In the light of this appalling confrontationist record of the mining industry and of conservative governments, Mr Hugh Morgan of the Australian Mining Industry Council and the honourable member for Barker, who is the shadow Minister, have the gall to talk about the lack of consultation in relation to the protection of Aboriginal sacred sites. While I am speaking about the honourable member for Barker, I want to say what a double the Opposition parties have dealt up to this Parliament on two sensitive areas of government administration. The track record of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) in the area of immigration and ethnic affairs is becoming legendary in debates in this House. In another crucial area, Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Barker is becoming a joke in Aboriginal communities right across Australia.

I turn my attention again to the record of the Australian mining giant, Conzinc Riotinto. Some five years ago a vast deposit of diamonds was discovered in the Kimberly Mountains of Western Australia. CRA and Ashton Mining formed a joint venture to exploit the estimated $2 billion plus deposit. The diamond resource was located in a sacred site. The joint venturers claimed to have a contract by which Aboriginal people consented to the mining of diamonds. However, neither the local Aboriginal land council nor the traditional owners were parties to the contract. The agreement was signed with this corporate master of dirty tricks by one family. They were flown 2,000 kilometres to Perth to negotiate with the company. The agreement with Ashton was appropriately described by Mr Phillip Adams as 'a pitiful barter of pocket knives, mirrors and beads for perhaps the richest piece of real estate on earth'. As further evidence of the dirty corporate behaviour of CRA, undertaken to advance its unrestraining ravaging of Aboriginal sites of significance, I wish to refer to a leaked internal company document of the Ashton joint venture which has been made publicly available. The document is dated November 1980 and states:
A public relations program for 1981 will be concerned principally with the following issues:

1. Sustaining the Argyle Agreement signed with the Glen Hill Aboriginal community and isolating this agreement from the general debate on Aboriginal land rights, while encouraging community acceptance of the company's policy towards its Aboriginal neighbours.

As well as being intended to put a favourable gloss on the joint venturers' notorious Aboriginal policies, the public relations programs were also intended to achieve favourable government action in relation to the processing of diamonds. The campaign in this regard was also notably successful.

I find this document a devastating expose of the corporate practice that this internal company document reveals. In one year, 1981, CRA and its joint venture partners proposed to spend $374,000 on public relations. The primary task of this public relations jaunt was to whitewash the appalling treatment by the joint venture of Aboriginal people living in the vicinity of the mine.

The $374,000 spent on public relations dwarfs the annual payment of only $40, 000 paid to one of the three adjacent Aboriginal communities. However, the weight and strength of transnational corporate power is not going to win this debate because the tide is changing and the Government is committed to ensuring the passage of the legislation before the House which is both a moderate and a modest measure to ensure minimum standards of protection to Aboriginal significant sites and objects which also have particular significance to Aboriginals or Islanders because of their traditions.

The legislation will fill a gap in the law of Australia which can allow sites of significance to be changed, destroyed or desecrated and can allow objects of significance, including Aboriginal human remains, to be traded, displayed or otherwise used in ways which are anathema to Aboriginals and their traditions.

The detailed provisions of the Bill have been outlined by the Minister in his second reading speech. I am constrained by time from proceeding to those provisions. Criticism has been expressed concerning certain limited provisions of the Bill which provide maximum penalties for individuals for certain breaches of the Act of a fine of up to $10,000 and five years gaol and, in the case of corporations, fines of up to $50,000. This does merit special attention by me. These are, indeed, substantial penalties for violation of Aboriginal places of special significance. However, I ask non-Aboriginal Australians to remember that they have long had protection. In fact draconian criminal law provisions have long been enshrined in the Australian criminal law to protect places of special significance to them. I refer to section 106 of the New South Wales Crimes Act which creates the crime of sacrilege. If the mining companies were to perpetrate their consultation by bulldozer in a non-Aboriginal established place of worship they would, under the New South Wales Act, be liable to a penalty of 20 years gaol.

I conclude by again stating that this legislation cannot be considered as any form of Aboriginal land rights. This is the first legislation of the Parliament since Federation which seeks directly to protect what remains of Aboriginal culture and significant sites, after 196 years of neglect. The legislation is so important that it deserves better treatment at the hands of the Opposition. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage ( Interim Protection) Bill, in my view, can be described only as a social timebomb . I listened very carefully to the contribution that was just made by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). He outlined in considerable detail the impact that mining companies have had on various parts of Australia. I can only conclude that, by implication, the honourable member was suggesting that the mining developments that he mentioned and perhaps others that he did not mention should not have been developed, rather the products of those mining ventures should have been left in the ground and not used for the benefit either of people in this country or people in other countries. That is the only conclusion that I can reach from the comments that were made by the honourable member for Hughes.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member mentioned other things in which I share his concern. He mentioned the potential that this Bill has for racial prejudice and violence. He also mentioned the possibility flowing from this Bill of a right wing backlash that could cause racial prejudice and violence. In that regard I totally share the honourable member's concern. I believe that we need to look very carefully- in doing that we ought not to be influenced by partisan bias-at what is happening in the community of Australia. We ought not to be influenced by our own partisan political viewpoints, rather we ought to be influenced by the people of this country. People who come into this House who believe that by the power of legislation they can cause the changing of the viewpoints of the people of Australia are doing no more than deceiving themselves. Honourable members in this place can only reflect the viewpoints of the people of this country. If we try to do other than that we cause a backlash that we cannot control.

Over a period there has been a political infiltration into the Aboriginal organisations of this country. That has caused the very genuine and needed protection in matters affecting Aboriginals to be used for blatant political purposes. That has been coming from those agitated, left wing-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about--
—Order! The honourable member for Leichhardt must not interject when he is not sitting in his own seat.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I must pause to concur with what you say. Quite frankly, I feel very sorry for the people of Leichhardt who voted for such an overweight, unintelligent clown. I am sure they will change their minds at the next election. I share the concern of the honourable member for Hughes that the agitation that has been evident for some considerable time by left wing political agitators within the Aboriginal movement is now causing a right wing backlash. That should be of great concern to everyone in this House. We are now seeing a confrontation between right wing and left wing groups in this country with the Aboriginals being the meat in the sandwich. Nothing in that will help the Aboriginals nor will it protect their land, sacred sites, culture or anything else.

SPEECH.PARA: Credibility is being given to people such as Geoff McDonald, to people in the League of Rights and other right wing groups that is not justified. The reason they are being given that credibility is that there is a genuine concern throughout the community. If we ignore that concern we do so at our great peril. To ignore that concern and simply be influenced by our own political bias is to incite the very racial prejudice and violence that this Bill has the potential to cause. It gives rise to the concern of the honourable member for Hughes. To ignore that concern of the people of Australia is folly in the extreme. I urge my friends on the other side of the House not to be dominated by their own party dogma and doctrine but to give serious thought to the direction in which the community of Australia wants this matter to go. It is not the winning of a brownie point in this House that is of concern. The real concern is the Aboriginals and what will happen to them as a consequence.

I assure the House that the Opposition has great respect for the Aboriginal people. We have great respect for their culture, their religions and the contributions that they can make to the future of this country. We do not want to see class or racial hatred being inflamed in this country because we respect the Aboriginal people, their culture and what they can contribute to this country. This Bill will incite that sort of class hatred with all the potential it has for violence, disruption and beyond.

This legislation gives advantages and privileges to one class of people because of the colour of their skin. Other Australians who do not have the same skin colour or are not of the same racial background will be denied those privileges and advantages. That is apartheid. Apartheid is being practised in this country by this Government. I share the abhorrence of the apartheid being practised in other countries and I know that my colleagues on this side of the House do also. We strongly urge the Government not to introduce apartheid practices in this country. Apartheid does not only give rise to white prejudice against black people; it can be the same in reverse. That is what is happening.

Because of my respect and concern for the Aboriginal people I wish to see the preservation of Aboriginal sacred sites, tribal laws and culture. As was pointed out recently by Professor Blainey during the immigration debate, government action and legislation cannot be allowed to move ahead of public opinion. That is precisely what this Government is doing with this legislation. In a recent Press statement the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) described this Bill as ill-considered and dangerous. I concur with him. It certainly has that potential. It is ill-considered because it takes no account of public opinion. It is dangerous because it has the potential to incite violent racial clashes in many parts of this country.

The major problem in framing policies for Aboriginals is to distinguish between what I class as various categories of Aboriginals. That is something with which nobody in this country seems to be prepared to come to terms. By accepting the definition of an Aborigine as outlined in the Bill as one who identifies as an Aborigine and is accepted by others as being an Aborigine, the Government is ignoring the different problems faced by people of Aboriginal descent. People who are part Aboriginal and who have different problems from full-blooded Aboriginals are completely ignored in this Bill and they are completely ignored in all the Aboriginal policies that have been framed over the years. I assure the House that there are differences. For honourable members not to come to grips with those differences is not, in the longer term, helping the Aboriginal people or their heritage. Equally, we should look objectively at the different problems being faced by those people living in urban areas, fringe dwellers and those living on tribal land. The problems faced by each of those groups are quite distinctly different. Simply to lump all these people into one big basket and to try to come up with blanket solutions is quite unrealistic and we simply cannot do it. That is what this Bill proposes. There are differences in the problems being faced by Aboriginals in different circumstances. We need to look objectively at the different problems they face. We need to come up with different solutions.

Clearly, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is accepting proposals put to him by so-called spokesmen for the Aboriginal movement. However , many of these spokesmen are left wing political agitators who are using the Aboriginal people as pawns in their political game. To these people helping the Aboriginals takes second place to causing disruption in a strategically placed Western democracy. I believe we may have heard some evidence of that given in an earlier contribution by the honourable member for Hughes. These people should be condemned by all Australians for their callous disregard and abuse of the Aboriginal people, but the fact that the Minister accedes to the demands of political agitation rather than to the genuine Aboriginals should be condemned and demonstrates just how out of touch this Minister is.

The Government is introducing this Bill to give greater claim to land rights for the Aboriginals. The Aboriginals claim to have a close affinity with the land and I have no doubt whatever that they have. But I remind the House that I too have a close affinity with the land because my people have been farmers for 300 years but I do not claim land rights. It is my view that Aboriginals have no greater claim to land than people of any other origin. The fact that they have occupied land for a considerable time does not give Aborigines or any other people the absolute ownership of that land. We must always remember that the land belongs to God and we are simply here for a short time as caretakers of that land. The fact that land and other natural assets have been provided by God does not mean that one group of people has greater claim to those assets than other people and therefore can dictate who can and who cannot enjoy those God- given assets. Surely the benefits of those things provided by God are for the maintenance and benefit of mankind regardless of where they live or what the colour of their skin is.

The Aboriginal people have a marvellous communal spirit that I greatly envy and that encourages those people to look after and help each other, and I greatly admire them for that. Why then do so-called spokesmen for Aboriginals try to deny other people access to the beauty of the land, to urgently needed minerals, to the productive capacity of that land that could help feed starving people? I cannot conceive that genuine Aboriginal people would be so selfish but I do accept that politically motivated agitators would deny those things to mankind. This Bill can be described only as apartheid. It encourages separate development depending on the colour of a person's skin. I notice the Minister laughs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What crap!

—The Minister says: 'What crap'. I hope that will be recorded by Hansard . Why this Minister and his Government are so intent on purposely and provocatively introducing apartheid into this country escapes me. We on this side of the House understand and accept the need to preserve significant Aboriginal sacred sites just as we accept the sanctity of places held sacred by people who have different religious beliefs. But significant Aboriginal sacred sites do not include half the Northern Territory nor does it give carte blanche to claim any area in Australia, which is precisely what my friend and colleague the honourable member for Barker has pointed out that this Bill does.

SPEECH.PARA: As one who rejects extremist politics of both the Left and the Right I am concerned at the invidious position that the Aboriginal people are being placed in. Marxist extremists have infiltrated and are using the Aboriginal organisations for extremist and disruptive purposes. That is now starting to cause this right wing backlash that I spoke of earlier and is giving credence to right wing extremist organisations. That backlash, as it is being accepted now by the community and as I have said has been given a credence that it does not deserve because of the widespread community concern, has all the potential to cause racial violence in this country. If the Government ignores that potential and ignores that community concern I assure it, the House and the Aboriginal people of this country that it does so at its own peril. I for one do not want to see the sort of racial and religious backlash that we have seen in countries such as England, Lebanon, Sri Lanka and other places of the world. Thankfully, we have managed to keep those things out of Australia and I hope we will always be able to keep them out of Australia. However this Bill could well introduce such differences, and potentially dangerous differences, into this country.

As I have said this Bill has the potential to cause widespread disruption in Australia, to incite violent and racial clashes on a scale that we have not seen in this country. Rather than help preserve the Aboriginal people, their culture and their religions, it has all the potential to destroy the Aboriginal people, to destroy their culture and to destroy their religion. If the Minister has any genuine concern for the Aboriginal people I strongly urge him to see the dangers of this Bill and have it withdrawn immediately.

—Most definitely.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The honourable member for Wilmot, in his contribution, stated repeatedly that I had said that the effect of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill was to incite racial hatred. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) referred to a gentleman-if I can call him a gentleman-by the name of Geoffrey McDonald. He criticised Geoffrey McDonald although on 2 May he referred to him as an expert on migration questions. The honourable member for Wilmot stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe the Government alone is the perpetrator of this master plan. I believe it is the innocent fool, if I can put it that way, which is being led by others of a more sinister nature. For the benefit of the Minister and the House I will quote from a book entitled Red Over Black, written by an Aboriginal named Geoff McDonald.

Not only was the honourable member for Wilmot quoting a person who is one of the greatest racists in our society but he is also quoting a person who is not an Aboriginal. So in an immigration debate he is quoting a person who is a known racist and claims that he is proud of his political beliefs and in this debate which is about Aborigines he is quoting an expert, claiming he is an Aboriginal which the gentleman is not. I think that puts to pay the views that have been expressed by the honourable member for Wilmot.

This legislation is historic and I am proud to be part of a government which has the moral conscience and the political strength to bring it forward. I remind the House of the policy on which the Australian Labor Party, of which I am a member, campaigned at the last election. Page 5 of the Federal platform concerning Aborigines and Islanders policy states that we will:
7 Take responsibility, where necessary-

(a) for the establishment of representative councils of Aborigines and Islanders, for securing identification and protection of sacred sites including women's sacred sites and other sites of significance; and
(b) for preserving sacred objects and other valued articles belonging to Aboriginal and Islander people, including those objects in museums and storage.
8 Assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders' guardians and custodians to regain and preserve objects of cultural and spiritual significance.
9 Develop, in co-operation with the states and territories, effective Aboriginal heritage legislation.

Although that statement was made at election time, people ought to be able to understand from it that we are committed to the views expressed in the legislation. Tonight we are debating the legislation and we are, in fact, going to pass it. I remind the House of what the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) said in his second reading speech. He stated:

This Bill has two main purposes: To preserve and protect areas in Australia and Australian waters which are of particular significance to Aboriginals or Islanders in accordance with their traditions; and to preserve and protect objects, including Aboriginal and Islander human remains, which are of particular significance to Aboriginals or Islanders in accordance with their traditions.

The Hawke Labor Government came to office in March 1983 with a mandate to pursue its constitutional responsibilities to advance the interests of the Aboriginal people. A very significant step towards advancing the position of the Aboriginal people in this country is that of recognising Aboriginal culture as a living culture and of ensuring the security and protection of Aboriginal sacred sites and Aboriginal sacred objects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this?

—If the honourable member came over here, I doubt whether he would be able to read it. It should be clearly understood that Aboriginal people consider this legislation to be less than adequate and they look forward to the enactment of comprehensive legislation which will provide a greater control of the protection of sacred sites and objects. It is good to see the shadow spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs in here tonight. I well recall his being absent for most of the discussion on the expenditure for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs when the Appropriation Bills were debated. It is interesting and good to see him present tonight, although his speech was full of inaccuracies. He accused members on this side of the House of not having read the Bill. For the benefit of the record I will read from the explanatory memorandum the section relating to clauses 9 and 10 of Division 1-Declarations by Minister of Part II-Protection of Significant Aboriginal Areas and Objects which states:

SPEECH.PARA: These clauses provide the scheme for the making of declarations by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in relation to areas of land or water of particular significance to Aboriginals.

Clause 9: Emergency declarations in relation to areas 11. On receipt of an application by or on behalf of Aboriginals, the Minister may make a declaration containing provisions for and in relation to the protection and preservation of an area from injury or desecration . . . Before making the declaration the Minister will need to be satisfied that the area is a significant Aboriginal area which is under serious and immediate threat of injury or desecration. Such an emergency declaration will have effect for not more than 30 days, although the Minister may extend the effect of the declaration for a further period up to 60 days from the day from which the declaration first came into effect.
Clause 10: Other declarations in relation to areas.

12. If the Minister receives an application as in clause 9, and he is satisfied that a threat exists, but it is not serious and immediate, he may make a declaration in similar terms to those outlined in clause 9. However, unlike the emergency declaration, he will also be required to have received and considered a report in respect of the application from a person nominated by him. The person will publish a notice inviting interested persons to make representations in connection with the report. He will give due consideration to any such representations and will attach them to the report. That report will deal with a range of matters relevant to the Minister's decision whether to make a declaration, and the contents and duration of any such declaration. In making his decision the Minister may consider such other matters as he thinks relevant. The declaration will have effect for such period as is specified in it.
There is no mention of the two years that was stated by the shadow spokesman. The reference to two years is in the Minister's speech and deals with the lifetime of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has a sunset clause.

—That is right. Clauses 9 and 10 show quite clearly that the Minister is bound to protect the interests of all parties involved in the declaration in relation to areas. The Minister has the same sort of responsibility-it is required of him-in regard to declarations in relation to objects in following clauses in the Bill. A later section of the Minister's second reading speech deals with State and Territory laws, another area which honourable members on the other side have misrepresented. For the purpose of the record it is well worth repeating what the Minister said. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is not attempting to cover the legislative field in this area of heritage protection. The Bill expresses an intention not to exclude or limit the operation of a law of a State or Territory that is capable of operating concurrently with it. In practice the Commonwealth sees this as legislation to be used as a last resort. The processes for the making and continuation of declarations will ensure that full recognition will be given to relevant State and Territory laws, and co-operation will be sought from State and Territory governments.

Where the Minister is considering whether to make a declaration in relation to an area, an object or a class of objects, he will be obliged to consult the relevant State or Territory Minister to ascertain whether there is effective protection of the area, object or objects. In the case of Norfolk Island he will consult the relevant Executive Member. By reference to long-standing convention, he will consult the Minister for Territories and Local Government . . . where the Australian Capital Territory or an external Territory, other than Norfolk Island is concerned.

Again the Bill states that we will consult all parties. This Bill complements State legislation. Many lies and half truths have been told by people in relation to the legislation. For that matter, proof is available that the coalition and the conservative forces have banded together with people referred to by the honourable member for Wilmot, such as Geoff McDonald, to hold back any legislation that would advantage Aboriginals. We have an incredible coalition of forces relating to ethnic affairs and Aborigines. I wonder which will be the next one in our society to jump on the bandwagon-which of the ratbag elements in our society-and seek to discredit for cheap political gain at election time. These forces whip up fear and frenzy in the community, frightening people as they did at Frankston, in the electorate of the honourable member for Flinders ( Mr Chynoweth) the other night and which they will be doing in the electorate of Wannon next week. I refer to people such as Geoff McDonald and Bruce Ruxton. What a notable pair to have on a platform! Conservative parties such as the Liberals and the Nationals have joined forces with the League of Rights, led by Geoff McDonald and other disreputable individuals throughout Victoria. Members of those parties have been joining up with the National Front. This is the organisation that is waging the campaign against Asian migrants. These people throughout Victoria have come together on the land rights issue. They are led by people such as Bruce Ruxton from the Returned Services League. These people out in the community are distorting the truth and creating fear in the non- Aboriginal community. To back up and get support for my claim I refer to the Age of 31 May 1984. The editorial is headed 'How the Right gets it wrong'. The editorial states:

There are many statistics-as in 'lies, damned lies and statistics'-being thrown around in what could be loosely termed the debate on Aboriginal land rights. There are also ambit claims, exaggerations, outrageous statements and attempts, thinly disguised or otherwise, to appeal to all that is selfish, nasty and racist in the Australian character: land rights will enable Aborigines to build a separate nation; Aborigines are only the stalking horses for communists in their bid to take over Australia; industry will halt and the lights will go out as Aborigines ban all mining; sacred sites are invented for greed, and, of course, recognition of the principle of land rights gives a blessing to cannibalism.

I repeat that this is a statement in the Melbourne Age, not a statement by honourable members on this side of the House, referring to members of the Opposition parties at the grass roots level in Victoria. The Age is talking about members of the National and Liberal parties in the State Parliament who are out beating the drum throughout Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dorothy Turner.

—One such person in Frankston is Dorothy Turner, a prominent member of the National Party in the Frankston Area. Honourable members should go down through Wannon and Corangamite and those areas. The two honourable members sitting opposite know exactly the people I am talking about. If they want to get up and claim that such people are friends of theirs, that is all right with me. At least the people will see. I return to the Age editorial. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: In rural Victoria the extreme Right is on the march, spreading alarm about the Victorian Government's Aboriginal Land--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do that again and I will take on your mate. I have not mentioned that .
—The honourable member should be quiet. The last time he had anything to do with an Aborigine his brother held him while he hit him over the head with an iron bar. Now he should be quiet.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Melbourne will cease making the remarks he made and continue with his speech.
—I will get back to the Age editorial. I never thought the Age could whip up such excitement on the other side.
—The honourable member will ignore the interjections.
—The Age states:

SPEECH.PARA: In rural Victoria, the extreme Right is on the march, spreading alarm about the Victorian Government's Aboriginal Land Claims Bill, casting wild and ugly conspiracy theories on to ground which, unfortunately, is, here and there, fertile.
Obviously, that refers to Corangamite, Wannon Gippsland and Frankston. The editorial goes on:

The Bill itself, in principle, is a sensible attempt to do a measure of justice to Victorian Aborigines and to provide them with means to overcome the devastating effects of dispossession and life as social and economic outcasts in what was their forebears' land . . . The extreme Right has seized upon, and distorted, the State Government's purchase of land at Lake Condah-
that is in the electorate of the honourable member for Wannon-
a 150th birthday project . . .

That is what the Melbourne Age thinks about the State Liberal Party and National Party in Victoria led by Kennett and Ross-Edwards who are out beating the drum and turning non-Aboriginal people against Aboriginal people right throughout Victoria. I turn now to the miners. I refer to an advertisement which appeared in the Canberra Times on 31 May 1984. Six points were made in the advertisement. Some outrageous claims were made, not dissimilar to claims being made by the League of Rights and other people.

As time is running away from me, I will not read them over. However, they are there for those people who want to go back to that Canberra Times and have a look at it. A number of accusations were made. However, every one of those accusations is untrue. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) can grin, but I am coming to him. He will grin a bit more when I am finished with him. The honourable member for Barker comes in here tonight and talks about what the State Labor Caucus of Western Australia does, what we as members of the Labor Party are to do at our Federal Conference and what goes on in our Cabinet rooms, et cetera. I remind the honourable member for Barker that those organisations have expressed support for this legislation. The Victorian, New South Wales, South Australian and Western Australian governments now support the Bill following the amendments to it. The Director of the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority, Mr Ellis, has expressed the view:

As it stands the Bill is a sensible and sensitive attempt to balance the various community needs and viewpoints and its passage will enable resolution of present and future potential conflicts in our State and Territories.

The National Aboriginal Conference has advised by telex that it supports the legislation. The honourable member for Barker comes in here tonight, having misread the Bill and makes wild accusations about people over here who have tried to correct him and get him on the right side of things. During Question Time today he was only $720,000 out in a Press release that was circulated to the Aboriginal community. That can only be described as an untruth, given that we are not allowed to say that other word in this place. However, everybody else would use the word we are not allowed to say. A person who wants to be a Minister in this place was $720,000 out in a Press release. It is a disgrace. I now refer to a telex from the National Aboriginal Conference to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It states:
I wish to clarify some matters concerning the Opposition spokesman for Aboriginal affairs, Mr James Porter.
1. The NAC has not discussed the interim heritage legislation in any depth at any stage.
2. The NAC is of the view that Mr Porter has not adequately consulted with Aboriginal people, either through their recognised advisors to the Federal Government, the NAC, or by any other means.
3. The NAC intends to ask that Mr Porter be transferred out of the portfolio-
that is, the shadow portfolio-
due to:
(A) his failure to consult with Aboriginal people or their representatives.
(B) his sellout of Aboriginal interests for mining interests shown by his ill- considered comments in the media on the Bill.

What do we have here? We have a shadow Minister for the Aboriginal affairs portfolio whom the people he is supposed to represent want removed. The New South Wales ethnic communities want to remove the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) from his portfolio.
