I wonder how many other community groups want people removed from the front bench opposite. I suggest that they keep the telegrams and letters coming in because we will keep reading them out.

This Bill will prevent problems such as that we had in Tasmania over the Crowther collection of relics which were brought about by the insensitivity of the Tasmanian Government which-I remind people-declared overnight that there were no Aboriginals in Tasmania. When it had a funding problem with the last Federal Government overnight they all just disappeared, even though the Tasmanian Government was receiving money for other programs to assist Tasmanian Aborigines. We will put an end to problems such as those which occurred in regard to the Roxby Downs project at Olympic Dam. I reject the comments made regarding that project and the effects it had on the Bill, as put by the shadow spokesman. The Kokatha people are glad we have introduced the Bill. I urge the shadow spokesman to talk to the Kokatha people and other communities which he has not done. I have been with him in various places and he has not talked to people once about this Bill when I have been with him, and I have been present at many Aboriginal meetings with him and he has not raised it once. Quite a number of other problems have occurred at Alice Springs. The Sotheby's auctions have occurred, at which Aboriginal relics have been sold. This Bill puts an end to all of those problems. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably the worst feature of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill is that it has been brought to this House without adequate consultation. Indeed, one of the professed objectives of the Hawke Labor Government has been to achieve consensus among people on issues of great importance to the community, both economic and social. I am very concerned that that consultation has not occurred, either with the State governments or with the interested organisations. Indeed, I believe that this legislation has a potential to cause anxiety and divisiveness in the community. It is the type of legislation that should at least lie on the table during the winter recess to enable proper consultation to take place and to avoid the sort of social backlash that I believe could flow from it.

SPEECH.PARA: The draconian provisions in the legislation vest in the Minister for Aboriginal affairs extraordinary powers over the property rights of Australian citizens and in this society they are important and precious rights.

Those property rights range from a farm to a suburban allotment to a mine on a mining prospect. This legislation has the potential to inflame racial differences between Australians, black and white, and in certain areas could cause a racial backlash against Aboriginal people who have earned a great deal of respect and community goodwill in recent times. It has been a long, hard road for those who have been concerned with Aboriginal rights and the social problems of Aboriginal people to condition the mind of the average Australian to the view that Aborigines should get special treatment to lift their self-esteem and their capacity to take their proper place in the Australian community. But I fear that this legislation will not achieve that sort of objective. I represent an electorate that contains a large number of Aboriginal people and where there can be racial difficulties from time to time in many of its towns.

This legislation affects or could affect many Australians. I believe it is an attack on our most cherished democratic right-that is, the property right of people. This legislation vests extraordinary powers in the hands of the Minister to achieve a professed objective to enable the Minister to declare areas of significance to Aborigines. It gives extensive powers to the Minister to make declarations of areas of significance to Aborigines, and not just significant sacred sites. The Opposition strongly supports both the recognition and the preservation of significant sacred sites for Aboriginal people.

This legislation can apply to all land throughout Australia, whether it is private, Crown, rural or urban land. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) attempts to water down the interpretation of the powers by saying that the Bill does not intend the powers to be used so widely. Therefore, I ask the question: Why does he not amend the legislation to make the law clear? That would, for instance, clear up the matter of what land is involved. 'Areas of significance' is a very wide definition of the type of land or object that is likely to be considered within the purview of this legislation. I believe that if the Minister redrafted the legislation it would alleviate some of the very valid fears held by a wide range of community bodies, although other basic flaws in the legislation would remain. I urge the Minister to take another look at what he is doing. He should at least attempt to obtain a greater degree of community support for the Bill than presently exists.

The Minister is seeking virtually unlimited discretion in choosing which areas or objects will be declared to be of significance to Aborigines. The Minister decides the restrictions and conditions applying to this declaration and the length of time that the declaration will remain in force. The Minister would be free to grab whatever land or objects he sees fit, the only controlling factor being the extent of the political backlash that he thought it might provoke. It is this sort of legislation that provides the weapon for the sort of extremist that none of us like. This legislation places every Australian landowner at the whim and mercy of a Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—It does, indeed-or his delegate. The legislation threatens to produce deep internal division between Aboriginal Australians and other Australians. Why is it that the Labor Government wants to give itself effective control over land rightly belonging to the citizens of this nation in the manner which this legislation enables?

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is riddled with blatant attacks on the rights of the Australian people. The powers of the Minister to make declarations on sites and objects are retrospective. He is unfettered in applying these powers to existing farmland, farm buildings, mines and all other objects on any land. There is no provision to serve notice prior to any declaration; there is no provision to compensate land owners affected by such declaration. Application for takeover of areas or objects need not be made by a person who claims association with such areas or objects. The application can be made by any Aboriginal or by anyone acting on behalf of an Aboriginal. That is spelt out in the legislation.

The Minister has failed to indicate how he will satisfy himself that an area is significant to Aboriginal people. He requires no verification of that significance. The Minister has open powers to appoint officers who may then make emergency declarations without reference to him. This Parliament has no authority to review those declarations. Further, there is no right of appeal by any person or persons affected by this action. Any soothing statements by the Minister that he does not intend a massive land grab are given the lie by the huge penalties imposed for contravention of a declaration.

The reason we have this legislation is that we must have specific statutes under which to operate in a democratic society. However, the Minister has given strong assurances to this Parliament that the Bill will not be used to declare huge areas. He said he will not use the powers for claims in relation to private property. As I understand it, the Minister has said he will take into account the impact of declarations on other affected parties. He will provide adequate compensation-I understand that he has said this-and ensure full recognition and encouragement is given to the use of State and Territory legislation in preference to Commonwealth legislation. But why does the Bill not say so? The fact is that the Government can slide out from under these assurances if it wishes under the terms of the legislation. The legislation ought to be taken away and redrafted so it will achieve its stated aims and not bring in a law which provides powers that can be misinterpreted, misrepresented and misunderstood.
The Australian Mining Industry Council has compiled an excellent critique of the Bill which points up flaws in most of the 32 clauses. The reaction of our mining industry is this:
The fact that the Bill is described as 'interim' legislation with a life of only two years is no answer to these substantial criticisms.
The mining industry's reaction continued:
The Bill should be withdrawn from Parliament to permit full consultation which has not taken place thus far.

The response of the mining industry is echoed by primary producers. All these people defend the rights of Aborigines to have protection for strictly defined sacred sites-and so they should. It is recognised that this may involve some compulsory acquisition of land. Indeed, most State governments have effectively legislated to protect such sites. In a discussion paper circulated earlier this week the National Farmers Federation stated:
The Bill confers power which far exceeds that required to achieve the purposes of the Act, namely the preservation and protection of sacred sites and objects.
The Federation, however, goes on to say that the Bill confers a totally unacceptable level of ministerial discretion, particularly in relation to ' emergency declarations'. The paper continues.

The substantial powers of interpretation vested in the Minister, the extreme vagueness of key definitions and the absence of adequate criteria to apply much of the proposed law has created a Bill which is a legal nightmare.

I think that Bill has the capacity to create an awful uproar in the Australian community because of the way in which the legislation was drafted. Whether or not it was intended to draft the legislation in that way, the fact remains that it has been drafted in a very sloppy, slipshod manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt whether you have read it, frankly.

—I have indeed read it. Why should Australians be subjected to the perpetual uncertainty which this Bill would make into law? The legislation is a clumsy step to achieve what I regard as a very vague purpose. There is great concern about the legislation among a great number of representative organisations. The Government would do itself, the Australian community and, indeed, the Aboriginal people a great service by laying this legislation on the table, consulting all the interest groups and at least attempting to remove the anxieties that have been created by vesting so much power in the hands of a Minister. It is a draconian and divisive piece of legislation and should be withdrawn from this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Friday, 1 June 1984

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the House is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill 1984. It deals with the heritage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. It does not deal with land rights. It is an interim protection measure, which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and members on this side of the House have stressed. Unfortunately, Opposition members apparently have not appreciated that it is an interim measure dealing with the heritage of the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) talked about this Bill being a blatant attack on the Australian people. At this hour of the night members are tired and I believe that the honourable member for Gwydir became somewhat carried away. There is compensation on just terms. I can assure him that the country people in this nation are proud of the Aboriginal people and their traditions. This was shown in 1967 when every electorate in Australia voted to give the Commonwealth power to make laws for the Aboriginal people. Overwhelmingly the Australian people showed their good sense in all electorates, even the ones that one could expect not to have voted in favour of the proposal. Every electorate voted to give the power to the Commonwealth to help the Aboriginal people. At the time of that referendum I was for the first time Secretary of a Labor Party Federal Council. I organised door-to-door canvassing to get that referendum through. I had hoped also to break the nexus in the Senate, but the people determined the answer otherwise. The Australian people to whom I spoke were very anxious that the Aboriginal people be advanced, that there be help for them and that they have a fair go. It is a long time since 1967. Anyone born in that year would almost be voting now. Nothing has happened. There has not been the advance that the Australian people hoped for and voted for in their ballots in that great referendum in 1967.

I have relatives in the electorate of the honourable member for Gwydir-many of them, as the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) can attest to. I asked an old aunt: 'Were there many Aborigines around Dubbo and Peak Hill when your mother was alive, or in your day?' She said that when her mother was a girl there were many Aborigines around Peak Hill and Dubbo but they were all rounded up and taken to Bourke, which is also in the electorate of Gwydir. Now the possibility of the Aboriginal people establishing sacred sites in Peak Hill, Dubbo or any other area in the electorate of the honourable member for Gwydir 100 years since all the Aboriginal people were forcibly taken away is, I would think, somewhat remote. I assure all the constituents of the honourable member for Gwydir that it is a manifestation of hysteria to say that this legislation is a blatant attack on the Australian people. This is total nonsense and for anyone to oppose the emergency declaration is quite incredible.

All of the States have planning and environment departments with laws to protect important buildings, European buildings and early structures in this country. In all such legislative proposals the States have emergency powers for a Minister to intervene. It is an emergency if a bulldozer is entering a property and about to run down and destroy a sacred site. What is the loss if an emergency declaration is made and if, as the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) says will be the case, the mining company has to wait three months? The minerals have been in the ground for millions of years. They will not go away or deteriorate. Perhaps the price is falling or changing but we no longer bring on stream the quick extraction of minerals. Mining companies just do not go in without providing the infrastructure of towns, shopping centres, schools, ports, railway lines and that type of thing. It is putting up a total smoke screen to say that the emergency declarations must be opposed.

What about Noonkanbah in the Kimberleys in 1980? That is a bit closer to home. What about the apalling acts of the Court Liberal-National Party Government in Western Australia when that Government forced an invasion on the Uniting Church mission at Noonkanbah? I have been there and I have seen the damage that the mining company did to the sacred site. It drilled right into the sacred site. It destroyed the only road into the settlement getting the drilling rigs in and then it had to get the drilling rigs out because there was nothing there. It was an appalling situation. The whole world looked at Australia and said: 'Is that the way you treat your Aborigines and care about their reserves and sacred sites ?'

The honourable member for Gwydir went on about uproar. Why will there be uproar in the community? Who cares whether there is a short delay in the development of a mineral deposit in this country? The Roxby Downs project might or might not go ahead. We still do not know whether a kilo of the various minerals that are there will ever be dug out of the ground and sold. Whatever is there is low grade anyway.

I think the speakers on the other side take a very poor view of the Australian people and the country people particularly. My own relations in the country, whatever their unfortunate political views might be, no matter what error they might make when they go to the ballot box, have great sympathy for the Aboriginal people. I know that some of them supported the honourable member for Calare and no doubt that helped him to get elected to this place.

The honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), who is a new member of this place, made a great contribution in which he pointed out the scandal that had taken place in the Kimberleys in respect of the CRA-Ashton joint venture. When I was in this area two years ago with one of the Labor Party committees we met lepers at the Turkey Creek mission. We saw that CRA had ignored its responsibility to the local community. The people of that area only wanted money for land rights but CRA denied it to them. It would do members of the Opposition a great deal of good and advance their interest and knowledge of Aboriginal affairs if they visited some of these sites. I congratulate the honourable member for Hughes on his contribution. I took great interest in his comment about beads and mirrors because that is all the people of Turkey Creek are getting as a result of one of the scandals that occurred under the previous Government.

This Bill has been dealt with in great detail by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand). The hour is late and I do not want to delay the House. So, without further ado, I commend the Bill to the House. I feel that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is to be congratulated for bringing forward important interim legislation which deals only with preserving in emergencies, particularly for a short time and to prevent hasty actions where sites are threatened. The procedures for declarations would then follow. The actual declarations would then be laid on the table of the Parliament and could be set aside. This is the only Parliament in Australia in which declarations can be overturned. In all the States except Queensland a decision by a State Minister is not reversible by Parliament. The legislation will also work hand in hand with the State legislation. The Commonwealth could have overthrown the State legislation not only under the dams case but also under sections of the Constitution that deal with this area. It chose instead to work with the States.

I commend the legislation to the House. I invite members of the Opposition to read the legislation. If they find that somewhat trying, they might read the Minister's second reading speech. This is fair legislation. It is not a threat to our country people. The people who live in the bush will appreciate that the legislation is reasonable. I know that fair play and common sense will prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to participate in this debate as, I would consider, a friend of Aboriginals. I have been interested in the comments by Opposition speakers in this debate. It is interesting to note that Government supporters who have spoken in this debate include the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), who is the member for Melbourne Ports, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) and the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), all of whom represent inner-city areas in the two great metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne. One could easily ask: Where are the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), the honourable for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves), the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil)-
—Here I am.

—Well done. But I note that the honourable member is not down to speak on this Bill. One wonders why honourable members on the Government side of the House who know something about Aboriginals and who have lived and worked with Aboriginals will not be speaking on this Bill. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and other honourable members on this side of the House have worked and lived with Aboriginals and are prepared to stand up as true friends of the Aborigines and criticise this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill symbolises to thousands of Australians, particularly Western Australians, the unacceptable face of the Hawke Government. It has only incidental significance to the protection of genuine sacred sites. It has everything to do with the backdoor imposition of so-called land rights and with the open-ended extension of centralised executive power. It has far more to do with the satisfaction of unreal, un-Australian dogma than with the true needs of Aboriginals or non-Aboriginal Australians.

The most fair minded people would concede that within various parts of this country there are some sites that have the same significance for tribal Aboriginals as churches in our society have for Christians. This Bill does not, however, talk of sacred sites. Rather, it lays stress on what are called ' significant Aboriginal areas'-which is a delightfully vague term. It is a term that clearly could be taken to embrace very wide areas, and the areas need only to be 'significant', not even sacred. It should be pointed out that whilst it has long been understood that a fairly limited number of sacred sites exist in regions occupied by tribal Aboriginals, concepts such as 'areas of influence' coming from sacred sites are a more recent development, whose place in Aboriginal tradition is open to question.

Areas of significance may be meaningless but they have their use. They are a simple device for giving 2 per cent of Australians effective control over massive land areas, even if as yet they do not gain title. Land covered by exploration licences, pastoral leases, public use, or simple freehold can be frozen by a ministerial decision. This Bill, above all, gives the Federal Government enormous power to override State governments and interfere with any project where Aboriginal areas may be fabricated or found.

It is said that the Bill is designed not to override existing State law in this field but to complement it. However, it is up to the subjective decisions of the Federal Minister to decide whether the State legislation is adequate. My own State has long-established laws protecting true sacred sites, but the tenor of this Bill encompasses a much broader definition of Aboriginal areas. It will be very easy for the Minister to say that the existing law is inadequate, and then to alienate much larger land areas by executive action.

There is, of course, no such legislation operating in Queensland and Tasmania. As a federalist, I believe that this is a matter for the parliaments of those States. It is really worth asking why any such legislation is needed in Tasmania , where there are no Aboriginal people living in a tribal state whose lives can be said to be influenced by sacred sites. Indeed, it is arguable whether there are any true Aboriginals in Tasmania at all. The people who now claim Aboriginality in that State have been living in a European society for a hundred years. It is a measure of the dogmatism and malice of this Government that it seeks to coerce Tasmania over an artificial concern.

Nothing better illustrates the arrogance of the Hawke Government towards sovereign State parliaments than clause 13 of the Bill, which deals with the making of declarations. Sub-clause (2) makes a bland referral to consultation with State Ministers to determine the effectiveness of State law before a declaration is made; yet sub-clause (4) goes on to state that any failure to comply with this requirement does not invalidate the making of a declaration. A child can see that this makes a farce of consultation. The Federal Minister will be able to do precisely what he wants without regard to the interests of the great majority of the people of any State. Consultation means no more than a mugger saying 'Please' before he knocks a person down and robs him.

Moreover, clause 8 (2) shows this Government's obsession with subordinating Australia to international treaties as a device for subverting State governments . There would be no need to make reference to so-called 'obligations under international law' if it were not for the intention of the Hawke Government to resort to the external affairs power should the validation of the Bill be challenged. I can only stress that this Government makes a mockery of its vaunted nationalism when it invokes alien authorities to deprive Australians of their rights.

This Bill is riddled with vague and simplistic definitions that result from deliberate intention rather than sloppy drafting. The effect is to give enormous power to a Minister to transform the non-metropolitan areas of Australia. Firstly, there is the deliberate vagueness as to how the Minister must satisfy himself that an area in question has true significance for Aboriginal Australians. Does he accept the word of the applicant or does he seek some impartial method of verification? It is my understanding that truly sacred sites depend upon secrecy, as with genuine living Aboriginal traditions.

The Bill conveniently ignores this paradox, just as it makes no distinction between areas of religious importance and those merely having some traditional significance. Within Western Australia the museum, the custodian of Aboriginal sites, has catalogued some 750,000 items. Quite clearly, however, many of these hardly have a deep religious significance. They can include a tree where the father of an Aboriginal Australian rested or even buried his dog. If such areas are to be equated with truly sacred sites and given equal legislative protection the inevitable result will be a community backlash that eventually will make it impossible to protect any site. Giving the Minister carte blanche to make decisions as to what deserves protection is to threaten the rule of law and the authority of our courts.

Similarly, in clause 3 (1) there is a very broad definition of 'Aboriginal tradition', which includes the observances of any Aboriginal group. This ignores the consideration that these customs are not static but dynamic and because of such happenings as death new areas are invested with significance over time. Such places and objects are not sacred sites as most people would understand them and to recognise them legally will simply exclude non-Aboriginal Australians from more areas of their own country. If the Government was sincere in trying to protect sacred sites rather than extend Aboriginal control over larger areas, it would limit this definition of 'tradition' by specifying that these observances must be handed down from generation to generation, as a perfectly reasonable proposal of the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia has suggested. Why then has the Minister ignored it?

Clause 3 (2) gives us a definition of 'desecration' as being the treatment of an area 'in a manner inconsistent with Aboriginal tradition'. Thus the 98 per cent on non-Aboriginal Australians may become lawbreakers if they walk past an Aboriginal area and somehow insult the Aboriginals concerned with that area. The Minister's amendment may address that position. Needless to say, farming, mining or tourism would be excluded, and to avoid the 'desecration' of the 750,000 listed sites in Western Australia, which represents one for every three square kilometres, most of us Western Australians would have to shift somewhere else. It is no use the Minister or anyone else saying that these provisions are academic and will not be invoked in full. The fact is that they will be there on the statute book, a constant threat to our economic progress and our freedom.

Clause 3 (3), by referring to the mere likelihood of desecration as threating an area, can mean that an actual application for a pastoral lease or exploration licence could breach the Act. Exploration licences in Western Australia cover areas of 200 square kilometres and it is quite likely that such areas might include a few square metres of an Aboriginal site. Thus the time honoured State government prerogative of granting mining tenements is jeopardised through the obvious extension of this legislation.

The Bill would be less unjust and harmful if it were specified that only traditional Aboriginal owners could apply for a ministerial declaration in respect of a land area. Clause 9 of the Bill, however, merely refers to any ' group of Aboriginals' who may be detribalised urban radicals with no genuine feeling for the site or its traditional observances. Surely the consent of all traditional owners should be mandatory before any declaration is made. The absence of any such provision shows that the Government is cynically determined that this Bill shall be the vehicle by which radical activists will impose their will on other Australians. Equally it shows a scant concern for the preservation of real sites and traditions of tribal Aboriginals.

Clause 17 continues this all-embracing trend by not specifying just whom the Minister may designate as the authorised officer who may make emergency declarations. It is bad enough to realise that there will be a new group of zealots interfering in the life of this country. It is more serious to consider that the sort of person likely to be appointed by this Government is the type of radical activist who has energetically poisoned community relations in the north of the State I represent, the type of person referred to by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie when he spoke of second-rate lawyers doing nicely out of land rights. Now the Minister is providing these people with a further avenue of employment. While policemen have to produce their authorisations at all times, these people need show their identification cards only if it is reasonably practical to do so. They will indeed be a privileged group, in keeping with their power to halt mining for two days, with the consequent financial loss that a mining company may incur.

When one considers the penalties set down in clause 22, it is not using too strong a word to accuse the Minister of fanaticism. For an individual contravening the new Holy Writ of a ministerial declaration, the maximum penalty is five years gaol or a fine of $10,000. In contrast, the penalty in my State for desecrating a Christian church is $500 or six months gaol. Desecrating a grave brings a fine of $40 or three months gaol. I understand from the honourable member for Hughes these penalties may vary from State to State.

This proposed Act is stupid and arrogant and will do nothing for Aboriginal Australians except arouse ill feeling towards them. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie warned his colleagues that the same thing would happen in similar circumstances over Ayers Rock. Equally draconian are the fines of $50,000 to be levied on any offending corporation. Such a corporation can be made liable by an unauthorised act by one of its employees. To cap it off, ignorance of a declaration will be no defence-I understand that the amendment the Minister proposes to move may redress that to a degree-and a person can be convicted, having caused no physical damage, and a prosecution can be launched even after a person has been acquitted under relevant State legislation. In essence, this divisive, extremist Bill gives precedence to Aboriginal tribal law over normal civil law, and it gives precedence to the religious and semi-religious beliefs of Aboriginals over those of their fellow Australians. I often think that this socialist Minister does not view Aboriginals as fellow Australians who need to be brought into the ambit of our society, but as another race to be alienated from us by a false sense of historic grievance and by a racial guilt complex.

Aboriginal Australians need help to take their rightful places in our national life, not to be set up with unsought privilege as a separate, stagnating community imprisoned in its past. Many of us are getting sick of the socialist style paternalism of the 1980s that implicitly treats Aboriginals as a group in communities rather than as individuals. The other 98 per cent of Australians have long assumed the right to be treated by their elected governments as individuals or as families. Somehow Aboriginals are less fortunate. This oversight will retard their development in the society in which, for better or worse, they must live. The result of this collectivist thinking by the Australian Labor Party has resulted in the sort of legislation that is now before the House. It seeks to place land under general Aboriginal control but does nothing for the real problems of these fellow Australians in regard to health, education, social development and their wish to develop as individuals.

We can also question any policy of assisting a disadvantaged section of the Australian community at the expense of the rights and freedoms of other Australians. Sadly, it will be the ordinary Aboriginal people, not the politicians and activists who caused the trouble, who will reap the inevitable backlash from the angry Australians deprived of income and free movement under this Bill. This Bill does not seek merely to give Aboriginal Australians dominance over vacant tracts of desert. It threatens private rights and property by allowing property owners to be deprived of access to their own land without entitlement to compensation. Here it must be stressed that compensation under the Bill relates only to the acquisition of property, while nothing is said about the deprivation of land use. Farmers and miners are threatened not only by compulsory seizure of land but also by prohibition of access and development. This is an appalling trend in legislation-de facto expropriation without compensation. Why bother with old fashioned nationalisation when a few significant Aboriginal areas can be conveniently sought and brought to light? In any case it would be very hard to give adequate compensation to a mining company which may be hit by a ministerial declaration before an exploration program has progressed to a stage at which a decision could be made as to whether a project was viable. It would therefore be very hard to agree to just terms of compensation; the financial loss to an exploration company would be inescapable.

The Minister thinks that the mining industry is so rich and powerful that it can somehow survive this drastic effect on its operations. He has not ventured out in the real world. The low levels of returns and the declining international competitiveness are all too real in the mining industry. Over the last six years the rate of return from mining has been only 8.9 per cent compared with 10.1 per cent in our cosseted manufacturing sector and 14.2 per cent in the finance sector.

The Minister can protest until he is black in the face that we are painting the worst case scenario and that he intends to proceed with moderation. If this were his intention he would have no need for the sweeping powers and the broad definitions in this Bill. If it proceeds to law some 98 per cent of Australians will be well down the road to becoming strangers in their own country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a contribution to this debate because over a number of years I have taken an interest in matters of concern to Aboriginal people, and have participated in the writing of a number of reports. Whatever views I have are largely on the public record, and for that reason I think it is appropriate that, having a long standing interest, I should express a few views on this subject. It is appropriate that I should say first of all, as did the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), in speaking on behalf of the Opposition, that we recognise the importance of sites of particular significance to Aboriginals. We recognise that there are occasions when those sites can be under threat and that on occasions steps need to be taken to protect sites. In broad recognition of that principle, legislation has been put in place in States which have had Liberal governments and, in some cases, that legislation has been in place for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also seen over time an acknowledgment by members on this side of the House of the need to protect important objects. On occasions there has been genuine concern that objects may be the subject of sale or export and that some steps ought to be taken to protect them. My former colleague the Hon. Bill Wentworth actively expressed some views on this subject. I was certainly very much aware of his desire to see some legislation in this area. I talked to some of the people, who are in this chamber tonight as guests, about the sort of legislation that Mr Wentworth proposed at one time and was told about the difficulties that might be occasioned by preparing and putting into place the legislation that he had drafted. Many of the people who have a great deal of experience and skill in this area highlighted the difficulties in moving in the area. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) says that this is interim legislation. The only thing that makes it interim is the use of the word ' interim' in the title and the fact that it contains a sunset clause which will bring it to and end after two years operation. It will be on the statute book for two years and will still have a significant impact. The Minister says it is intended to be interim legislation because to his mind the legislation in its present form is unsatisfactory, needs to be improved and needs further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not go far enough.

—The Minister may want to live with that statement; he may not. The point is that this legislation is seen to be interim, which implies that the legislation, for whatever reason is unsatisfactory. To an extent, that indicates the haste with which the legislation has been drafted. Obviously at this stage, while it is interim and is not the end result, it cannot in my view be in any way adequate. For that reason I looked to the Minister's second reading speech to try to glean some reason why the Minister was giving this matter priority over other matters that I will mention in a short while and why this matter is being pushed in an interim way at this time, particularly when it has occasioned a great deal of misunderstanding.
—Misrepresentation.

—Some aspects of it may have been misrepresented by individuals. It certainly will not be misrepresented by me. It has occasioned a good deal of concern, and that must worry anybody who has an interest in Aboriginal affairs. The Minister and I have disagreed in the past, when I was on the other side and he was on this side, about circumstances which highlight tensions within the community and which ultimately make it very much more difficult, not for me or for the Minister, but for the people who are most deprived and for whom we all have a genuine concern. When there are tensions, pressures and concerns, Aboriginal people suffer. As a result of the way in which this matter has been handled there is a great deal of concern and, I suspect, a good deal of misunderstanding in the community. As a result, the Aboriginal people will find it very much more difficult over time.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a method of dealing with these matters and I argue that the Minister should have adopted it. I am not a farmer and I suppose that for me to suggest that the Minister should have tilled the soil perhaps sounds somewhat trite. In this area it would have been more appropriate for there to have been a draft Bill at least. It would have been appropriate for the Minister to look at the solution that the former Labor Government adopted in its effort to till the soil in an area which it saw as difficult, the area of land rights, particularly in the Northern Territory, when it commissioned an inquiry by Mr Justice Woodward. That enabled the views of people in the community, both those for and against, to be canvassed and I think that made it very much easier for legislation ultimately to be passed. Sure it took a little longer, but I think the end result was far more satisfactory because it did lead to a situation in which, although there were differences of opinion over the ultimate nature of the legislation that was passed, legislation was passed to give effect to land rights in the Northern Territory.

The Minister could have asked the parliamentary Committee to look at the matter and to canvass opinions. In fact, I think from the time that the Minister himself was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs there was a desire on his part to have the Committee look at things other than those which I would have had the Committee look at. I am sure one of the matters he would have proposed-if I go back through the records I will probably find he did propose it-is an examination of this question of how we might better protect sacred sites. It could well have been an area in which there was a positive role for the parliamentary Committee, to prepare public opinion and to try to develop a real understanding of what these issues are about. There are allegations that there is misrepresentation; misrepresentation perhaps by my colleagues--

TALK.START.PARA: —Misunderstanding; I prefer that term.

—A misunderstanding by some of my colleagues. I think people could be forgiven for having a misunderstanding of some of these questions when we relate them to some of the other comments that have been made in debate. I have in mind particularly the comments tonight of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). I will have a look at his speech tomorrow to see that I am not misrepresenting him in what I am about to say but I listened very carefully to his speech and it contained some key words. He referred, I think in the context of a great deal of concern within the mining industry about what the impact of this legislation might be, to particular mining developments that have occurred in this country. He mentioned the substantial Nabalco Pty Ltd development in the Northern Territory and the Ashton Mining Ltd mine in Western Australia, a very rich diamond deposit at Lake Argyle. I think he was suggesting to us that if this legislation had been in place there might well have been a very different result in relation to the way in which those developments proceeded. Perhaps that is understating the proposition somewhat. I will not be surprised if people pick it up later and argue that the honourable member, by raising those matters in this context, was signalling that they were the sorts of developments that would not have been able to proceed if legislation like this was in place.
—He didn't say that.
—Signalling.
—No, he didn't say that.
—He did not say that?
—They might have developed differently. That is not saying they would not have developed.

—No, it certainly is not. The point I am making is that when one is dealing with a matter as sensitive and as difficult as this, and the Minister has told me that it has occasioned some difficulty for him, the fact of the matter is that statements of this sort do suggest to those people who are concerned that they might very well be under threat. It gives them greater credence to go out and argue that cause. Of course I think the Minister is in the position, unfortunately for him, whereby in relation to this legislation that he sees as having great priority, not even all of his colleagues fully appreciate the matter in the same way that he does. I can rely only on newspaper reports. No doubt those I am referring to can correct me if I am wrong in suggesting that these comments have some validity. In the Sydney Morning Herald of Friday, 30 March, Amanda Buckley wrote about this matter. She stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Some members complained-
She was speaking about one of the papers that was being prepared in relation to Aboriginal questions-
that the paper would falsely raise Aboriginal expectations about the government' s intentions on land rights.
Then we had comments such as this:

Government backbenchers said yesterday that one of the main concerns about Mr Holding's proposals, especially among Western Australians, was that plans to give Aborigines control over mining on their land would adversely affect business interests and could lead to unemployment and dissatisfaction with Labor policies. If these are views that are being expressed by the Minister's colleagues, is it any wonder that we see in the wider community comments which the Minister sees as evidencing a considerable misunderstanding about this legislation? A report in the Bulletin of 8 May indicated that one of the Minister's colleagues, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), had some concern about this matter. I do not know how accurate it is but I am told there has been tabled-if not tabled at least seen-a letter from the honourable member to his colleagues in which he had this to say:

There are many thinking Aboriginals who already sense the backlash and, as a politician representing a large number of Aboriginals, I know the backlash is there and I am concerned to see that it does not become an irresistible groundswell.
The Minister's colleague, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), had some comments to make at a mining industry meeting. He stated:
Aboriginal sacred sites are a related issue. It is essential that resource companies consult with Aboriginals to ensure that sacred sites are respected.
I agree with that.
There is also an area where legislation is being introduced, or has been introduced, at both Commonwealth and State levels.
The Minister went on to say:
There is a need to promote goodwill and respect on the part of both the resource companies and the Aborigines concerned, by the adoption of effective consultation procedures.

Why do I refer to these matters? Because I think they evidence not only amongst members on this side of the House but also amongst some members of the Government a concern that this legislation might well lead to a situation in which the rest of the community, of whom we have to have an understanding in these sensitive issues and whom we need to carry along with us, might well feel alienated, frustrated and concerned-as a result of misunderstanding perhaps, but certainly as a result of the very fact that there are these legislative proposals. I think that there is good reason for the Government to reconsider its approach, to take the matter back to look at how it can try to retrieve this situation to try to get some of this pressure that is developing within the community off the backs of Aboriginal people. The Government should highlight the sorts of issues that we were dealing with in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, such as the important questions of Aboriginal health, Aboriginal education, the way in which we can get resources into those areas, and Aboriginal housing. This is an area I hope the Committee will spend a great deal of its time working on after completing its report on Aboriginal education. I think there are positive results to be achieved in these areas, runs that can be got on the board. If the Minister is able to see that there is merit in withdrawing this matter and taking it a little more slowly, developing the final product-perhaps a product that is far less alarmist than that which we have before us-I think he could do Aboriginal people a real service.

Aboriginal people will be better served by a reduction in the conflict rather than a heightening of the pressures that can result. This legislation also is of some concern in that in some ways the position of the States might not be properly protected. The Minister added to that tonight by indicating that he might delegate some of his powers to State officials and that that might lead to a more co-operative approach from some States. In my experience, when we seek to impose our view over and above the views of a State on these sorts of issues it can lead to further pressures and difficulties. We saw this particularly in relation to Queensland.

I reiterate some of the views I have put on the public record. I believe it is appropriate that in this area where the States have a role as well as the Commonwealth the role of the Commonwealth should be exercised in a co-operative way. The Commonwealth's view should not be substituted for the view of the States. I offer those views to the Minister in a constructive spirit and as one whose record shows an interest in the subject over time. Perhaps this will lead to a reconsideration of these questions without some of the rancour we have seen in the debate to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill as I have an interest in the legislation and an interest in the people it is to serve. More importantly, I think some comment should be made at this time in the interest of all Australians. If one considers the haste with which this legislation has been introduced and the lack of consultation on it, one has to question whether this has been the proper approach to a very delicate subject. Already speakers for the Government have accused the Opposition of racist attitudes for bringing to the attention of this Parliament and the people of Australia some of the real fears that we have. This Bill could be more divisive than collective in the sense of bringing together the aspirations of some of the people.
—Tell us about your fears.

—I will reply to the interjection. The honourable member for Leichhardt has been interjecting all night. He has not been prepared to talk on the Bill. He becomes an apologist for everything else the Labor Party does. I am sick and tired of standing here and being subjected to his barrages when he has not got the guts to stand up and speak on the Bill himself. While the contribution from the Opposition is being made by people from various parts of Australia, the contribution made by the Government to date has come, as the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) said earlier, solely from members from the metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne. One wonders why this is the case. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), the honourable member for Leichhardt and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) could make a contribution and tell us what is on their minds instead of sitting and making no contribution except by way of inane interjection. Perhaps this is symbolic of the attitude of the Government towards this Bill. It can get people from Melbourne and Sydney to speak on it. They can protect themselves by saying they are the conscience of the Government. They can say what should or should not be done with the known protection that it would be absurd of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) to declare the Melbourne Cricket Ground or the Sydney Opera House sacred sites.
—Don't bet on it.

—No, we should not bet on it. But that is the situation. The people who are affected, the people in the country-the pastoralists, the miners and the like-are the ones who should speak on the legislation. That is what we are trying to do. I am reminded of the comments made by a Minister in the Western Australian Government-a government that has certain similar persuasive political views to those of the Federal Labor Government. He said that, as far as he was concerned, the legislation was unnecessary. Western Australia could do the work that it wanted to do and impose the controls that it wanted to impose in its own way. I know that somebody will immediately say: 'That is the Western Australian Government. What about Queensland?' Queensland has already operated in its own right to protect sacred sites.
—Oh, yes!

—I ask the honourable member who has just interjected to recall that the Jackson pipeline opened today. I understand that a major deviation was made at an additional cost to take that pipeline around a sacred site. That was not done under any pressure from the Commonwealth; that was done by the State Government in its own right. This Bill-
—That is commendable.

—The honourable member for Lowe who has just interjected is very loud on rhetoric. He knows for sure that his house will not be declared a sacred site. He knows that, similarly, the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Opera House will not be chosen. That is the safety in which he speaks. He has thrown up a guilt complex against the Liberal Party and National Party of Australia. It is inane and rather puerile for him to interject in that way. Why is there concern by the people we are supposed to represent; mining people, pastoralists, business people and country people? Why is there this concern?
—Tell us. No one else has.

—Right. I will. I have been asked by the honourable member to tell him why there is this concern. Let me start with the report about the Minister himself as reported in the Australian on 10 April 1984. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Holding told a Brisbane Rotary Club meeting the Federal Government would deploy the power and authority of the national Parliament to improve the lot of the Aboriginals.
We will not be deterred by spurious arguments about States' rights.

Initially concern was expressed about State rights. Let us look at a comment made by the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Charles Perkins. In an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio morning program this year he said, more or less in these words: 'We will be insisting on the return of all sacred sites.' He said that if they were irretrievable-again I return to the examples I gave of the Melbourne Cricket Ground and the Sydney Opera House- they would want compensation. Is this not an inference that the sacred sites themselves are for sale? Just how sacred are the sites to the people concerned if compensation will be an alternative? Are they the reason for the concern in society? There is also the more recent situation. People from the Government have been telling us not to confuse this issue about land rights. We are talking tonight about land rights in this Bill. It is the experience--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you are not.

—If the Minister reads his own Bill he will see that it concerns land rights. That is what it will lead to. The Chief Minister in the Northern Territory has already indicated that over 50 per cent of the territory is under threat.
—That is your legislation.

—I know that is my legislation; that is why I am saying there is a concern by the people. I have been asked to demonstrate why that concern should be and I think I should be given the liberty of doing that. Recently a film crew was not allowed to film Ayers Rock. All these things are reasons for concern within the community. I think it is only fair for us to warn the Government that while it might be trying to reduce passions, inadvertently it might be inflaming them. That could be a divisive characteristic. The Minister's haste in introducing the legislation is certainly evidenced by the fact that he has come into the chamber tonight with a whole host of amendments which should not have been necessary if due consideration and consultation had taken place well before now. The Australian Mining Industry Council has been criticised by some Government speakers, but it must have put some relevant points because some of them are now incorporated within the framework of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been asked to explain why there is concern about this legislation. I believe the Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders want some guarantees as to how the legislation is to be interpreted. Again, we have come up against that inglorious situation of allowing the Minister discretion in the application of the Act and granting authority to certain officials to implement or make declarations. Giving any type of discretion is dangerous because that discretion is not necessarily held in the hands of a named person; it is vested in an office. Who is to say how the holder of that office will act and how the Act will be interpreted, particularly as the discretion afforded to the Minister is not-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 10 minutes and you have another colleague who wishes to speak.

—Yes, I know that. If the Minister would keep quiet I would be able to keep going. We are concerned about the discretionary matter and also the aspect which is contained in many of the clauses and amendments that one is guilty until one has proved one's innocence. We are voicing the concerns of the people who will have to meet face to face the application of the proposed Act. I believe it is felt by lots of people themselves that in many respects the Bill should have gone further to prevent misunderstandings, but advantage has not been taken of this opportunity to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Other speakers have spoken on other aspects of the legislation. As the Minister reminded me, I am limited by time constraints. I believe this is the best opportunity we have had of discussing a problem for which so many people in the cities have no answers except to pass the buck back to the country people and northern Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) for giving me the opportunity to make some remarks at the second reading stage of the passage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill because that gives me the opportunity to be a little broader in my remarks. It was interesting tonight to hear the Minister foreshadow some amendments. One of those amendments seeks to avoid the very valid criticism that has come from all sectors of the community that very innocent people doing the normal things that Australians do today, such as travelling in 4-wheel drive vehicles and so on, could find themselves subject to the draconian fines. I thought I heard the Minister say that the Government will assist people as much in this regard by fencing off all these sites and putting signs on them. I wonder whether he really meant that.
—You could not read them.

—Any time the honourable member for Leichhardt wants to debate this issue in a few pubs in his electorate, I will go there and debate it with him. He runs round his electorate saying one thing and votes in the opposite way here .
—What are you going to hit them with-a sand bag?

—Ken Colbung is sitting behind the honourable member. He knows Jane Winda. When the honourable member has a moment he should ask Mr Colbung about the circumstances. He will tell him the truth. I wonder whether the Minister will fence in all those sacred sites so that the rest of the Australian people will know where they are and they can go and desecrate them in the way that Australians do to many tourist spots. He has a very interesting situation to answer for in that regard. I am standing here because of my objections to this Bill. I am not objecting to what the Minister set out to do, which was to protect certain things that certain people hold valuable. I am objecting to the way that he has tried to do it and, more particularly, the power which he has given to himself, as has been said by speaker after speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has legal training. I see that he is shaking his head. I can only read what is before me. I have seen him tell Australians on television: 'You do not have to worry about what you find in the Bill'. He told Max Walsh the other day, with smiles all over his face, that he had put all the details in the second reading speech. He said: 'You do not have to worry about that; you can trust me'. Let us look at the opportunity for trust. Let me read to the House from the report of the board of inquiry relating to certain matters within the Richmond City Council. On page 582 of the report it is stated:
Some years later a curious incident occurred in relation to the 1969 agreement. In 1977, the Minister for Local Government made a written request to the Town Clerk to explain--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This does not have the faintest semblance of relevance to the matter before the House. I request that the honourable member be directed to stick to the Bill.
—I uphold the point of order and ask the honourable member to restrict his remarks to the matters contained in the Bill.
—This Bill is about ministerial power and we are entitled to draw attention--
—I have just advised the honourable member for O'Connor to restrict his remarks to the Bill.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, let me tell you a bit about this Bill. This Bill gives power to a Minister who has told a royal commission--
—It was an inquiry.

—Okay, it was an inquiry, and the Minister was under oath. I will tell honourable members what the Minister told the inquiry. He told it that he could lie to a Minister of an opposite government because he was a political enemy. With the powers that the Minister has, he has refused me the right to read the document so I will send it to the Minister to read if he likes. If he had given me the chance to read it I could have proved the point. I have to do it in this fashion because the Minister would not let me read it.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. What the honourable member for O'Connor is saying has no relevance to the Bill we are discussing here tonight and besides he is the one who has the conviction, not anybody else in this place.
—There is no point of order. I have already advised the honourable member for O'Connor to restrict his remarks to the Bill.
—I will continue to debate the Bill and I will give honourable members examples of why I am talking in this way. I am quite happy to admit to this House that I have been fined $40 for assault.
—What did you do?

—It was for attacking a person who happened to be black, and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Gorman) who sits alongside the honourable member for Melbourne was fined $150 for bashing his wife. Can the honourable member deny that?
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable member for Hughes thinks it is funny to bash one's wife. He is laughing his head off. He does not mind bashing wives. I have told him what to do. He should turn around to the man sitting behind him and ask him the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I will return to the Bill. You do not seem too concerned that the interjection was irrelevant. Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the fact that this Bill is about ministerial power; it is absolute ministerial power. There is a slight reference to declarations reviewable by the Parliament and, to quote the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), the truth is in the numbers in this place. That means that a Minister is part of the Government and therefore he has the numbers. So that is no protection for the Australian people who may, in some innocent way, transgress.

What I am putting is that the assumption then has to be taken that the Minister is a man of justice. However, I have just drawn to the attention of honourable members the fact that the Minister, by his own admission, is prepared to treat political enemies differently. In fact he is prepared to write misleading letters telling a Minister of the Crown what is not the truth. Of course on another occasion in this place I have drawn the Parliament's attention to answers given to a question on notice by the Minister in which he denied having done something when months before he had written a letter to a fellow Minister stating that he had done just that thing. That matter is on the record and if anybody doubts it I will give him the information. That is the point we are dealing with. We are giving power to a Minister who is prepared to treat political enemies differently, and that is what is in this piece of paper that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Get back to the subject.
—That is the subject all right. It is all right if you are not a political enemy but if you are a political enemy you can get fixed right up by this piece of legislation.
—Who are you going to fix up this time, you big mug?
—Oh--
—Come over here and have a go, you big mug; have a go.
—You are all wind. I have seen your type a thousand times.
—Come over and have a go, you big mug. You bloody fascist.
—Order! The honourable member for Casey will remain silent.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order.
—I have asked the honourable member for Casey to remain silent .
—I will go further on my point of order, with your permission, Mr Deputy Speaker, and ask that he withdraw the words that he used to describe the honourable member for O'Connor.
—I am not aware of the words the honourable member used.
—If I can enlighten you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member said that I was a big mug and I should come outside.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is your responsibility to uphold the dignity of this Parliament, and I call on you to ask the honourable member to withdraw and to apologise.
—I ask the honourable member for O'Connor whether he was offended by the remarks.
—I was certainly offended. I do not believe that I should be attacked in that fashion.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. I ask the honourable member for Casey to withdraw his remarks.
—Certainly. I am not quite sure what I said. Could I please have the remarks repeated so I will know what I have to withdraw?
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw the offensive remarks .
—Certainly. I am not quite sure what I said that was offensive, but I withdraw unreservedly for the honourable member for O'Connor, who bashes people.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask for another withdrawal from and a warning to the honourable member. He just referred to me as the person who bashes people, and he does not know that.
—You said that you bashed people.
—I am offended by the remark, and I ask the honourable member to withdraw it.
—The remark has been withdrawn. I call on the honourable member for O'Connor to continue.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will return to the Bill. It is necessary that I say this. The letter continued:

SPEECH.PARA: His letter was drafted by Mr Clyde Holding at the Council's request, and according to the evidence of Mr Holding, it was drafted upon the basis that as the enquiry came from a political enemy, namely the Minister, he accordingly took the view that a political answer was required.

That was the view of this Minister. He has a different rule for his political enemies. If one is a political enemy, what sort of treatment would one get under this Minister, who would have total power under this Bill? That is what I am drawing to honourable members' attention. Let us get down to saying why this Bill is like it is. The Bill states in clause 9 (1), headed 'Emergency declarations in relation to areas':
Where the Minister-
(a) receives an applicant made orally or in writing by or on behalf of an Aboriginal or a group of Aboriginals seeking the preservation or protection-
The Bill says 'by or on behalf of'. It does not say 'by traditional Aboriginals' or anything like that. Clause 10 goes a little further and says what the Minister may do. Clause 9 (2) states:
Subject to this part, a declaration under sub-section (1) has effect for such period, not exceeding 30 days, . . .

If a company has $300m tied up in a mining project, that provision will cost it $30m in interest. Clause 9 (3) provides that the Minister may, if he is satisfied that it is necessary to do so, declare that a declaration goes on for another 30 days. Clause 10 (1) (c) states that the Minister may take action if he 'has received a report under sub-section (4) in relation to the area from a person nominated by him'. Let us go to clause 17 and see what 'a person nominated by him' means:
(1) The Minister may, by instrument in writing, designate persons to be authorized officers for the purposes of this Division.
(2) The Minister shall cause to be issued to each authorized officer an identity card in the form prescribed, containing a photograph . . .

It appears to me that under clause 17 as long as bloke gets a plastic card with his photo on it he is an authorised officer. There is no requirement that he do anything else. He does not have to have any qualifications; as long as he has his little plastic card he is all right. He reports back to the Minister. Therefore, what do we have? We have an all-powerful Minister. I have told honourable members this Minister's philosophy in his own words. They are not my words; they are what the Minister said to the Board of Inquiry relating to certain matters within the city of Richmond. If he wants to deny that they are the facts, we can sit down together and read page 582, because that is what was said at that time, Mr Chairman, Madam Chairman, Mr Chairman.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite think that is really funny. I have seen them make mistakes hundreds of times. They are like a mob of monkeys.
—Sit down, you mug.

—I will take the ten minutes I was allotted. I am just using up the time members opposite wasted. If they want to waste more time, I will waste that too. This Bill gives total power to a Minister. It gives no rights to Australians. In the hands of the present Minister it is a very dangerous instrument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have a certain sadness in respect of this debate, that is, the purpose and intention of the Government in respect of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill have been totally ignored by members of the Opposition, with the possible exception of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). What is this legislation about? What does it seek to do? This legislation is about the Commonwealth Parliament on behalf of the people of Australia recognising the hopes and aspirations of the Aboriginal people of Australia who have asked me, as Minister, to use the legislative powers of the Commonwealth to protect their heritage. The honourable gentlemen opposite tell us that they are concerned about these aspirations and that they really would like to do something about the situation, if only the time were right. After all , this is the first piece of legislation directed to all the Aboriginal people of Australia which is trying to say a number of things.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing that the legislation is saying is that the power of this Parliament and the Constitution will protect the Aboriginal people's heritage and rights and this Parliament will honour its constitutional responsibilities to Aboriginal people. That is not easy. There are many com-plexities in it. I would be the first to acknowledge that. Of course it is true to say that when one contemplates legislation of this kind it can affect other people's rights. It is proper and appropriate that we should consider the representations of those other organisations that feel thus affected. It was in that spirit that we were prepared to try to reach consensus with organisations such as the Australian Mining Industry Council and the National Farmers Federation. Consensus does not mean submission to the views of those organisations.

When we introduce legislation which affects the rural economy and which might confer benefits on farmers there is no way that such legislation would not affect the rights of consumers and trade unionists. Will the National Farmers Federation say: 'Well, it is perfectly appropriate and we will concede a veto right to the trade union movement and to consumer organisations to tell us what is in the interests of farmers?' Of course, the Federation would not be in it for two minutes.

Now, for the first time since the referendum gave powers to this Parliament to do something for Aboriginal people around Australia, what we are being told is that we should look not to the aspirations and hopes of the Aboriginal people- God knows they are minimal enough-but that the standards on which this Parliament will determine the legitimacy of those hopes and aspirations will be determined by the National Farmers Federation or the miners. It must be heart rending for honourable gentlemen opposite who say that we should have done other things. They say we should have sought consensus and perhaps we should have had an inquiry.

A very important inquiry is going on in Western Australia. I have said publicly and I say again that the Seaman's Aboriginal Land Inquiry is of tremendous relevance. Our duty is to try to get legislation on land rights properly based. We are waiting on the outcome of that inquiry. This is an inquiry of great relevance. How can I get consensus with the Opposition in Western Australia when representatives of honourable gentlemen opposite in the State Parliament of Western Australia have said that it does not matter what the inquiry finds, they are opposed to land rights? How do I get consensus when the Parliament of Victoria has said, very properly: 'We will try to go as far as we can with land rights'? What is the response of the National Party and the Liberal Party of Australia in Victoria? Their State conferences passed resolutions saying: 'We are implacably opposed to land rights and we will not consider it.' How do I get consensus with the Premier of Queensland when he says that land rights is really an attempt to establish bastions for overseas guerrillas operating around Australia? How do I get consensus when I hear the pious bleating from the honourable gentlemen opposite, who say: 'Oh, the time is not right'? The time will never be right as far as these people are concerned.

In the final analysis, which one of them has stood up in this Parliament on this occasion and said: 'I dissociate myself from the statements of the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia and I deplore the statements of the Premier of Queensland'? Not one of them has done that. The obligation is put upon me, when we try to bring legislation into this House, to say: 'You must take it away. You must withdraw it. We need another 25 years.' Well, honourable members opposite are not going to have another 25 years. Let it be understood: The miners and the farmers might have stood over honourable members opposite, and the League of Rights might be campaigning and locking the National Party into impossibly racist positions, but that is their problem, it is not a problem for this Government.

It is the honourable gentlemen opposite who have quoted their patron saint. There have been many injustices done to Aboriginal people, but I suggest it is an awful injustice and a terrible indictment to quote to the half-crazed ex- communist who is living on the income paid to him by the most racist organisation in Australia, the League of Rights. It has a reputation without parallel for anti-Semitism. What it has said about the Jewish people it is now saying with equal venom about Aboriginal people. Where is the one honourable member opposite who will say: 'I dissociate myself from that. I deplore it. I cast it out.'? No, it is dragged in here and given to us as an example of a document which we should consider deeply in formulating our position as a government in terms of the kinds of racist manifestations that are taking place in this community.

I say to honourable members that I have sat down and listened. Very few organisations can get two and a half hours of the time of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). No Aboriginal organisation to date has got it, but the miners got it and the farmers have had more than a fair go. What did honourable members opposite do when they sat down with these people? The first thing they said was: 'We do not think the Commonwealth should be doing this, we think the States should be doing it.' When the States try to do it the very same people oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that Malcolm Fraser spent far more than two and a half hours with the Aborigines.

—I concede that Malcolm Fraser spent a great deal of time considering these problems, and he had enough strength and enough guts to keep honourable gentlemen opposite in line on these issues. He did not walk away from the problems of South Africa. He did not allow some of the lunatic fringe now operating within the Party opposite to mouth the kind of nonsense that has been talked here tonight in terms of this legislation. Let me deal with some of the problems that have been posed.
—What were you saying three or four years ago?

—I realise the honourable member does not like Malcolm Fraser. He recognised the honourable member's talents and sacked him. He is not an admirer or a fan. We know that. Let us look at the legislation which will tear the nation in two. What does it propose to do? It contains three elements, all requested by the Aboriginal people of Australia. Let me say, by way of leading into this that one of the other things that I find slightly hypocritical about the attitude of the Opposition is that earlier this week I was contacted by the Chairman of the NAC who was somewhat upset because he had read about the policy that was formulated by the Opposition, those gentlemen opposite who tell me that I must consult.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I ask the Minister to return to the Bill. He is now getting on to the Opposition's policy.
—There is no point of order. I listened to most of this debate and honourable members on both sides of the House ranged far and wide.

—The Chairman of the NAC rang me to say that he was upset because he had read in the newspaper that the policy of the Opposition had been formulated at a party meeting and that there had been no reference to or discussion with the NAC or any Aboriginal body representing Aboriginal people in Australia. I said that I found that a bit difficult to believe, even knowing the reluctance of the shadow Minister to confirm. So in case there was some injustice being done to the honourable gentleman opposite by the Chairman of the NAC I had my staff inquire. What was the result of that inquiry? It confirmed that neither of the major land councils had been communicated with, no one on the executive of the National Aboriginal Conference at a State or a Federal level had been conferred with to seek the views of Aboriginal organisations and people on this legislation. There was one attempt at contact. The Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority was telephoned by the research assistant of the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) who asked whether there had been any consultation with the Authority. The answer was yes. The Authority was asked by the research assistant of the honourable member for Barker what its reaction was to the legislation. A representative said that he thought it was a valuable piece of legislation. He was asked by the research assistant whether he knew what the Northern Territory Government's reaction was to the legislation. The honourable member for Barker's research assistant was told that he had better direct that question to the Northern Territory authority. Tonight the Government and I have been lectured about consultation, as speaker after speaker got up to base his speech on the statements that have been made-mainly inaccurate statements-about this legislation by the mining companies and the farmers.
