Not one speaker got up and said that the policy position of the Opposition in respect of the first piece of Commonwealth legislation dealing with Aboriginal heritage was formulated as a result of discussions with Aboriginal people. In 1984 one would not believe it possible. But in 1984 that is the calibre of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members have the gall to come in here and lecture about the need to consult. I have consulted with the farmers. I have consulted with the mining companies. I have listened to them ad nausaum but the Opposition which has listened to both organisations does not happen to have got around to talking to any of the Aboriginal organisations anywhere in Australia. Its members could not even pick up a telephone to make an appointment to inquire about the views of the Aboriginal people in regard to this legislation. If they had done so, they would have been told that Aboriginal people do not believe that this legislation goes far enough, but they are prepared to accept it as an interim measure until we get further down the track in developing the whole question of land rights. They are prepared to enter into debate and discussion with any of the representative groups who want to have an input into this area. Let me say this: Aboriginal leadership in Australia, whatever its imperfections and inadequacies, in terms of its approach to this legislation, has shown a sincerity, objectivity and awareness and a willingness to compromise which might well be emulated by some of the captains of industry and some of those who represent farmer groups in this country.

The purpose of this legislation has been significantly wilfully and mischievously misrepresented. It is not land rights legislation. It is not even sites legislation. What it deals with is sites that are under threat, and I would be the first to concede--

TALK.START.PARA: —In your opinion.
—No. If the honourable member read the legislation--
—I have read the legislation.

—I realise the difficulties the honourable gentleman might have when it comes to dealing with matters of a legal nature. If he likes I will make available to him officers of my Department so that he understands the legislation. The legislation is designed to give the Commonwealth constitutional power, not to override the States on the whole question of the registering of sites. We are not into that business. What we are into is providing a mechanism when sites are under threat--
—Total power to you.

—I will deal with that question-and there is no equivalent State legislation or the States are breaking their legislation, whereby the Commonwealth can intervene. That is all the legislation does and that is all it is designed to do. I do not accept the view of honourable members opposite in terms of the perception of Roxby Downs. But I do say this: It is strange that there was no mention of Noonkanbah.
—That was not in your term. You referred to incidents in your term of government.

—I have said that what we are dealing with is the question of sites under threat. Let us quickly recount the situation at Noonkanbah. The fact is that there was a site that was registered, which was known to be registered and which was protected by State law. The prevailing government directed the mining company to go in and mine and used the coercive power of the State to force that situation. The only means available to the Aboriginal people when that act of desecration was taking place were the trade union movement, members of the Christian church and the Aboriginal people themselves, who had to put their bodies in front of machines. I have not heard that situation deplored by one honourable member opposite. But I say this: When this legislation becomes law there will never be another Noonkanbah in Australia. That is what this legislation is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: I say this to the mining companies: If the mining companies are prepared and concerned to follow the practices in which they say they believe, of consulting Aboriginal people, I do not see a single occasion when this legislation will be relevant to them where States have effective mechanisms as exist in the Territory, Western Australia and most States, this legislation will not be relevant. But what it does in the final analysis is to give to the Commonwealth in crisis situations such as occurred at Noonkanbah a legislative base either to go to the courts or to act in a way which can cool the situation and see that justice is done to all parties. That is the purpose of this legislation. I will be happy to address some of the other misunderstandings that have taken place in the speeches of honourable members opposite. There is a great deal of misunderstanding. Officers of the Department are available to help honourable members opposite understand the legislation. I ask honourable members to use them please. (Extension of time granted).
There is one matter upon which I feel I should quickly address this House. It has been pointed out that this legislation gives enormous power to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in Western Australia you don't.

—In fact I have enormous power, not under this legislation but under the land rights legislation of the honourable member's Government. Honourable members opposite talk about having a discretion to confer vast tracts of land. That situation does not exist in respect of this legislation.
—Do you have responsibility for the Northern Territory?
—In respect of the land rights legislation, I have a discretion-
—Do you for Western Australia?
—No.
—Order! Will the honourable member for Barker-
—Perhaps that is the difference.
—Order! Will the honourable member for Barker heed the Chair.

—Under the legislation of the previous Government the discretion that I have is an unfettered discretion to act on the commissioner's report in respect of the granting of large areas of land which have been the subject of claims. The only basis upon which that can be challenged is through the judicial process. It is a very difficult operation, as countries that have tried it will tell us. The mechanism that this legislation will put in place for dealing with sites is as follows: First of all, the only sites that we are concerned to deal with are sites which are under immediate threat. If a watering place has been in existence on a farm and an Aboriginal group comes along and says 'We want you to declare that site', that is not on. It is not on because the site is not under threat. The obligation upon me when a site is under threat is to inquire from my State colleague whether that site is registered and protected under that State's law and whether he is aware of the threat, whatever it may be. If the answer is yes, the Commonwealth is not involved. It is as simple as that.

SPEECH.PARA: If we become involved, if we are in a situation in which there is no effective law, I am compelled under this legislation-it is all set out there if honourable members opposite would only read it-to appoint someone to advise, to produce a report which addresses a whole range of interests, including the interests of any citizen who may be adversely affected. We have enlarged that provision in the amendment before the House. That report comes to me and if I believe that the site has to be declared I have to take the matter to cabinet and it is for the Cabinet to make a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not in the Act.
—No, but that is the process that has been decided upon and I want to record it. I have told the farmers and I have told--
—Well, put it in the Act.

—The honourable member still would not vote for the Bill if I put it in. Then the report is laid on the table of both Houses so that any member can move that it be disallowed, so that the final determinant is not the Minister or the Government but the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Could there be a more conservative mechanism than that? Do the conservative gentlemen opposite, who all of a sudden are outraged by this situation, believe in the law which has operated in respect of the declaration of sites in the Northern Territory which are not subject to review by the Northern Territory Parliament? There was no complaint about that; that did not worry them. In Western Australia declarations of sites are made by the Governor-in-Council and are not subject to review by the State Parliament. That is not a matter of concern. In Tasmania the Minister may make a declaration under the Aboriginal Relics Act and the Minister's powers are not subject to any review by Parliament . That is in other State legislation and there is no problem. They do not feel anguished and they do not feel threatened. But when we produce a mechanism of registration which vests final say in the Parliament on the basis of documents that have to be made public, what do they say? They say: 'Not now; the time is not right; you have to have an inquiry and you have to get consensus'. What honourable members opposite are saying is palpably dishonest and hypocritical. It shows a complete lack of understanding of this legislation.

Members of the Opposition have not consulted or sought the views of the Aboriginal people. They have not sought the advice of officers of the Department who could inform them on how the legislation is drafted and how it is to operate . They have regurgitated the views of the mining companies and the Australian Farmers Federation. They have said: 'That will do; that is near enough'. They are not considering seriously the hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people. I know that there are many honourable members opposite who are genuinely concerned . I hope that when this Bill is dealt with during the Committee stage tomorrow the kind of examination and the kind of responsible criticism which I would hope to see in respect of a piece of legislation that is sensitive will emerge from the Opposition. It has not, unfortunately, emerged during the course of this debate.

Let me finish on this note. Unfortunately there is occurring in this society at the present time a backlash directed against Aboriginal people, just as there is a backlash against Asian immigration-and that is something which this Government is prepared to do something about and act upon. The gentlemen opposite have become so desperate in their overall political plight that they do not want to get too close to these issues but they are happy to climb on the bandwagon and pick up a few votes. Statistics show that Aboriginal people are still the most neglected and dispossessed group in this community and the propositions in this legislation-

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill will do a lot for them! It does nothing for them.

—The honourable member would not know because he does not talk to them. His social relationship with Aboriginal people is much more limited than that. The reality of this situation is that, in the face of a co-ordinated campaign of misrepresentation run by people who are closely allied to honourable gentlemen opposite, basically they are saying that they are opposed to land rights per se. That is the basic position as it has emerged, for example, with the Liberal Party in Western Australia. That is the position that has emerged in the advertisements of the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia (Inc.). They are entitled to that position.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation has become a question of political resolution and political will. We have listened to the views of farmers and we have listened to the views of miners, and we will go on doing that. But in the final analysis the time has come when we have to take the first steps to use the constitutional powers that are vested in this Parliament to realise the rights, the hopes and the aspirations of the Aboriginal people of Australia. That is an obligation that this Government has accepted. Despite the pressures and despite the misrepresentations, that is an obligation that this Government intends to discharge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I shall be very brief given the lateness of the hour. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) suggested and made great play of the suggestion that I had not obtained the views of the Aboriginal communities or Aboriginal organisations. I have only some of the information with me here at the table, but I have copy of a telex from the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress in relation to its views, the Central Land Council, whose views are well known and the National Aboriginal Conference, whose views, especially those of Ossie Cruse are well known. I have another telex from five Aboriginal communities. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill was drawn up in secret and Aboriginal people have had no opportunity to discuss it. There appear to be no procedures or standards by which claims are to be judged, especially when there are potentially conflicting Aboriginal interests. The Minister seems to have absolute power over Aboriginal matters and can delegate the powers at his discretion. We are very concerned that there are people to whom these powers may be given that will abuse these powers.
The telex contains another message to myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable gentleman to table the document from which he quoted.
—Order! There is no provision within the Standing Orders for the honourable gentleman to have to table the document.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Professors World Peace Academy of Australia Ltd

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to Professors World Peace Academy of Australia Ltd (PWPA) and its paid or voluntary young helpers including American Moonies.

(2) Can he state whether the Unificationist Movement of Rev. Sun Myung Moon is funding the Australian chapter, has links with the US and South Korean CIA's, uses dubious fundraising and brainwashing techniques, and sponsors academic conferences and organisations.

(3) Is he able to say whether the 1st PWPA annual conference on interdisciplinary approaches to peace, in Sydney in late August 1983, (a) claimed to offer coverage of all viewpoints, (b) gave prominence to 'peace through strength' (deadlier weapons) as a way to peace among its speakers and the audience of some 40 invitees and (c) identified the main threats to peace as the Soviet Union and the broader peace movement.

(4) Will he consult with his colleagues with a view to having Australian security organisations monitor PWPA activities as closely as they do peace movements which identify major threats to peace such as the superpower arms race and the international armaments industry.

(5) Will he consult with the Ministers for Defence, Health, Employment and Industrial Relations, Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Education and Youth Affairs and Communications to increase government involvement in informing Australians of statistics of military expenditure and activities, world poverty and political persecution, and of proposals for overcoming the apathy, inertia, ineffectiveness and irrelevance of the United Nations Charter organs and declarations in achieving the minimum requirement of enforceable peace-keeping based on persuasion of world citizens that this is more important than the national military sovereignty which is enshrined in the Charter and which is the essential cause of all wars.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) It is Government policy not to comment on security matters. My concern in relation to members of the peace movement is to develop a dialogue with them on the questions of peace, arms control and disarmament.

(5) The Government makes information available on the issues mentioned by Dr Everingham through a variety of its publications. It does not share the view that the UN Charter and declarations are irrelevant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 27 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does his interview reported in The Financial Review of 28 February 1984 indicate that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is favoured by the Government for radiated subscription television (RSTV) services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The report in The Financial Review of 28 February 1984, to which the honourable member refers, reflected my view that the ABC has now addressed the issue of RSTV in great detail and is well prepared to put its case. However, I also stressed that the Government had not yet decided whether to proceed with RSTV; nor has it yet adopted an attitude regarding participation by the ABC.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australia Post: Speedy Wheels Australia Pty Ltd

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 30 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Manager of Australia Post for New South Wales been able to explain satisfactorily to Speedy Wheels Australia Pty Ltd why a letter postmarked Melbourne 2 March 1984 was not delivered in Sydney until 8 March 1984; if so, what was the explanation) if not, when will this be done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, from information provided by the Australian Postal Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Speedy Wheels Australia Pty Ltd wrote to Australia Post's New South Wales administration concerning the delayed delivery of a mail article bearing a franking impression* (not a postmark) dated 2 March 1984.

Australia Post's New South Wales administration responded to the Speedy Wheels Australia Pty Ltd complaint on 10 April 1984, and apologised for the delay in delivery of the letter. In essence, the response covered the following points:

Australia Post's inquiries into the delayed delivery of the letter were inconclusive; because of the volume of mail processed daily it is impracticable to record the movement of individual ordinary mail articles during their progress through the post. It is generally not possible, therefore, to identify the point or points of delay in delivery of an ordinary mail article;

staff shortages and abnormally heavy volumes of mail at the State mail centre and southern region mail centres, through which the article would have circulated, at about the time of posting caused delays in processing of mail and this would have contributed to the delayed delivery of the letter.

Australia Post is aware that delays in the delivery of mail, such as that experienced by Speedy Wheels, cause considerable difficulties for customers. Significant resources are being devoted to resolving the mail service problems in New South Wales.

*(Note: Franked impressions are made by franking machines located in private offices. Such mail may be posted other than on the date appearing on the franked impression. Australia Post has no reason to believe that in this case the letter was not posted on the date franked.)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Running Costs of Australian National Line Vessels

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 30 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: What were the running costs for Australian National Line's (a) Allunga and (b) Paralla for (i) crew, (ii) stores, (iii) insurance, (iv) repairs, (v) administration and (vi) other, for each of the years 1978 to 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The information sought is commercial in nature, and I believe it would be more appropriate to seek such information from the owners or operators of the ships.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 30 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What repairs, if any, are carried out by crew members of Australian National Line ships while at sea.
(2) Is he able to say whether, on comparable vessels of other flags (excluding flags of convenience), crew members undertake repairs as part of their on-going duties.
(3) Do crews on Australian flag vessels carry out similar duties; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian National Line has stated that the following repairs and maintenance are carried out by Australian crews: Engine room maintenance, auxiliary and electrical, machinery maintenance, upkeep of deck mechanical, electrical and hydraulic machinery and life saving equipment. Descaling and painting of decks, hull and superstructure are undertaken. Cargo equipment such as refrigerated containers and cargo handling equipment, cranes, fork lift trucks, etc, are maintained.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government intend to establish a post in Montevideo, Uruguay, to assist the processing of applications for migration to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has no plans to establish a post in Montevideo, Uruguay to assist the processing of applications for migration to Australia.

Migration matters are the responsibility of my colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and his Department has advised that all migration matters in Uruguay are being adequately handled by migration officers in Buenos Aires.
